fields.headline: Witty words win California dream
fields.trailText: A few poetic words, $100, and South African Marc Gorin was a restaurateur.
fields.body:
A few poetic words, $100, and South African Marc Gorin was a restaurateur.

It all started when Larry Broughton and John Alonge decided to give their cosy city centre Surfside Cafe in Carpinteria, California, to the winner of a worldwide essay contest rather than sell it.

Thousands paid roughly £64 to write 400 words or less about how winning the Surfside Cafe would be their ultimate California dream, but it was Mr Gorin's well-chosen words that got the attention of a four-judge panel assembled by the owners.

Mr Broughton and Mr Alonge valued the Surfside at at least £130,000 and, while they declined to reveal the number of essays they had received, they promised to give 10% of the proceeds to charity.

It wasn't easy picking a winner, though. Some entries were humorous; others were home spun. Several were real tear-jerkers.

A monk wrote that owning the Surfside would be like providing the ultimate service to people. "It was ecclesiastical. A robes-to-riches story," Mr Alonge said. Others told stories about how they've cooked all their lives and dreamed of owning a restaurant. "We were flooded with entries, and you wanted to give a piece of the restaurant to everyone," he said.

But it was Mr Gorin who took the prize. "In my youth, I had a dream, which as I grew, became a scheme, to find a seaside, special nook, where I could wait, serve and cook," Mr Gorin's essay began.

A hotel school graduate, the South African has worked in the restaurant business for 12 years and had always dreamed of owning a restaurant.

"What do I have to lose?" he asked. AP

fields.headline: A long hard road ahead
fields.standfirst:
Not every phoenix can rise from the ashes
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: This is an ominous week for the British motor industry, and given the damage which stands to be done directly and indirectly to industry and employment, an ominous week for the government too. And not just because it coincides with a week of local elections. Labour's general election hopes could be blighted by the job losses now threatened in a host of marginal constituencies, and the wider loss of confidence in Labour's dependability if people come to believe that the issue has been handled incompetently.
fields.body:
This is an ominous week for the British motor industry, and given the damage which stands to be done directly and indirectly to industry and employment, an ominous week for the government too. And not just because it coincides with a week of local elections. Labour's general election hopes could be blighted by the job losses now threatened in a host of marginal constituencies, and the wider loss of confidence in Labour's dependability if people come to believe that the issue has been handled incompetently.

It may not come to that. The portents today look brighter than they did late last week as the Alchemy bid foundered and BMW dismissed the rival bid from Phoenix with something like open contempt. Now BMW begins to sound upbeat, while Tony Blair is communing with the German chancellor in the hope of pushing the company towards a job-saving deal - especially by abandoning the hopeless unrealistic deadline of one month to get everything settled. The unions want more from Labour than that. They are looking for an early government commitment to back the deal with at least the £152m which it hoped to put BMW's way before the present crisis began. And then there's the chancellor's juicy £22bn from the auction of radio spectrum: why should not some at least of that windfall be spent on a package to rescue jobs - and perhaps to rescue Labour?

But these hopes remain frail. BMW's more welcoming approach could mean a change of heart: it could mean a mere change of presentation. The clumsy handling of this affair has tarnished the company's image, not least in Germany: that has to be repaired. The books were opened up to Phoenix at the end of last week, ahead of schedule, but there is much anguished crawling over of figures yet to be done before there is any certainty that this is a viable investment. BMW, equally, still has to size up Phoenix, which remains very much an unknown quantity. There is still in the end the fundamental problem that Rovers has developed an image which does not sell. Once a Rover on the drive was what every self-regarding middle class household aspired to. Not now. No one should underestimate how difficult it will be in today's saturated market for any successor company, however much it changes designs and dreams up new names, to reverse the long and melancholy story which has led to the present fix. It needs a kind of managerial magic which has not often been evident in this industry.

If the government is holding back on specific promises of funding, that is no doubt one reason why. There is also the European dimension. The £152m subvention for BMW was never cleared. There is absolutely no certainty that a fresh proposition would win approval in Brussels. Not soon enough for the present time scale, certainly; and perhaps not ever. Even more fundamentally, ministers have to ask themselves how far putting money into the Phoenix bid would be a sound investment in the future, rather than a temporary shoring-up of the past - keeping some kind of show on the road until after the next election but probably not much beyond it.

All that justifies caution. What the government could do at once, though, is to recognise, as the chancellor stubbornly refuses to do, the effect on the motor industry of the soaraway pound. And not just on this industry: on the textile industry, too, which is being squeezed out of existence, on tourism, and elsewhere. How much more damage needs to be done to industry and employment before Gordon Brown gets the message?

fields.headline: Top thief-taker with liberal leanings
fields.standfirst:
Head of Met's race task force has seen his star rise since the Lawrence debacle but is no stranger to controversy and has made enemies

Macpherson report - one year on: special report
fields.trailText: They haven't had much to smile about at New Scotland Yard in recent months, but one incident a few weeks ago helped to lift flagging spirits. A small group of protesters gathered outside the Metropolitan police headquarters to wave banners and chant slogans.
fields.body:
They haven't had much to smile about at New Scotland Yard in recent months, but one incident a few weeks ago helped to lift flagging spirits. A small group of protesters gathered outside the Metropolitan police headquarters to wave banners and chant slogans.

One of the faces was familiar: Imran Khan, the solicitor who acted for the family of Stephen Lawrence and has been one of the Yard's fiercest critics. So, was this another protest against some blunder, mishap or allegation of corruption?

Nothing could have been further from the truth. Most of the demonstrators had driven to London from Telford in a hired coach to demand that Scotland Yard take over the investigation into the deaths of Harold McGowan, 34, and his nephew, Jason, 20, who were hanged in mysterious circumstances.

The idea of campaigners demanding Scotland Yard expertise in a possible race crime was laughable last year, an irony not lost on those who watched from the staff canteen. But perceptions have changed and while some reputations were tainted or destroyed in the Lawrence debacle, others have been enhanced.

John Gilbert Grieve, director of the racial and violent crimes task force and a deputy assistant commissioner, has seen his grow exponentially. With race issues driving the police agenda, he is now the most important detective in the country, with a higher profile than Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Met, or his deputy, Ian Blair.

Mr Grieve, 53, is in charge of the investigation into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, the teenager murdered by a racist gang in Eltham, south London, seven years ago. The home secretary, Jack Straw, seconded him to coordinate the McGowan inquiry, and he has stepped in to help solve one of the country's longest running race hate campaigns, waged against cornershop owners Mal Hussein and Linda Livingstone in Lancaster.

To the amusement (and envy) of some colleagues, he appears on BBC's Crimewatch almost as often as the presenter Nick Ross, and has been the star of a BBC2 documentary. Not bad for a man whose first application to join the police was turned down because of poor eyesight, forcing him to become a navvy on a road gang.

Admirers use two adjectives to describe him. Unconventional and brilliant. The worst most have to say is that he is "a bit odd". He is certainly an individual. The lugubrious face and tatty suit camouflage a sharp mind, and his affability hides the ruthless streak which has made him one of the Yard's best "thief-takers".

There are contradictions in his character. He is, say friends, very sensitive. But he doesn't seem to mind deliberately stir ring up controversy. His unlikely quirks include painting with watercolours and interests stretching from the writings of Dostoevsky (he has a masters degree in philosophy) to the drum rhythms of the Rolling Stones, to the heroics of the 19th century Apache Indian, Geronimo.

Beneath this veneer is a hardnosed detective who, despite apparently liberal inclinations, has been involved in some of the dirtiest crime-fighting campaigns of the last 20 years. "JG is a bloody good cop," says one contemporary. "Forget all the airy-fairy bollocks. He works hard, nicks people and puts them in the dock. He likes being at the flashpoint of policing."

Mr Grieve, an accountant's son born in Gosforth, Tyen and Wear, built his reputation in the drugs squad working undercover. He grew his hair and wore flares to infiltrate street gangs in the east end, securing numerous convictions. He went on to write a definitive guide to undercover work which has been adopted by other forces.

His experiences then challenged him to "think the unthinkable". Speaking to the Association of Chief Police Officers several years later, he said licensing drug dealers would have to be considered. The suggestion, he admitted, was born of despair because the police were only "sitting on the lid of the problem".

Lateral thinking

His first high profile job came in the early 1990s when he was appointed director of SO11, Scotland Yard's criminal intelligence division. Mr Grieve seems to be at his most creative when he is thinking laterally and considering different ways of dealing with old problems. In SO11, he took risks with the use of informants to tackle Yardie-gangs and it landed him, and the division, in piping hot water.

The division was using a registered informant and cocaine dealer, Eaton Green, a prolific source of information on the underworld in which he lived. In 1993, Green and an accomplice robbed 150 people at gunpoint at a party in Nottingham. Green shot one man in the foot and sneered at him: "Bleed, pussy, bleed."

When the pair were arrested by local officers six weeks later, SO11 did not tell them he was an informant; worse, it seemed to do everything it could to have the trial of the two men aborted. After they were convicted, Mr Grieve said he "deeply regretted" the whole episode, but his attitude to using high risk strategies was unchanged. Green, he said, had been "well worth the investment. It is extremely unfortunate that we no longer have him available to us".

Mr Grieve believes it is "impossible" to tackle serious crime without the use of informants. Though controversial, his tactics seemed to work and the number of Yardie murders levelled off. He was equally successful as head of the anti-terrorist squad, SO13.

His appointment coincided with the IRA bombing of the Docklands, a spectacular and bloody end to the ceasefire. Mr Grieve, who was apparently "wide-eyed with astonishment" at the devastation caused by the blast, drew on all his experience. "John's time in the anti-terrorist branch was very significant," said one insider. "The provos realised there was a whole new ball game. He didn't wait for things to happen. He went out to find them. He was proactive in a way that some of his predecessors had not been. It gave the police the initiative."

When the former commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, asked him to set up the racial and violent crimes task force in September, 1998, he creamed off the best detectives to work with him. Their first case was to reinvestigate the death of the black musician, Michael Menson, who died in February 1997, after being set on fire. Initially, the police had insisted Mr Menson had committed suicide. The Met was forced to reevaluate because of determined campaigning by the Menson family, and an inquest which ruled the 30-year-old had been unlawfully killed.

Four months after taking over the inquiry, Grieve's men had arrested three of the men responsible for killing Mr Menson, and traced another, Ozgay Cevat, to northern Cyprus. The investigation bore all the hallmarks of the anti-terrorist branch. The evidence against the men came from conversations which were picked up and recorded by a bugging device planted in one of their homes. The men had been teased into talking about the crime again by fresh appeals for witnesses, including leafleting of the area where they lived.

Sophisticated unit

It was bold stuff. The conviction of Cevat in a republic which the British government does not even recognise was particularly audacious. Mr Grieve has been able to fashion the task force; this is reflected in the people he has recruited, and the way they work.

The unit has the most sophisticated intelligence gathering and assessment system of any department in the Met. Mr Grieve regards his team of civilian computer analysts as core members of the team. Refreshingly, he is not obsessed by rank. If he thinks a junior officer has something to contribute, he or she will be invited to speak at the top table.

Others in the Met have found this difficult to cope with. On one occasion, a young detective sergeant was asked by Grieve to join a high ranking meeting chaired by an assistant commissioner. The older men referred to each other by their christian names. The assistant commissioner was apparently apoplectic that the whipper-snapper had the temerity to join in.

Mr Grieve was a regular visitor to the Lawrence inquiry, both for its hearings in London and around the country. Unlike some of his more defensive and straightlaced colleagues, he went out of his way to be affable and approachable to anyone who cared to engage with him. Despite his bear-like stature, he had a slightly shambolic, bluff persona which seemed to inspire confidence.

He was an assiduous cultivator of selected journalists, giving them the impression that he valued their views and knowledge. "Come by and see how we really work," he would say, offering the sort of access that few senior detectives would contemplate. He went to the opening night of The Colour of Justice, the dramatisation of the Macpherson hearings, in January last year, and caused something of a stir by suggesting the play could have been much tougher on the Met.

To some, his bonhommie has a touch of calculation: his handling of the new Lawrence inquiry has shown that he needs the support of the media to fly his kites. Mr Grieve has been on to something for months. Three people have been arrested and then released on bail, a knife was discovered in a back garden, and he has hinted that the alliances that once bound the original suspects are breaking down.

Not everyone has been pleased to see his star rise. Last year, someone, possibly a Met officer, went to the trouble of sending to Stephen Lawrence's parents, Doreen and Neville, a four page document which attempted to smear him and other officers.

It claimed, without foundation, that he had friends in the force who were known racists. It referred to a £32,000 payout awarded seven years ago to Sarah Locker, a police woman who claimed she had been denied promotion because of sexual and racial discrimination. Mr Grieve had been her overall boss at Lehman Street police station in the east end and apologised to her in public on behalf of Sir Paul Condon.

It illustrates that Grieve has made enemies. Most of his colleagues, however, treat him with reverence. Officers in the task force call him "the boss" and look up to him with respect and affection. "He's like no other officer I have ever served with," said one. "He doesn't think like a normal detective."

There is a fear at Scotland Yard that if Mr Grieve manages to charge and convict the racist killers of Stephen Lawrence, then he might be tempted to retire to his library of crime books, his canvases and selection of Bob Dylan records. "That's the last thing anyone wants," said an insider. "He's our prime asset at the moment. No wonder they're keeping him so busy."

fields.headline: Defiant Haider rails against EU's 'exorcism'
fields.standfirst:
Leader of Austria's Freedom party quits as May Day rallies show dwindling support for extremists across Europe

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, Austria's most controversial post-war politician, officially bowed out as the leader of the far-right Freedom party yesterday following months of fierce international protest against his party's participation in the government.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, Austria's most controversial post-war politician, officially bowed out as the leader of the far-right Freedom party yesterday following months of fierce international protest against his party's participation in the government.

In his 14-year climb to the top, Mr Haider brought the Freedom party (FPO) out of provincial obscurity, tripled its share of the vote and thrust it on to the international stage.

Critics said his step down, which he first announced in March, could mark "the end of the Haider era", although party members described it as "just a change of shifts".

Vice-chancellor Susanne Riess-Passer, 39, Mr Haider's hand-picked successor, won 91.5% of the vote for party leader. Known in party circles as the "King Cobra" for her no-nonsense approach, she stressed that the party's leadership style of the past decade and a half would continue. "This is still Jörg Haider's party," she told delegates at the party's May Day congress in Klagenfurt in the southern province of Carinthia, where Mr Haider is governor.

Mr Haider, 50, used the occasion of his resignation to launch a new attack on the European Union. He delivered a passionate 90-minute speech in which he railed against the EU and promised to end the sanctions imposed by Austria's 14 EU partners. Sanctions were introduced three months ago after the FPO was sworn into government along with the Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party.

Mr Haider yesterday called for a nationwide referendum to end the sanctions, accusing the partner states of practising "medieval exorcism" in their efforts to "hound" the Freedom party out of government. The referendum would send a "strong signal" to Brussels, he said, especially coming from a country which is one of the EU's biggest net contributors.

He also stressed that the EU and not the FPO should reform. "Why should the most successful European political movement of the last few decades change?" he asked. "They want us to change so that they don't have to."

However, recent rumours have suggested that splits are forming within the FPO. Yesterday, Mr Haider, best known abroad for his remarks playing down Nazi crimes, appealed for unity and asked party members to understand his decision. He said his resignation was a necessity to show that FPO ministers were not his puppets. The party he said, could not move forward if members were "constantly under suspicion of being only marionettes who are being governed from Carinthia".

The leadership change, he added, would "take the wind out of the sails of those who say 'without Haider, you are nothing'."

webTitle: Clash in Florida court over 'political' IRA gunrunning trial

fields.headline: Clash in Florida court over 'political' IRA gunrunning trial
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The trial of three men accused of attempting to smuggle guns to the IRA from the United States was marked by confrontation yesterday, even before it had got under way.
fields.body:
The trial of three men accused of attempting to smuggle guns to the IRA from the United States was marked by confrontation yesterday, even before it had got under way.

Fred Haddad, a lawyer for one of the three, said: "There's no way to do it without politics. The US does nothing but act as apologists for the Brits no matter how many human rights they violate in Ireland."

But, as jury selection began in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, US district judge Wilkie Ferguson said: "I certainly don't want this to become a political trial. I don't want that problem I now see surfacing."

The prosecution says that the gunrunning plot helped to derail the Good Friday peace deal.

Conor Claxton, 27, Anthony Smyth, 33, and Martin Mullan, 30, were charged with posting handguns from Florida and Philadelphia to Ireland last year.

Mullan, Smyth, and Smyth's girlfriend, Siobhan Browne, are said to have bought at least 47 guns, and Mullan and Smyth are accused of posting 18 packages.

Browne, 35, a former stockbroker from Cork who is expected to give evidence against the others, is facing up to five years in prison after pleading guilty to conspiracy.

"I was the purchaser for Anthony Smyth," she told a court in March. "I knew he was going to give the weapons to Conor Claxton and I knew the weapons were going to Northern Ireland."

Ten revolvers and pistols were found in Claxton's apartment when he was arrested.

Mullan handled bank withdrawals linked by prosecutors to gun purchases and mailed three gun shipments in six days, it is alleged.

John Panaro, chairman of the local Irish Northern Aid Committee, which is said to have raised more than $100,000 towards the defence costs of the so-called Florida Four, said: "This has been a political persecution from the beginning."

fields.headline: Racists are so blind
fields.standfirst:
Immigrant workers make us richer not poorer, says Nigel Harris. So we should welcome all of them in

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Why do governments have immigration controls? It seems a silly question. The answer is so obvious, only fools would not know it. While nearly 5bn people live in the poor countries of the world, only immigration controls stop them pouring into the rich world.
fields.body:
Why do governments have immigration controls? It seems a silly question. The answer is so obvious, only fools would not know it. While nearly 5bn people live in the poor countries of the world, only immigration controls stop them pouring into the rich world.

As so often with common sense, this turns out to be uncommon nonsense. There have been poor and rich countries since countries began, but only controls on movement (and what goes with them, passports) this century. Why did not all the poor swamp the rich countries then?

It is not the poor who move, not those from either the poorest countries or the poorest areas in the countries where immigrants come from. The overwhelming majority stay at home. Even those who think about it are deterred by the costs - especially of moving to the notoriously dangerous, inhospitable and racist conditions of Europe. It is only the foolish vanity of Europeans which makes them think everyone wants to get in.

Blaming poverty is a cop-out to hide the real reason for migration. Europe and North America need the workers. Even when unemployment is high, there are areas of great shortages of workers. Anyone who has had the misfortune to work in McDonald's, flipping hamburgers, as a dishwasher in a hotel, or gutting chickens in rural factories, knows the desperate scarcity of workers in jobs where the pay and conditions are rotten.

In general, immigrants don't do the jobs the natives want (except if they're students on their uppers), so they don't displace native workers nor drive down wages. In fact, the situation is the opposite. If a hospital cannot recruit enough workers to do the unskilled jobs - porters, cleaners, laundry and canteen workers, security guards - it is impossible for the nurses, doctors, managers to work. So if you cut the number of immigrant workers, you increase native unemployment.

Indeed, an increase in the numbers of workers usually expands the economy and so increases the jobs available for native workers. A study of the Los Angeles garment industry showed that the availability of Mexican illegal immigrants made possible the survival of the industry - and so the survival of jobs for Americans as technicians, foremen, managers, salespeople, truckers, shop assistants, not to mention all those others who provided the immigrants with food, accommodation, transport, etc. That is why a million Cubans lifted the economy of Miami out of slump, and a million French colonists returning from Algeria (at independence) lifted the south of France.

The extreme rightwing argument - kick the immigrants out and unemployment will be ended - is not only nonsense, it is the opposite of what would happen. Expel the immigrants and native unemployment would soar. In the postwar baby boom, when the children became adults and looked for work, there was no increase in unemployment. Think of the immense increase in the number of women looking for work in the 1960s and 1970s, far more than the number of immigrants: they did not cause unemployment. It is not the size of the labour force that determines unemployment but the profits of business. People only object to immigrants not because they are workers, but because they are foreigners.

Furthermore, controls are expensive and ineffective. Hunting illegals inflicts yet further savageries on immigrants, and now on refugees (who are also forbidden to work while waiting a decision on their refugee status, and thus reduced to dependence on government handouts). Indeed, ending controls would go some way to radically reducing unemployment - as happened in the great boom years of the 1950s and 1960s when unemployment was at a low and immigration not limited.

So why are there controls? The issue is not about jobs but about sovereignty, the power of the state. That is embedded in the perceptions of the citizens. The population is drilled from an early age in xenophobia, socialised in a culture of hating foreigners and blaming them for whatever goes wrong (and look how it flourishes in international football, or in the beef trade ) .

It is also barely concealed racism. Foreigners don't arrive by plane or train, they "invade", "swamp", "flood", "pour in", "take over" - they are soldiers of an enemy onslaught. So increased numbers of immigrants supposedly weaken the foundation of loyalty to the state, muddying it with loyalty to other states.

In practice, governments are ambivalent. In a global economy, they are obliged to acknowledge that jobs and incomes depend on increased movement of workers, immigration and emigration - the global labour market. Yet, they fear this undermines what it is to be "British" or "French" or whatever. The compromise is to define many exceptions for selected workers - doctors, nurses, businessmen, employees of multinational corporations or international organisations, seasonal agricultural labour, sometimes hotel workers and domestics, while reserving the full ferocity of persecution to those at the bottom of the pile, the illegal immigrants and refugees.

It cannot last forever. The pressures of worker movement are too strong - the system cannot control the world labour market, only drive it into the miseries of illegality. Furthermore, ageing is undermining it. As the numbers of aged increase, the active labour force is set to shrink - and wages, as a result, to soar. The aged need more and more labour intensive services, the caring professions, just when the number of workers is shrinking.

Already, the developed countries are beginning to reshape immigration policy in order to recruit the workers they need. The US is currently offering computer programmers and engineers work permits, and Germany is doing the same. But if the misery of the aged is to be tackled, this will have to be vastly expanded to lesser skills.

Increased migration is actually an immense opportunity to advance the world. Labour migration generates strong reverse flows of income - workers send money home to their families. The UN has done some calculations on how much immigration controls in the developed countries cost the third world. If they were ended, there could be a massive flow of income from the earnings of migrant workers back to developing countries, far more than current flows of aid or private capital. At last there would be a serious possibility of a real attack on world poverty.

And would it lead to the decline of the national state? Let's hope so - their highest 20th-century triumphs were two world wars of unprecedented destruction. Then we can amend the UN Declaration of Human Rights which boldly promises the right to emigrate - but is silent on the right to immigration. The underlying principle, universal in most places up to the last century, needs to be restored - that people have the right to travel where they will, to settle and to work, as they wish. The world belongs to us all.

Extracted from the current issue of Red Pepper. Nigel Harris, professor of Urban Economics at University College London, is an adviser to the World Bank.

webTitle: Private homes mooted to ease NHS crisis

fields.headline: Private homes mooted to ease NHS crisis
fields.standfirst:
Health team looks at options to free hospital beds
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, will insist that private nursing homes do far more than they now do to help elderly patients get better before he allows NHS managers to use the private sector to ease the hospital beds crisis.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, will insist that private nursing homes do far more than they now do to help elderly patients get better before he allows NHS managers to use the private sector to ease the hospital beds crisis.

Mr Milburn's deputy, John Denham, yesterday confirmed that one of the action teams set up after Tony Blair's NHS modernisation initiative is considering partnership with the private sector as one means of easing the so-called "bed-blocking" problem.

It would be daft not to, said Mr Denham. "You have got a lot of patients, particularly elderly patients, in hospitals who don't need to be there but can't yet go home, they need rehabilitation.

"There are a lot of ideas being put forward for expanding the number of so-called intermediate care beds," he told Radio 4's Today.

But as Labour MPs voiced their concern, health officials later made clear that other options exist. They include special wards for elderly people on the mend which could be set up within mainstream hospitals, local community hospitals or in new facilities.

Before Mr Milburn sanctions NHS funds going to private nursing or residential homes he will also expect them to replace what one official called "the missing component of care" - the hands-on work needed to get an elderly patient back at home after a stay of up to three months.

The Tories welcomed the move as a sign of belated ministerial pragmatism towards the private sector, though Mr Milburn and Mr Blair have always distinguished between using private facilities and the Tory preference for extending private health care finance - via insurance.

Age Concern and the Liberal Democrats also gave a cautious welcome.

But David Hinchcliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health select committee, spoke for many Labour MPs who will be wary of such a shift in case it weakens the NHS.

"I don't see the way forward as using the nursing home sector because that sector is, frankly, not geared to the rehabilitation process that these patients will require," said Mr Hinchliffe, a former social worker who has long argued for integration on health and social services in critical fields like care of the elderly.

"Most of these people will be returning to their own homes and the private care sector has, quite frankly, a record of encouraging dependence rather than independence.

"So I would be very worried if a role was being envisaged for them," he told the BBC's World at One

He complained: "In many instances their record is one of encouraging dependence because it is in their interests to do that - they then get the business to fill their own beds."

Bed-blocking, whereby elderly patients stay in hospital because they are not well enough to look after themselves at home, is a long-standing but growing problem for the NHS which gets most of its patients in and out of hospital in ever-shorter times - and has fewer beds as a result. Most emergency admissions to hospital are among the over-75s.

Ministers are keen to woo older voters - not least because they are so numerous.

The partnership action team, chaired by John Hutton, junior health minister, also includes Dr Ian Bogle, BMA chairman, Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nurses, whose members bear the brunt of such work, and Andrew Foster, head of the audit commission.

Gordon Brown is stumping up a record 6.3% increase in NHS spending, but Mr Blair wants better value for money.

The Conservatives' health spokesman, Dr Liam Fox, accused the government of sending out mixed signals to the private sector.

fields.headline: Hague turns on asylum critics
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader unrepentant on hardline stance as Lib Dems lambast him for being 'prisoner of the right'
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: An unrepentant William Hague will turn the tables on critics of his hardline stance on crime and asylum today when he accuses Tony Blair of betrayal and Charles Kennedy of leading the Liberal Democrats to "the extreme fringes of the political debate".
fields.body:
An unrepentant William Hague will turn the tables on critics of his hardline stance on crime and asylum today when he accuses Tony Blair of betrayal and Charles Kennedy of leading the Liberal Democrats to "the extreme fringes of the political debate".

Evidently stung by Mr Kennedy's attacks - which the Lib Dem leader plans to repeat today - Mr Hague will say Mr Kennedy is "more interested in the rights of criminals than the rights of people who are burgled" - a reference to farmer Tony Martin's murder conviction in Norfolk.

He will also give short shrift to the moderate Tory back bencher Andrew Rowe, who gave his leader a coded warning yesterday of the danger of blaming asylum seekers for wider problems.

Mr Hague and Mr Kennedy, both hoping to see their candidate win Thursday's Romsey byelection, are returning to the Hampshire town for one last push today.

Mr Kennedy is warily hoping for a narrow win in the seat where the late Michael Colvin had a Tory majority of 8,585 in 1997. He will tell supporters that they - and disgusted Tory voters - can send a message to Mr Hague that he is "not fit to lead the country" or his party.

Mr Rowe, MP for Faversham in the asylum hotspot of Kent, may share those doubts, but he only hinted at them on Radio 4's Today programme yesterday.

"I think everybody who is comfortably off - particularly if they are in a leadership position of a political party - needs to be extremely careful of going down the track of blaming the relatively small number of people who come into this country," he said.

Mr Hague was right to challenge the government on its handling on the latest asylum surge, he conceded. But he invoked the spirit of an older Toryism when he added: "The idea that somehow the numbers of people coming into this country are going to put the whole fabric of our society at risk is nonsense."

Mr Kennedy will be more blunt in Romsey today, when he will accuse Mr Hague of peddling "irresponsible politics, an immature politics".

"His are the politics of fear and division. Mr Hague is a prisoner of the right and has turned the Conservative party into little more than an extremist sect," he will say.

Mr Hague's effort to retain the seat, and pick up 400 or more gains in the 3,300 contested council seats on Thursday, is prompting him to raise the temperature once again.

He will tell voters that they face "a stark choice between Conservative candidate Tim Palmer, who was born and bred in Hampshire, knows the area, and speaks for the people of the area, and Labour and Liberal candidates who speak for no one but their political masters in Westminster".

Hammering home the theme, he will contrast "a Conservative party that speaks for the mainstream majority of the British people [with] a Labour party that has broken and betrayed its promises to the whole of the British people, and a Liberal Democrat party that has given up all pretence of speaking for any significant group of the British people.

"We have seen that stark choice between the political parties clearly in the issues that have dominated the political agenda in recent weeks. We see it in the ongoing debate about the crisis of bogus asylum seekers.

"Labour's soft touch on asylum has meant that the controls have all but collapsed, the backlog of cases has doubled to over 100,000, the costs to taxpayers have spiralled out of control, and the genuine refugees who we have a duty to help are getting lost in the large number of bogus applications."

By contrast, "the Conservative party has not been afraid to speak up for mainstream majority Britain that wants firm action. We will detain asylum seekers when they come into the country. We will process their claims swiftly. We will then welcome genuine refugees with open arms. And we will deport there and then those making bogus claims."

"I think everybody who is comfortably off - particularly if they are in a leadership position of a political party - needs to be extremely careful of going down the track of blaming the relatively small number of people who come into this country," he said. Mr Hague was right to challenge the government on its handling on the latest asylum surge, he conceded. But he invoked the spirit of an older Toryism when he added: "The idea that somehow the numbers of people coming into this country are going to put the whole fabric of our society at risk is nonsense." Mr Kennedy will be more blunt in Romsey today, when he will accuse Mr Hague of peddling "irresponsible politics, an immature politics". "His are the politics of fear and division. Mr Hague is a prisoner of the right and has turned the Conservative party into little more than an extremist sect," he will say. Mr Hague's effort to retain the seat, and pick up 400 or more gains in the 3,300 contested council seats on Thursday, is prompting him to raise the temperature once again. He will tell voters that they face "a stark choice between Conservative candidate Tim Palmer, who was born and bred in Hampshire, knows the area, and speaks for the people of the area, and Labour and Liberal candidates who speak for no one but their political masters in Westminster". Hammering home the theme, he will contrast "a Conservative party that speaks for the mainstream majority of the British people [with] a Labour party that has broken and betrayed its promises to the whole of the British people, and a Liberal Democrat party that has given up all pretence of speaking for any significant group of the British people. "We have seen that stark choice between the political parties clearly in the issues that have dominated the political agenda in recent weeks. We see it in the ongoing debate about the crisis of bogus asylum seekers. "Labour's soft touch on asylum has meant that the controls have all but collapsed, the backlog of cases has doubled to over 100,000, the costs to taxpayers have spiralled out of control, and the genuine refugees who we have a duty to help are getting lost in the large number of bogus applications." By contrast, "the Conservative party has not been afraid to speak up for mainstream majority Britain that wants firm action. We will detain asylum seekers when they come into the country. We will process their claims swiftly. We will then welcome genuine refugees with open arms. And we will deport there and then those making bogus claims."

webTitle: Island hostages plead for swift release

fields.headline: Island hostages plead for swift release
fields.standfirst: Rebel Filipinos allow access to captives living in fear
fields.trailText: Tourists, local officials and workers kidnapped from a Malaysian diving resort by Islamic guerrillas a week ago are being held in appalling conditions in a hut on the southern Philippine island of Jolo.The 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists, appeared weak and frightened. They pleaded yesterday to be freed soon, saying their conditions were deteriorating.
fields.byline: Arlyn de la Cruz in Zamboanga Philippines
fields.body:
Tourists, local officials and workers kidnapped from a Malaysian diving resort by Islamic guerrillas a week ago are being held in appalling conditions in a hut on the southern Philippine island of Jolo.The 21 hostages, including 10 foreign tourists, appeared weak and frightened. They pleaded yesterday to be freed soon, saying their conditions were deteriorating.

Several were suffering from diarrhoea or infections. They were allowed to see a doctor yesterday who said they were "OK under the circumstances".

A spokeman for the kidnappers said interviews with the captives were being granted "to confirm to the world that we are holding the hostages".

The captives have not bathed since they were kidnapped on April 23, and have been drinking only rainwater and eating mainly rice. Some had cuts on their feet from walking barefoot in the jungle, a German woman had high blood pressure and they were filthy.

One corner of their hut was used as the bathroom, another corner was earmarked for cooking.

The hostages are 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipina.

They were guarded by about 500 armed men of the Al-Harkatul Al-Islamiya, or the Abu Sayyaf, a Muslim militia fighting for independence from the Catholic-dominated Philippines. In turn, Philippine troops have ringed the camp to ensure the rebels do not escape.

The captives' hut was in the hills near Talipao, some 960km (600 miles) south of Manila, reached after a two-hour walk through jungle. Inside, Werner Gunter Kort, from Germany, and Carel Strydom, from South Africa, were playing chess with a wooden set provided by the kidnappers.

The others sat listlessly on the floor waiting for the afternoon meal.

"They are treating us absolutely correctly. There is no question of being terrorised or anything like that. We are being treated correctly, but conditions here are very poor and are deteriorating from day to day," said Mr Kort, whose wife and son are with him.

He urged the Philippine military not to try a rescue operation, saying "it would have no chance at all".

The tourists had just finished dinner on the Sipadan Island diving resort in Malaysia on April 23 when they were kidnapped. They were taken with other hostages on a 22-hour boat ride to Jolo, the largest of the Sulu group of islands.

The kidnappers procured T-shirts, shorts and trousers for the hostages in Jolo town because many of them were wearing only swimming costumes when kidnapped.

A couple of the women broke down while speaking of their ordeal. "I miss my son. I miss my son," said Renate Juta, from Germany.

Marie Michel, a Lebanese, said she "will never go to another Asian place starting from now". She added: "It's getting very, very hard, nothing happens, they don't want to take any decision.

"We don't have enough food, we don't have anything to drink, we don't have anything, but I want to tell my parents in Lebanon that I am OK."

But most of the hostages exuded a resigned calm and said they were coping with the situation. "I'm feeling okay. I'm losing weight," said Monique Strydom, of South Africa. "It's not as bad as it looks. I think [the guerrillas] are doing the best they can under the circumstances."

Her husband, Carel, said he wanted his family back home to know that they were basically all right but getting weaker. "It's very hot and treatment is not very good. In terms of food, it's very basic and therefore I think we're getting a little bit weaker as time goes by."

Commander Radhulan, a spokesman for the Abu Sayyaf, said the main demand of the group was to negotiate with a representative of the UN. He did not make any threats against the hostages.

Meanwhile, Philippine troops yesterday continued to search a maze of second world war tunnels in a hilltop rebel hideout where a further 27 hostages, most of them children, have been held by the same group of Islamic guerrillas for over a month. Troops launched the search after taking control of the hideout on Basilan island in the southern Philippines on Sunday in fierce hand-to-hand fighting.

Arlyn de la Cruz is a freelance journalist working for Reuters.

fields.headline: New light on Casement's diaries
fields.trailText: New light should be shed this week on whether private diaries kept by Sir Roger Casement - Irish patriot, humanitarian crusader and closet homosexual - were forged by British intelligence to smear him after he was condemned to death for high treason.
fields.body:
New light should be shed this week on whether private diaries kept by Sir Roger Casement - Irish patriot, humanitarian crusader and closet homosexual - were forged by British intelligence to smear him after he was condemned to death for high treason.

Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, is to open a two-day symposium organised by the Royal Irish Academy in Dublin. The idea, says Patrick Buckley, the academy's executive director, is "to rescue Casement from being a peripheral figure".

Most historians now believe the "black diaries" were genuine, though documents released at the public record office make it clear that Whitehall and the security services used them to foil a campaign to save his life.

One of those who believes they were forged is Angus Mitchell, who has been awarded an Irish peace and reconciliation fund grant to complete his research.

Mr Mitchell, who is pressing for an independent forensic examination of the diaries, believes they could have been forged by Admiral Reginald "Blinker" Hall, the head of naval intelligence.

The admiral was later instrumental in leaking the forged Zinoviev letter to help bring down the Labour government in 1924. Hall was one of those who circulated the Casement diaries.

Though security sources in sist there are no more hidden documents relating to the diaries,13 pages of MI5 files released last year on the Casement case were withheld.

Born into the Irish Protestant ascendancy, Casement was a British consul in Africa and South America knighted for his work in exposing the exploitation and slaughter of Africans and South American Indians.

He was arrested on a beach in Co Kerry, three days before the 1916 Easter rising, after landing in a boat which had picked him up from a German submarine. A trawler accompanying the submarine and carrying 20,000 guns was scuttled after being intercepted.

Documents released at the public record office in 1998 show that Casement knew the Easter rising was doomed to failure after Germany reneged on its promises to send troops to help the rebels.

Casement told his MI5 interrogators he had been let down by Germany but unless he accepted what he called its "wholly futile scheme" - the supply of a limited amount of weapons - he would be "branded by his friends in Ireland and America as a coward and traitor to their cause".

"I have done nothing dishonourable, as you will one day learn ... I came ... knowing that you were bound to catch me," he told Frank Hall, a senior MI5 officer, and Sir Basil Thomson, Scotland Yard head of CID.

According to the documents, Casement told Thomson that "when he knew the Germans had refused to send men, he felt it his duty to come and warn the rebels a rising would be hopeless".

Whitehall was deeply concerned about a campaign for clemency by prominent figures, including Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, George Bernard Shaw, Joseph Conrad and TE Lawrence.

Casement was hanged in Pentonville prison on August 3, 1916.

fields.headline: DNA tests offer roots revival
fields.standfirst: US geneticists to offer black Americans the opportunity to trace their family's cultural and religious heritages
fields.trailText: Black Americans will soon be offered the chance to take a DNA test which will help them to track down their roots in Africa - a scientific advance which could trigger a "back-to-Africa" movement not witnessed since the 1970s.
fields.body:
Black Americans will soon be offered the chance to take a DNA test which will help them to track down their roots in Africa - a scientific advance which could trigger a "back-to-Africa" movement not witnessed since the 1970s.

The new DNA test, which should be available this summer, could uncover links between the genes of black Americans and a database of 2,000 samples taken from 40 separate ethnic groups in west Africa, from where the overwhelming majority of slaves were taken.

Richard Newman, a researcher at Harvard University's WEB DuBois Institute for African-American research, said: "It doesn't mean anything to know that some of my people came from Africa. But if I can pinpoint a culture, a religion and language, then it can strengthen my sense of identity and relationship with Africa."

In the 1970s, the phenomenally successful television series Roots reawakened the curiosity of many US blacks about their family history before slavery uprooted their ancestors. Thousands travelled to west Africa in the hope of finding out more about their lineage, but many returned from their trips disappointed by the absence of specific information about their roots.

Geneticists at Washington's Howard University, which is offering the DNA tests, have predicted that many black Americans will also find genetic roots in England and the rest of Europe. Tests have revealed that about a third of African-American men have inherited European genes through the paternal line of the family - either as a consequence of rape or of master-slave relationships like the one recently confirmed between US President Thomas Jefferson and his servant girl Sally Hemings, they say.

Howard University will perform two sorts of tests. One will examine mitochondrial DNA, which is handed down from mother to child; the other will look at the male, or "Y" chromosome, which is passed from father to son. Researchers will then search for small, identifying mutations which might tie the subject to a distinct ethnic group in Africa.

"To a lot of blacks, knowing a little bit of the story is important," said Rick Kittles, the geneticist leading the study. "This will definitely contribute a lot to understanding the history of African-Americans."

Jerry Large, a columnist for the Seattle Times, welcomed the breakthrough, arguing it could give blacks the same sense of history that other "hyphenated-Americans" like the Irish and Italian communities, take for granted.

"They know just where their families came from and that helps them feel placed in the world. Being able to trace one's roots isn't a necessity like food or water, but it can give a person a nice psychological boost, a connection to the broader world," Mr Large wrote.

Similar DNA surveys have helped established a historical lineage for other ethnic groups; one study found that many families with the name Levy or Cohen could trace their lineage back to Jewish priests of the biblical era.

However, some genealogists have warned that establishing such links may be harder for black Americans. Some of the clans and tribes of west and central Africa have been dispersed by population movements during the past four centuries and may be impossible to track down.

Even if a genetic match can be found with communities still living in Africa, it could also be hard to re-establish cultural and emotional connections violently severed so long ago, argued one genealogist, Lester Burroughs. "The years that have passed since we have been off the African shores have been difficult on both sides of the ocean," he said. "And there has been little attempt to bridge those gaps."

Harsh reality behind dream of returning

The desire to reverse the direction of the slave trade and "go home" has tugged at the African-American consciousness for nearly two centuries, but returnees have had only patchy success in establishing roots in African soil.

In 1787, an English opponent of slavery, Granville Sharp, financed and organised the resettling of 400 freed American slaves on the West African coast, in a town that came to be known as Freetown, the capital of modern Sierra Leone.

About 40 years later, in 1822, the West African state of Liberia was founded in 1822, also by freed US slaves who were resettled there with help from another charitable society, the American Colonisation Society.

Both settlements came under attack from the European colonial powers and by local African tribes, but retained their toe-hold with financial help from supporters and freed slaves back in the US.

The experience of resettled slaves in Sierra Leone and Liberia was sufficiently daunting to deter further large-scale returns, which were resisted by the colonial powers, who had carved up Africa by the end of the 19th century. Besides, conditions were improving in the US. Slavery was abolished - first in the North and then in the South following the Civil War.

But the improvements in the lot of black Americans came to a halt in the post-war decades and ultimately provoked a furious white backlash, in places like Tulsa, Oklahoma, where prosperous black districts were razed to the ground by white rioters.

The resurgence of racial oppression spurred the next back-to-Africa movement, led by Marcus Garvey in the 1920s. Garvey, a charismatic, Jamaican-born leader who dressed in a ceremonial uniform complete with black-plumed hat, argued that blacks would never win justice in America, and should therefore return to their ancestral homelands in Africa.

Funded by his two million supporters and by a string of black-owned businesses, he shipped thousands of hopeful black Americans to new lives in Africa on his Black Star shipping line. However, Garvey was jailed in 1925, on trumped-up fraud-charges, and his movement died out before the new African-American settlements could take hold. Garvey returned to Jamaica, and then to Britain. He died in poverty in London at the age of 53.

An echo of the Marcus Garvey movement seized African-American imaginations in the late 1970's with the television series Roots, based on a book by Alex Haley about his quest to trace his lineage back before the age of slavery to his cultural African roots. Hundreds of thousands of black Americans tried to follow his example, but lacking any records, most returned disappointed and shocked by African conditions.

However, the dream of an eventual return has survived, and was fuelled last year by the Ghanaian president, Jerry Rawlings, who offered dual citizenship to the black US diaspora.

"You're our kith and kin," Mr Rawlings announced at the White House. "After all, is there any reason why you should not have the right to enjoy the citizenship of where you come from?"

fields.headline: Park and play
fields.standfirst: Unusual venue for symphony of (nearly) a thousand
fields.trailText: Bath may be the city where Handel first conducted The Messiah, and may be able to boast a music festival attracting the likes of Kyung Wha Chung, the classical violinist, and George Shearing, the jazz legend.
fields.body:
Bath may be the city where Handel first conducted The Messiah, and may be able to boast a music festival attracting the likes of Kyung Wha Chung, the classical violinist, and George Shearing, the jazz legend.

Yet when the Bath Philharmonia decided to perform Mahler's 8th, it found the city had no venue big enough to hold a symphony orchestra - let alone the Austrian composer's prescribed strength of a thousand.

Its solution was novel: when the 1906 masterpiece is performed later this month, it will be in a disused railway station - at present doubling as a craft market and a Sainsbury's car park (above, with orchestra members).

For one night only, the trolley stalls and disabled parking signs will be uprooted while an audience of 2,000 clusters beneath the station's Victorian iron girders and glass roof to hear the 117-strong orchestra, offstage brass band, eight soloists and four choirs.

Health and safety officials have banned the full cast of 1,000, for fear they will fall through the station's decking, and the building's acoustic resonance is to be checked, in case the 800 singing and playing fortissimo shatter the glass.

"We might suffer from sound pollution because we can't have the surrounding roads closed off, and we're susceptible to the weather," said the orchestra's conductor and founder, Jason Thornton, 30.

"If it rains, the noise on the glass is horrendous. And if there's thunder and lightning, we're stuffed. It's also not waterproof, so we run the risk of the audience getting soaked."

Despite this, the orchestra, which has attracted the likes of soprano Theresa Cahill, tenor Neil Jenkins, the London Philharmonic Choir and the Bournemouth Symphony Chorus to take part in the Symphony of a Thousand, has begun selling seats for the dress rehearsal to cope with demand.

"It's clear people want to see this scale of performance, but there just aren't the facilities," said Mr Thornton, whose four-year-old ensemble will turn professional next season.

webTitle: A-level maths just doesn't add up

fields.headline: A-level maths just doesn't add up
fields.trailText: How can Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, interpret good news so badly (A-level maths to be made harder, May 1)? Having taught maths for over 20 years, I think the fact that A-level maths is now easier is great.
fields.body:
How can Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, interpret good news so badly (A-level maths to be made harder, May 1)? Having taught maths for over 20 years, I think the fact that A-level maths is now easier is great.

Ten years ago maths A-level was in trouble. Research showed that it was a grade harder than the average A-level. Most students knew it and did something else. Those that did try lost confidence. How did this elitism help them, or the nation?

Since my school moved to a modular course, maths has become increasingly popular. Many more students enjoy it and have the confidence to use it. The coursework element demands that they work as mathematicians - reading, writing, problem solving. They see topics such as statistics as essential preparation for their adult life.

David Jennings
Bognor Regis, W Sussex
djennings@felpham.org.uk

 I am concerned that "easy" statistics is to be dropped in order to raise the overall difficulty. As a postgraduate student with responsibility for teaching physics undergraduate students, I have noticed their already poor grasp of basic statistics. I have to teach them the rudiments of data analysis, and if statistics is dropped from A-levels then I fear for the skills of future students.

Karl Sherratt
Coventry
karl@mrmorden.freeserve.co.uk

 As a teacher of A-level maths for the past 26 years I am baffled that anyone should want to make the subject more difficult. Yes, it probably has got easier in the past 25 years but it needed to.

I prefer to believe that it has become more accessible to young people. What's wrong with shorter questions, testing what they know rather than elaborate long questions that students often couldn't start?

Maths is still a hard A-level with a high drop-out rate. The last thing this country needs is fewer people studying maths. Just listen to anyone trying to recruit a maths teacher in the south-east.

Geoff Poole
Prescot, Merseyside
Gpoole@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Power to the workers
fields.trailText: Max Hess (Letters, May 1) argues that Paul Foot and other London Socialist Assembly candidates "hold with" waged work, profit-making and money. I defy him to find an instance where Paul Foot has defended profit-making as a way to run society.
fields.body:
Max Hess (Letters, May 1) argues that Paul Foot and other London Socialist Assembly candidates "hold with" waged work, profit-making and money. I defy him to find an instance where Paul Foot has defended profit-making as a way to run society.

As to wage labour and money; Paul Foot, like any good socialist, knows and agrees with Marx's adage that workers should inscribe on their banner "Abolition of the wages system", rather than the conservative slogan "A fair day's work for a fair day's pay". Only those who think socialism is about having the "correct ideas" see a contradiction between working for the abolition of the wages system and fighting for higher pay now.

Only a tiny proportion of the world's workers are yet ready to subscribe to the abolition of wages. For most, the abolition of wages would mean starvation - and that is too high a price to pay for Max Hess's "socialism".

Derek Howl
Leeds
derekhowl@beeb.ne t

 Presumably Max Hess is using a PC, electricity and telephone equipment supplied by the Anarchists' Collective? What a terrific shop that is.

Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife
Tom.Locke@kscl.com

 May Day, Labour Day? The holiday intended for those working under the poorest conditions for the lowest pay? That comprises those of us working in catering, leisure and retail. Yet we are the ones who work on May Day, serving those who are better paid and who have far longer holidays. When does the next revolution start?

Tony Day
Cromer, Norfolk
sunrise@paston.co.uk

 Tony Benn repeated on television this weekend Ken Livingstone's assertion that capitalism is responsible for the deaths of millions. In sympathy with that view, a motley lot plants parsnips in London's streets. Let that lie be nailed. Without capitalism, the world's population could not be supported by the planet's resources. As Margaret Thatcher's mentor, Friedrich Hayek, so aptly expresses it, "capitalism created the proletariat, but not by making anybody worse off; rather by enabling many to survive who would not otherwise have done so".

GR Steele
Lancaster
G.Steele@lancaster.ac.uk

 In the 1960s, the French riot police, the CRS, had the habit of calling any protest against De Gaulle "a riot" then wading in with big sticks and CS gas to make sure it was one. So different from our own Metropolitan police.

Derek McMillan
East Grinstead, W Sussex
mcmillan@enterprise.net

 Isabel Hilton asks rhetorically (Attacking Goliath, May 1) where is the democratic body that corresponds to the World Trade Organisation?

It already exists: it is the World Trade Organisation. The WTO is a constitutional court that acts as a check on arbitrary power exercised by special interests. Its first major ruling, in 1996, struck a blow for developing nations against protectionism by the rich world, in insisting that the United States not discriminate against petroleum imports from Venezuela.

Developing countries need expanded trade, and foreign capital to fund their accompanying current account deficits, if they are to lift themselves out of poverty. The WTO is an essential tool in that task, while the protesters on the streets this weekend are an obstacle to it.

Oliver Kamm
London
oliver.kamm@virgin.net

fields.headline: Beefy men
fields.trailText: Why is Shane Watson so surprised that so many men persist in making themselves more muscular than women find attractive (More cake and less beef please, April 28)?
fields.body:
Why is Shane Watson so surprised that so many men persist in making themselves more muscular than women find attractive (More cake and less beef please, April 28)?

She should know that men develop their bodies for the benefit of other men, not women. Likewise women's make-up and clothes are for other women, not men.

Just observe any mixed group of people, especially young adults - all the really intense stuff going on is men-men or (to a lesser degree) women-women.

Richard Rogers
Oxford
harpes@rogersr.fsbusiness. co.uk

fields.headline: Getting mobile
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago I tried to buy a new Rover 25 after taking an impressive test drive, only to be told when I arrived back at the showroom that the models in the basic colours I wanted (either red, white or blue) had sold out due to unprecedented demand since the sell-off announcement. They could, however, find one in metallic paint for roughly £1,000 extra. I rest my case.

Two weeks ago I tried to buy a new Rover 25 after taking an impressive test drive, only to be told when I arrived back at the showroom that the models in the basic colours I wanted (either red, white or blue) had sold out due to unprecedented demand since the sell-off announcement. They could, however, find one in metallic paint for roughly £1,000 extra. I rest my case.

David Windridge
Nuneaton, Warks
david@mojoland.freeserve. co.uk

 Taking a railway journey the other evening I overheard someone say on their mobile phone, "Hello, I'm on the wrong train." I understood from recent research that these phones do not affect the brain, but now am doubtful.

Richard Herbert
Leeds

 I commend Napoleon Bonaparte's remark, "What a beautiful country," as he gazed around Torbay while en route to St Helena in 1815. As far as I know, his thoughts on Morecambe, Goole, Southport et al are not recorded (Letters, May 1).

Jack Critchlow
Torquay, Devon

 You describe Hard Times as "an improbable musical" (West End awash with the next big thing, May 1) What the Dickens does this mean? Surely all musicals are improbable. Or does the night shift at the Guardian burst into spontaneous song and tap dance as part of their routine behaviour when they come into work?

Tim Shepheard
High Wycombe, Bucks
cagliari@easynet.co.uk

 Peter Preston (Hague, the Dome and Rover, May 1) says the dome "wasn't a lousy idea". I beg to differ. Most people outside the charmed, metropolitan establishment loop always knew it was a lousy idea.

Nick Blackstock
Bradford, W Yorks
n.blackstock@which.net

fields.headline: Home life
fields.trailText: I was brought up in local authority children's homes and I suffered all sorts of deprivations, mostly because of the time that my parents spent looking after children who had no one to look after them. There are a number of people like myself who were the children of very committed staff who gave their lives to look after other people's children. While the outcome was not always rosy, the benefits cannot be overlooked.
fields.body:
I was brought up in local authority children's homes and I suffered all sorts of deprivations, mostly because of the time that my parents spent looking after children who had no one to look after them. There are a number of people like myself who were the children of very committed staff who gave their lives to look after other people's children. While the outcome was not always rosy, the benefits cannot be overlooked.

Why is so much attention being given to the negative side of all this (Devon abuse inquiry may rival north Wales scandal, April 28) when so many caring people have devoted their lives to residential care work? My own parents were founder members of the Residential Care Association; my father, Frank Hanson, was the president (1958-59).

Fewer and fewer people of that era are able to defend themselves against the allegations made against them. I believe that there is a story to be told from the point of view of we children who shared our parents' love, and our lives, with hundreds of others. I may have lost some things, for which some would no doubt claim compensation, but I gained a great deal, too.

Dr Ann Hanson
Eccleston, Lancs

webTitle: Holidays in hell, and their brighter side

fields.headline: Holidays in hell, and their brighter side
fields.trailText: The problem with Helen Kolawole's "honest guide for black travellers" (See the world, be insulted, G2, April 27) is that the overwhelming majority of easily and cheaply accessible destinations would receive a rating ranging from "pretty bad" to "absolutely intolerable". Sadly this includes Britain as well as continental Europe.
fields.body:
The problem with Helen Kolawole's "honest guide for black travellers" (See the world, be insulted, G2, April 27) is that the overwhelming majority of easily and cheaply accessible destinations would receive a rating ranging from "pretty bad" to "absolutely intolerable". Sadly this includes Britain as well as continental Europe.

As a white man I have learned almost as much about the day-to-day impact of racism from the tension of holidays with my black partner as I have from nearly 40 years of political campaigning and academic study.

I have travelled widely in Britain and southern Europe. There are many places where I know that my partner (and our young son) would appreciate the architecture, the cultural attractions, the food, the hill walking, the beaches, but where I dare not suggest we travel because of the racism - if it is only the persistent, and clearly hostile, stares - that we are certain to encounter. The local CREs in Devon and Cornwall once entitled a report on racism in their region Keep Them In Birmingham. This attitude is shared across most of Europe's tourist areas and indicates how far we still have to go before we can talk of a genuinely tolerant society.

Richard Kirkwood
University of North London
r.kirkwood@unl.ac.uk

 I fear Helen Kolawole's article might dissuade some black Britons from sampling the pleasures of foreign travel. I'd like to point out some of the positive benefits.

When confronted with badly behaved arrogant British tourists, natives are quick to absolve the black Briton of associated guilt since we're not really British anyway. While there are often problems on entry to certain countries, a rapid exit can be guaranteed. Passports never get lost because they're constantly in demand. Privacy in expensive restaurants can be counted on and tipping waiters for service is completely unnecessary. Souvenir shopping is always a pleasure with accompanying shop assistants on hand to assist. Finally, on return, luggage is thoroughly searched, ensuring all foreign currency can be conveniently retrieved and changed into sterling prior to leaving the airport.

Joanna Traynor
Plymouth

fields.headline: Just making trouble
fields.trailText: Barbara Roche MP (Letters, April 29) is correct in stating that a version of the letter currently being sent to many asylum seekers existed in 1996. It was an ill-conceived response by the Home Office, following criticism by the high court in some social security cases.
fields.body:
Barbara Roche MP (Letters, April 29) is correct in stating that a version of the letter currently being sent to many asylum seekers existed in 1996. It was an ill-conceived response by the Home Office, following criticism by the high court in some social security cases.

This letter has not been seen for some time as it is deeply flawed and dishonest. It states it is a decision, but it is not a decision that can be appealed against. It advises that only by lodging an appeal can the asylum seeker receive any support. Even elements within the immigration service have lobbied against its use.

The resurrection of this letter allows the Home Office to claim a vast increase in decisions without proper regard to any remedy by the asylum seeker. It creates further confusion and despair and should be withdrawn.

Paul Morris
Manchester

 William Hague believes that if the immigration "issue" is not tackled it will lead to growing support for rightwing groups (Hague stirs race row, May 1). Is this an example of a self-fulfilling prophecy, or merely wishful thinking ?

DJ Browning
Altrincham, Cheshire
mufc1@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Ray Brown's delightfully offbeat afternoon play Barnes And Molly (2.15pm, Radio 4)

is based on 260 letters which were discovered by Sir Barnes Wallis's daughter after her father (who devised the Dam Busters' bouncing bomb) died in 1979. In the early 1920s, aged 34, Wallace sent them to Molly Bloxam (pictured with Wallace), a 17-year-old step-cousin with whom he had fallen madly in love. Her father's fiercely Victorian opposition led to this strange courtship by correspondence, in which Wallis, ever the engineer, relied on differential calculus to press his suit.

Richard Coles is also aiming for the offbeat in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3), with the alleged "memoirs" of an aristocratic Japanese woman about whom virtually nothing is known. She has come down to the modern world as Shikibu Murasaki, pseudonymous author of the earliest and most complex Japanese novel, still a gripping read a millennium later. What titbits we know come from a diary she kept at court between 1007 and 1010.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A letter, page 21, April 29 (Doing good without a dog collar), misidentified David Pollock whose correct title is chair of the British Humanist Association's education committee.
fields.body:
A letter, page 21, April 29 (Doing good without a dog collar), misidentified David Pollock whose correct title is chair of the British Humanist Association's education committee.

To clarify the matter of Roger Taylor's age after a Birthdays entry April 26, page 24, and correction April 28, page 23: Birthdays correctly listed Roger Taylor, rock drummer, as turning 40; he is the Roger Taylor of Duran Duran. It is Queen drummer Roger Taylor who is due to turn 51 on July 26.

The cricket county championship system for awarding bonus points - Scoreboard panel, page 6, Sport, April 29 - has been superseded. This year, bonus points are awarded for runs and wickets in the first 130 overs, rather than 120. A fifth batting point can now be gained by scoring 400 or more. And bowling points have been reduced from four to three, for taking the third, sixth and ninth wickets in an innings.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Has Anybody Seen My Gal? (Douglas Sirk, 1952) 9am, Carlton Cinema

Douglas Sirk directs this part-musical/part-comedy with vigour, but it falls short of both. Charles Coburn once again plays a tycoon set among the people - in this case inveigling himself into the lives of a family to whom he intends to leave his fortune. Cue much confusion, especially when he gives them money anonymously and young Millicent (Piper Laurie) has to give up her poor-but-loving beau (Rock Hudson). Look out, also, for a blink-and-you'll-miss-it appearance by one James Dean. (RC)

City Slickers (Ron Underwood, 1991) 10pm, Sky Cinema

Likeable comedy with a trio of middle-aged, middle-class men heading west to rediscover themselves on a cattle-drive holiday: plenty of horse-laughs, and thoughtful on the pressures of urban life. Billy Crystal (pictured), Daniel Stern and Bruno Kirby are the slickers who learn what a man's gotta do, but star of the show is tough-as-boots trail boss Jack Palance, who won an Oscar.

Down By Law (Jim Jarmusch, 1986) 10pm, FilmFour

Now this is serious comedy: one of Jim "Ghost Dog" Jarmusch's early, eloquent, funny essays on the beauty and beastliness of life. Tom Waits and John Lurie - who also provide a fine soundtrack - play hard cons slammed up in a New Orleans jail; little Italian Roberto Benigni shows them the way out and the meaning of life. Quirky, warm-hearted humour, beautifully photographed in black and white.

The Long Riders (Walter Hill, 1980) 1.35am, FilmFour

A stylish, unsentimental retelling of the Jesse James legend, playing large on the importance of land and kin. Thus real brothers play the outlaw families: the Keachs are the Jameses, the Carradines the Youngers, the Quaids the Millers, and all on the verge of a violent falling-out. This being Walter Hill, there's inevitably some fantastic slow-mo gunfighinting action, notably the calamitous Northfield, Minnesota bank raid. (PH)

(RC) City Slickers (Ron Underwood, 1991) 10pm, Sky Cinema Likeable comedy with a trio of middle-aged, middle-class men heading west to rediscover themselves on a cattle-drive holiday: plenty of horse-laughs, and thoughtful on the pressures of urban life. Billy Crystal (pictured), Daniel Stern and Bruno Kirby are the slickers who learn what a man's gotta do, but star of the show is tough-as-boots trail boss Jack Palance, who won an Oscar. Down By Law (Jim Jarmusch, 1986) 10pm, FilmFour Now this is serious comedy: one of Jim "Ghost Dog" Jarmusch's early, eloquent, funny essays on the beauty and beastliness of life. Tom Waits and John Lurie - who also provide a fine soundtrack - play hard cons slammed up in a New Orleans jail; little Italian Roberto Benigni shows them the way out and the meaning of life. Quirky, warm-hearted humour, beautifully photographed in black and white. The Long Riders (Walter Hill, 1980) 1.35am, FilmFour A stylish, unsentimental retelling of the Jesse James legend, playing large on the importance of land and kin. Thus real brothers play the outlaw families: the Keachs are the Jameses, the Carradines the Youngers, the Quaids the Millers, and all on the verge of a violent falling-out. This being Walter Hill, there's inevitably some fantastic slow-mo gunfighinting action, notably the calamitous Northfield, Minnesota bank raid. (PH)
