fields.headline: Weighing the world
fields.standfirst: If this is the answer, what does it mean?
fields.trailText: If this is the answer, what does it mean?
fields.body:
The reputation of Atlas, King of Mauritania, was mildly diminished yesterday when American scientists announced that the weight of the world is 5,972 billion billion tons. This means that when Atlas held the world on his shoulders he was supporting a weight some 10 billion billion tons less than previous estimates had suggested. This, to be sure, reduces the size of his burden by less than 0.2%; but we do like to be precise. The calculation comes, like so much else nowadays, from Seattle, where Professor Jens Gundlach of the University of Washington says he is confident that we now know the mass of our home planet more precisely than it has ever been known to mankind. Like the news which broke only last week that the universe is not curved, as we've thought since Einstein, but flat, this disclosure is easier to wonder at than to comprehend. Few will walk on the earth with any less confidence for knowing it is that much frailer than they might have assumed before. For most, this discovery will be less a fact of life than a fresh adornment for the stock of useless knowledge so many nowadays treasure, and one more figure to be memorised by those taking part in Mastermind, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, or quiz night down at the pub.

For professionals, though - geologists, astrophysicists and cosmologists especially - this is a calculation of huge practical significance. Its discovery is hailed, certainly in Seattle, as an historic breakthrough. But as always with unilateral claims of this kind, one reservation must be attached. Even Seattle is sometimes wrong. The Americans have got in a whisker ahead of a team at Birmingham University which has been doing the same kind of exercise. Its results are expected later this week. So far, Birmingham has responded with a kind of polite surprise, but it may be about to unveil something entirely different. Better, perhaps, not to revise our opinions of Atlas until the British have spoken.

fields.headline: Off the hook
fields.standfirst: No one ever said creating TV drama was easy - but some shows take such a tortuous route to our screens, you begin to wonder if they're jinxed.  Ed Waller  on the bizarre story behind the making of Fish
fields.trailText: No one ever said creating TV drama was easy - but some shows take such a tortuous route to our screens, you begin to wonder if they're jinxed. Ed Waller on the bizarre story behind the making of Fish
fields.body:
Whatever the collective noun for lawyers may be, one is to descend on to our screens very soon. Attracted to the dramatic mileage found in matters of legality versus morality, Channel 4 has 10 hours of Lawyers up its sleeve, plus another ten of Judicial Enquiry. ITV has four hours of In Defence, complete with Ross Kemp in a barrister's wig. But first to arrive is BBC1's £3m legal drama Fish, starring Paul McGann and Jemma Redgrave.

McGann plays a Jewish civil rights lawyer who champions underdogs in smaller courtroom battles than we normally see in legal dramas. In his first case, for example, he is fighting to get a teenage girl reinstated in her job at a chip-shop. But, as is something of an occupational hazard among TV good guys, he's finding the course of true love seldom runs smooth.

Neither does TV production, and Fish's tortuous journey from script to screen demonstrates this magnificently. Conceived in 1994, the series was the brainchild of Kate Winslet's then boyfriend, Stephen Tredre. He was an unemployed actor at the time (you might remember him from the BBC1 sci-fi Dark Season), and he'd turned his hand to screenwriting only because he was ill. Producing the series was Miriam Segal, a refugee script editor from EastEnders. Reluctant to approach her ex-employers in White City, Segal managed to wrangle some development cash from independent TV company Principal Pictures, a documentary company keen to try its hand at drama.

Tredre's pilot script, penned between bouts of worsening illness, was first popped into the in-tray of the ITV drama department. Unfortunately, it was already brimming with the network's latest hit Kavanagh QC and the Fish pilot was relegated to long term development. So Segal approached the ICG, the department within the BBC dedicated to commissioning programmes from independent TV pro ducers. They turned her down flat.

For most first-time drama producers with a script from a first-time writer, this would be the end of the line. Channel 4's drama budget is increasingly distributed among a shortlist of favoured companies. Channel 5 had yet to be born, and anyway is hardly in the mood to invest in big drama since its £2.5m low-rating Wing And A Prayer, about - yes - another bunch of lawyers. But instead of putting it down to experience, Segal took the script up the M40 to BBC Pebble Mill and tried to get Fish in on the regional quota.

It worked - the BBC's Midlands outpost loved it. A commission was landed and green lights went on all over the place. But this turn of fortune didn't last. In December 1997, Tredre died of bone cancer. Winslet, away shooting Hideous Kinky at the time, skipped the LA premiere of Titanic to sing a song at his funeral. Then Fish's champion in Pebble Mill was ousted and his drama department all but disappeared in a puff of Birtian management theory. Fish was back where it started.

But all was not lost. By now Tredre's script had caught the eye of the new controller of BBC1, who liked what he saw. After another hiatus while the new head of drama got comfortable in his chair, Fish ended up as a co-production with the BBC.

Then came the usual cut-and-thrust of casting. After some lively debates with the BBC about whether to use celebrities or actors, McGann was signed as the lead with Redgrave as his colleague/confidante/potential love interest.

But even then, Fish's troubles were far from over. After one look at what Segal admits was a chaotic shooting schedule, the director she'd signed up simply threw in the towel. A couple of young directors also of EastEnders lineage were quickly drafted in to direct three episodes each, and were soon discovering the joys of shooting in central London.

So, after six long years, what sort of animal is Fish? Well, banish Rumpole and Kavanagh QC from your minds, along with Ally McBeal and This Life.

Neither court drama nor sexy young legal folk feature large in Fish.

Nor is there much action of any variety, focusing as it does on the few solitary characters within Mr Fish's domestic story: son, absentee wife, female colleague and cafe owner.

Even the shooting style is slightly odd. Having little time for the "bollocks camera-work" that made This Life so memorable and has since become de rigueur for so many contemporary dramas, Segal preferred long and fluid tracking shots, often up to three minutes, rather than close-ups and jerky cuts. This, she reckons, forces the audience to get involved in the story .

Whether Segal's experiment in what she calls "naked TV" proves a victory for content over style will be decided over the next six Tuesdays. If the White City number-crunchers are happy, Tredre's legacy might live on for another series. If not, Segal can find comfort in the fact that at least the show survived a little longer than the ICG, the department that turned her down all those years ago. Recently it too disappeared in yet another puff of BBC management theory, this time Greg Dyke's.

 Fish, tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Happy as Lowry?
fields.standfirst: Salford's new arts centre claims there is more to its patron saint than matchstick men.  Jonathan Jones  is not convinced
fields.trailText: Salford's new arts centre claims there is more to its patron saint than matchstick men. Jonathan Jones is not convinced
fields.body:
LS Lowry told people they were nothing, and they loved him for it. He painted an industrial world in which people have been so dehumanised by the big black factories that they walk around like automatons. Yet Lowry was a popular hero who, when he died in 1977, was the most famous painter in Britain. He spent his life roaming around Salford and Manchester in his trademark trenchcoat and flat cap, said dour things about art and life and was despised by critics, though he had a champion in John Berger, who saw him as a social realist. Now he has the Lowry, a glittering new arts centre and gallery that houses the city of Salford's collection of his work.

The Lowry is a happy place. This people's palace is all vertiginous views, funky bars, a purple-walled theatre and paintings of stunted millworkers, cripples, disasters and belching smoke stacks. It is extraordinary to see Lowry's paintings here, juxtaposed with the view across the landscape he once painted; to look from a painted panorama of chimneys to the vista of Salford Quays today, surrounded by executive homes, with not a single pall of smoke in sight.

Lowry began painting before the first world war, in time off from his job as a rent collector. His famous style was developed by 1930. It was in post-war Britain, in the 60s and 70s, that he became a plain-speaking northern superstar. In the early 70s his paintings were the kind of thing everyone bought as an Athena poster. Yet since then he has more or less vanished from our national consciousness. There has been such a change in Britain since then. The mills started to vanish long before his death but in the 70s people still believed in the working class and industry and society. Lowry's paintings fetch huge prices, he has a work in Tate Britain, but you could hardly call him a popular icon. The centre has a hard task on its hands to fulfil its lottery brief by reassessing and preserving the heritage of LS Lowry.

So it is understandable that the curators should try to turn him into a "proper" artist whose legacy is more complex than we imagine. Lowry's People, the opening show at the centre, which bulks out Salford's paintings with borrowed works, attempts to show that it wasn't all matchstick men.

The exhibition is revealing, but not in the way it intends. It does not prove its case that there was more to Lowry than mills and stick figures, something it attempts by juxtaposing the famous cityscapes of the 30s and 40s with the more intimate small groups and portraits he did at the height of his fame but didn't show. Many of these were found in his house after his death, along with a bedroom entirely decorated with Rossettis. Lowry's late portraits are very bad. They lack any sense of idiosyncrasy or attention to the person painted; they have big, mad, staring eyes, are grotesque, sentimental. They belong to the world of kitsch - which is where critics always wanted to dump Lowry.

What these portraits give you is a glimpse of Lowry's psychic state, and it's not a pretty sight. His 1938 Head of a Man with Red Eyes is a self- portrait of someone slipping into despair and madness. Lowry's People reveals the opposite of what it intends, a sad inability or unwillingness to engage with others.

Lowry was a deeply shy, inept young man whose parents - people with middle-class aspirations who before the first world war were forced to move down in the world to industrial Pendlebury, near Salford - appear to have despised him. He said he was sent to art school because he was thought good for nothing else. Contemporaries there described him as "asexual". In the late 30s and 40s he shared a house with his dying mother and then lived alone. He never had an adult relationship, though when he died his executors found pornographic artworks by him. What did grip Lowry was the industrial landscape in which he grew up.

The Lowry paintings worth looking at are the ones everyone knows. There's no point trying to turn him into a well-rounded artist because he wasn't one. He was a melancholy compulsive who painted the industrial north of England through deeply disturbed eyes, and caught aspects of it no one else was prepared to look at. It is easy today to sneer at matchstick men but no one can ignore the real authority of a painting like Coming From the Mill (1930). It's a terrifying vision. The lowering buildings are so much more real than the people. Windows repeat themselves in a thudding, monotonous rhythm that is continued by the people trudging along. This is not an angry painting; it is numb. Lowry has internalised what he feels is the city's spiritual death.

Lowry painted the social world of Salford and Pendlebury systematically, illustrating how the factories produced people deprived of identity. His most disturbing images of the working-class crowd depict moments of supposed freedom and leisure: a drawing from 1925 of the bandstand in Peel Park shows people gathering like maggots around a piece of food, while above them the chimneys tower. Again and again he paints the crowd's attempts at leisure as feeble reproductions of the discipline of the factory. Going to the Match (1953) makes supporting the local football team seem a desperate ritual. One of his scathing images of a crowd trying to forget the factory is called Britain at Play (1943).

Now Britain is at play. The factories have gone, the leisure industry is all. The constrained world of Lowry's north seems to be ancient history. The Lowry is a post-industrial building that comes with its own in-built memorial to the industrial age: its collection of paintings by this massively flawed, weirdly imaginative artist.

 Lowry's People is at the Lowry, Manchester (0161-876 2020), till September 4.

webTitle: Is it a boy? Is it a girl?

fields.headline: Is it a boy? Is it a girl?
fields.trailText: Ultrasoundings
fields.body:
Week 22
'What is it?" I am asked, often by total strangers, as they examine my just-about-discernible bump. It's a disconcerting query. It took me a while, in fact, to realise they don't mean "Fibroid or alien?" but "Boy or girl?" I am commonly supposed to know, especially now I've had a scan. Not knowing, in fact, is often considered deliberately perverse. "Did you ask them not to tell you?" they enquire, tenderly, as if I were keeping the knowledge for a special treat, or preserving my faith in Santa.

I didn't. Honestly. My hospital doesn't tell you the embryo's sex on principle and I was too busy worrying about whether Baby had a brain to push an enquiry. And it seemed irrelevant anyway: Baby certainly didn't look gendered on his/her ultrasound image, in the same way that s/he didn't look young or sweet - just distantly human.

I think of tiny babies as being only distantly gendered, too, and the tutus and machine guns as emerging later, as part of a toddler's identity. But I seem to be behind the times. We may be in the era of equal education, fashionable androgyny and universal combat trousers from Gap, but little babies seem more strongly gendered than ever - or their consumer goods are. Most clothes for newborns are divided by sex: sugar pink frocks for girls, blue sailor babygros for boys. Even innocuous items such as pyjamas and nursery friezes are gendered according to the skirts or trousers of the cavorting teddies that adorn them. We seem to be going backwards: until the 19th century, all children wore the same long clothes and curls till they were five or six. Maybe they were more secure in their gender identity then. And when did teddies fall from grace and start covering their parts? I'm sure my teddy was nude, neuter and unashamed.

Some gender assumptions, of course, aren't modern at all. "It's a boy," proclaimed a woman in the butcher's, eyeing my bag of steak (full: my blood fixation continues). Then, seeing I was taken aback: "Isn't that what you want?" Lots of people ask that, too. As usual, I denied any preference. But red meat woman's counterattack was surprising: "Wouldn't your husband like a little girl, though, really?" I went home and asked him. "Maybe," he said. "Girls are easier to talk to." But then he went off into the garden to teach the cat football again, so I wasn't sure he meant it. The cat is a gifted dribbler, but he is never going to grasp offside.

I wonder if I meant my denials, either. I keep referring to the baby as "he" - maybe I do think of him as masculine. And I think I might worry less about a boy, assume he was better able to take care of himself. It might be easier to have a little distance and not presume I understood everything he was going through - after all, I've always found men emotionally inscrutable. Little boys rushing off on mysterious missions, or filled with a need to kick something, or getting obsessions with Romans or cars or dinosaurs, seem simply and pleasantly foreign to me.

Girls, though, are scary. I watched a line of 11-year-olds in the swimming pool changing rooms today, waiting for the hairdryer. The girl under the dryer had a mini-skirt and glitter eye make-up, and looked, as 11-year-olds alarmingly can, like a fashion model. The next in line had a transparent mac and pedalpushers, and was devotedly straightening her friend's fringe. The third had a tummy sticking out of a sweatshirt, poor posture and was not, you could tell, going to make it to the dryer at all.

Lolita, best friend, victim - I have all too strong an idea of what is going on in each of those little girls' heads and wouldn't want my daughter to be any of them. So I would intervene, demand confidences, insist I knew best, fail, as mothers have been doing for generations, to draw a line between her pain and my pain, her body and my body. Before I knew what was happening, I would be Aurelia Plath.

I think I'll stop there. My pregnancy book advises me to "take a little time every day to imagine life with the baby". But I don't think this sort of speculation can really be what it has in mind. After all, whatever I'm going to give birth to, it won't be a fully-made-up tweenie. Tweenies may even be passé in a decade's time and children will be allowed to play Hares and Hounds in mixed-gender groups again. Next time someone asks: "What is it?" I'll say: "A baby." Very firmly.

Even innocuous items such as pyjamas and nursery friezes are gendered according to the skirts or trousers of the cavorting teddies that adorn them. We seem to be going backwards: until the 19th century, all children wore the same long clothes and curls till they were five or six. Maybe they were more secure in their gender identity then. And when did teddies fall from grace and start covering their parts? I'm sure my teddy was nude, neuter and unashamed. Some gender assumptions, of course, aren't modern at all. "It's a boy," proclaimed a woman in the butcher's, eyeing my bag of steak (full: my blood fixation continues). Then, seeing I was taken aback: "Isn't that what you want?" Lots of people ask that, too. As usual, I denied any preference. But red meat woman's counterattack was surprising: "Wouldn't your husband like a little girl, though, really?" I went home and asked him. "Maybe," he said. "Girls are easier to talk to." But then he went off into the garden to teach the cat football again, so I wasn't sure he meant it. The cat is a gifted dribbler, but he is never going to grasp offside. I wonder if I meant my denials, either. I keep referring to the baby as "he" - maybe I do think of him as masculine. And I think I might worry less about a boy, assume he was better able to take care of himself. It might be easier to have a little distance and not presume I understood everything he was going through - after all, I've always found men emotionally inscrutable. Little boys rushing off on mysterious missions, or filled with a need to kick something, or getting obsessions with Romans or cars or dinosaurs, seem simply and pleasantly foreign to me. Girls, though, are scary. I watched a line of 11-year-olds in the swimming pool changing rooms today, waiting for the hairdryer. The girl under the dryer had a mini-skirt and glitter eye make-up, and looked, as 11-year-olds alarmingly can, like a fashion model. The next in line had a transparent mac and pedalpushers, and was devotedly straightening her friend's fringe. The third had a tummy sticking out of a sweatshirt, poor posture and was not, you could tell, going to make it to the dryer at all. Lolita, best friend, victim - I have all too strong an idea of what is going on in each of those little girls' heads and wouldn't want my daughter to be any of them. So I would intervene, demand confidences, insist I knew best, fail, as mothers have been doing for generations, to draw a line between her pain and my pain, her body and my body. Before I knew what was happening, I would be Aurelia Plath. I think I'll stop there. My pregnancy book advises me to "take a little time every day to imagine life with the baby". But I don't think this sort of speculation can really be what it has in mind. After all, whatever I'm going to give birth to, it won't be a fully-made-up tweenie. Tweenies may even be passé in a decade's time and children will be allowed to play Hares and Hounds in mixed-gender groups again. Next time someone asks: "What is it?" I'll say: "A baby." Very firmly.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... Ira Kaplan
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?
Yes - Stretch. I wanted to appear taller.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?
First to get cheaper tickets to the movies, then to be allowed into the movies without an adult, and perhaps not since.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?
Tall, happy-go-lucky, likes Count Me In by Gary Lewis and the Playboys and doesn't care who knows it.

What was the last illegal thing you did?
Subverted the system from within; turned right on red without coming to a full stop.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?
Apologized for subverting the system from within.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
Hard to choose just one. Maybe Sean, the nicest bouncer I've ever met.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?
JW

Has a critic ever made you cry?
No.

What would you advertise without a fee?
Peace, love and understanding.

What would you never advertise?
Olive loaf.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?
Yes, someone screaming at 4 in the morning wakes me up.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
Finishing questionnaires

 Yo La Tengo's UK tour begins tomorrow; they play the Royal Festival Hall, London on May 8th

fields.headline: Back from the dead
fields.trailText: Dallas Night | Arabian Nights
fields.body:
Last night I dreamed I returned to Southfork again. Nothing was changed. The bijou pool where bodies were frequently found floating. The windswept patio where Raoul and Teresa, the speechless Latino help, tried to serve food to a family arguing too ferociously to eat. The kitchenette where Miss Ellie and Bobby discussed sending another search party out for Sue Ellen. Only the people were gone, apart from tourists marvelling at the His and Hers loos in the master bedroom. Not that any Ewing ever seemed to feel the urge.

Southfork was just like the little house on the prairie except - in a gritty, new take on family life - they all hated each other. A point eerily underlined in the current production of Art, which stars not only Bobby Ewing but also John Boy Walton, proving there is life after soap. Little Lucy Ewing, for instance, is now selling toupees on TV ("They look so natural!") What a trouper.

Dallas Night on Channel 4 celebrated the time 20 years ago when Bing Crosby's daughter shot JR. At the time, Larry Hagman was in dispute with the studio about his contract. "I figured", he said, "this is the time to go for the big bucks." He figured right. As an estimated 350 million watched worldwide, he could have asked for the head of the studio on a platter. Patrick Duffy was tempted back from the dead when, as he put it, "They backed up the money truck." This amply accounts for Bobby's smile in the shower. Presumably Channel 4 did not back up the money truck far enough for Victoria Principal, who did not appear. There was more wheeling and dealing behind the cameras than in front of them. There was no mention of the time Thames TV tried, with a noise like velcro in Valhalla, to tear Dallas away from the BBC.

Steve Kanaly (Ray Krebbs) said that when Bobby died, surrounded by sobbing Ewings, "There was nobody acting." There was nobody acting a lot of the time, but most of them knew a trick worth two of that. Years ahead of Hannibal Lecter, JR seemed forever licking a last delicious drop from his lips. Cliff Barnes did a world class impression of Donald Duck. Sue Ellen's face had the quality of a pool of oil, in constant mesmeric movement. And Pamela looked spectacular standing sideways. As the director, Michael Preece said (not to put too fine a point on it or, indeed, them) "She was married to a plastic surgeon."

It hurts your heart to see they are all grey now - except, curiously, Terry Wogan, a tireless commentator on the Southfork scene. The phenomenon lives on. There is a Southfork in Romania, the pride of a theme park. Ceausescu allowed it to be shown on TV as an indictment of capitalism. This proved counter-productive. As Larry Hagman put it "They thought 'How come we don't live like that?' So they took him out and shot him." When the Yorks, plain folks from a feuding family, designed a ranch house that made you laugh, it was instantly known as Southfork.

As the city guide, ending his tour of the site of another shooting in Dallas, said, "Our country is founded on truth and justice. Hey, I hope you enjoyed it!" Hey, yourself! I sure did.

Hallmark, a company which sprang rather endearingly from greetings cards, ("Rose's are red, Violet's are blue. So, Violet, go wash your mouth out now !") specialises in inoffensive family viewing. No Hallmark programme is intimidatingly preceded by "Contains nudity and obscenity From The Start." They make shows like Gulliver's Travels, The Tenth Kingdom and this weekend's Arabian Nights (BBC 1).

Arabs invented the cliffhanger. As Sheherazade said to the Sultan (not so much a psycho, more upset in this version) when Aladdin rubbed his magic lamp, "Tomorrow night! Wait for tomorrow night!" Magic is more difficult to conjure in the home than in the orange-scented darkness of what used to be called a picture palace, where I once heard Tony Curtis say "Yondah lies da palace of my foddah, da sheikh!" And believed him. Arabian Nights was lavish entertainment, with some good actors, mostly lost in whiskers, excellent effects like the flying carpet, and sly lines woven in to amuse the adults. It also gave honest employment to half of Morocco and every living turban maker.

Hallmark now has its own channel on Sky Digital from May 1st, the pièce de resistance being Cleopatra. It is not bad, but not bad enough to be amusing.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: The youth of today... | Text messaging
fields.body:
Today's teenagers don't know they're born. At the weekend, exam authorities said that A-level maths papers are to be made more difficult, with calculator use restricted to a quarter of exams. About time - Sidelines had to sit its Higher Maths with nary abacus nor cheat sheet for help. And surely the pertinent issue is not calculus, but whether today's young people can write "BOOB" in numbers on their new-fangled technology.

 At risk of scaling the higher peaks of Luddism, we must protest at the ubiquity of text messaging. A phone is for phoning, a computer is for emailing - don't confuse the two or you'll end up one of those hopeless characters who wastes literally hours of their life footering with their super-slim handsets when they could be having genuine human interaction. Moreover, the already dying art of conversation is dealt a further body blow by the need to communicate in as reductive a form as possible - whrs the rmnc in mnml vwls? Stop it now... and don't try doing it under the table. I can see you.

fields.headline: Monte Shapiro
fields.standfirst: Putting clinical psychology at the service of the patient
fields.trailText: Monte Shapiro, who has died aged 87, made three significant contributions to the development of clinical psychology while working at the Institute of Psychiatry and Maudsley hospital under the late Hans Eysenck.
fields.body:
Monte Shapiro, who has died aged 87, made three significant contributions to the development of clinical psychology while working at the Institute of Psychiatry and Maudsley hospital under the late Hans Eysenck. In all these activities, he was adamant that clinical psychology should not merely comply ritualistically with the rules of science, but that the central focus of clinical activity was to ensure the wellbeing of the patient.

Shapiro was one of a number of gifted psychologists who emigrated to Britain from southern Africa before the second world war. After completing psychology degrees at Rhodes University, he went to Cambridge to study with Oliver Zangwill, who was to become professor of psychology.

At the outbreak of the war, Shapiro, who had joined the Communist party in the 1930s, volunteered for aircrew duties and was assigned as a navigator/bomb aimer, though he had hopeless spatial skills. He was shot down over the Netherlands in 1943 and severely injured an arm, leading to lifelong disability.

In the late 1940s, Shapiro joined the Institute of Psychiatry and Maudsley hospital, and, after Eysenck's appointment as head of the psychology department, he was invited to organise the clinical psychology training course and the provision of psychology services to the Bethlem and Maudsley hospitals. At that time, the nascent discipline of clinical psychology was confined largely to psychological testing, and the group of psychologists at the institute began work to apply scientific psychology to clinical problems. Early work included Eysenck's critical review, which undermined the contemporary claims for the effectiveness of psychotherapy. Shapiro's contributions were perhaps more subtle, but similarly long-lasting.

Convinced that psychological treatments should be based on scientific principles, Shapiro and his colleagues began to investigate the implications of Pavlov's psychology, and the work of other theorists, in a series of seminars. Members of the department also conducted experimental case analyses of clinical problems using the principles derived from theory.

The marriage of theory, and the application of experimental methods to single cases, was again apparent in Shapiro's second contribution to clinical psychology. From 1951 onwards, he published a series of papers applying an experimental method to diagnostic problems, which, in many ways, foreshadowed developments in the field of neuropsychology 25 years later.

Shapiro's third significant contribution came with the extension of single-case methods into problems where the subjective report of the patient, rather than performance on a cognitive test, was the focus of inquiry. He recognised the limitations in the available measures and devised a personal questionnaire method for scaling an individual's self-reported symptoms. The questionnaire cleverly exploited robust pair comparison methodology to provide rapid scoring and inherent reliability checks.

In the clinic, Shapiro was a man of infinite patience: tolerant, empathic and non-judgmental. To students, he was both encouraging and demanding. If an answer to a question was not apparent, one would be briefed to research the literature before the next clinical supervision. This then became the basis for an exhaustive inquiry into the validity of one's conclusions and the merits of the literature.

Shapiro left the Communist party in 1956 after Krushchev's denunciation of Stalin. He became dogmatically opposed to dogma and, at the institute, his opposition to the house line - crudely expressed as "behaviour therapy good, psychoanalysis bad" - was refreshing to many junior colleagues. He was nevertheless a man of strong convictions, which sometimes led to ruptures in working relationships and demanded tolerance from his family. He was also extraordinarily self-critical. He wrote slowly, constantly redrafting his papers, much to the chagrin of secretarial colleagues.

Shapiro was never awarded a professorship, although many believed he merited one. At a dinner to celebrate 25 years at the institute, colleagues presented him with a splendid leather chair in place of the academic position he never had.

He is survived by his wife, Jean, and their children, David and Rose.

Monte Bernard Shapiro, clinical psychologist, born May 31 1912; died April 29 2000

fields.headline: No: 1627 Jersey Royal
fields.body:
Description: New potato.

Origin: According to Jersey lore, 19th-century farmer Hugh de la Haye received the first two specimens as a mysterious gift. And didn't mention them on his tax return, I'll be bound.

Appearance: Disappearance, more like. The tasty tubers are at the centre of a shocking new crime on the island enclave of the super-rich.

Somebody cooking the books? Perhaps uniquely for this outcrop of fiscal laxity, the crime isn't tax-related. Jersey Royals have been vanishing suspiciously.

Crikey! Sounds like a case for... Exactly - everybody's favourite 1980s investigator of Channel Island-based wrongdoing, Detective Sergeant James "Jim" Bergerac.

A bit of a comedown, surely? Bergerac's nemesis, the jewel thief Philippa Vale, has been lying low for 10 years, and out-of-work detectives can't be choosers. "I'm here to inspire potato producers to be extra vigilant and to form patrols to deter potato poachers," says the hardman's alter ego, John Nettles.

I bet I know who's behind these Smash and grabs: Not Jersey kingpin Charlie Hungerford?

The very same: Maybe, but the island's 90 commercial growers have other ideas. "Sometimes local people take their dogs for a walk and pick as many potatoes as they can carry while they're at it," says farmer Michael Labey.

Hardly the Brinks Mat robbery: Enough cynicism. Jersey's economy relies on exports of the £32m annual crop - with competition from Egypt and Cornwall, growers are feeling the pinch.

Any leads? Labey has an inkling of the thieves' MO. "They often wait until dusk before parking their cars and taking the potatoes," he notes.

Not to be confused with: Royal Jerseys (the queen's herd of cows); Jersey Royale (breed of tomato).

Do say: "We're on to your game, Hungerford, but owing to your centrality to the plot of every single episode of Bergerac, we've decided to take no further action."

Don't say: "Book him, Pettit! This bailiwick ain't big enough for the both of us!"

fields.headline: And so to bed
fields.standfirst: It's been a lovely evening. Your companion was charming, the wine and conversation flowed. But now it's all over... or is it?  Caroline Sullivan considers that first date dilemma
fields.trailText: It's been a lovely evening. Your companion was charming, the wine and conversation flowed. But now it's all over... or is it?  Caroline Sullivan considers that first date dilemma
fields.body:
Tonight you're mine completely/You give your love so sweetly/Tonight the light of love is in your eyes/But will you love me tomorrow? So sang the Shirelles in 1961, voicing one of the classic female dilemmas. Should you have sex on the first date? And if you do, will he respect you afterwards? Or, as Shirley put it: "Will my heart be broken when the night meets the morning sun?"

What absurdly antediluvian worries, you may be thinking. Of course you should sleep with him, if you want to. Of course he'll respect you because modern men are comfortable with female self-determination. Haven't the last few years taught him that, for women, sex no longer necessarily equals that supposed ultimate male terror, commitment? With magazines like Company boasting such lyrical headlines as "Come like a train - whenever you want" it must be obvious to him that a woman is as capable as a man of detaching herself emotionally from the act, placing her own gratification ahead of such abstractions as who respects whom.

Except that, as we all know, these brave-new-world fantasies exist only in the pages of magazines like Company. Women still agonise over whether doing it on the first date means goodbye to any chance of a relationship, while men still tend to think less of girls who put out. And almost four decades of feminism has done little to alter the imbalance. A new book by Prozac Nation author Elizabeth Wurtzel makes a stab at pretending things have changed. "It doesn't matter when you sleep with someone for the first time," The Bitch Rules argues - but in real life we haven't progressed all that far since the Shirelles asked: "Can I believe the magic of your sighs?"

Even The Bitch Rules (a riposte to bestselling dating manual The Rules, which advocated a return to traditional femininity) concedes "often women become more needy and insecure" after crossing the great divide that is sex with a new partner. That's because, even if one's primary goal is to come like a train, there is usually some emotional investment, since female brains are hardwired to crave permanence. No amount of ladette braggadocio can change that. Even my friend Holly, who has slept with "around 60" blokes and claims she often uses them just for sex, says: "I can just shag someone and feel OK about it, but I do desperately want a relationship."

The way to a relationship, it seems, is to do what The Rules suggests: wait. For weeks, if not months. Wait till the second date, at the very least. Unless a man is Peter Stringfellow (more of whom later), he will almost certainly be unimpressed by a woman who is too willing too early. That's the advice from both 31-year- old Robert, who has had 35 partners, and Mark, 33, who has had just four. Robert says: "If I liked a girl and wanted to establish a relationship, I would rather go for the thrill of the chase. If I were drunk or on one, I'd have sex on a first date, but I probably wouldn't call her again and I wouldn't want her to call me."

Mark, meanwhile, trots out the age-old refrain: "If a girl will sleep with you on the first night, you wonder if she does it with everyone."

At this point, we should establish the difference between a date - which is pre-arranged and usually involves expectations of getting to know someone better - and tumbling into bed in a vodka stupor with someone you met two hours ago at a party. Women are becoming more aggressive in the latter category - they're often the ones doing the asking, emboldened by the examples set by celebrity ladettes. This is where women's magazines have actually had a hand in shaping the zeitgeist. Holly says: "Women don't feel so guilty now about uncomplicated sex and magazines have helped them feel like that. They write about sex because it sells, but the message about taking control of your sex life does get through."

Jo Elvin, editor of New Woman (whose current issue includes the feature It's Sex Week: Seven Reasons To Say Yes... Yes... Yes... Yes... Yes... Yes... Yes...) is pleased to hear it. "Our readers do have sexual confidence. They meet men and think: 'He's nice, but he's not the one.' But they don't want to miss having a good time, so sex is less complicated."

Almost as an afterthought, she adds: "But they also want to meet The One. We run a lot of stories on commitment and babies."

Women these days fairly brim with sexual confidence, if by "confidence" we mean initiating contact and asking men out. Once past 30, especially, you are less likely to jump through hoops just to impress the opposite sex. As Robert says: "Older women know what they want, which is very sexy."

But despite the impression of liberation and empowerment, sex is rarely as uncomplicated for women as Elvin suggests. Barring drunken one-night stands, they don't often enter a sexual relationship without at least some emotional involvement. Entering it on the first date creates a premature intimacy, according to Emma Harvey, a 37-year-old journalist: "You take your clothes off in front of someone and you make yourself emotionally vulnerable." Withholding sex early in a relationship, as we all know, is instant empowerment, but once the line has been crossed, "all your anxieties about yourself kick in".

Most of Harvey's recent dates have been through small ads, she says. She slept with one after their second meeting and they had arranged to meet again, but he never rang and didn't return her calls. "You've been physically intimate with someone, so you're upset if you don't see them again," she comments, adding that she might have felt less angry about his rudeness if they hadn't had sex.

Oops, there we go again, silly hormonal women emotionalising attraction. Can't we just approach sex as men do, as a bodily function to be savoured, with or without the complications of a relationship? Well, it depends on whether we want it to retain some meaning or just be added to our repertoire of stunts, along the lines of Ulrika Jonsson's party trick of drinking a pint of beer in seven seconds.

"The longest I've ever waited was two dates," he claims. "If I want to have sex in the first place, I'll want to have sex again. If it's romantic and pleasant and you go to each other's apartment rather than ripping your clothes off in a car, there's nothing crude about doing it on the first date. I'll want to see her again."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Remand on kidnap charge
fields.body:
Remand on kidnap charge

A man appeared in court yesterday charged with the kidnap of a mother and her two children from their home.

Peter Robert Hughes, 58, of no fixed address, is accused of robbery, kidnapping and possessing an imitation firearm after an incident in Horsforth, Leeds, last Wednesday. He was remanded in custody until May 9.

Union boost for dome

The Millennium Dome had its busiest day yet yesterday when thousands of trade unionists and their families swelled the attendance. Unions launched a series of campaigns to mark May Day.

Unofficial estimates put the attendance figure at around 35,000.

Shakespeare marathon

A group of 40 Leicester university students yesterday set off on a five-day marathon to recite all 38 of Shakespeare's plays non-stop.

Rally round the world

The first around-the-world rally set off from London's Tower Bridge yesterday in front of thousands of spectators.

Ex-racing driver Stirling Moss flagged off 95 veteran, vintage and classic cars. The drivers will be hoping to go around the world in 80 days.

Car security cover blown

Half the 18 mechanical car immobilisers examined in a security test took experts less than three minutes 20 seconds to overcome, according to a What Car? report.

Stowaways arrested

Seven Kosovans were arrested yesterday after a lorry driver tipped off police.

The Dutch driver used a mobile phone to call ahead to a West Sussex farm where he was due to make a delivery. Five men and two women, all from Kosovo, were arrested.

fields.headline: Phillip Katz
fields.trailText: Phillip Katz, who has died aged 37, in a Milwaukee motel room of complications from alcholism, was the creator of one of the internet's most popular programs, PK Zip.
fields.body:
Phillip Katz, who has died aged 37, in a Milwaukee motel room of complications from alcholism, was the creator of one of the internet's most popular programs, PK Zip.

Almost all the programs on the internet have been compressed into zip files, the format Katz developed and made popular though the Phil Katz Zip program. PKZip allows software publishers to package many different programs into one file, which is easier for users to download. It uses sophisticated algorithms to compress the zip file and make it smaller, saving users countless hours of telephone time.

Katz studied computer science at the University of Milwaukee-Wisconsin (UMW), where he used many archiving programs that worked like PKZip. His first version, released in 1986, was called PK Pak, a name that chimed well with the local American football team, the Green Bay Packers. However, a rival company objected to his use of their .arc extension, with which Katz's program was compatible.

In 1989, Katz produced a new version, using the .zip format, and the program's popularity exploded. This was partly because other computer users supported him (they were furious about the lawsuit), partly because his program was faster, and partly because it was available free. Under the shareware system, you only sent Katz a fee if you liked the program and decided to keep using it. So many people liked Katz's programs that his mother gave up her teaching post to help process orders.

The kitchen-table operation grew into PKWare Inc, a privately-held software publisher based in Brown Deer, Wisconsin, employing more than 20 people. In an interview in 1993, Katz said: "It was just a hobby. I didn't expect it to turn into a business."

According to Professor Leonard Levine, of the UWM computer science department, Katz "would appear at local computer societies and talk about his concepts. People understood that he was important, but he wasn't a smooth talker. He just wasn't a chummy kind of guy." However, at some point during the 1990s, Levine said, Katz "just disappeared."

In 1997, the Milwaukee Sentinel reported that his neighbours had "complained about odours, insects and mice" at his luxury condominium, where the city authorities later found knee- deep garbage and decaying food. Katz's lawyers paid the city of Mequon about $8,000 for the cost of cleanup and legal fees.

Katz's death, surrounded by empty liquor bottles, was a sad end for the man Levine summed up as "a quiet hero". He is survived by his mother and sister.

Phillip Katz, computer programmer, born November 3 1962; died April 14 2000

fields.headline: Jails watchdog may lose bite
fields.standfirst: 'Rambo' faces axe after clashes with Straw
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is considering abolishing the job of chief inspector of prisons, under a plan which would see the watchdog role merged with that of overseeing the probation service in a new job of chief inspector of corrections.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is considering abolishing the job of chief inspector of prisons, under a plan which would see the watchdog role merged with that of overseeing the probation service in a new job of chief inspector of corrections.

The present chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham - a former army general nicknamed "Rambo" - has repeatedly clashed with Mr Straw over criminal justice policy in general, and in particular over Sir David's call for the early release of the boys who killed the toddler James Bulger.

Fears have already been raised that Sir David's role as an independent watchdog will be curbed as a result of a merger with the probation inspectorate. He has proved a thorn in the side of prisons policy ever since he led an inspectors' walkout of Holloway prison because it was filthy and infested with rats.

Sir David's five-year term expires in November and it is understood that he has been asked whether he wishes to continue. The Home Office has already drawn up plans for a much closer working relationship between the prisons and the probation service, although a recent internal review rejected a merger option.

Home Office sources have stressed that the Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, is now responsible for the prisons and probation service and that the drive for more "joined up government" could mean a more effective scrutiny is provided by a merged inspectorate, but they stress that no decisions have yet been taken. They insist that ministers have no plans to change the legal role of chief inspector, which was last defined in 1952.

Sir David was expected to take a low-key approach when he was appointed by the then home secretary, Michael Howard, in 1995.

But a series of reports has proved him critical of prison conditions, even if he has shown himself more interested in internal bureaucratic structures than his predecessor, Sir Stephen Tumim, a former circuit court judge.

It is believed that Mr Straw has not made any final decision over the future role of the chief inspector of prisons. But ministers were infuriated when Sir David proved unable to produce evidence to substantiate a claim he made in front of MPs that there were at least 10 drug barons in every prison.

Prison service chiefs have since directly challenged some of the claims in his inspection reports, including allegations of brutality at Wandsworth prison in south London.

The chief inspector of probation, Sir Graham Smith, is believed to be opposed to the move on the grounds that the two fields need different areas of expertise, and the plan has already been criticised in the House of Lords.

Peers claimed a new title of "chief inspector of corrections" would be appalling and suggested that the independent watchdog has played a vital role in pressing the need for prison reform.

Home Office ministers have recently praised Sir David's record, saying that his good reports on Pentonville, Werrington, Ashwell, Brockhill and Feltham prisons have outweighed his critical reports in recent months on Dorchester, Rochester and Portland jails.

fields.headline: Neal Matthews
fields.standfirst: The man who made the 'aaah' for Elvis
fields.trailText: As a member of the Jordanaires vocal group, Neal Matthews, who has died aged 70, created the vocal arrangements for such Elvis Presley hits as Hound Dog and Don't Be Cruel. The group itself made a major contribution to the sound of country music in the 1960s.
fields.body:
As a member of the Jordanaires vocal group, Neal Matthews, who has died aged 70, created the vocal arrangements for such Elvis Presley hits as Hound Dog and Don't Be Cruel. The group itself made a major contribution to the sound of country music in the 1960s.

Matthews was born in Nashville, Tennessee. He learned to play guitar as a teenager and sang gospel harmonies with his father. In the 1940s, they appeared together as part of the Crook Brothers group on the Grand Ole Opry, Nashville's premier country-music radio show. After serving in the US army during the Korean war, Matt- hews returned home to study psychology at Belmont College, Nashville.

He was invited to join the Jordanaires, led by Gordon Stoker, in 1953. The group had developed a modern sound based on barbershop-style close harmonies, and had already made a name for itself by supporting Red Foley on his 1950 million-seller, Just A Closer Walk With Thee. Matthews became second tenor to Stoker's lead tenor, with the other parts taken by Hoyt Hawkins (baritone) and Culley Holt (bass).

The Jordanaires became regulars on Eddy Arnold's television programme, the first country-music show to be networked across America. They toured with Arnold and, in 1954, appeared at the Memphis Cotton Carnival, where the teenage Elvis Presley was among the audience. Two years later, Stoker was in the RCA recording studio as a backing singer on Elvis's recording of Heartbreak Hotel.

The full Jordanaires line-up first featured on a Presley recording in 1956, when Matthews made on-the-spot arrangements for Don't Be Cruel and Hound Dog. For the latter, the group provided hand-clapping, as well as the "aaah" sounds that framed Scotty Moore's guitar solos. The song was recorded 31 times before Presley was satisfied he had the perfect version. After the session, he told the Jordanaires: "If any of these songs goes big, I want you to record all my stuff with me".

Both songs were massive hits and subsequently the Jordanaires appeared on numerous Elvis Presley recordings, including the sound- tracks of almost all the 28 films in which he starred. Perhaps the apex of their collaboration was the 1960 religious album, His Hand In Mine. For this, Matthews created a series of arrangements for such hymns as Joshua Fit The Battle and Swing Low Sweet Chariot.

The Jordanaires also appeared live with Presley, and on occasions the group - as well as the fans - would become so engrossed with Elvis's performance that they would forget to come in on cue. When that happened, Gordon Stoker recalled, "he'd turn around and give us the lip".

In addition to their work with Elvis, the quartet was in constant demand for recording sessions arranged by the top Nashville producers Chet Atkins and Owen Bradley. Their sweet, at times sickly, harmonies contributed to a new country-pop music, epitomised by such singers as Jim Reeves, Faron Young and Patsy Cline - the Jordanaires sang on her famous recording, I Fall To Pieces. Outside country music, they made albums with Julie Andrews and Steve Lawrence.

The Jordanaires also made their own recordings. Sugaree was a minor hit in 1956, while their 1964 album with Tennessee Ernie Ford, Great Gospel Songs, won a Grammy award as best gospel album. When Presley died in 1977, the Jordanaires contributed to the tribute album, My Farewell to Elvis: From Graceland To the Promised Land, recorded by Merle Haggard, and later made their own recording of Elvis's Favourite Spirituals. They even graced the records and shows of Elvis imperson- ators, while Matthews himself wrote a memoir, Elvis: A Golden Tribute, that was published in 1985.

The group continued to record and tour, and in the 1990s were much in demand. A stroke forced Matthews to retire in 1995, but he had planned to return to touring later this year. He is survived by his wife, Charlsie.

fields.headline: Jaroslav Ondra
fields.trailText: Though Czech Protestants are few in number, their influence has never been absent from national life. After the second world war, that tradition found a voice in Josef Hromadka, a theologian who had returned to Prague from American exile. But it was Jaroslav Ondra, a pastor in the Church of the Czech Brethren, who has died aged 75, who had the organisational skills to give shape to Hromadka's ideals.
fields.body:
Though Czech Protestants are few in number, their influence has never been absent from national life. After the second world war, that tradition found a voice in Josef Hromadka, a theologian who had returned to Prague from American exile. But it was Jaroslav Ondra, a pastor in the Church of the Czech Brethren, who has died aged 75, who had the organisational skills to give shape to Hromadka's ideals.

In Discretion And Valour, his study of Christianity in communist-ruled eastern Europe, Trevor Beeson records that with "a mixture of prophetic vision and naivete - and more than a pinch of Quixotic foolhardiness, Hromadka and his friends founded a movement to be known as the Christian Peace Conference (CPC). Its terms of reference and its style would be East European, but the movement would be open to all Christians who were prepared to work for the ending of the cold war and for justice and peace."

In 1959, Ondra became the CPC's general secretary. Discretion, charm and diplomatic skill were his assets. Genuine east-west dialogue was Hromadka's dream and Ondra's objective. But with the KGB at their elbow, could this venture succeed in a country with hardly any religious freedom?

Under pressure - and when he felt the organisation was at risk - Ondra's line was more concilatory to the regime than that of his idealistic mentor, but he helped make the venture work. The 1968 Prague Spring seemed to be a fulfilment of Hromadka's vision. But the Soviet pressures remained relentless - even before the August invasion - and Ondra flew to London to tell me that the Russian Orthodox church (the main CPC paymasters) had threatened to withdraw their support if he did not remove me from the executive on account of my allegedly anti-Soviet influence - my insistence on raising human rights issues. I resigned to save Ondra's position.

Opocensky and Lochman both built theological careers in the west. Though some people of integrity tried to rebuild it, the CPC's credibility had gone. Unemployed, Ondra began to study law. No hero by nature, he did not join the open opposition of Charter 77. In many ways, he reflected the brokenness of most Czech people but remained a charming and affable host. Eventually, he received permission to teach ecumenical theology in the seminary of his church.

It was a tough assignment for, despite his treatment at communist hands, he was identified in the minds of many of his students with a policy of appeasement which they could not understand. It is not uncommon for the diplomat, the reconciler, to be rejected by both sides when attitudes harden.

After the peaceful revolution of 1990, those who had been silenced for so long became the muted voices of today's church, but Ondra's health was beginning to fail. Free to travel, he enjoyed visiting friends in the west, and was still the good company he always had been.

With advancing Alzheimer's, his last years were spent in a home. He is survived by his wife Vera and their son.

fields.headline: Toddler drowns in river
fields.trailText: A two-year-old boy died yesterday when he fell into a fast flowing river in Lancashire. His body was found on a mudbank after an extensive search by the Liverpool and Fleetwood coastguard, a lifeboat, holidaymakers and a police helicopter.
fields.body:
A two-year-old boy died yesterday when he fell into a fast flowing river in Lancashire. His body was found on a mudbank after an extensive search by the Liverpool and Fleetwood coastguard, a lifeboat, holidaymakers and a police helicopter.

He had been staying with relatives at the River Wyre caravan park at Thornton, near Fleetwood. The alarm was raised at lunchtime by his grandfather and the body was found less than two hours later.

Detective Inspector Stuart Williams, of Lancashire police, said: "Everyone had tried their best to rescue the boy. We received a call from someone to say that their grandson was missing. A search was immediately initiated.

"The river was fast flowing and the tide was quite high at midday. Once the tide began to recede a police officer saw the child's body lying on a bank in the mud in the centre of the river about a quarter of a mile downstream from the caravan park."

The boy, who has not been named, was taken to the Victoria hospital in Blackpool.

Ged Lynch, watch manager for the Liverpool coastguard said: "Sadly, despite a frantic search involving dozens of rescuers, from Shard Bridge seawards, the body of a two-year-old child was located on the banks of the river at 1.50pm."

The caravan park was closed off by police yesterday afternoon.

Colin Gaw, the manager, said: "We have been very busy because of the hot weather. A lot of people helped join in the search. It has cast a shadow over a beautiful bank holiday."

Elsewhere, the bank holiday brought sunshine and warm temperatures. A Met Office spokesman said the highest temperatures were in Bristol, Cardiff and the west country. However, there were pockets of cloud in the south east and on the east coast. The RAC said there were no major problems on the roads. But a carnival at Ecchinswell, Hampshire, ended in chaos when a horse pulling a cart in a parade bolted into the crowd and trampled spectators. At least four people were badly hurt and many others received cuts and bruises.

webTitle: Vorderman strikes it rich for charity

fields.headline: Vorderman strikes it rich for charity
fields.trailText: Carol Vorderman won the battle of the screen savantes last night when she beat fellow television intellectual Kirsty Young in the first celebrity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
fields.body:
Carol Vorderman won the battle of the screen savantes last night when she beat fellow television intellectual Kirsty Young in the first celebrity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

With phone-a-friend help from the keeper of the Countdown puns, Richard Whiteley, Vorderman made an impressive total of £125,000 for charity before passing on a Shakespearean poser.

Vorderman later excused her literary lacuna by claiming not to read the bard. She failed to identify Twelfth Night as the play which features Sir Toby Belch.

Young clocked up £64,000 before a gap in her film knowledge let her down. When asked to name John Wayne's last movie, she could not pick out The Shootist from the choice of four outlined by the Millionaire host, Chris Tarrant. "It was a totally nerve-racking experience and I'm glad it's over," she said last night.

The computer firm Tiny matched Vorderman's winnings, bringing the total raised for her nominated charity, Express Link Up, which puts computers into children's hospital wards, to £250,000. Young's £64,000 - achieved with assistance from smooth-talking BBC sports presenter, John Inverdale - will go to Centrepoint, a charity for the homeless.

Prize money for the quiz show is usually funded by premium rate phone lines, but the charity money will be donated by ITV, which screened the show as part of its Day of Promise campaign yesterday.

The rules were the same as for the regular version. The celebrities had three lifelines, and one wrong answer could have spelled humiliation.

fields.headline: Pay deals fuel inflation worries
fields.trailText: Bank of England concerns about the size of recent pay deals is likely to be reignited today by news that the average settlement in April reached 3%.
fields.body:
Bank of England concerns about the size of recent pay deals is likely to be reignited today by news that the average settlement in April reached 3%.

Threadneedle Street is watching the labour market closely for signs that falling unemployment is causing wage inflation which could spill over into price pressures throughout the economy.

Basic pay awards in April averaged 3%, a rise of a half a percentage point on the March figures, according to pay analyst Industrial Relations Services.

However, pay experts said the Bank was to blame for the increase in settlements in April. Headline inflation is rising as a result of the Bank's four increases in interest rates since September which have pushed up housing costs and that in turn is pushing up wage claims.

"The upturn in the annual inflation rate since the beginning of the year is starting to have an impact on pay awards," said Alastair Hatchett of Incomes Data Services.

"Most pay talks over the winter months were conducted against the background of a lower inflation rate, and the higher inflation rate, combined with a tight labour market in many areas, has only recently begun to have an effect on pay decisions."

While the Bank's target measure of inflation, which excludes housing costs, is at record lows, headline inflation jumped to 2.6% in March.

However, fierce competition makes it likely companies will resist higher pay deals, according to Industrial Relations Services. "The strong competitive pressures on employers to keep a lid on [payroll] costs are likely to have a moderating effect on future pay claims," said Jeremy Baugh, editor of IRS's Pay and Benefits Bulletin. "This suggests that pay deals are unlikely to breach the 3% mark in coming months."

The April figures were also boosted by above-inflation deals for many public sector workers. Nurses, doctors and teachers were awarded rises above the 3% mark.

The Bank's rate-setting committee meets this week and most City economists expect a further quarter-point increase in borrowing costs despite official data last week showing that the economy slowed.

webTitle: Israeli spy suspect owns up, says Iran

fields.headline: Israeli spy suspect owns up, says Iran
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Iran disclosed its evidence against 13 Jews accused of spying for Israel for the first time yesterday, saying that the prime suspect confessed to being a trained Israeli agent, and that he worked with a network of accomplices.
fields.body:
Iran disclosed its evidence against 13 Jews accused of spying for Israel for the first time yesterday, saying that the prime suspect confessed to being a trained Israeli agent, and that he worked with a network of accomplices.

The detailed information and the confession, revealed in the southern city of Shiraz where a second closed-door hearing in the case took place, cast serious doubts on the claims by many western governments that the case is based on trumped-up charges.

The Shiraz judiciary chief, Hossein Ali Amiri, said Hamid "Danny" Tefileen had confessed to passing classified information to the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service, and had asked for a pardon.

"Tefileen has confessed to relations with the Mossad, to being trained in Israel, to being on the [Mossad] payroll and to giving classified information to the Mossad," Mr Amiri told reporters after the hearing. "Tefileen said they were acting as a team, not individually."

Esmail Nasseri, the lead defence lawyer, reiterated remarks he had made after the first hearing on April 13, saying the guilt or innocence of his clients depended on the definition of espionage in Iranian law. He said the acts committed by his clients did not meet the legal standard for spying because the information passed on was unclassified.

Already, members of the Jewish community in Shiraz were distancing themselves from Mr Tefileen yesterday, claiming that he was involved in crimes before his arrest, including selling alcohol, which is illegal in Iran.

From the time Iran announced a year ago that 13 Jews and eight Muslims had been arrested and charged with spying for Israel, the case has preoccupied the outside world. Western governments, pressured by powerful Jewish groups abroad, demanded that Iran release the suspects.

Iran never disclosed the details to substantiate the charges, making the Islamic Republic vulnerable to accusations that the case was bogus. The question asked by the suspects' defenders was: How could a rabbi, shopkeepers, Hebrew teachers, and even a teenager have access to information concerning Iran's national security?

"This argument that because the suspects have innocent professions, they could never have committed this crime, misses the point," said a well-placed western analyst in Tehran. "It comes down to how you define what is considered a national security issue."

But judiciary officials are deeply concerned about how the outside world views the case. During yesterday's hearing, a representative from the New York-based Human Rights Watch was allowed to speak with the judge presiding over the Revolutionary Court. In the past Iran has generally refused visas to western human rights monitors.

After her meeting, Elahe Hicks said Judge Sadeq Nourani assured her that he intended to render a ruling based solely on the evidence, and that he would ignore domestic and international pressure.

webTitle: Prime farmland to be made wilderness

fields.headline: Prime farmland to be made wilderness
fields.standfirst:
National Trust plans to restore fenland glory in East Anglia with wetland reserve to ensure survival of rich but threatened wildlife

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The National Trust is planning to buy and flood 14 square miles of top grade farmland in one of the most ambitious wildlife projects undertaken in Britain.
fields.body:
The National Trust is planning to buy and flood 14 square miles of top grade farmland in one of the most ambitious wildlife projects undertaken in Britain.

The move would secure the survival of hundreds of threatened plants and animals by transforming bleak and intensively cultivated fenland into a vast wetland nature reserve twice the size of the trust's recent Snowdon purchase.

Habitat recreation on such a scale has never before been attempted in England, according to the trust, and would have to be a gradual affair since the farmland involved is among the richest and most expensive in Britain.

The move, which marks a radical policy shift, must be confirmed by the trust's executive. It will consider the issue when it meets in June.

The heart of the scheme is Wicken Fen which supports more wildlife in a small area than nearly anywhere else in Britain. Occupying 800 acres, it is a tiny fragment of the vast fen wilderness that once occupied much of East Anglia.

The problem is that despite its richness, it is a jewel in a barren landscape and species are gradually being lost. The plan is to reverse that process.

Most of the land round Wicken is below sea level and prone to flooding, making it sparsely populated. Farming is viable only with constant pumping. When the pumps are turned off centuries of drainage will be reversed and Wicken's reedbeds and grazing marshes will be extended six miles to the outskirts of Cambridge.

Established a century ago, Wicken is the country's oldest national nature reserve, and has served as an outdoor laboratory for generations of Cambridge scientists. In the early 19th century a young Charles Darwin was drawn to the area, fascinated by its 1,000 different beetles.

Insects are present in exceptional variety: 212 species of spider, 1,000 moths, and 1,700 flies, many unknown anywhere else. Other rare species include marsh harriers, hen harriers, otters, and threatened wildflowers such as fen violet and milk parsley.

Species have been disappearing from Wicken for decades despite maximum protection under British and EU law. Losses include five out of 19 dragonflies, four beetles, water vole, Montagu's harrier, marsh warbler, short-eared owl, and 35 flowering plants. A fifth beetle - the twin-spot longhorn - is under threat.

Adrian Colston, the reserve's manager, said that although Wicken is the third biggest reserve in Cambridgeshire, it suffers as an island in a sea of hostile farmland and is too small to protect wildlife effectively.

"The average nature reserve in this area is 35 acres but that's hopelessly small," he said. "If a cow dungs in the wrong place or someone treads on the wrong spot, that can wipe out a vulnerable species."

He predicted the return of many vanished creatures to a bigger reserve and said greater populations of species would be much less vulnerable to drought, bad weather or other mishap. A network of nature trails and cycleways would be a key feature. Martin Drury, director general of the National Trust, said: "It's a visionary scheme consistent with the trust's wonderfully simple purpose: acquiring and holding places for people."

fields.bylineHtml: Jonathan Theobald and Paul Brown

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Today may very well be the 500th-day anniversary (then again, it may not: who has time to check?) since my old friend Mandy Mandelson's sacking - "resignation", to indulge in crude satire - by Mr Tony Blair. This seems a fitting time, then, to review one of political history's more intriguing paradoxes. Had Mandy's act of ultra-secret naughtiness not been discovered, among the consequences of his continuing as trade secretary (apart from Rupert Murdoch being permitted to buy Manchester United), Mandy would have had to take responsibility for the Dome, instead of somehow (and hats off for this miracle) escaping without any apparent shred of the blame for this unmitigated calamity. He would also still be in charge of Rover. In other words, he would be twice as finished as poor little Byers is now. Instead, Mandy is a year away from winning the Foreign Office. To put it in a nutshell, then - and is this unique? - the disgrace everyone assumed had ended his career saved it. Amazing. A very happy 500th-day anniversary, Mandy! (Or not.)

The fine print of Gordon Brown's budget continues to impress the fiscal experts, not least west country accountants Baker Tilly who have discovered an intriguing anomaly. Female employees given rape alarms as a company perk will have to pay tax on an item considered an essential accessory for women working in urban or unsafe areas, or who travel extensively in their jobs, but not on mobile phones. Tax must be paid on stress counselling. Very odd.

And so to inaugural web site of the month, www.ruthgledhill.com, and to the section entitled "freelance articles" where we find news of the Times's religion correspondent's 16th birthday ... "a riotous night out at a local further education college, surrounded by lots of dishy 18-year-old boys." The late Basil Rathbone's cousin reveals that "I wore my mother's 'coming out' dress from the 1950s. It still sparkled with blue and silver, and I barely noticed that the whalebones in the corset dug into my ribs. But this dress, which perhaps looked a little out of place among the flared trousers, midi skirts and hot pants, was designed for waltzing not rock-and-roll. As I span around in the French 'ceroc' we had learned on a school twinning trip ... ", wait for it, "... the corset collapsed and two of my newly burgeoning assets were totally exposed, to the ribald hilarity of all." Blimey.

With apologies to all who find the whole mayoral business boring beyond words (and few of us could manage a single more "London will be laughing on the other side of its face when joker Ken wins" article), I have reluctantly agreed to read Frank Dobson's new book Oooh, You Won't Believe What His Nibs Did To Me! (Bargain Basement Books, £2.99) with a view to serialisation. "It's not that I've written a book or owt, you understand," said Frank when he rang last night. "But if I had, which I haven't, and if that slimy little shit didn't bring me back into cabinet, which he will .... well, not that there's a manuscript, of course, but if there was could I send it over now on the old menstrual." On the what, Frank? "The menstrual cycle! The motor bike! Just my little joke. Oooh, please yourself!" The manuscript has arrived, and we may start dipping into it soon.

fields.headline: Mayan mob kills two 'baby stealers'
fields.trailText: A Japanese tourist and a Guatemalan bus driver were killed in a rural Indian market after being attacked by a mob of about 500 angry villagers who thought the victims were there to steal children.
fields.body:
A Japanese tourist and a Guatemalan bus driver were killed in a rural Indian market after being attacked by a mob of about 500 angry villagers who thought the victims were there to steal children.

Tetsuo Yamahiro, 40, was killed when he and 22 other Japanese tourists were attacked with stones and sticks by a mob while visiting a popular Mayan market on Saturday in the highland village of Todos Santos Cuchumatan, police spokesman Faustino Sanchez said.

Edgar Castellanos, a Guatemalan tour-bus driver whose body was doused in gasoline and partially burned, was also killed during the attack in the town about 90 miles north-west of the Guatemala City.

"The tourists were taking pictures of women and children in the market when someone started to scream that they were stealing children and a crowd of 500 villagers quickly closed in around them," Mr Sanchez said.

Local police rushed to the market and fired teargas to disperse the crowd. Two police officers and two more Japanese tourists were injured, but not seriously. Police are investigating the incident and arrest warrants have been issued.

There have been persistent rumours in some Mayan communities that foreigners come to steal children in order to sell them or their body parts abroad, although no cases have been documented.

In 1994 an American journalist, June Weinstock, was attacked and severely beaten by hundreds of angry peasants who thought she was trying to steal a baby in the remote village of San Cristobal Verapaz. And in 1997, a Guatemalan woman suspected of trying to snatch a baby died after a crowd of villagers dragged her and another women from jail and beat them savagely.

Mob lynching is not uncommon in Guatemala, where a legacy of violence remains from a 36-year civil war that ended in 1996 and killed 200,000 people. At least 71 people, mostly suspected criminals, were killed by mobs in peasant villages in 1999.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
War deaths of reporters rise
Armed conflict claimed the lives of 36 reporters in 1999, doubling the previous year's total, Reporters Without Borders said.
fields.body:
War deaths of reporters rise
Armed conflict claimed the lives of 36 reporters in 1999, doubling the previous year's total, Reporters Without Borders said.

The Paris-based group said there were an estimated 100 journalists currently jailed for speaking out against governments. More than 200 had been detained at some point during the year. Journalists were detained in the Middle East, hunted by armed guerrillas in Colombia and jailed in Burma, it said. [Reuters, Paris]

Legionnaires' hits Australia
An outbreak of legionnaires' disease is likely to be Australia's worst, as the number of infections climbed to 37, a Victoria state official said yesterday.

The outbreak was blamed on Melbourne's new £12m aquarium, visited last month by almost all the victims. The prime minister, John Howard, and his wife visited in April but neither is showing symptoms. [AP, Melbourne]

Dig begins for two US MIAs
US and South Korean officials will begin digging at the site of a Seoul hospital tomorrow to retrieve remains of what are thought to be two US soldiers killed in the 1950-53 Korean war.

A Korean defence ministry spokesman said workers found the remains in 1990 and reburied them. Some 8,100 US soldiers are listed as missing from the war. [Reuters, Seoul]

Parents kill girl for low marks
An eight-year old girl died in northern Iran after being poisoned by her parents for getting bad school marks, the official news agency reported yesterday.

Abbas Rajabalizadeh and his wife confessed to forcing their daughter to drink a glass of weed-killer because "they wanted to save her from becoming a burden on society", the agency said. [AP, Tehran]

Harare protest boosts morale
More than 3,000 supporters of the Movement for Democratic Change ignored security fears and gathered in Harare yesterday to protest against Zimbabwe president Robert Mugabe's government and to encourage voters not to be intimidated by rising political violence. [Reuters, Harare]
