webTitle: China sends out long May Day to boost economy

fields.headline: China sends out long May Day to boost economy
fields.standfirst: NetNotes: Everything you need to know about May Day on the net
fields.trailText: China yesterday began a week-long holiday aimed at getting its sluggish economy going again.The traditional May Day break has been extended to seven days in a desperate attempt to break a three year deflationary spiral that has sent unemployment soaring.
fields.body:
China yesterday began a week-long holiday aimed at getting its sluggish economy going again.The traditional May Day break has been extended to seven days in a desperate attempt to break a three year deflationary spiral that has sent unemployment soaring.

More than 10m Chinese are expected to flock to beaches and remote areas such as Tibet, as well as recently-built theme parks and holiday resorts.

Beijing is struggling to boost consumer spending. China's economy grew by only 7.1% last year, too slow to create jobs for the millions being laid-off by bankrupt state-owned enterprises, who have staged sporadic and violent protests. The economy is expected to perform only slightly better this year.

But the week-long holiday seems to be helping. A Beijing survey found that travelling families expect to spend an average of about 1,558 yuan (£123) over the next seven days, according to the state-run Xinhua news agency.

This is a sizeable sum in Chinese terms, amounting to several months' wages, even for relatively affluent urban dwellers.

Some are choosing to venture abroad instead, following the loosening of restrictions on the issue of passports. Package tours to southeast Asian and even European destinations reportedly sold out long in advance of this week's holiday, as these are still the only way most people can legally travel overseas.

But there are fears that Chinese holidaymakers' lack of experience makes them easy prey for unscrupulous tour agencies and other rip-off artists.

"The food was terrible and the hotels unbearable. Even worse were the obligatory stops at endless special tourism sites," said Xiao Quan, who works in south-western China.

He joined a£35 tour to the southern island of Hainan, which has beaches that have been dubbed "China's Hawaii", only to find the three day trip degenerate into an exercise in milking as much money as possible from him, as he was dragged from one souvenir shop to another.

"Worst of all was the traditional medicine show," he complained. "After an electric current was passed through the audience, women in white shirts rushed to diagnose all kinds of illnesses and dispense healing potions for a hefty fee."

Zhang Yuanchao, of the Chinese consumer association, said that being forced to visit souvenir shops, where the guide receives a commission, was the most common source of protests. The association received a record 5,330 complaints about travel agencies last year, up 41% from 1998.

Even those who venture overseas do not necessarily fare any better. Beijing lawyer Liu Chi is suing a Chinese travel agency and its Swiss partners for embezzlement and misleading advertising in a Lausanne court after a trip to see the 1998 World Cup in France went badly wrong.

He said the agencies never provided the promised match tickets and forced the 22-strong tour party to cross Switzerland by coach rather than plane, despite spending £2,520 a head on the tour package.

webTitle: Australian site puts criminal records on web

fields.headline: Australian site puts criminal records on web
fields.standfirst: www.CrimeNet.com.au,
fields.trailText: A website which claims to be the world's first complete internet service devoted to helping employers, neighbours and parents to snoop on people's criminal records was launched in Perth, Western Australia yesterday, and proved so popular that it promptly crashed.
fields.body:
A website which claims to be the world's first complete internet service devoted to helping employers, neighbours and parents to snoop on people's criminal records was launched in Perth, Western Australia yesterday, and proved so popular that it promptly crashed.

Despite its blue and white checked borders, which is reminiscent of Australian police uniforms, the site, at www.CrimeNet.com.au, is not officially sanctioned.

For a fee, internet users can obtain details about convicted criminals, cross-referenced by name, type of crime and occupation. The information on the site's database is drawn by researchers from sources in the public domain, such as newspapers and court records.

A list of 270 convicted paedophiles also features on the website, which has been attacked by the Australian Council of Civil Liberties as a "disgraceful" venture which will only encourage vigilantes.

The site's manager - a former policeman, Roy Hampton - said the service would allow employers to screen staff, parents to check on babysitters, and people to find out more about new neighbours.

"If you're starting up a new business and you're looking to know a bit more about the partner that you have in mind to take on, then obviously you'd want to be checking," he said. "If you've got somebody coming into your home, either as a nanny or as somebody doing a security job in your home, then it would be as well to be making reference through CrimeNet."

The Western Australian assistant police commissioner, Bob Kucera, said the information on rewards, and on wanted and missing persons, were excellent crimefighting tools. But he warned about the cost of misinformation to the organisers, and to anyone falsely accused.

"If they were to get it wrong I could imagine that people would have some comeback civilly on that. There's always a problem using newspaper sources as they get it wrong sometimes."

A similar site in the US offers criminal background checks. But the Australian site claims to be unique in providing a complete service covering criminal records, "con artists" and people convicted abroad, as well as including war crimes and terrorism.

Peter Weygers, the president of the Civil Liberties Council in Western Australia, said he was concerned that making the information more easily available could damage the prospects of rehabilitation.

"What we want is to get them back into society; back into a job; back socialising with people. This sort of thing could potentially make that even more difficult to do than it already is," he said.

fields.headline: Family joins Tunis hunger strike
fields.trailText: Seven brothers and sisters are now on hunger strike in a dispute over press freedom in Tunisia.
fields.body:
Seven brothers and sisters are now on hunger strike in a dispute over press freedom in Tunisia.

Taoufik Ben Brick, a news agency correspondent, began the fast on April 3 at his home in Tunis and is reported to be in rapidly declining health. The house is sealed off by police. His brother Jalal Zoghlami who tried to visit him was arrested last week and is refusing food in jail. Five brothers and sisters in France, Britain and Tunisia joined the protest yesterday.

Mr Ben Brick vowed to starve to death unless his brother is freed. "I am going to die. I am fascinated by thoughts about those who have fallen on the battlefield," he said.

He admitted the interior ministry had returned his passport, the seizure of which sparked his protest, but court proceedings prevented him leaving the country. France has offered him asylum.

"I am not going to stop my hunger strike just because they return my passport or reconnect my telephone. They have given me a trinket and taken away the person who is the most important to me in the world. Jalal and I are siamese twins," he said.

Mr Ben Brick, 39, briefly lost consciousness on Friday. His wife said he had lost more than three stone. She said dozens of Tunisians, including journalists and doctors, were considering a hunger strike starting tomorrow, international day of press freedom.

The ruling Constitutional Democratic Rally party has said Mr Ben Brick's passport was taken because of legal proceedings. A human rights group says he was charged with libel for criticising the government in print.

webTitle: Making capital out of the good old days

fields.headline: Making capital out of the good old days
fields.standfirst: Large sums of cash have helped Bonn's economy to thrive despite the loss of the Bundestag. But the city's arts missed out on the good fortune
fields.trailText: Maike Menden, a law student, stands in the public gallery of the old Bundestag. She is giving a tour to a group of pensioners from Cologne.
fields.body:
Maike Menden, a law student, stands in the public gallery of the old Bundestag. She is giving a tour to a group of pensioners from Cologne.

"And that," she says, gesturing towards the seats below, "is where the SPD members of parliament sit." The pensioners peer into the chamber. Germany's flag is there. The steel eagle, emblem of the federal republic, is there. But despite Ms Menden's determined use of the present tense, the MPs are nowhere to be seen.

The building, which until a year ago served as the lower house of the German parliament, has been leased to a hotel chain and is used for exhibitions and conferences.

A mile away, it is lunchtime at Sassella, ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl's favourite restaurant. "He used to come once or twice a week and sit at that table over there in the corner," says Giorgio Tartero. "He liked mushroom-based dishes."

The tables are one-third occupied. Mr Tartero and his brother spent hundreds of thousands of marks on decor and equipment and now find themselves running one of the world's finest Italian restaurants in an unexceptional suburb in a minor German city.

There are moments in Bonn when you half expect to glimpse tumbleweed in the streets. So it comes as a surprise to discover that despite the relocation of the parliament and administration to Berlin, Bonn is the city with the fastest-growing economy in North Rhine-Westphalia.

Large amounts of cash and effort have gone into ensuring that the loss of capital status does not ruin the city, and so far the money appears to be having the desired effect.

Five ministries have stayed on, and more than 20 other government organisations have been moved to Bonn from Berlin and Frankfurt under a compensation agreement which also provides the city with some £930m.

Two more UN organisations are to join the five based in Bonn, which is also home to the headquarters of Deutsche Telekom and a distinguished university. The city aims to build on their presence to create a service-oriented economy, especially in telecommunications. It offers start-up facilities to small enterprises and much of the cash from the compensation deal is being spent on promoting research.

Above a shopping centre, holographic images of facial tissue are being studied in a laboratory. On the floor below, men in blue anti-contamination suits check a project to design "intelligent tyres" which would monitor their own wear. Across the corridor, a technician adjusts a machine which generates microscopic images for research on teeth braces.

This is the temporary headquarters of Caesar, the Centre of Advanced European Studies and Research, the largest single project in the programme to compensate Bonn.

But one area of the city's life is being left out of this cosy circle. Bonn's cultural infrastructure faces destruction.

In 1980, with no sign of the communists giving up east Berlin, it was decided that Bonn should continue indefinitely as capital of West Germany. It was also agreed that this city of 300,000 should be endowed with the cultural life befitting a capital.

Government subsidies were stepped up to their present level of DM70m (£21m) a year. Bonn soon boasted an orchestra of 120 members and a Biennale."In footballing terms, we are in the Champions' League," says Manfred Beilharz, who is responsible for the city's performing arts.

But Bonn faces relegation. In 2001, the first cut will be made to the arts subsidy which will disappear in 2004.

"The theatre, opera and dance companies and the other cultural institutions of Bonn are the children of the old federal republic of West Germany," says Mr Beilharz. "The federal republic had a liaison with Bonn and left her with these cultural offspring. Now, it has gone. But it is no longer interested in its children and does not want to pay for them."

webTitle: Beatles still rule the rockers' roost

fields.headline: Beatles still rule the rockers' roost
fields.trailText: Thirty years after they split up the Beatles are still the best British band of all time, according to a poll published yesterday.
fields.body:
Thirty years after they split up the Beatles are still the best British band of all time, according to a poll published yesterday.

A survey of the 100 greatest British albums compiled by writers and critics at Q magazine, monthly journal of grown-up rockers everywhere, is headed by the band's 1966 album Revolver.

Four other Beatles albums, A Hard Day's Night (5th), The Beatles (7th), Sgt Peppers' Lonely Hearts Club Band (13th) and Abbey Road (17th) feature in the top 20, and a sixth, Rubber Soul, is at no 21.

David Bowie is the next best-represented artist with four albums in the top 100, while the Rolling Stones have three, led by Exile on Main Street at no 3.

But Radiohead's 1997 prog-rock pastiche OK Computer leads the way for the under 40s at no 2, while Oasis and Massive Attack also make it into the top 10.

The Clash's 1979 London Calling is at no 4, six places higher than Never Mind the Bollocks by the Sex Pistols. Astral Weeks by Van Morrison completes the top 10.

Q editor Andy Pemberton believes the list confirms that the 1990s were British music's "second golden age" - 34 of the 100 come from the last decade - but that only Radiohead appear to have the staying power of the previous generation.

There is room for the innovators and eccentrics who have lent British rock much of its colour. Nick Drake's Bryter Later is at no 23, Ian Dury and the Blockheads' New Boots and Panties!! at no 66, and New Order's Low Life creeps into 97th place.

fields.headline: Philip Keenan
fields.trailText: The career of the American astronomer Philip Keenan, who has died aged 92, spanned more than 70 years. A prolific researcher, he published his first observations in 1929 on the colour of the moon during eclipses. Last year, he wrote his final paper, in a collaborative project that calculated the distances of stars from earth using the Hipparchos satellite - thus providing the most accurate measurements to date.
fields.body:
The career of the American astronomer Philip Keenan, who has died aged 92, spanned more than 70 years. A prolific researcher, he published his first observations in 1929 on the colour of the moon during eclipses. Last year, he wrote his final paper, in a collaborative project that calculated the distances of stars from earth using the Hipparchos satellite - thus providing the most accurate measurements to date.

Keenan's most outstanding work was to devise a new way to calculate the true power of stars, and overcome the problem of making accurate measurements of their distances from earth. Called the MK system, it was developed 60 years ago with another eminent astronomer, William Wilson Morgan.

The new approach meant that, for the first time, astronomers could determine the luminosity of stars directly by analysing their spectra, the detailed colours in the light emitted by all stars which gives them their stellar fingerprint.

A heavenly object that looks bright to the naked eye is often a far more modest star than one that is seemingly dim, but in fact is several light years further away from earth. The MK system was a more accurate way of comparing the activity of stars and understanding the chemical evolution of galaxies. It gave a way of looking at the spectra of each star to determine its luminosity and temperature.

Luminosity is the total brightness of a star or galaxy, and a measure of the total amount of energy it radiates each second in all wavelengths of the electromagnetic radiation. In the MK system, the spectral lines are like a special bar code, and the stars are assigned to groups, according to the width of the lines. For a group of stars with the same temperature, the differences in luminosity can be used to classify their sizes as supergiants, giants, main-sequence stars and sub-dwarfs.

The MK system was used in 1943 to produce a new league table of stars, the Atlas of Stellar Spectra. It was prepared by Keenan and Morgan in collaboration with Edith Kellman, and remains a fundamental work still widely used by astronomers. The atlas provided the framework for astronomers to put stars into categories, according to their stellar evolution. Morgan employed the system to calculate the distances of bright stars within the Milky Way, and in so doing discovered the galaxy's spiral structure.

Keenan was born in Bellevue, Pennsylvania, graduating in physics at the University of Arizona in 1929. He obtained a PhD from the University of Chicago in 1932, where he taught until 1942, before doing war service in the US Navy Bureau of Ordnance. In 1946, he became assistant professor of astronomy at Ohio State University and a member of the staff at Perkins Observatory. He retired in 1976, but continued to research until shortly before his final illness.

Philip Keenan, astronomer, born March 31 1908; died 20 April 2000

fields.headline: Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona
fields.trailText: Follow every kick here from 7.45pm.
fields.body:
Valencia CF: Canizares, Pellegrino, Djukic, Carboni, Angloma, Mendieta, Farinos, Gerard, Gonzalez, Angulo, Lopez.
Substitutes: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Sanchez, Albelda, Gerardo.

FC Barcelona: Hesp, Reiziger, F. de Boer, Puyol, Guardiola, Cocu, Zenden, Rivaldo, Gabri, Kluivert, Dani.
Substitutes: Arnau, Abelardo, Litmanen, Sergi, Bogarde, Simao, Xavi.

Referee: Urs Meier (Switzerland)

Valencia will be looking to win this first-leg tie handsomely, as their away form this season, both domestically and in the Champions League, has been poor. The 5-2 demolition of Lazio in the last Champions League match to be played at the Mestalla showed that Valencia are capable of beating any team in Europe at home. A lot depends on which Barcelona we see tonight - the muted side that turned out at Stamford Bridge, or the glorious unit that destroyed Chelsea in the return leg?

1 min Barcelona kick off to a cacophony of whistles. When Valencia gain possession, the home side instantly try and find playmaker and captain Mendieta, who has started wide on the right.
3 The first meaningful attack comes from Valencia, who break down the right through Djukic, who feeds Carboni. The cross is deep enough, but too near Hesp, who collects under his crossbar.
5 Mendieta and Angulo combines well on the right to force a corner. The centre is wasted and Barcelona clear with ease.
6 Valencia attack again, through Angloma who is unceremoniously dumped on his behind by Guardiola. The Swiss official is unmoved and tells Angolma to get up and get on with it.
7 Angulo provides what is almost the perfect cross from the right. Mendieta, who has shirked his marker, rises unopposed over the penalty spot, but the cross is a shade too high. Barca's marking was woeful.
9 Another corner for Valencia, again from the right. All the attacking play is coming from the home side during these opening moments.
11 GOAL! Valencia 1 - 0 Barcelona Barcelona are slow to clear a corner, and the ball falls to Angulo 15 yards out. His right foot makes no mistake and sends the ball rising past Hesp into the roof of the net and the Mestalla goes nuts.
13 Barca have two chances to equalize, and they both fall to the European Player of the Year, Rivaldo. His first, a header from point-blank range after a corner from the left, is palmed out by Canizares. From the restart, Rivaldo latches onto a weak back-pass and breaks towards the Valencia goal, pursued by Pellegrino. The defender does just enough to cause Rivaldo to screw his shot wide across the Valencia goal.
17 Barcelona, encouraged by Rivaldo's forays and stung by the goal they conceded, have finally decided to start playing. Guardiola feeds Zenden on the left, who is fouled by Pellegrino. The free kick is headed out and Valencia break.
20 Barcelona are very much a one man show at the moment. Rivaldo picks up a loose ball just outside the area and drives a rising half-volley just over the crossbar.
21 Farinos, with the unenviable task of marking Rivaldo, wrestles his charge to the ground to end one of his foraging runs, and is booked for his trouble.
24 Carboni, who is unfortunate enough to play a cross onto Guardiola's back, finds himself running back at full pelt to deal with the Barca attack he unwittingly started. He runs back 70 yards to cut out Zenden's cross from the left.
26 Claudio Lopez feeds Gonzalez on the left, in space. His pace takes him clear of Puyol and his rasping shot hits Hesp's near upright. The rebound is picked up by Lopez, who from a good 25 yards out drills the ball into the bottom corner. The linesman has spotted a foul and the 'goal' will not count.
27 GOAL! Valencia 1 - 1 Barcelona Shades of Roy Keane as Zenden, in space on the left, slides in a low cross aimed at Kluivert. Pellegrino, sliding in full-stretch, pokes the ball into his own net, wrong-footing Canizares. All that Barca pressure pays off at last.
32 A lot more ball for Barcelona since the goal. A free kick on the right, taken by Guardiola. Play is switched to Zenden on the left, and Angloma flies in with a tackle that makes the Dutchman wish he'd never been born. Strangely enough, the referee decides against a caution.
37 Valencia's Kily Gonzalez, always a handful on the left, is bundled over by the hapless Puyol, who is pretty much at the end of his tether. After Puyol is booked, play restarts but the set-piece is wasted.
40 Carboni and Gonzalez exchange three, four, five passes on the left touchline, before feeding Mendieta on the left of the Barca area. The Valencia skipper goes down dramatically as soon as Cocu brushes his shoulder. Despite what the crowd think, the referee is not impressed.
42 Gabri kicks Gerard under the referee's nose, and then looks surprised when he is booked.
43 GOAL! Valencia 2 - 1 Barcelona Kily Gonzalez can do no wrong tonight. A perfectly weighted cross from the left is met by Angulo, holding off two defenders. His rising drive soars past Hesp at his near post and it's no more than the home side deserve.
44 Penalty to Valencia Kily Gonzalez and Carboni play passing triangles on the left, before slotting the ball through to Mendieta, who plays a first-time side foot pass to Angulo. He is up-ended in the area for the clearest penalty a referee could ever hope for.
45 GOAL! Valencia 3 - 1 Barcelona Mendieta slots the penalty past Hesp, low and to the keeper's right. What a great half for the majority of fans in the Mestalla.
47 A breathless first half comes to a close.

45 Barcelona substitution: Bogarde for Puyol.
46 Barca have started half-asleep. Farinos crosses for the home side from the right, and Gerard, tormentor of Lazio, rises and appears to be fouled in the centre of the area. The ball overflies everyone in the centre of the box and falls to Kily Gonzalez, who smashes the ball into the side-netting.
49 Rivaldo spies a gap in the middle of the Valencia defence, but Djukic is all over him in a flash and the home side win back possession.
52 Kluivert, playing very deep, has been practically anonymous during the first 50 minutes. Van Gaal will be looking at him to push up more as Barcelona chase the game.
54 Zenden is trying his hardest on the left, but Dani cannot math his team-mate for industry or penetration on the opposite flank. Dani is trying to fill the suspended Luis Figo's shoes, and doesn't seem up to the challenge tonight.
60 Van Gaal is already looking to his substitutes bench for inspiration as Litmanen, Simao and Sergi start to warm up. A free kick on the left for the away side comes to nothing as Barcelona look bereft of attacking ideas.
61 Barcelona substitution: Litmanen for Dani.
63 Two corners in quick succession from the right for Valencia, but both a no problem for Ruud Hesp in the Barca goal.
66 Rivaldo has also had a quiet night since a bright period half-way through the first half. Farinos almost looks like he's enjoying marking the Brazilian now. The Valencia man makes an easy interception in the centre of the pitch and the Barca star troops away disconsolately.
68 Some head-tennis follows a Barcelona corner on the left, and finally Kluivert directs a header at goal, but the effort is weak and easily gathered by Canizares.
69 Ruud Hesp may have done just enough to keep Barcelona in this tie. A superb cross by Kily Gonzalez sails over everyone in front of goal, to be met by Mendieta on the volley, from the right. Hesp's desperate dive just reaches the shot before it flashes inside his near post.
73 Carboni does everything right to dispossess the marauding Zenden on the right, just inside his own area. The corner is hit deep, but the confident Canizares comes and claims well.
75 Barcelona are slowly starting to push upfield, and so Valencia are finding more space for their breaks. One can't help feeling that Barcelona would be happy with 3 - 1, but Valencia are a more accomplished side than Chelsea on tonight's evidence.
76 Barcelona substitution: Simao for Zenden. An unusual substitution, to say the least. Zenden has been one of Barca's more influential players.
78 Valencia substitution: Albelda for Angulo. The two-goal hero goes off to a standing ovation.
81 Some good pressure from Barca results in a corner from the right. Guardiola's cross is directed at the near post, but poses no danger. Another corner results, which this time is headed clear.
84 Albelda, on fresh legs, turns Reiziger inside-out on the right, before slipping a low cross through to Farinos. His back heel goes so close, but just trickles wide of the far post.
85 Valencia substitution: Sanchez for Gerard.
87 A horrible defensive error by Bogarde gifts the ball to Mendieta, who in a one-on-one with Hesp, loses out. The ball doesn't fall for Sanchez, and the chance is gone.
88 Claudio Lopez is narrowly denied a fourth goal for Valencia by Guardiola's excellent interception. The Spanish international then berates his team-mates for not getting back - he's got a point - he was the only one back by a stretch.
90 Two minutes of added time displayed. A tense few moments for the Mestalla faithful, as Barca chase the away goal that could make all the difference.
92 GOAL! Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona Kily Gonzalez, involved in everything tonight, squares to Claudio Lopez, just outside the area on the left. His low, fizzing shot cannons in off Hesp's left-hand post and sends the Mestalla crowd delirious for good. A brilliant, brilliant goal.
93 Full time: Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona.

He runs back 70 yards to cut out Zenden's cross from the left. 26 Claudio Lopez feeds Gonzalez on the left, in space. His pace takes him clear of Puyol and his rasping shot hits Hesp's near upright. The rebound is picked up by Lopez, who from a good 25 yards out drills the ball into the bottom corner. The linesman has spotted a foul and the 'goal' will not count. 27 GOAL! Valencia 1 - 1 Barcelona Shades of Roy Keane as Zenden, in space on the left, slides in a low cross aimed at Kluivert. Pellegrino, sliding in full-stretch, pokes the ball into his own net, wrong-footing Canizares. All that Barca pressure pays off at last. 32 A lot more ball for Barcelona since the goal. A free kick on the right, taken by Guardiola. Play is switched to Zenden on the left, and Angloma flies in with a tackle that makes the Dutchman wish he'd never been born. Strangely enough, the referee decides against a caution. 37 Valencia's Kily Gonzalez, always a handful on the left, is bundled over by the hapless Puyol, who is pretty much at the end of his tether. After Puyol is booked, play restarts but the set-piece is wasted. 40 Carboni and Gonzalez exchange three, four, five passes on the left touchline, before feeding Mendieta on the left of the Barca area. The Valencia skipper goes down dramatically as soon as Cocu brushes his shoulder. Despite what the crowd think, the referee is not impressed. 42 Gabri kicks Gerard under the referee's nose, and then looks surprised when he is booked. 43 GOAL! Valencia 2 - 1 Barcelona Kily Gonzalez can do no wrong tonight. A perfectly weighted cross from the left is met by Angulo, holding off two defenders. His rising drive soars past Hesp at his near post and it's no more than the home side deserve. 44 Penalty to Valencia Kily Gonzalez and Carboni play passing triangles on the left, before slotting the ball through to Mendieta, who plays a first-time side foot pass to Angulo. He is up-ended in the area for the clearest penalty a referee could ever hope for. 45 GOAL! Valencia 3 - 1 Barcelona Mendieta slots the penalty past Hesp, low and to the keeper's right. What a great half for the majority of fans in the Mestalla. 47 A breathless first half comes to a close. 45 Barcelona substitution: Bogarde for Puyol. 46 Barca have started half-asleep. Farinos crosses for the home side from the right, and Gerard, tormentor of Lazio, rises and appears to be fouled in the centre of the area. The ball overflies everyone in the centre of the box and falls to Kily Gonzalez, who smashes the ball into the side-netting. 49 Rivaldo spies a gap in the middle of the Valencia defence, but Djukic is all over him in a flash and the home side win back possession. 52 Kluivert, playing very deep, has been practically anonymous during the first 50 minutes. Van Gaal will be looking at him to push up more as Barcelona chase the game. 54 Zenden is trying his hardest on the left, but Dani cannot math his team-mate for industry or penetration on the opposite flank. Dani is trying to fill the suspended Luis Figo's shoes, and doesn't seem up to the challenge tonight. 60 Van Gaal is already looking to his substitutes bench for inspiration as Litmanen, Simao and Sergi start to warm up. A free kick on the left for the away side comes to nothing as Barcelona look bereft of attacking ideas. 61 Barcelona substitution: Litmanen for Dani. 63 Two corners in quick succession from the right for Valencia, but both a no problem for Ruud Hesp in the Barca goal. 66 Rivaldo has also had a quiet night since a bright period half-way through the first half. Farinos almost looks like he's enjoying marking the Brazilian now. The Valencia man makes an easy interception in the centre of the pitch and the Barca star troops away disconsolately. 68 Some head-tennis follows a Barcelona corner on the left, and finally Kluivert directs a header at goal, but the effort is weak and easily gathered by Canizares. 69 Ruud Hesp may have done just enough to keep Barcelona in this tie. A superb cross by Kily Gonzalez sails over everyone in front of goal, to be met by Mendieta on the volley, from the right. Hesp's desperate dive just reaches the shot before it flashes inside his near post. 73 Carboni does everything right to dispossess the marauding Zenden on the right, just inside his own area. The corner is hit deep, but the confident Canizares comes and claims well. 75 Barcelona are slowly starting to push upfield, and so Valencia are finding more space for their breaks. One can't help feeling that Barcelona would be happy with 3 - 1, but Valencia are a more accomplished side than Chelsea on tonight's evidence. 76 Barcelona substitution: Simao for Zenden. An unusual substitution, to say the least. Zenden has been one of Barca's more influential players. 78 Valencia substitution: Albelda for Angulo. The two-goal hero goes off to a standing ovation. 81 Some good pressure from Barca results in a corner from the right. Guardiola's cross is directed at the near post, but poses no danger. Another corner results, which this time is headed clear. 84 Albelda, on fresh legs, turns Reiziger inside-out on the right, before slipping a low cross through to Farinos. His back heel goes so close, but just trickles wide of the far post. 85 Valencia substitution: Sanchez for Gerard. 87 A horrible defensive error by Bogarde gifts the ball to Mendieta, who in a one-on-one with Hesp, loses out. The ball doesn't fall for Sanchez, and the chance is gone. 88 Claudio Lopez is narrowly denied a fourth goal for Valencia by Guardiola's excellent interception. The Spanish international then berates his team-mates for not getting back - he's got a point - he was the only one back by a stretch. 90 Two minutes of added time displayed. A tense few moments for the Mestalla faithful, as Barca chase the away goal that could make all the difference. 92 GOAL! Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona Kily Gonzalez, involved in everything tonight, squares to Claudio Lopez, just outside the area on the left. His low, fizzing shot cannons in off Hesp's left-hand post and sends the Mestalla crowd delirious for good. A brilliant, brilliant goal. 93 Full time: Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona.

webTitle: Hague and Kennedy in campaign war of words

fields.headline: Hague and Kennedy in campaign war of words
fields.trailText: William Hague today defended his tough stance on asylum seekers and prepared to trade accusations of extremism with Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, in the Romsey byelection campaign.
fields.body:
William Hague today defended his tough stance on asylum seekers and prepared to trade accusations of extremism with Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, in the Romsey byelection campaign.

Before his speech in Romsey, where the Conservatives are fighting to hold off a strong Lib Dem challenge for the vacant Hampshire parliamentary seat, the Tory leader launched a pre-emptive strike against Mr Kennedy.

"We must not be browbeaten out of raising this subject because other people want to distort the way we raise it," Mr Hague said. "We have been right to raise it and we have been cheered on by many thousands of people across the country wherever we have been."

By advocating detention centres for asylum seekers and in speaking about an influx of running "out of control", Mr Hague has been accused of playing the race card and is being compared to Enoch Powell, the MP who made himself a pariah with his "rivers of blood" speech in 1968. But a defiant Mr Hague said today: "These are not right-wing themes. Labour voters, people who voted Liberal in the past are saying to me these are the sort of things which we should be raising."

Mr Hague is expected to mount a strong attack on the Lib Dems, accusing them of being on the "extreme fringes of the political debate". On asylum-seekers, Mr Hague will accuse the Liberals of "descending into gutter politics by referring both the Labour and Conservative parties to the Commission for Racial Equality". On rural crime, he will say: "The Liberals head an assorted bunch of left-wing pressure groups who are more interested in the rights of criminals than in the rights of people who are burgled and victimised by crime."

Mr Kennedy will hit back in similarly strong terms, accusing him of being "immature and dangerous" and indulging in "irresponsible politics". Mr Kennedy will tell a rally in the byelection contest: "I like William personally but publicly, professionally, he is dangerous. Voicing ever more grotesque impulses he is in danger of becoming the epitome of the saloon bar politician - over-reacting to every news headline, pandering to every passing prejudice, exploiting people's problems for party political gain."

The Lib Dems are hoping for a narrow win in the seat left vacant by the death of Michael Colvin where the Tories had a majority of 8,555 in 1997. Mr Hague's statements on asylum seekers and his proposals for a change self-defence laws after the murder conviction of Norfolk farmer Tony Martin has rattled some of his moderate colleagues.

Tory backbencher Andrew Rowe yesterday said: "I think everybody who is comfortably off - particularly if they are in a leadership of a political party - needs to be extremely careful of going down the track of blaming the relatively small number of people who come into this country.''

fields.headline: Two discuss £90bn telecoms tie-up
fields.standfirst:
Telefonica and KPN explore prospect of pan-European alliance

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Telefonica, the Spanish telecoms company, yesterday confirmed it was in talks with Dutch rival KPN Telekom about a possible 160bn (£90bn) merger.
fields.body:
Telefonica, the Spanish telecoms company, yesterday confirmed it was in talks with Dutch rival KPN Telekom about a possible €160bn (£90bn) merger.

Analysts said a deal could spur further consolidation among Europe's longer established national telephone companies as they try to keep up with newly merged US firms such as MCI WorldCom and Sprint and mobile phone firms such as Vodafone.

Analysts said a mobile telecoms tie-up would boost the two carriers' ability to buy competitors and gain costly third generation mobile licences. Telefonica pulled out of the race for one of the UK's third generation licences, saying it would pursue cheaper options.

KPN Mobile has about 8.5m customers and is active in central and eastern Europe while Telefonica says it has 20m wireless clients in Europe, Latin America and North Africa.

The Dutch group's shares rose nearly 10% yesterday. Spain's stock market was closed for the May Day holiday.

"An alliance or merger would be good added value for both companies whose activities and ideas are similar," said Henk van de Meent, an analyst at NIB Capital. "It could be quite a powerhouse, especially when other parties are involved as well."

A spokesman for Telefonica said: "The company has been holding conversations with KPN on several matters, including the possibility of inte gration of all or part of their businesses.

"However, no definitive agreement has been reached and there is no certainty that the mentioned conversations will give positive results."

KPN said earlier it would delay the initial public offering of KPN Mobile, Europe's seventh largest mobile operator, because of talks with a possible new partner.

The two are reported to be considering creating a company 60% owned by Telefonica and 40% by KPN.

webTitle: The arrival of a new world order

fields.headline: The arrival of a new world order
fields.standfirst:
Mark Lockheart's Scratch Band
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
****
fields.trailText:
Mark Lockheart's Scratch Band
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
****
fields.body:
World music is becoming ever more prominent at the Cheltenham Jazz Festival. You even hear venerable jazz buffs saying what a pleasant surprise this is - it isn't a transformation that only a younger audience notices.

The influence of world music was most strongly felt this year in the Scratch Band, led by former Loose Tubes saxophonist Mark Lockheart. The eight-part festival commission he composed for this group bore some telltale Loose Tubes signs. It featured abrupt tempo changes; folksy, busy counter-melodies under lurching jazzy horn lines; and a blend of the bluesy and the rustic. But it also marked the maturing of Lockheart as an ambitious composer.

Although the suite had its occasional longueurs (including the occasional uncentred melody), for the most part it was a compelling melange. There was Tubesy clamour; dark, urgent bass ostinatos with fast, car-chase horn themes on top; long brass fanfares reminiscent of Michael Gibbs and Carla Bley; and pastoral sections enriched by Rowland Sutherland's lovely flute sound. In Sutherland, pianist Huw Warren, saxophonist Rob Townsend and Lockheart himself, the band has improvisers of real character.

Guitarist Phil Robson's octet, another local band with a world vision, also used plenty of non-jazz inspiration (Greek dance music, among other things), but was in some respects closer to the mainstream in its open, blowing feel.

Drummer Gene Calderazzo did much to stoke this up with a characteristically volatile performance, and Robson confirmed in one unaccompanied guitar break that he has first-rate jazz skills. Saxophonist/composer Stan Sulzmann didn't set the pulses racing quite as much with the ambitious full-scale orchestra he is currently taking around the country, on a rare tour. But he did turn several Gil Evans-like meditations of considerable textural subtlety into engagingly rousing swingers. Soloists Pat White and Derek Watkins (trumpets) and Nigel Hitchcock, Julian Siegel and Pete Hurt (saxes) kept the pot close to the boil.

Lapse play Underworld, London NW1 (020-7482 1932), tonight.

fields.headline: Microsoft bounces back
fields.standfirst:
Bargain hunters snap up shares despite US government's break-up ruling

The future of Microsoft: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bargain hunters rushed to buy shares in Microsoft yesterday despite the US government's radical restructuring proposals for the world's largest software company. Shares in Microsoft rose 5% in New York during morning trading.
fields.body:
Bargain hunters rushed to buy shares in Microsoft yesterday despite the US government's radical restructuring proposals for the world's largest software company. Shares in Microsoft rose 5% in New York during morning trading.

Wall Street analysts said investors were taking advantage of what could be a low point for the company after falling more than 40% in the run-up to the proposals revealed late on Friday night.

"This is a bounce-back on relief that the government's proposals were not worse than expected," said one Wall Street analyst. The justice department and 17 US states demanded that Microsoft be broken into two on Friday as a way of preventing further abuses of its stranglehold on the world's computer market.

The proposals are to be studied by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who last month ruled that Microsoft had broken US anti-trust laws.

Bill Gates, the Microsoft founder and chairman, attacked the government's proposals as excessive and said they would be bad for shareholders. But the company also vowed to fight the government all the way to the US supreme court if necessary.

Joel Klein, the assistant attorney general, has said he expects the legal process to last at least another year.

Some analysts have taken advantage of the government's proposals for a radical restructuring to reiterate their buy ratings on the company.

Michael Stanek, analyst at Lehman Brothers, said the shares were worth between $125 and $135 - almost twice the current level - on the basis of a sum of two parts valuation. "Investor objections of not owning the stock based on break-up fears are no longer rooted in reality," he told Reuters news agency. The government's case is based on increased competition between the two companies - one which would run the Windows operating system and the other the company's applications, such as Office.

Melissa Eisenstat, an analyst with CIBC World Markets, has estimated that the company could trade anywhere between $52 and $134 a share because of the uncertainties of the protracted legal action.

In a note she offered more cautious advice to investors: "This is the last of the really bad news. If you're a really long-term investor I wouldn't be afraid, but I wouldn't be backing up a truck."

One analyst warned that it was too early for investors to be buying on the break-up news because of the likelihood of an appeal.

"Given how things change in this industry, Microsoft is likely to be a very different company in two years' time," he said.

"We are really in the third innings of a nine-innings game."

Microsoft's shares were up more than $3 to $73 at noon yesterday, prompting a rally in the Nasdaq composite index. The company exacerbated the trend set off by Friday's ruling by warning that slower demand for PCs would hit revenues this year and next.

The Seattle-based company has also delayed its planned Forum 2000, when it was expected to announce its "next generation" software because of the legal uncertainties.

Microsoft's rivals also benefited from Friday's decision. Providers of Linux, the freely distributed software, were among the biggest gainers.

Red Hat jumped 15%, while VA Linux gained 18%. Corel, an applications provider, also rose 16%. Microsoft has argued increased competition from such companies contradicts the government's suit.

webTitle: Keeping it all in the family

fields.headline: Keeping it all in the family
fields.standfirst:
Normal
The Bush Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Normal
The Bush Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Helen Blakeman's new play more than confirms the promise that she showed three years ago in Caravan. That was a lively portrait of a disintegrating Liverpool working-class family; this, while boasting a lot of acrid humour, offers a disturbing picture of the way families conspire to cover up tragedy and even to ignore the breakdown happening in their midst.

What Blakeman has learned since her first play is the art of withholding information, of not playing one's best cards all at once. The focus is on Kate, a lonely, insecure 21-year-old Liverpool student pouring out her heart, possibly to a shrink or priest.

Gradually Blakeman pieces together the key facts of Kate's life: the deaths of her baby brother and sister in hospital, her mother's strange erotic liaison with the doctor held responsible, and not least, Kate's own sense of rejection when her tarty college flatmate steals her boyfriend from under her nose. Kate is clearly in crisis; you have to wait until the end to find out precisely how and why.

In Caravan family tensions were quickly resolved in a slightly soapy way; here Blakeman suggests, more truthfully, that nothing is ever quite buried or forgotten. Kate's siblings died 15 years ago but she can never erase the memory of her father's obsessive cinematic recording of their funeral. Equally her mother, wonderfully played by a silkily oppressive, maturely sexy Marion Bailey, keeps grief alive by haunting hospitals and consorting with doctors.

Blakeman is sometimes a bit hazy about social details. What she conveys excellently is the attritional power of the past and the way families observe social rituals while ignoring psychological crack-up - a very Ayckbournian theme.

Like Ayckbourn, Blakeman also shows that pain is actually intensified by the counterpoint of comedy. She contrasts Kate's breakdown with the remorseless advance of her bumptious chum Holly, whose aim is to be a TV presenter and who, accordingly, goes in for breast enhancement.

Holly is well played by Emma Pike, who invests her with the pathos of the pushy. But the best scenes in Mike Bradwell's sensitive production are those involving Kate, whom Lisa Ellis endows with an echoing solitude born of total desperation. Both unnerving and strangely watchable, it's a second play that, for once, is a striking advance on the first.

Until May 27. Box office: 020-8743 3388.

fields.headline: Poseidon
fields.standfirst:
Primitive Science
Young Vic, London
**
fields.trailText:
Primitive Science
Young Vic, London
**
fields.body:
Over the past few years Primitive Science has established itself as a major visual-theatre company. There is nobody else in Britain who creates work that is so ravishing. But just as so much mainstream, text-based work is drama but not theatre, Primitive Science sometimes falls into the trap of making work that is theatrical but not dramatic.

This is exactly what happens to its slight revenge story about global warming and Poseidon, in which the god is presented as a middle-aged bureaucrat, concerned that his brothers Zeus and Hades have got all the best jobs. He is keen to assert his place in the pecking order, but the real blow comes when his nephew Hermes turns up and slyly announces that humans no longer believe in the god of the seas any more than they believe in Father Christmas.

It is a mildly amusing hour, reminiscent of a Radio 4 Peter Tinniswood monologue that has been mugged by performance art, but the lack of substance in the writing makes the visual element of the production look like mere prettified trappings.

Having said that, if you've not yet caught a Primitive Science show, and so are unfamiliar with its use of water, you will probably be knocked sideways by a production in which the action is presented entirely through a fine film of drizzle. For the rest of us, beautiful though it is, Primitive Science has done the same thing much better before.

Till May 27. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

But just as so much mainstream, text-based work is drama but not theatre, Primitive Science sometimes falls into the trap of making work that is theatrical but not dramatic. This is exactly what happens to its slight revenge story about global warming and Poseidon, in which the god is presented as a middle-aged bureaucrat, concerned that his brothers Zeus and Hades have got all the best jobs. He is keen to assert his place in the pecking order, but the real blow comes when his nephew Hermes turns up and slyly announces that humans no longer believe in the god of the seas any more than they believe in Father Christmas. It is a mildly amusing hour, reminiscent of a Radio 4 Peter Tinniswood monologue that has been mugged by performance art, but the lack of substance in the writing makes the visual element of the production look like mere prettified trappings. Having said that, if you've not yet caught a Primitive Science show, and so are unfamiliar with its use of water, you will probably be knocked sideways by a production in which the action is presented entirely through a fine film of drizzle. For the rest of us, beautiful though it is, Primitive Science has done the same thing much better before. Till May 27. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

webTitle: Disney-Time Warner row leads to TV blackout

fields.headline: Disney-Time Warner row leads to TV blackout
fields.trailText: Millions of Americans are set to miss their regular dose of the popular television quiz show, Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, after a bitter dispute broke out yesterday between media and cable group Time Warner and Walt Disney.
fields.body:
Millions of Americans are set to miss their regular dose of the popular television quiz show, Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, after a bitter dispute broke out yesterday between media and cable group Time Warner and Walt Disney.

Time Warner said it would stop carrying the ABC channel - effectively shutting out the Disney-owned network from 11 US cities including New York. The decision was taken after the two corporations failed to agree new transmission terms before a deadline of midnight on Sunday.

ABC immediately appealed to US regulators to force Time Warner to stop blocking access to its cable television network.

It accused Time Warner, which is to merge with America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, of acting illegally and of abusing its market position.

The federal communications commission is reviewing the AOL Time Warner merger and has already received complaints from consumer groups about the increased power created by the deal.

Bruce Gordon, the president of ABC in North Carolina, told Bloomberg news agency: "This blackout is a frightening foreshadowing of the implications of the Time Warner-AOL merger." ABC is also expected to suffer falling audiences during the month-long ratings period local television stations use to set advertising rates in the US.

Talks over a new transmission contract have been going on since the end of last year, just before the AOL acquisition was announced.

Time Warner yesterday accused ABC of trying to extract "excessive and unreasonable terms for its cable television channels". It had objected to ABC's attempt to have the Disney Channel and other services offered in the cable company's basic package to consumers, saying that such a deal would cost about $300m.

It pulled the plug on some 3.5m homes after failing to reach a deal. A broadcast announcement transmitted in place of normal programmes read: "Disney has taken ABC away from you." It promised to provide substitute programming as soon as possible.

Shares in Disney and Time Warner fell slightly yesterday. Analysts said the dispute would not seriously hurt earnings unless they were still unresolved in a few weeks' time.

fields.headline: Surf rage
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Stress on the beach Plus how to call for a better time at work
fields.body:
Just when you think business people have got the monopoly on barmy behaviour with bullying, harassment and outbreaks of office rage, psychologists have thrown down the gauntlet by coming up with statistics on surf rage. This is not - as you might think - some new internet mood-blighter, but the genuine, beach place item. Surfers are turning feral over who owns the right to which wave.

This snippet must surely put paid to the great workplace myth that it is the job alone that creates the killer stress, and that the only cure is to quit and become a beach bum.

Some alternatives According to recruitment consultants Office Angels, one path to greater happiness and enlightenment at work is to change your job title. Evidently 70% of office workers might be willing to forgo a pay rise in favour of a more motivational or professional job title. American options, like envisioner ( the artist formerly known as product designer) and chief imagination officer (aka creative assistant) are said to make the job 'instantly more dynamic and inspirational'.

So what do you do, then This rash of euphemistic monikers does little to reduce embarrassment levels during that well-known social exchange at drinks and dinner parties, the "So what do you do, then?" conversation. Modern jobs and their titles have rendered this small-talk option almost extinct. It takes a brave man/woman to relate, poker-faced, in reply: "I am The Office Logistics Co-ordinator", knowing that the response will either be total confusion or derision. "So what exactly is that, then?" will be the next gambit, to which you have to reply: 'Post Person', or whatever.

Going up market Re-creating yourself via your title can be hugely therapeutic, though, especially if you manage to tweak a "senior" or "chief executive" in there somewhere. This would be the perfect counter to all the reverse snobbery attached to jobs. One real chief executive of a large manufacturing firm was always said to tell anyone dumb enough to ask what he did in the company as 'oh, nothing much'. Title tips Assuming you are one of the 70% who would swap cash for a name-change, then, how to select one that will work in your favour?  Eschew anything too ghastly, however grand it might sound. People will laugh when they hear it, and you will spend your entire time apologising and blushing.  Stick to something with a UK ring to it. At least it will sound as though you came up with it yourself.  Less is always more. Size may be the ultimate job title snobbery but think how bored you will get when you have to keep rattling off the five or six-worder. One or two word titles are more than enough for the lungs to cope with. Business cards always look better without a fold-out panel to accommodate the never-ending title, and your name badge will have a less detrimental effect on your designer business suit.  Keep it simple. It helps communications in general if your title reflects and describes the job that you do. Too esoteric and you could just add to the general job-confusion.  Never be ashamed to ask for a return to something more basic if your firm has already gone down the title snobbery trail. Simple, old-style titles are coming back into vogue again

fields.headline: When small is still beautiful
fields.standfirst:
The Lapse
The Fenton, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
The Lapse
The Fenton, Leeds
****
fields.body:
There's something pathological about a band who journey all the way from New York to play in the upstairs room of a pub, but the Lapse are that band. So far underground they probably smell of coal dust, they've endured 10 years of extremely minor cultdom without anything approaching "success". Before that, they toiled in the even more obscure Van Pelt.

None of this - not even the recent split with long-term band/life partner Toko Yasuda - seems to have dampened main man Chris Leo's fearsome spirit. When he spits out "We are the rejects", it's more a cry of pride and defiance than a sulk about not being even a thousandth as big as the Spice Girls.

Quite why the Lapse aren't better known (although they do attract a pub full of devotees) is a mystery. Perhaps Leo - on this evidence one of the great anti-establishment, anti-mainstream pop poets - would have it no other way. It's surely nothing to do with their music. Close to the UK post-punk rattle of the Fire Engines and the Fall, with added waves of glorious Husker Du melody-drama and Leo's Richard Hell-ish, agitated vocals, the trio's spiky anthems are so hook-laden they seem instantly memorable. In another world, a handful of them - not least the urgent Speed Train - would be recognised as real classics.

With their combat fatigues and belligerent grins, the band could have come straight from the set of Mash. Leo's resemblance to Iggy Pop playing Hawkeye is uncanny, but more remarkable is the sheer passion and hard work they bring to such a tiny arena.

By the end, the sweat-soaked drummer looks like he has been run over by a car, but the Lapse have proved an important point. Big may be back, but small can still be infinitely more beautiful. The Lapse play Underworld, London NW1 (020-7482 1932), tonight.

fields.headline: Teenage Taibu gives tourists hope
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 131 & 234-4
Zimbabwe 364-7dec
Match drawn
fields.trailText: Hampshire v Zimbabwe
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's tourists will be hoping to be offered some more exacting preparation before their two test matches with England. The combination of almost two days lost to rain, an easy-paced wicket and a weakened opposition ensured an inevitable draw.

If the Zimbabweans were looking for a gentle start to their first tour as a test-playing nation then this was certainly the place to be. The inducement of an £11,000 victory bounty failed to excite Hampshire even before rain played such a decisive part in the outcome.

Shane Warne did at least make an appearance. He got as far as the middle to examine the wicket for today's National League match and then departed, but not before being asked to sign many more autographs than any of those actually playing in the match.

The Zimbabweans will hope that most of the counties they face during the tour do not follow Hampshire's example and leave out their overseas player or reduce the number of seasoned professionals. Warne aside, Hampshire omitted Shaun Udal, Peter Hartley, Dimitri Mascarenhas, Alan Mullally and Adrian Aymes, of which only the latter was genuinely injured.

A devalued home side and no Warne meant that Hampshire failed to make the most of one of the most prestigious matches in their calendar. They projected a loss this year of £150,000 and over the four days the match was watched by no more than 2,000 spectators.

Yesterday's attendance was estimated by Hampshire to be around 600 and there was little for them to enthuse about apart from a cultured 150 not out in 4 hours by Zimbabwe's acting captain Alistair Campbell and some batting and wicketkeeping of high promise by 16-year-old Tatenda Taibu.

Taibu is a product of the schools coaching programme in Harare and all suggestions of tokenism were dispelled by his athleticism behind the stumps and his correctness in front of them. Two cover drives off Alex Morris and Simon Francis hint at a long and distinguished career to come.

Campbell declared their first innings when 233 ahead but there was never a chance of Zimbabwe forcing a win as Jason Laney and Giles White put on 86 for the first wicket and later Will Kendall and Robin Smith added 123 for the third.

Pommie Mbangwa and Neil Johnson looked lively in the Hampshire first innings when they each took four wickets, but there was no encouragement for them yesterday. Campbell used six bowlers as the match petered out and thoughts quickly turned to Kent on Wednesday, and perhaps some opposition of a more demanding nature.

fields.headline: Glamorgan in a twirl
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 185-9
Glamorgan 175
Surrey won by 10 runs
fields.trailText: Glamorgan v Surrey
fields.body:
A turner in Cardiff at the end of April is almost as rare as a snowflake in the Sahara, but Robert Croft and Ian Salisbury found an unexpected treasure trove yesterday as weeks of rain in the city were relieved by an outbreak of sunshine.

There was the usual lack of bounce here on the opening day of this season's national league matches, and batsmen were only able to confidently go for their shots when the ball was new. After that it became a matter of waiting for the bad ball and Glamorgan sent down most of those.

It would have been a dull affair but for the wiles of Croft and Salisbury, two spinners tried and rejected by England, whose coach Duncan Fletcher was among the crowd.

Croft was ignored last year after turning from an off-spinner into a medium-pacer, while the leg-spinner Salisbury has been a victim of his own inconsistency. Croft has since spent time developing his repertoire, which now includes a delivery bowled from 23 yards and an alternative run-up reminiscent of Graham Gooch, while Salisbury's ability to generate turn, lift and disguise his googly made him unplayable at times yesterday.

Surrey's total of 185 for nine was above par, the foundation set by Mark Butcher and Graham Thorpe, who took 87 balls over his 61. Croft and Alex Wharf induced a degree of paralysis which saw Surrey fail to score a boundary in their final 28 overs but they converted enough singles into twos to set a reasonable target.

In the absence of Matthew Elliott, whose three-year-old son was taken to hospital after an accident, Glamorgan opened up with two pinch-hitters, Croft and Wharf. They were soon pinching themselves in the pavilion after being deceived by Martin Bicknell's slower ball.

Mike Powell and Matthew Maynard briefly got on top before Powell was superbly caught by Butcher at deep mid-wicket off Adam Hollioake, who finished with 4-39, and Salisbury removed the dangerous Maynard.

The younger Hollioake, Ben, conceded only 19 runs from his nine overs as Glamorgan's middle-order became bogged down, 27 runs coming off 10 overs when acceleration was needed. Darren Thomas hit a cameo 20 off 12 balls but it was too little, too late as Glamorgan fell victim to their own pitch.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Glenn McGrath launched his National League career for Worcestershire with figures of four for nine off nine overs yesterday, but finished on the losing side as Yorkshire edged home by 19 runs in a low-scoring First Division match at New Road. The Australian did not concede a run in a six over opening spell and allowed only five scoring shots in all. Yet Yorkshire crept up to 151 for eight, then dismissed last year's runners-up for 132.

webTitle: Deal maker at the heart of cricket

fields.headline: Deal maker at the heart of cricket
fields.standfirst:
Dalmiya sues over TV rights 'abuse'
Chairman Dalmiya in the hot seat
fields.trailText: In less than a decade Mark Mascarenhas, the 42-year-old television executive linked with allegations against the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya, has established himself as one of the most powerful men in world cricket through control of broadcast rights on the subcontinent, the game's biggest market.
fields.body:
In less than a decade Mark Mascarenhas, the 42-year-old television executive linked with allegations against the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya, has established himself as one of the most powerful men in world cricket through control of broadcast rights on the subcontinent, the game's biggest market.

Mascarenhas struck gold in 1996 when a bold $10m bid by his firm WorldTel won the rights to that year's World Cup, held on the subcontinent. At a stroke the Bangalore-born businessman became a pivotal figure, selling on the rights to individual national broadcasters.

As a young man he went to America and after a brief spell selling airtime for a New York radio station he moved to CBS Television. There he learned enough to launch WorldTel in 1989.

Four years later he showed the opportunist streak that has characterised his career, securing the rights to some of the matches in the football World Cup warm-up tournament in the summer of 1993. American stations had planned to show only matches involving the United States, but Mascarenhas realised that games involving the other teams - England, Germany and Brazil - would have a far larger audience.

Since the cricket World Cup coup WorldTel has been pivotal in helping the ICC further its president's declared aim of spreading the game's popularity. WorldTel broadcasts of the annual tournaments in Sharjah and Bangladesh, under the official umbrella of the ICC, have drawn crucial sponsorship revenue.

But it is Mascarenhas's relationship with the ICC, and Dalmiya in particular, that is now under the spotlight. Mascarenhas made clear his admiration for the new ICC head when he was elected in 1997, saying: "He will do wonders for the game but I have no business dealings with him."

He rejects the accusations of corruption, yesterday describing them as "scandalous and libellous" on www.total-cricket.com, a WorldTel website. fields.headline: Dalmiya sues over TV rights 'abuse'
fields.standfirst:
The ICC president will be the centre of attention at tomorrow's match-fixing inquiry at Lord's
Deal maker at the heart of cricket
Chairman Dalmiya in the hot seat
fields.trailText: The scandal enveloping cricket reached new heights yesterday when it was announced that Jagmohan Dalmiya, the Calcutta-based president of the International Cricket Council, will sue over claims that he abused his position to award television rights for the 1998 ICC Trophy one-day tournament in Bangladesh.
fields.body:
The scandal enveloping cricket reached new heights yesterday when it was announced that Jagmohan Dalmiya, the Calcutta-based president of the International Cricket Council, will sue over claims that he abused his position to award television rights for the 1998 ICC Trophy one-day tournament in Bangladesh.

Dalmiya is due at Lord's tomorrow to head an emergency meeting of the ICC to investigate allegations of bribery and match-fixing in the wake of the Hansie Cronje affair. Dalmiya's lawyers have filed a criminal case for defamation in Calcutta against Arun Agarwal, an Indian financial adviser who claimed financial misconduct, alleging the TV rights had been sold at a bargain-basement £1.875m.

The cricket website total-cricket.com, which announced details of the writ, said Dalmiya submitted to the court that his "reputation has been injured and harmed in a conspiracy against him".

He is claiming that "all allegations made by Agarwal were false", with the worldwide TV rights being secured for £6.25m before being subcontracted to WorldTel, the company headed by Mark Mascarenhas, Indian-born but now a resident of the United States. Mascarenhas, who also acts as agent for many top cricketers on the subcontinent, owns total-cricket.com.

Only on Saturday, Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board who convened the emergency meeting, said that as part of the inquiry into corruption "everybody should be investigated, from the president downwards". It is believed the allegations will be discussed, though progress will be hamstrung by the pending court proceedings.

The spotlight fell on Dalmiya just under a fortnight ago when Inderjit Singh Bindra, his predecessor as president of the Indian Cricket Board, told press that Dalmiya was "in the grip of the mafia and sharks".

Last Wednesday Agarwal, who had been hired by Doordarshan, the Indian TV company, to investigate sports scams between 1998 and 1999, went public, alleging that Dalmiya, as sole negotiator for the ICC when the television rights for the ICC Trophy were awarded in October 1998, had abused his position.

On Friday SS Dhindsa, the Indian sports minister, fanned the flames by announcing that the country's Central Bureau of Investigation would probe cricket corruption in India, including "the sale of telecast rights to a foreign firm".

Dalmiya has been ICC president for three years. In July he will stand down to be replaced by the former president of the Australian board, Malcolm Gray.

 The Pakistan Cricket Board yesterday said that it would not release Justice Mohammad Qayyum's report into match-fixing in time for tomorrow's meeting at Lord's but would submit it next month.

webTitle: Chairman Dalmiya in the hot seat

fields.headline: Chairman Dalmiya in the hot seat
fields.standfirst:
The ICC president will be the centre of attention at tomorrow's match-fixing inquiry at Lord's
Deal maker at the heart of cricket
Dalmiya sues over TV rights 'abuse'
fields.trailText: Hours after being elected president of the International Cricket Council in June 1997, Jagmohan Dalmiya threw a party in central London to celebrate the fulfilment of his life's ambition. The alcohol ran freely, wellwishers chatted late into the night and a good time was had by all.
fields.body:
Hours after being elected president of the International Cricket Council in June 1997, Jagmohan Dalmiya threw a party in central London to celebrate the fulfilment of his life's ambition. The alcohol ran freely, wellwishers chatted late into the night and a good time was had by all.

Or it would have been, had everyone in cricket been there. Notable by their absence were representatives of five of the senior test nations who, until Dalmiya's election, had dominated the politics of international cricket.

There was no sign of Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, nor were there official representatives from the West Indies, Australia, New Zealand or South Africa. But tomorrow they will all meet, officially, as the ICC convenes at Lord's in an emergency session to discuss the match-fixing allegations currently engulfing the international game.

Dalmiya's reign always threatened to be controversial. He promised to break up the cosy world of international cricket and drag the game into a new era of commercialism. He was mistrusted by the cricket establishment even before he took office as he outlined plans to increase sponsorship and corporate involvement and, controversially, generate new riches from television rights by increasing the number of one-day internationals. Tradition- alists see Dalmiya as a maverick and unsafe pair of hands whose tenure has damaged test cricket and taken the game into dangerous, uncharted territory.

Dalmiya's power-base has remained firmly within the subcontinent. Pakistan and Sri Lanka are his biggest backers among the test-playing nations and, remaining hugely popular among the ICC's 23 associate members, he was able to secure his election as ICC president because of their support.

He first clashed with the cricket establishment in the mid-90s, when as president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) he snatched the 1996 World Cup from England in a manoeuvre that mixed hard-nosed arrogance and political sophistica tion. It had already been agreed that the event should be held in England when Dalmiya promised a larger share of the profits to the ICC's 23 associate members should they vote for the tournament to be held on the subcontinent. They had one vote each compared with two for each full member, but they were enough to win the day for Dalmiya.

The tournament in India and Pakistan proved a huge commercial success by generating profits of around £30m. Dalmiya was seen as the financial wizard behind its success. The same 23 minor cricketing countries, with Zimbabwe, then backed Dalmiya when he challenged Australia for the ICC presidency in 1997.

Dalmiya, 61, belongs to one of Calcutta's wealthiest famillies, inheriting one of India's largest construction companies at the age of 19. He is married, has two sons and is described as a workaholic. A keen cricketer, he opened the batting for one of the city's leading clubs and also kept wicket.

His world presidency has been characterised by ICC-backed one-day tournaments, many taking place in Bangladesh, the Far East and Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates. These generate millions of pounds in sponsorship and television rights and, according to some, are at the centre of match-fixing.

Dalmiya has defended the use of the one-day game for spreading the game's popularity and denies that his presidency has damaged test cricket. He once said: "I am a traditionalist. To me, test cricket is real cricket, a precious product to be preserved. But at the same time one-day cricket is an important version, especially in countries where five-day cricket is not played."

Since match-fixing allegations first surfaced in India last month, some of Dalmiya's greatest critics have been his own compatriots, who claim that his shift of emphasis has provided the conditions in which corruption can flourish.

One of the most vociferous has been Inderjit Singh Bindra, a former BCCI president, who claims to be preparing a report on match-fixing and wider corruption in cricket, and once famously claimed that Dalmiya is "in the grip of mafia and sharks".

Dalmiya has denied any allegations, claiming: "Bindra has nothing to do with the ICC. The ICC is dealing with the Indian board. It can't deal with individuals."

With Dalmiya due to step down as ICC president next month, those gathering under his chairmanship at Lord's will be hoping that the man who vowed to spread the game will now vow to clean it up. "There is no cover-up," he has insisted. "There should be no reason for that. If anything is happening . . . then it must be uravelled." The world is watching.

webTitle: Kiddy snatch league status from jaws of defeat

fields.headline: Kiddy snatch league status from jaws of defeat
fields.standfirst: Molby's men finally make it to the Third Division as Rushden result goes their way
fields.trailText: Woking 1 - 0 Kidderminster
fields.body:
Seldom can the joy of a 1-0 victory have been so lost in the joy of a 1-0 defeat. Both sides normally play in red and white halves and Kidderminster's wayward display suggested they had forgotten they had changed. At the end both sets of fans met in red and white concert in front of the main stand. Kiddy, the new champions, won that; Woking knew they still had work to do to avoid relegation.

Jan Molby, Kiddy's manager, said in March: "We'll not lose till we've won the league." He was right by a minute. After eight wins and a draw had pulled them all but out of Rushden's reach, news came in injury-time of the Diamonds' draw that confirmed Kidderminster, champions also in 1994, had made it to the League for the first time.

The great Dane, reclining on the bench like a beached whale for most of the match, rose like a barrage balloon tugged from its moorings. It's all over when the manager leaps. His chairman Lionel Newton, hot on Molby's mobile as the players jigged in the stand to their fans' acclaim, talked last summer of "giving it a go in three years". Molby has done it in one. The party continues today at Aggborough, where Forest Green Rovers are desperate visitors.

Molby had no need for modesty. "It's a fair reflection of the Conference; the best side won," he said. "It's the toughest promotion race in football." Rushden, pipped for the third year running, will not disagree: one up from 22 clubs, though the League is thinking of extending it to two.

"I'm proud," Molby went on in the scouse he picked up at Anfield. "It's a great achievement for me." In 1997 he took Swansea to the Third Division play-off final before being unseemly sacked by new owners. He claimed no magic formula from playing at Liverpool - just as well in view of what has happened to Steve McMahon, John Barnes and Ronnie Whelan. The answer, he thinks, lies in "passion" - or perhaps in his lucky green shorts. They could become as talismanic as Brian Clough's green sweater.

His team took 56 points out of 69 before the Kiddy car ran out of fuel on Saturday, only the second match lost since Mike Marsh, an Anfield team-mate, joined in November. Marsh says "Molby's coaching is good. He's still the best player in training. He's got everything and will go to the top."

Marsh cannot go with him even to the Third Division after taking a £m insurance pay-out for a knee injury. The same may apply to Ian Clarkson, who broke his leg with Northampton, though the forfeit would be less. Kiddy will need new players anyway, perhaps five. Newton, a furniture millionaire, will not leave them short but he laments the lack of support from big local business.

Marsh, unable to train full-time, is a fine advertisement for damaged goods, which may interest Manchester United. Molby said his influence was "massive". Marsh says he does "simple jobs, passing the ball. My signature is up for grabs." Mark Wright, another Liverpool man reviving Southport, should hurry; Marsh may prove a Conference talisman.

For Woking this was a third win running to silence Moaner's Corner. It was achieved by tight central defence and endorsed by Scott Steele's penalty. "We dug a 1-0 up," said their manager Colin Lippiatt. They are digging their pitch up next to lay new drainage. This is the one which once opened up, causing a match to be abandoned. Molby wisely stuck to the touchline.
