fields.headline: Bradford on the safe side
fields.standfirst:
Olsen factfile
Olsen's record
Olsen lashes players after sacking
fields.trailText: Bradford 3 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Bradford are still alive, Wimbledon merely livid. After dominating much of a tense, scrappy match yesterday Wimbledon went home with their Premiership status looking more precarious than ever.

A bizarre sequence of events led to a Bradford win which sent Wimbledon into the bottom three for the first time this season and Paul Jewell's team moved up to a place of safety for the first time this century. Now, whatever Wimbledon do, Bradford will stay up if they win their last two games.

Not that the denouement is likely to be that simple. For one thing Wimbledon have the easier fixtures: at home to an Aston Villa side with the FA Cup final on their minds followed by sleepy Southampton at the Dell. Bradford go to Leicester before Liverpool visit Valley Parade.

In addition, a smouldering sense of injustice at the manner of this defeat may provide the extra spur Wimbledon need.

Shortly before half-time they fell behind to the sort of home-town penalty which suggested the contest had been promoted by Don King. Early in the second half Bradford scored again, admittedly following a bad goalkeeping error by Neil Sullivan but with Wimbledon convinced that they should have had a free-kick for handball.

In the ensuing shemozzle John Hartson was sent off by Jeff Winter for foul and abusive language, and although Wimbledon still looked the superior side, even with 10 men, slack defending helped Bradford put the match beyond their reach.

This was Wimbledon's eighth successive league defeat. To a large extent they have dug the deepening hole in which they find themselves. Yet their approach to this game was much more like the Wimbledon of old with an emphasis on working the ball swiftly down the flanks, peppering the opposing goalmouth with swift, accurate crosses and forcing a dozen corners to Bradford's three.

As Bradford found themselves reduced to deep, desperate defence, clearing the ball to nowhere in particular and inviting Wimbledon to come straight back at them, Valley Parade sensed that even the side lying 17th might carry too much know-how.

Wimbledon should have gone ahead after 19 minutes when Matt Clarke failed to reach a corner from Michael Hughes and the ball fell to Jason Euell, who with all the goal to aim at lifted his shot high. On the half-hour Clarke again missed a corner and again the chance fell to Euell, who this time failed to make proper contact.

Bradford's first significant opportunity did not arrive until nine minutes before half-time when Dean Saunders, exploiting a lucky ricochet off the referee, outpaced the Wimbledon defence only to see Sullivan deflect his shot wide.

Then came the moment that may yet help to keep Bradford up and leave Wimbledon to contemplate life in the Nationwide League. As Ben Thatcher went to block Saunders the striker volleyed the ball against the defender and appealed for a corner. But on the say-so of a linesman, Ralph Bone from Orpington, the referee awarded Bradford a penalty from which Peter Beagrie scored.

Television replays showed that the ball had struck Thatcher on the upper arm from a distance of mere inches and that the defender, trying to keep his hands out of the way, had adopted a pose akin to the Venus de Milo. Wimbledon, therefore, were entitled to grumble, although it was a combination of indiscipline and incompetence which led to Bradford's second goal.

Wayne Jacobs did appear to handle the ball before releasing Beagrie, who turned inside a defender before seeing his low, bouncing shot beat Sullivan too easily for the goalkeeper's peace of mind. But as Terry Burton, Wimbledon's assistant manager, remarked later : "No matter how bad the decision you have to keep playing, and our players should have played on."

Not so Hartson, who was immediately dismissed for the bad-mouthing the other linesman. "I'm sorry to get sent off but I can't help what I am," Hartson explained. "I went across to the linesman to tell him it was a disgrace. Two scandalous decisions like that could cost us our Premier League status."

It could be argued that the bigger scandal was Hartson's behaviour since his presence was vital to Wimbledon's hopes of saving the game.

As it was, their last chance disappeared seven minutes from the end when Dean Windass beat first Thatcher and then the advancing Sullivan before scoring a goal that was preventable from a tight angle.

Wayne Jacobs did appear to handle the ball before releasing Beagrie, who turned inside a defender before seeing his low, bouncing shot beat Sullivan too easily for the goalkeeper's peace of mind. But as Terry Burton, Wimbledon's assistant manager, remarked later : "No matter how bad the decision you have to keep playing, and our players should have played on." Not so Hartson, who was immediately dismissed for the bad-mouthing the other linesman. "I'm sorry to get sent off but I can't help what I am," Hartson explained. "I went across to the linesman to tell him it was a disgrace. Two scandalous decisions like that could cost us our Premier League status." It could be argued that the bigger scandal was Hartson's behaviour since his presence was vital to Wimbledon's hopes of saving the game. As it was, their last chance disappeared seven minutes from the end when Dean Windass beat first Thatcher and then the advancing Sullivan before scoring a goal that was preventable from a tight angle.

fields.headline: Scotland round-up
fields.trailText:
Saints in heaven

St Mirren rolled back the years in winning the First Division, 23 years after claiming the same title under the guidance of the young and ambitious Alex Ferguson.
fields.body:
Saints in heaven

St Mirren rolled back the years in winning the First Division, 23 years after claiming the same title under the guidance of the young and ambitious Alex Ferguson.

Their current manager Tom Hendrie, formerly a schoolteacher, had written in the programme apologising for "ulcer-inducing football and nail-biting results". But they beat Raith Rovers 3-0 to spark wild celebrations among the 8,386 at Love Street, newly renovated to Scottish Premier League standards. Cheekily the players did a lap of honour in T-shirts proclaiming: "The bubble didn't burst." Mark Yardley, Steve McGarry and Brian McLaughlin scored the goals.

 Clyde won the Second Division title by beating Arbroath 4-1 and celebrated in front of the Gypsy Army, named after the years when the club were without a ground. "My grandad won a Second Division medal with Clyde in the 1950s; it's the greatest day of my life," said Pat Keogh, scorer of their third goal.

 The amateurs of Queen's Park will win the Third Division if they draw at Cowdenbeath on Saturday.

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText:
Big finish set up

Swansea and Rotherham both made sure of promotion to the Second Division on Saturday and their meeting next Saturday will be for the Third Division championship, a grandstand finish which may test the 11,514 capacity at Millmoor.
fields.body:
Big finish set up

Swansea and Rotherham both made sure of promotion to the Second Division on Saturday and their meeting next Saturday will be for the Third Division championship, a grandstand finish which may test the 11,514 capacity at Millmoor.

Swansea need only a draw to take the title, after a convincing 3-0 win at home to Exeter on Saturday, but a home victory by Rotherham, who stayed in second place with a 2-1 win at Hartlepool, would give them their first championship since they won the old Third Division in 1980-81. Swansea last won a title in 1948-49 when they took the Third Division South.

 Northampton will go up in the third automatic-promotion slot if they gain a point or better from their visit to Torquay on Saturday, but if they lose then Darlington, who have a much better goal difference, can snatch their place with a win at home to Lincoln City.

 Peterborough missed out on automatic promotion by slipping to their first defeat in eight games, against Torquay, but have a guaranteed play-off place with Barnet. Cheltenham, Hartlepool, Rochdale and Torquay all have a theoretical chance to take the other play-off spot.

 Shrewsbury need to beat Exeter away on Saturday to have any chance of staying in the league, but will go down anyway if Chester and Carlisle win at home to Peterborough and away at Brighton respectively.

fields.trailText:
Burnley boost
The champions Preston enjoyed a 3-2 win over Millwall at Deepdale that helped to send the south London side down to sixth, the last play-off place.
fields.body:
Burnley boost
The champions Preston enjoyed a 3-2 win over Millwall at Deepdale that helped to send the south London side down to sixth, the last play-off place.

 Burnley moved into second with a 2-0 home win over Cambridge United. Both goals came from Andy Payton, taking his season's tally to 27.

 Wigan slipped to third after their 1-0 home defeat by Wrexham, Karl Connolly scoring his ninth of the season. They are now equal on points with Gillingham who won 2-0 at home to Brentford with goals from Iffy Onuora and Steve Butler.

 Bristol Rovers missed the opportunity to make up much ground, only drawing 2-2 at home with Bournemouth. The veteran winger Mark Walters and Jamie Cureton scored for Rovers, Carl and Steve Fletcher for the Cherries.

 Bristol City came out on top 4-3 against Colchester at Layer Road. Colchester led 3-1 before goals by Alex Meechan, Mickey Bell and a Barry Ferguson own-goal took the points for City.

 Oxford United improved their chances of avoiding the drop with a 2-0 victory over Scunthorpe at the Manor Ground, a result that sends Scunthorpe down to the Third Division a year after they won promotion through the play-offs.

 Blackpool were also relegated after drawing 1-1 at Oldham. The Seasiders held the lead with a Clarke Carlisle goal until the final minute, when Ryan Sugden equalised.

fields.body:
Matias magic
The Spanish winger Pedro Matias ensured a climactic end to the season at the bottom of the table when his 13th-minute goal earned Walsall a 1-0 win at home to Portsmouth which kept alive their tenuous survival hopes.

The win brought them level on points with West Bromwich Albion but behind on goal difference, and they must now beat Ipswich - whose win at Charlton in turn ensured a thrilling climax at the top - to avoid the drop.

 West Brom remain favourites to stay up after they drew 0-0 at Queens Park Rangers. "I don't expect many people expected us to get a point down here," said their relieved manager Gary Megson.

 Crewe are still in danger of relegation after losing 3-1 at home to Bolton, whose win kept alive their hopes of a promotion play-off spot.

Premiership

Little was determined this weekend in the top flight. Derby would have been safe had they won at Tottenham, and neither Sunderland nor West Ham can qualify automatically for Europe after dropping points.
fields.body:
Premiership

Little was determined this weekend in the top flight. Derby would have been safe had they won at Tottenham, and neither Sunderland nor West Ham can qualify automatically for Europe after dropping points.

First Division

Ipswich's win keeps their promotion dreams alive, but Birmingham and Huddersfield both lost when wins would have secured a play-off berth. Walsall won but will be down if they fail to beat Ipswich next week.

Second Division

Blackpool and Scunthorpe were relegated after they drew and lost respectively. Wigan's defeat saw them overtaken by Burnley, who need only a draw on Saturday for promotion.

Third Division

Swansea and Rotherham both won and go up, and Barnet secured a play-off place. Shrewsbury lost and must win next week - and hope that other results go their way - to avoid relegation. Kidderminster are ready to take their place after winning the Conference.

fields.headline: McAllister the Red
fields.trailText: Having spent much of the season giving youth its head, the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier is preparing to add the vast experience of Coventry City's Gary McAllister to his squad.
fields.body:
Having spent much of the season giving youth its head, the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier is preparing to add the vast experience of Coventry City's Gary McAllister to his squad.

Although the former Scotland captain is very much in the twilight of his illustrious career at 35, Houllier is thought willing to offer him a 12-month contract which could net him as much as £1.5m in wages and signing-on fee.

McAllister's contract expires this summer, when he is entitled to a Bosman free transfer, and though City's manager Gordon Strachan is keen for him to remain at Highfield Road the veteran midfielder will be tempted by the lure of finishing his playing days with a club he has long admired.

Liverpool's interest, however, may well prompt Strachan to offer him either a vastly improved two-year deal or a place on the coaching staff.

McAllister is likely to delay an announcement for at least two months. Houllier would like to sign him in readiness for an anticipated assault on next season's Champions League, still a realistic target despite Saturday's defeat by Chelsea at Stamford Bridge.

The Liverpool manager acknowledges that he will have to buy four, possibly five players before next season. There also remains the possibility of at least one of his high-profile players departing, with Jamie Redknapp arguably having the most to lose should the manager opt for a Chelsea-style rotation system.

Blackburn Rovers' owner Jack Walker, meanwhile, is "making good progress" in his fight with cancer but will take a back seat until he recovers.

 The race for the Scudetto became closer yesterday when Juventus lost 2-0 at Verona while second-placed Lazio were winning 3-2 at home to Venezia to close the gap to two points. Juve now face a home game with Parma and a trip to Perugia while Lazio visit Bologna and entertain Reggina.

fields.headline: Anderson misses out
fields.trailText: Rachel Anderson, the players' agent who won a sex discrimination case last year after being turned away from the 1997 and 1998 Professional Footballers' Association awards dinners, missed out again last night.
fields.body:
Rachel Anderson, the players' agent who won a sex discrimination case last year after being turned away from the 1997 and 1998 Professional Footballers' Association awards dinners, missed out again last night.

Anderson, who has 31 players on her books, was not invited to the Grosvenor House hotel in London because the dinner was designated a private party. The PFA sold no invitations, as it usually does, but instead issued free tickets to members and guests who included some women, among them the sports minister Kate Hoey.

Last September's ruling left the PFA with a bill for £7,500 damages and £210,000 costs.

"I think Gordon Taylor, the chief executive, might have made it personal. This is a public function masquerading as a private party," Anderson said yesterday. "If I was a cynic I would suggest that this is the year they are inviting women as they recently said that women's football will be professional within three years."

webTitle: Time for Ferguson to open his eyes

fields.headline: Time for Ferguson to open his eyes
fields.trailText: Watford 2 - 3 Man Utd
fields.body:
Poor Sir Alex Ferguson, surely the only person among 20,000 who did not see the schoolboy scrap involving one of his players. If such bad luck continues, the Manchester United manager will start to feel he is jinxed. Perhaps he could fit a replay monitor in the dug-out.

It seemed harder to miss the fight which got Nicky Butt and Micah Hyde sent off than it would be to play bowls in the Silverstone car parks. Yet Ferguson "wasn't even looking towards it" and "didn't see it at all". Maybe so, though such bouts of myopia and misfortune leave Graham Taylor with a bitter taste.

"It falls upon us managers to see a little bit more than we say we see at certain times," Watford's manager said. "I think there's a responsibility on us sometimes to say it how it is. It's right in a lot of ways for managers to defend their players. But there are occasions when a manager has got to say: 'This is wrong'."

Taylor did as much with Hyde and his admirable sentiments are supported, for one, by Peter Reid. Earlier this season the Sunderland manager made no attempt to defend Alex Rae's elbow on Derby's Darryl Powell. On Friday he bemoaned the tendency of "other high-profile managers [to] bury their heads in the sand and say they did not see it".

Ferguson criticised his team's intimidation of the referee Andy d'Urso in January, amid photographs of bulging veins. But he is known for defending players to remarkable lengths. Arsène Wenger is similar.

The see-no-evil line is tedious and unconvincing, particularly as refereeing "errors" are generally spotted with eagle eyes. It gives the impression, too, that bad behaviour is not condemned. Behind the scenes it is safe to assume Butt will be taken to task.

It was an achievement by both players to be sent off 65 minutes into such a tepid match. Tenacity, more than skill, has carried Butt to the top but this was a reminder that his aggression is a liability as well as an asset. He was sent off at Chelsea after rising to Dennis Wise's bait and also saw red twice last term. Will Ferguson continue to tolerate his indiscipline?

After tackling Hyde by the touchline he lost his cool, first screaming at the referee, then shoving his opponent. Hyde retaliated, arms were swung and faces grabbed. Others joined the fun.

Before departing Butt yelled at a linesman, an incident not in the referee's report. Ferguson said the midfielder felt "hard done by," though it was hard to understand why. Provocation would hardly justify his actions and it is unlikely he was helpfully trying to remove a hornet from Hyde's shirt.

Butt's rashness helped United. Fired up by the dismissal and aided by the deeper role taken by Dwight Yorke, they turned 0-1 into 3-2. Several regulars preparing for Euro 2000 were rested; good for Kevin Keegan, a shame for "the genuine fan", Taylor said.

Within three minutes of the red cards Yorke equalised Heidar Helguson's header. Ryan Giggs lobbed United ahead and, although the exciting Tommy Smith brought Watford level, a Robert Page error let Jordi Cruyff in. Ferguson almost certainly saw that.

webTitle: Safety zone makes sinners out of Saints

fields.headline: Safety zone makes sinners out of Saints
fields.trailText: Southampton 1 - 2 Leicester
fields.body:
When a manager puts his players' futures on the line it is reasonable for him to expect a wholehearted response. Glenn Hoddle will be pleased that he does not have to go into a real battle with his players, after he asked them to play as if their lives depended on it and they responded with as abject a performance as they have produced all season.

His attempt to motivate his Southampton players for a final flourish after the relief of securing their Premiership status with an unfamiliar amount of time to spare was made after their tepid display at Derby a week ago. Defeat against Leicester, who had equally little to play for but showed considerably more willing, was no less undeserved.

If Hoddle remains true to his threat of a summer clear-out, on Saturday's display Southampton will struggle to field a seven-a-side team come August. The manager was rightly swingeing after his side fast receded following a sprightly opening when Hassan Kachloul opened the scoring with a deflected shot, but is likely to be told this week by the chairman Rupert Lowe that a summer spending spree to improve matters is not financially viable.

Yet the problems for Hoddle, who wishes to raise Southampton's aspirations, go deeper - psychology is needed, it seems.

"We looked like a side who were under the threat of relegation," he said after exchanging "a few strong words" with his players in the dressing room. "That's obviously not the case, so there's something mentally not right in there at the moment.

"Whether the players can't cope without the pressure of relegation I don't know, but it seems bizarre that they are performing as if there is a lot of pressure on ourselves, which is not the case."

The one saving grace for Hoddle and his players was that the dismissal of Dean Richards in stoppage-time for an alleged stamp on Robbie Savage meant that some of the home fans' loudly vented disgust was transferred to the referee Mike Reed.

Richards later denied stamping on the Leicester midfielder, claiming only that he had "kicked out in frustration as Savage held on to my leg". It was an understandable reaction to his side's display, given that Richards was one of the few Southampton players to emerge with any credit.

Marians Pahars vented his anger in a more constructive way. So fed up did the Latvian striker become with the failings of his team-mates that he tried to inspire them by doing everything on his own. The ploy did not succeed.

Southampton's midfield was overrun by Leicester's trio of Savage, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon. It was no surprise when Tony Cottee finished off good work from Steve Guppy and Matt Elliott to equalise. Though the winner was fortuitous, Neil Moss's attempted clearance rebounding off the on-rushing Izzet's backside to trickle over the line, the victory certainly was not.

fields.headline: Dobbo's omen of defeat
fields.trailText: West Ham 0 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
If Frank Dobson was hoping for a profitable afternoon he would have found his time better spent round at No11 helping the Blairs decorate the new baby's bedroom.

Instead New Labour's candidate for the post of London mayor dusted down his suit and wandered over to the East End to try to improve his ratings in the opinion polls before rounding off the day by watching his beloved West Ham.

The exercise may have scraped a few more votes but Dobbo's immediate reward was to witness West Ham's third home defeat of the season. At least it got him used to the feeling; Ken Livingstone will provide another on Thursday.

That was not in the original script, of course, and neither was West Ham's failure to take the points here, for they have an InterToto Cup place in their sights and had put five past Coventry the previous week. With the on-loan Frédéric Kanoute and Paulo Wanchope again up front and Paolo di Canio playing just behind them, the crowd were understandably confident. And even after a dire first half, in which Di Canio dithered and Frank Lampard and Wanchope missed chances, the feeling was that their team would still click.

Instead the heartily barracked but quietly effective Paul Ince - the Guv'nor tends to play better when a major tournament is approaching - and his able assistant Mark Summerbell increasingly put themselves about in midfield while Boro's stoic defence, with Steve Vickers in outstanding form, chased and threw themselves at everything.

Wanchope did hit the outside of a post with a header but they were already one down by then, and as the clock ticked down West Ham were reduced to trying their luck from distance.

Boro's one inspired moment produced the goal, Summerbell finding Juninho, who deftly flicked it back for the mid fielder to free Andy Campbell. The young forward advanced and knocked the ball beyond Ian Feuer, who promptly clipped his ankles. Brian Deane sent the goalkeeper the wrong way from the penalty spot.

webTitle: Derby on the up as Ginola mourns past

fields.headline: Derby on the up as Ginola mourns past
fields.trailText: Tottenham 1 - 1 Derby
fields.byline: Russell Thomas at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham can only hope that Sol Campbell at this stage next season is not feeling the acute frustration that David Ginola feels now. For that will mean the club are just as far away from the English elite as they looked here against a 10-man Derby County still not entirely free of relegation fear.

The Frenchman may have been 1999's double player of the year but bitterly regrets his five-year English career, saying his talents have been wasted at Newcastle and now Spurs. His second successive substitution at home will only reinforce his view. The derision that greeted Stewart Houston's decision suggests Ginola's belief has the strong support of the White Hart Lane customers.

Ginola was balked at every turn on Saturday: by Derby's deep defence, by the stand-in manager and, finally, by car-park congestion as he attempted to drive away just after the final whistle. He had walked off the pitch, a picture of anger and bemusement, after time was called on the No14 in the 70th minute.

He gesticulated, muttered and studiously avoided Houston before pointing back to the bench as he entered the tunnel. It was a gesture saying: "Don't expect me to sit there."

He had a point, his creative if fitful ability again standing out in a team outplayed for long periods by Derby. But, quite apart from his comments, Ginola's age - 33 - and Houston's explanation of his decision hardly enhance the Frenchman's long-term prospects at Spurs.

"I wanted to give the youngsters a chance," said Houston. "If David wants to come and see me on Monday, that's fine." He added that the substitute, Matthew Etherington, 18, "has done very well for this club since he's been here".

Whether Ginola is a misunderstood genius or his own worst enemy, his message is clear: never undersell yourself. "When I look at the past and I think about my quality, I really deserve to have played in a really top team," he said. "I will not say Newcastle and Tottenham are not big teams but when I talk about big I mean AC Milan, Barcelona, Manchester United."

He and Campbell share little other than a Spurs shirt but Ginola's words may strike a chord with a 25-year-old, who will probably have to move, at £15m or more, to United - or Italy - to realise his ambitions. The captain wants his future settled before Euro 2000.

Jim Smith was also frustrated, protesting to Neale Barry at half-time over the sending-off of Stefan Schnoor, shown two of the 11 yellow cards flourished by the referee. Derby's manager was banished from the dug-out and revealed he was being reported to the FA, but continued his attack.

"It's very difficult, 10 against 12," he said. "He's a bad referee; I said that before the game and he didn't disappoint me. It's poor refereeing, it costs people jobs and costs people games. The lads were magnificent but they were cheated."

Five other Derby players and four Tottenham men were booked. Horacio Carbonari volleyed in during Derby's second-half ascendancy and Stephen Clemence equalised in stoppage-time with a backheel of Ginola-esque flair, muting the booing at the final whistle.

webTitle: Wednesday one step from the fall

fields.headline: Wednesday one step from the fall
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 0 - 3 Leeds
fields.body:
It may not be over until the fat lady sings but in the case of Sheffield Wednesday the dreaded diva is already waddling on to the stage, microphone in hand.

The pecking order of Yorkshire football was emphatically brought home yesterday and the fall-out leaves Wednesday needing a snooker or two in their seemingly hopeless pursuit of survival.

Another demoralising nul point, coupled with Bradford seizing the moment against Wimbledon, casts Hillsborough's sorry occupants six points adrift with an inferior goal difference and the clock ticking down.

To stand any chance of defying the prophets of gloom they must realistically take seven, if not nine points from their remaining three games. However, trips to Coventry and Arsenal, both of whom boast formidable home records, before the curtain comes down against Leicester City, hardly inspire unbridled optimism for a side that cannot go much longer teetering on the precipice.

As the whiff of relegation descended over a sparsely-populated Hillsborough the thought occurred that any side that musters 30 goals from 35 league games - the worst record in all four divisions - can hardly bristle with a smouldering sense of injustice at their impending fate.

Only 38 seconds had elapsed before the Wednesday band had lost its oomph and the home defenders were casting accusing looks in each other's direction.

They had read Michael Bridges' intentions as he worked a shooting opportunity from just outside the penalty area, but in converging on the young striker the rest of their marking was hospitable to say the least. Bridges was grounded in a tangle of legs but still managed to pick out the craggy features of David Hopkin, bounding into the penalty area, and the midfielder's first touch left the ball nestling in the corner of Kevin Pressman's net.

The home side rallied briefly but seldom threatened with any conviction. Wim Jonk floated a free-kick narrowly wide and Alan Quinn brought a fine one-handed save from Nigel Martyn. But their leading scorer Gilles de Bilde was a peripheral figure and Andy Booth his usual leaden-footed self.

Leeds were seldom illuminating but still managed to outshine their opponents for long periods of a match that burned slowly without truly igniting. The large pitch suited their elaborate methods and seven minutes after the interval they doubled their advantage courtesy of Bridges' 19th goal in his first Premiership season. Matthew Jones took the ball off Barry Horne and Bridges accepted his pass on the left-hand side of the penalty area before curling a right-foot shot into the opposite corner.

The pièce de résistance, however, was conjured up by the impudent Harry Kewell midway through the second half. His shot with the outside of his left boot was audacious in its method and exquisite in its delivery, catching Pressman off his line and finding the net via the underside of the crossbar.

Afterwards Peter Shreeves was in straw-clutching mode but his optimism was not contagious. "We must believe we can beat Coventry and Leicester and get something from Highbury," said Wednesday's acting manager. "While there is still a chance we have to remain positive."

Although Leeds have been stumbling across the finishing line like a pantomime horse, this being their first victory in nine matches, David O'Leary's summer pursuit of new players should incorporate the need for them to possess a valid passport. They are back in fourth place, leapfrogging Chelsea with a game in hand, and a third successive European campaign beckons.

"It would be a crying shame if we didn't get into the Uefa Cup at least," said their manager. Somewhat preposterously, Wednesday could join them if the Fair Play League qualifying draw goes their way.

fields.headline: Wolves keep up the pressure
fields.trailText: Wolves 3 - 0 Fulham
fields.body:
Victory for Wolves yesterday has made the scramble to leave the First Division even more intriguing than the skirmish to stay in it at the other end of the table with four teams harbouring hopes of occupying one of the two vacant places in the play-off zone.

Birmingham City, Huddersfield Town, Wolves and Bolton Wanderers are still in contention and all permutations as to filling the two places are possible, bar one.

Wolves and Bolton cannot both qualify because they meet each other at the Reebok Stadium on Wednesday.

Wolves' gruesome away record - they have won once in their last six outings, losing the other five - does not augur well. But if they can replicate the form that brushed away an off-colour Fulham side, the division's other Wanderers will be hard-pressed to hold them.

Pivotal to their chances must be the fitness of the Danish midfielder Allan Neilsen. Wolves took something of a flyer when they paid Spurs a reported £50,000 loan fee to keep Neilsen at Molineux for another month to boost their chances of the play-offs.

Had Saturday's results gone against Wolves and defeat by Fulham followed, the punt would have been in grave danger of going down the pan. In the event it was Neilsen who struck first yesterday to ensure the wager remains in play.

A succession of penetrating moves down both flanks were followed by high-quality crosses but the head work of Ade Akinbiyi and Neil Emblen did not match the sort that had gone into creating the opportunities.

Their efforts were either weak or wayward before Neilsen showed how headers should be executed. That he was on the pitch to do so owed much to the persuasive powers of Wolves' manager Colin Lee.

"Neilsen suffered a calf injury against Barnsley last week and missed Denmark's international on Wednesday because of it," Lee explained. "It troubled him again today and he wanted to come off at half-time. I persuaded him to stay on and give me another 10 minutes of his best."

After four of them Neilsen, 12 yards from goal, stooped to head home Darren Bazeley's right-wing corner and Wolves were on their way.

Kevin Muscat added the second from the penalty spot 10 minutes later after the impressive Michael Branch had been sent tumbling by Terry Phelan but not even that seemed to rouse Fulham, not in the footballing sense anyway.

While their efforts at breaking down the resolute Wolves defence were largely ineffective, Fulham did pack a punch of an unacceptable kind.

Even the club's PR guru Max Clifford would be hard-pushed to put a positive spin on two crunching challenges by Gus Uhlembeek, an apparent elbowing of Ludo Pollet by Geoff Horsfield and why Paul Peschisolido appeared to go to ground every time Muscat curled his lip at him.

The defeat became even more comprehensive in the dying seconds when Maik Taylor's clearance was returned past him by Scott Taylor for the third.

webTitle: Wenger is cheered by old pals' act

fields.headline: Wenger is cheered by old pals' act
fields.standfirst: Everton 0 - 1 Arsenal
fields.trailText: Title-race intrigue having long since evaporated, Arsenal gained an important advantage in the contest for second place and the automatic passage it provides into the Champions League.
fields.body:
Title-race intrigue having long since evaporated, Arsenal gained an important advantage in the contest for second place and the automatic passage it provides into the Champions League.

Ten successive victories in all competitions, a characteristic late-season Arsenal surge, signals Arsène Wenger's side as the undoubted form team of the moment, as their comprehensive win over an Everton side beaten at home only once in more than a year indicated.

There is a hunger and eagerness about Arsenal which was manifested at Goodison in an absorbing, often brutal, contest between Martin Keown and Mark Hughes which should have carried with it a parental-discretion advisory, and in the energy and steel the Gunners showed in midfield.

So emphatic was this victory that it begged the question of how a Manchester United side arguably inferior to last season's, and certainly no better, can have built a 19-point advantage over Arsenal and the chasing pack.

Wenger argued, without much conviction, that the close title contests of the previous two campaigns were a truer indication of the standings of the Premiership's leading teams, then remounted his current hobbyhorse that United's non-involvement in the FA Cup set them up for their record-breaking league success. It is a moot point, but the fact remains that for Arsenal a season which until fairly recently looked like fizzling out may now conclude with victory in the Uefa Cup final and a runners-up place in the league.

"It is very important to finish second," said Wenger. "It would put us straight into the Champions League, which is vital. After winning the championship, second is the best possible position and you could see that from the way we played against Everton. We will fight for that position until the last second of the season."

It is a rallying cry which has been adopted by Wenger's side, who now stand four wins shy of the 12-year-old club record of 14 consecutive victories.

Without the injured Thierry Henry, their leading scorer, and with Patrick Vieira limited to a late substitute appearance because of his own fitness problem, Emmanuel Petit was redoubtable in midfield and Marc Overmars unstoppable in attack, his goal the result of a committed run and fine finish from Dennis Bergkamp's intelligent pass. And then, of course, there is the back four.

How perverse that whereas United's defensive shortcomings were their Achilles heel in Europe this year, Arsenal's back line shows few, if any, signs of losing its grip, as a 10-goal edge over United in the goals-against column testifies.

Wenger certainly believes that Keown and Tony Adams, both 33, and David Seaman, 36, should form the cornerstone of Kevin Keegan's England team this summer, as they will Arsenal's European campaign next season.

"Martin and Tony had outstanding games and if I were English I would be confident if all three were playing for the national team," said Wenger. "They read the game so well, they know each other well and when you look at the best defenders all over Europe they are over 30. I believe they are the best English pairing and having them around is a huge advantage because in international competition sometimes not conceding a goal is one step better than scoring one.

"Age played against age out there and it was a huge battle between Keown and Hughes. The older they get the tougher they get and it was a match within a match especially in the first half. I was almost scared; I thought one of them might lose their nerve."

All Keown and Adams have to ensure is that Arsenal hold their nerve for the remaining four games of the season.

fields.headline: Swans glide high and deliver
fields.trailText: Swansea 3 - 0 Exeter
fields.body:
In obedience to a tradition even more hoary than the Vetch, the Tannoy announced before kick-off that a spectator's wife had just gone into labour.

Swansea then delivered promotion, with no pain and much more style than the occasion or their reputation called for. They were two up in 23 minutes from confidently struck goals, then made certain when Jason Price's mis-hit volley scurried into the net off an Exeter defender. Next Saturday they go to Rotherham to decide the championship.

Without the 6ft 5in Julian Alsop to aim at, the Swans looked almost elegant. Walter Boyd, flitting across the field in scarlet satin slippers like a Jamaican Oscar Wilde, made dull wits of all the visitors.

Swansea's defence allowed them no hope of a comeback and Roger Freestone earned his club-record 22nd clean sheet of the season without having to make a save.

The formidable Matthew Bound and Nick Cusack, a 35-year-old driving force in midfield, are the only Swans to have been selected for the PFA's Third Division team of the season. Swansea are meant to be a side without stars whose willingness to work hard and for each other is reflected in harmonious off-field relationships.

"They're growing together," the manager John Hollins said. "They're all good guys and they work their legs off."

If he can keep Boyd and Bound, they should do rather better in the Second Division than other recently promoted sides. And if Hollins can be persuaded to stay on after the move to the Morfa stadium next year, they may be capable of even more.

"It's absolutely tremendous to play for a manager like that," Cusack said. "He's tactically tremendous, his man-management is terrific and he never panics."

Not even when invited to strip. Hollins declined to toss his kit out into the throng, indicating that his body was no longer suitable for tea-time viewing. In obedience to hoary tradition, the fans responded with a chorus of "you fat bastard", confident that the rest of the club is in better shape.

"He's tactically tremendous, his man-management is terrific and he never panics." Not even when invited to strip. Hollins declined to toss his kit out into the throng, indicating that his body was no longer suitable for tea-time viewing. In obedience to hoary tradition, the fans responded with a chorus of "you fat bastard", confident that the rest of the club is in better shape.
fields.bylineHtml: Robert Pryce at Vetch Field

fields.headline: Stoke fans in more trouble
fields.trailText: Stoke 2 - 1 Cardiff
fields.byline: David Plummer at the Britannia Stadium
fields.body:
Crowd trouble marred a Stoke game for the second time in as many months when Cardiff fans broke through security netting here yesterday and in the melee, seats were ripped up and thrown on to the pitch. Early in the second half 300 visiting fans clashed with the home supporters, and police in riot gear and on horseback had to restore order.

The ugly scenes come hot on the heels of the Stoke fans' pitch invasion at Wigan on the day the late Sir Stanley Matthews was being honoured around the country. The FA is investigating that incident.

On the pitch Stoke made light work of seeing off struggling Cardiff, with Scott Young's strike for the visitors the merest of replies. Stoke's brace from Arnar Gunnlaugsson and James O'Connor put further pressure on Millwall in the scramble for the play-offs. They are level with the Londoners on points and goal difference, with a game in hand.

It also condemned Cardiff to freefall and they need at least a win and a draw in their remaining last two games to catch Oxford United, for whom a win in their last game will do.

At Deepdale on Saturday, Millwall learned that these tense final weeks of the season are not the best time to forge a reputation for staging valiant yet ultimately futile fightbacks. The previous week Millwall came within a whisker of recovering a four-goal deficit at Burnley. Back in Lancashire they handed the champions Preston a three-goal first-half advantage but again fell agonisingly short of a valuable point.

Millwall's return of one point from three games is looking costly. Their manager Keith Stevens inspired his charges with a stirring half time talk but their defending was way too generous.

Stevens said: "We've said all along that we'll worry about our own results and not what everyone else is doing. But now we're in the position of having to rely on other people."

Preston's championship celebrations were given a boost when David Eyres' free-kick went past Tony Warner after just 30 seconds. Michael Jackson added another and, with the interval looming, Brett Angell made it three. Within eight minutes of half-time Paul Ifill and Lucas Neill had reduced the deficit, but the rally ended there.

webTitle: Robson puts Lee in England frame

fields.headline: Robson puts Lee in England frame
fields.trailText: Newcastle 2 - 0 Coventry
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
"I don't want to tell Kevin Keegan/Craig Brown/Dino Zoff how to do their job but ..." When Premiership managers say that, you know one of their players is about to be put forward for international recognition. If Newcastle's Bobby Robson is the manager concerned, it pays to listen.

Robert Lee, aged 34 and brutally written off by Ruud Gullit only six months ago, has emerged as an outrageous long-shot for inclusion in Keegan's squad for Euro 2000.

What a glorious irony if Gullit, back home in Holland, found himself commentating on a player who was not deemed worthy of a shirt number under his Newcastle regime. It could happen. A long-term injury to David Batty has reduced Keegan's options as he looks for somebody to anchor his midfield with a mixture of strength, mobility and intelligence.

Lee, faultless in this Newcastle win, fits the bill and is arguably playing better than when he was a regular in the England squad. "I don't have to recommend him to Kevin Keegan," said Robson. (Cue the job reference). "Kevin knows what he can do - after all, he bought him while at Newcastle. There's not a better midfield player in his role in the country. He's one of England's most constructive players, keeps things simple and keeps us ticking over.

"Rob has been sensational for us and it would cost a lot of money for me to buy a player better than him. He would have to be a top-drawer midfield star."

Lee insists his own horizons do not extend beyond Tyneside, although he has conceivably forced himself into Keegan's thinking with performances destined to earn him an extra year on a contract that expires at the end of next season.

Robson disclosed that Newcastle are now negotiating a deal that will extend Lee's stay at the club to a decade and earn him a lucrative testimonial.

The 29 goals of Lee's pal Alan Shearer - his best-ever return for Newcastle - have been even more significant and he took his career total to 299 with a 78th-minute penalty.

Diego Gavilan, the promising Paraguayan teenager, added the second goal in the 84th minute to show why Robson is inclined to sell Nolberto Solano in the summer.

The harsh hand-ball decision against Noel Whelan which led to the penalty and shaped the outcome did not even warrant a moan from the Coventry manager Gordon Strachan.

He pondered on why his team have failed to win away this season but his own failure to get more from a reasonably talented squad is also a suitable subject for debate. "You'd think we'd make more chances and make it more exciting," admitted Strachan, whose players can still claim that elusive away win at Watford on the final day of the season.

webTitle: Ipswich turn into masters of suspense

fields.headline: Ipswich turn into masters of suspense
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 3 Ipswich
fields.body:
The war of nerves continues. Ipswich Town have ensured a week of sleepless nights on Moss Side by seeing off the champions Charlton in some style and making sure that the second automatic promotion place will not be settled until the last day of the season.

The scenario is as follows. At 1.30pm next Sunday Ipswich will kick off against Walsall knowing that only a win will do. They are two points behind Manchester City in second place with an inferior goal difference. Ipswich have the home advantage, but Walsall need at least a point themselves to avoid relegation.

City are away to Blackburn Rovers, who on paper have nothing to play for. But their players have been complaining that Graeme Souness has been putting the fear of God into them and so pity that poor Rover who has to return to the dressing room having not sweated blood for his manager. "Anything can happen," the Ipswich manager George Burley said.

The whole appeal of English football is based on these situations being impossible to call: who knows which way the dice will fall? Similarly, everyone thinks that, should Ipswich have to settle for the play-offs, then they are likely to struggle, but even that is not certain.

They have made the last three and been knocked out in the semi-finals but the experience should stand them in good stead and now is as good a time as any to shake off their "nearly men" tag.

"Many pundits say if we get in the play-offs we've got no chance because of some sort of mental block, but I don't agree," the Ipswich captain Matt Holland said.

"Our particular problem has been getting over the disappointment of missing automatic promotion. If we do finish third, then we have to look on the positive side: a lot of teams would love to be in our position and we can beat anyone we come up against."

Charlton would vouch for that. Defeat on Saturday meant Ipswich had done the double over the awesome Addicks this season, a feat worthy of automatic promotion in itself.

Charlton managed to make life difficult for the visitors until David Johnson whacked in their second goal in the 58th minute, after which home thoughts turned to the after-match presentation of the First Division trophy.

Jim Magilton had a field day for Ipswich, opening the scoring with a curling free-kick, setting up Johnson and then creating Martijn Reuser's tapped-in third goal. Andy Hunt's late header was a consolation for Charlton.

The season seemed to have caught up with their deflated manager Alan Curbishley. He refused to comment on rumours that he was about to sign a new player, possibly Teddy Sheringham, saying that "it would be disrespectful to the people who got us where we are". But both Ipswich and Charlton are lacking a striker who can carry them through a Premiership campaign.

At least Charlton are already thinking like a Premiership club: their match programme cost a whopping £3.

fields.headline: Gregory's tinkering distracts Villa
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 1 Sunderland
fields.body:
We are all actors when it suits us, and John Gregory was hamming it up with gloom something rotten after this less than riveting draw which was, in both essence and execution, a metaphor for Premiership life outside the elite.

Sunderland have every reason to be pleased with their position in the table, even if the early-season butter which was spread so thickly has, since Christmas, been reduced to a few scrapings.

Villa, by contrast, have turned around an indifferent start, when Gregory's job appeared threatened, but now need to win the FA Cup, or weasel into Europe via Chelsea's Premiership position, in order to convince themselves that some progress has been made.

Gregory's post-match despond was laughable. "We blew it ... Four points lost in two games ... Too many mistakes." Yet here was a man three weeks away from Wembley, and the high point of his short managerial career. Who could possibly take such maudlin ramblings seriously?

His brow furrowed, Gregory finally conceded that he would "fall back on the good points". Better than his sword, but much more of this forced despair and the pre-Wembley mind games he is obviously playing may be horribly misinterpreted. Footballers are simple souls, and Gregory's attempts to give everybody a crack of the Wembley whip appears to be inducing a somewhat hesitant, introverted response within his side. Perhaps they see it as a lack of conviction by their manager.

The big bonus for Gregory was the return of Gareth Southgate, whose presence had much to do with Kevin Phillips's anonymity. But if this was an encouragement, Ugo Ehiogu's guileless and abortive lunge at Niall Quinn, who then deftly turned in Nicky Summerbee's low corner, was a genuine reason for Gregory to get out the worry beads despite Gareth Barry's opener on the hour.

With the vast areas of Wembley to defend, no manager wants to see a key player make this sort of mistake; and neither does he want to see another player, whom he has misgivings about anyway, so out of touch, namely Benito Carbone.

Paul Merson, for all his sudden surges, was also bereft of that final cutting edge and when he was off the field he received telephonic instructions from Gregory in the stand. Of course, the one call that Merson would dearly love to receive is from Kevin Keegan, and this despite his self-imposed international retirement.

Peter Reid's summer is already sketched out, and it does not include the InterToto Cup. He wants his players refreshed and replenished. He also needs more of them, and of a higher quality, for the pressure on the Sunderland manager and players alike will be far more acute next season.

As for Gregory, he must surely now play his most decisive hand in the remaining matches against Wimbledon and Manchester United. Currently his efforts to give everybody a chance to prove themselves prior to Wembley look counterproductive.

webTitle: Bruce's world closes in on him

fields.headline: Bruce's world closes in on him
fields.trailText: Huddersfield 0 - 2 Stockport
fields.byline: Dave Alexander at the McAlpine stadium
fields.body:
Stockport's manager Andy Kilner was expecting free tea and sandwiches and an after-match drink on the clubhouse when he reported for cricket duty yesterday after watching his players hit Huddersfield's promotion hopes for six.

The surprise result keeps Bolton and Wolves, who meet on Wednesday, in contention for the play-offs and Kilner the cricketer revealed with a smile: "I play in the Bolton League, so I don't anticipate having to pay this time."

For Steve Bruce, however, the holiday break is less pleasurable as he contemplates the shattering prospect of not even being in the play-off lottery after holding a top-six ticket for almost the entire season.

The Huddersfield manager, unused to failure as a player, struggled to contain his disappointment after watching his players write another suicide note instead of completing a Premiership application.

"The players have worked unbelievably hard to get into this position and the great thing is it's still in our own hands," said Bruce. "But this is a terrible, terrible result for us. It's going to be a horrible weekend and a long bank holiday.

"Whatever the level, you can't do this. It was schoolboy stuff, elementary. Everyone is edgy, the supporters are nervous and mistakes follow. That's why you don't get flowing football at this stage."

Huddersfield's last three home games have yielded no goals and one point - with five goals conceded - and on Saturday they again handed their opponents a start that pitched the stadium into a state of anxiety. Caught cold by Kevin Cooper's strike in the fourth minute, they were stunned by a Craig Armstrong own-goal eight minutes later and failed to recover from what were basic errors.

They visit Fulham on Sunday and their scoring record of 19 goals in 22 away league games suggests there is no room for any more defensive gaffes. "We've got to take this on the chin, pick ourselves up and try to get the result," said Bruce.

But he faces major injury problems, with the defender Ken Monkou out again after limping off with an injured hamstring. "We've got five or six missing and we can't afford it," he admitted.

fields.headline: Bassett plays cool card
fields.trailText: Swindon 1 - 2 Barnsley
fields.byline: Ian Prior  at the County Ground
fields.body:
Dave Bassett has made a career of shaping teams in his own bristly image, bolshie sides that have hustled and barged their way to the seven promotions notched on his managerial belt.

Barnsley are a Bassett kind of club whom, despite the perhaps silkier qualities of Ipswich or Manchester City, the other teams in the play-offs shake-up would probably rather avoid in the first leg.

What should be a comfortable home fixture against Crewe next Sunday completes their regular season. Injury-free and scoring fluently, the Tykes are pervaded with a cautious optimism.

"We got what we deserved and let's hope we can carry that form into the play-offs, whoever that may be against," said Bassett after Saturday's formality, with the air of a man for whom such situations are so commonplace as to negate the need for grandiose statements of intent.

Barnsley did what they needed to do with ease against a Swindon side worn out by the ravages of relegation and penury, barely capable of playing even for pride.

Matt Appleby's neat side-foot and a sweet lob from Mike Sheron did the damage after numerous acrobatics from Swindon's goalkeeper Steve Mildenhall had frustrated Barnsley throughout the opening period. The substitute James Williams gave the home side brief hope but it was far more than they deserved.

Barnsley will have their top scorer Craig Hignett and the South African midfielder Eric Tinkler, both rested here, back for the play-offs. With fresh legs and Bassett's know-how at the helm, what price another season in the sun for Oakwell's faithful?

webTitle: Vialli vows to achieve home rule next year

fields.headline: Vialli vows to achieve home rule next year
fields.trailText: Chelsea 2 - 0 Liverpool
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli has been in English football long enough to know the dubious value of a chairman's vote of confidence. Which is why the Chelsea manager had to laugh as he shared the outcome of last week's meeting with Ken Bates.

"I'm about 100% sure that he is quite happy about what I am doing," he said with 75% certainty and a knowing giggle.

Thankfully for Vialli, faith in his ability to meet the challenge at Stamford Bridge was lent timely support by a Chelsea performance which reminded everyone just how good this team can be when they put their minds to it.

A big game and a Vialli ear-bashing woke Chelsea from their post-Barcelona blues, sparking the sort of all-tackling, all-dancing display that had overwhelmed Barcelona at home.

Liverpool's Grard Houllier was left to muse on the work that still must be done before his young team are equipped to turn potential into trophies. Vialli too faces a summer of contemplation after confirming that Chelsea's priority next season will be the Premiership, even if they qualify for the Champions League.

The team's positive reaction to his fusillade of home truths last week was an encouraging sign that he still wields influence in the dressing room. But the professionalism and commitment of Chelsea's pampered millionaires must be questioned if they only turn it on when confronted with big games and managerial threats.

For the Premiership, Vialli needs players prepared to battle it out at the Valley rather than count mountains of cash. Younger legs and stouter hearts will be drafted in. The absence of Dan Petrescu and Didier Deschamps from Saturday's squad already hints at who will be sold.

Perverse as it sounds, Chelsea's Premiership aims next season would also be improved if they did fail to qualify for the Champions League. Vialli knows better than most how a dalliance in Europe can turn into a fatal distraction. Liverpool, absent totally from Europe this season, will end up playing 43 games in total compared with Chelsea's tiring 61.

It would serve Chelsea's purposes better to qualify for the less demanding Uefa Cup via fourth place in the table or victory in the FA Cup final. The term "football is a funny old game" was surely invented for situations such as this. In what other sport is it tempting to finish lower in the table?

Liverpool face a similar no-win situation, a sort of Catch-44. For if Houllier's team qualify for next season's Champions League - they must beat Leicester on Wednesday to stay on track - the extra fixtures will almost certainly scupper their hope of the Premiership title.

Based on this season's experience, Vialli is clear on his priorities. "The Premiership is our main target next season, even if Europe is more prestigious and financially important."

Strangely for the team with the Premiership's best defensive record, it was sloppiness at the back which contributed to Liverpool's defeat.

After two minutes Chelsea's Mario Melchiot won the ball with a tackle typical of his side's commitment and fed Roberto di Matteo. He found George Weah, who did not misuse the space he was allowed and slotted the ball home.

Chelsea added a second on 14 minutes. Weah, his pace and presence all afternoon only strengthening Vialli's desire to retain him for next season, caught the Liverpool defence napping with the speed and accuracy of a pass to Di Matteo which gave the rejuvenated Italian time to pick his spot.

Liverpool huffed and puffed but hardly troubled Ed de Goey. The only good news was that Jamie Redknapp and Robbie Fowler made it through two more comeback stints. However, Steven Gerrard limped off with a groin injury which may threaten his Euro 2000 dreams.

Which is why the Chelsea manager had to laugh as he shared the outcome of last week's meeting with Ken Bates. "I'm about 100% sure that he is quite happy about what I am doing," he said with 75% certainty and a knowing giggle. Thankfully for Vialli, faith in his ability to meet the challenge at Stamford Bridge was lent timely support by a Chelsea performance which reminded everyone just how good this team can be when they put their minds to it. A big game and a Vialli ear-bashing woke Chelsea from their post-Barcelona blues, sparking the sort of all-tackling, all-dancing display that had overwhelmed Barcelona at home. Liverpool's Grard Houllier was left to muse on the work that still must be done before his young team are equipped to turn potential into trophies. Vialli too faces a summer of contemplation after confirming that Chelsea's priority next season will be the Premiership, even if they qualify for the Champions League. The team's positive reaction to his fusillade of home truths last week was an encouraging sign that he still wields influence in the dressing room. But the professionalism and commitment of Chelsea's pampered millionaires must be questioned if they only turn it on when confronted with big games and managerial threats. For the Premiership, Vialli needs players prepared to battle it out at the Valley rather than count mountains of cash. Younger legs and stouter hearts will be drafted in. The absence of Dan Petrescu and Didier Deschamps from Saturday's squad already hints at who will be sold. Perverse as it sounds, Chelsea's Premiership aims next season would also be improved if they did fail to qualify for the Champions League. Vialli knows better than most how a dalliance in Europe can turn into a fatal distraction. Liverpool, absent totally from Europe this season, will end up playing 43 games in total compared with Chelsea's tiring 61. It would serve Chelsea's purposes better to qualify for the less demanding Uefa Cup via fourth place in the table or victory in the FA Cup final. The term "football is a funny old game" was surely invented for situations such as this. In what other sport is it tempting to finish lower in the table? Liverpool face a similar no-win situation, a sort of Catch-44. For if Houllier's team qualify for next season's Champions League - they must beat Leicester on Wednesday to stay on track - the extra fixtures will almost certainly scupper their hope of the Premiership title. Based on this season's experience, Vialli is clear on his priorities. "The Premiership is our main target next season, even if Europe is more prestigious and financially important." Strangely for the team with the Premiership's best defensive record, it was sloppiness at the back which contributed to Liverpool's defeat. After two minutes Chelsea's Mario Melchiot won the ball with a tackle typical of his side's commitment and fed Roberto di Matteo. He found George Weah, who did not misuse the space he was allowed and slotted the ball home. Chelsea added a second on 14 minutes. Weah, his pace and presence all afternoon only strengthening Vialli's desire to retain him for next season, caught the Liverpool defence napping with the speed and accuracy of a pass to Di Matteo which gave the rejuvenated Italian time to pick his spot. Liverpool huffed and puffed but hardly troubled Ed de Goey. The only good news was that Jamie Redknapp and Robbie Fowler made it through two more comeback stints. However, Steven Gerrard limped off with a groin injury which may threaten his Euro 2000 dreams.

webTitle: Olsen down and out at Plough Lane

fields.headline: Olsen down and out at Plough Lane
fields.trailText: Wimbledon boss Egil Olsen paid the price for losing the respect of his players and failing to halt the club's dramatic dive into the Premiership relegation zone as he was sacked with just two games of the season left.
fields.body:
Wimbledon boss Egil Olsen paid the price for losing the respect of his players and failing to halt the club's dramatic dive into the Premiership relegation zone as he was sacked with just two games of the season left.

Assistant boss Terry Burton, who was only promoted from being academy director towards the end of last month, will replace him for those last two matches of the campaign in a desperate bid to avoid the drop.

The club's Norwegian owners insisted the move was not fuelled by panic and indeed was not due to the constant and almost unprecedented criticism of maverick compatriot Olsen, who only took charge last summer, and his tactics by his players.

However, it is clear that a crisis was descending on Wimbledon when they not only lost 3-0 away to relegation rivals Bradford to fall into the drop zone but then striker John Hartson called for a change of manager this summer.

Hartson was certainly not the first Dons player to speak out this season, with Carl Cort and Michael Hughes - among others - already having made their frustrations abundantly clear.

And given that Burton, former boss Joe Kinnear's number two, was apparently promoted after appeals from the squad, it is hard to resist the conclusion that player power simply became irresistible.

Wimbledon only have those two games left - at home to Aston Villa and away to Southampton - in which to rescue themselves from a run of eight consecutive defeats and a crisis in confidence.

Otherwise the Dons' 14-year fairytale stay in the top flight, which has encompassed a memorable 1988 FA Cup triumph against Liverpool - just 11 years after being elected from non-League football into Division Four - will come to an end.

And despite the multi-million pound backing of their owners, the prospects for a team without a home of their own, with a small following and with the prospect of losing a host of star names this summer if they go down, hardly bear thinking about.

Chairman Bjarne Rune Gjelsten, who had a lengthy meeting with Olsen this morning in the wake of the 3-0 defeat at Bradford, simply declared: "Relegation is not an option." As he then attempted to expand upon his decision to axe Olsen, there was a sense of desperation in the air at the club's training ground as well as a feeling that too little may have been done too late.

But Gjelsten, who rather predictably and lamely blamed the media for the current pressure on the Dons, insisted: "I had a long talk with Egil Olsen and we agreed that a change was needed.

"We must put Wimbledon Football Club first and put emotions aside. I am sorry to announce that Egil Olsen will be relieved of his post with immediate effect, but he was hired for the right reasons.

"The bottom line is results. You win no points for style. After five or six defeats it is tough to be focused on doing a proper job in managing a club

"We need to move forward with fresh ideas. Terry Burton and his team can do that now. We will stay up - it is never too late and we have six points still to play for."

With what could be taken as thinly-veiled criticism of Hammam but may simply have been an admission that relative confusion had reigned, Gjelsten conceded: "The only thing we can be blamed for is not taking the full step and buying the club 100% from day one. Instead we were 80% owners and were not in daily control of the club

Insisting that injuries had also played their part, Gjelsten added that the club were in dire need of the new training ground facilities that were now finally on the way

Burton has now set his sights not only keeping Wimbledon up - and their best chance of doing that probably lies in the fact that Bradford have tougher remaining fixtures away to Leicester and home to Liverpool - but also making his new role permanent

Speculation has nevertheless been rife in Norway that former Manchester City player Aage Hareide will be recruited this summer and for all of his declarations of faith in Burton, Gjelsten has only given him temporary charge of the side

webTitle: Keeping the promise We owe a debt to world education

fields.headline: Keeping the promise We owe a debt to world education
fields.standfirst: World Education Forum
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, international leaders promised the world's children an education. Did they keep their word? Look around: as we enter the information age, one in four adults is unable to write a simple letter, while 125m children have never set foot inside a classroom.
fields.body:
Ten years ago, international leaders promised the world's children an education. Did they keep their word? Look around: as we enter the information age, one in four adults is unable to write a simple letter, while 125m children have never set foot inside a classroom. When it comes to education, the 1990s proved to be the decade of broken promises. World leaders had a chance to redeem themselves last week at the UN Education For All conference in Dakar.Unfortunately many fell at the first hurdle by failing to turn up, including the man whose mantra is "education, education, education": Tony Blair.

Despite that, the conference made some progress by committing itself to developing a global action plan - similar to the scemes advocated by Oxfam and a coalition of aid agencies and teacher unions. But a question remains: does the political will exist for the richest governments to help - and for developing countries to divert what money they have away from arms and into schools?

Britain's development minister, Clare Short, complicated matters in Dakar by claiming that money is not the root of the crisis in third world education. No one who has seen a class of Zambian children using twigs to write in the dust for want of a pencil or paper could believe that money does not matter. But the backers of the global action plan agree with Ms Short that, without good policies, resources will be wasted.

Still, Ms Short risks being left behind by the growing global consensus that education must be the first priority for tackling world poverty. In the new, knowledge-centred, global economy education is the essential start that no individual or society can do without. That point was made often by the representatives of developing nations in Dakar, who spoke movingly of the hunger at the grassroots for learning. There is a link here to the issue of debt relief: the rich nations cannot urge the poor to spend more on schools when we are still taking so much from them in debt repayment.

Now it is up to the people who missed the party to put real resources behind the commitments made in Dakar. It will take a global campaign of the kind led by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, on debt, to squeeze real money out of donors from the northern hemisphere. Mr Blair should be first among those pushing the world's leaders into fulfilling their promise - and his.

webTitle: Promises come in for education: Sponsors step up in Dakar

fields.headline: Promises come in for education: Sponsors step up in Dakar
fields.standfirst:
UN agencies laud conference as 'milestone'
World Education Forum
fields.trailText: The United States, the Netherlands, the World Bank and other international bodies have been quick to say that they intend to spearhead the funding of the new global initiative for education agreed at the UN's meeting in Dakar which ended over the weekend.
fields.body:
The United States, the Netherlands, the World Bank and other international bodies have been quick to say that they intend to spearhead the funding of the new global initiative for education agreed at the UN's meeting in Dakar which ended over the weekend.

However, the British Development Secretary, Clare Short, was embarrassed by the outcome of the Education For All conference convened by five UN agencies and attended by 181 countries. Britain opposed the idea of a global initiative and the raising of more money specifically for education.

Ms Short and the Department for International Development (DfID) argued strongly in public and behind the scenes at Dakar that countries should show a willingness for political reform as a precondition for aid and that a country-by-country approach to education was better than another global initiative.

Ms Short also argued that there was was enough international aid available to help any country prepared to reform its policies, and that the figure of $4bn (£2.6bn) a year that Oxfam and other non-government groups had argued would be needed was "insignificant in a total aid budget of more than $500bn [£322bn]". This was rejected by most of the poorest countries.

The 14-point declaration that came out of the conference included the statement that priority for education assistance should be given to countries in sub-Saharan Africa and south-east Asia, where the majority of the 125m children currently without schooling live. But it rejected the idea of setting up another global bureaucracy to monitor countries' plans.

The World Bank, by far the leading provider of international education aid with about £1.25bn a year in assistance, said yesterday that it intended to increase its levels of assistance "substantially", but could give no figure.

The head of the bank, James Wolfensohn, said he was happy to press for debt relief to be used for education.

The US government said that it would immediately increase by 50% its funding of basic education in developing countries and would push the G8 countries at their next meeting to rally round education as they did for world debt last year.

Yesterday, UN bodies said that the Dakar conference was a "milestone" for development. "There has been a parent revolt for education across the world," said the head of the UN Development Programme, Mark Malloch Brown.

"Huge pressure is coming on politicians from the grassroots to do something. The debate here has been whether you wait for good performances from countries or do you put up extra money immediately.

"There must be political reform but where you get countries who through no fault of their own do not have sound policies in place, provision must be made," he said.

"Children must not be punished for the lack of good government. Education is as much a right as as food and drink."

webTitle: Clashes in Whitehall at May Day protests

fields.headline: Clashes in Whitehall at May Day protests
fields.standfirst: Audio report from Sean Dodson in Whitehall
fields.trailText: The violence feared by police erupted in central London today, where thousands have gathered for a series of demonstrations against capitalism.
fields.body:
The violence feared by police erupted in central London today, where thousands have gathered for a series of demonstrations against capitalism.

After three-and-a-half days of peaceful protest, the first violent incidents occurred on Whitehall when marchers passed a branch of McDonald's. Windows were smashed before protesters entered the restaurant, ripping up tables and throwing out burgers from the kitchen.

A bureau de change next door was also attacked before police moved in. An eyewitness reported panic and a crush in the crowds as a police cordon pushed the crowd back to Trafalgar Square, hitting protesters with batons. By later afternoon, Trafalgar Square was sealed off with protesters surrounded by a police cordon.

One demonstrator trapped behind police lines told Guardian Unlimited: "It's ridiculous, there are no obvious troublemakers here, it's just a mix of ordinary people and tourists, and we want to go home."

A policeman joked: "We're trying to bore them to death so they'll go home." But it was not clear how the protesters would be able to leave.

Earlier, bottles were thrown at riot police at the entrance to Downing Street and at least one police officer has been taken to hospital.

The violent outburst threatened to become an issue in the London mayoral election, with voting due on Thursday. Liberal Democrat candidate Susan Kramer hit out at front-runner Ken Livingstone, who has courted controversy by making anti-capitalist remarks.

She said: "This is a sad day for London. Ken Livingstone praised direct action. Now he's got direct action. This is not the sort of leadership London needs."

Tory mayoral candidate Steven Norris chimed in: "Welcome to Livingstone's London. These actions have absolutely no place in this great city. Londoners will wonder whether this is the shape of things to come if they have a mayor who sides with rioters and protesters rather than ordinary, law-abiding Londoners."

The day's events had started at Parliament Square, where protesters gathered at 11am with gardening tools, seeds and plants as part of a "guerrilla gardening" event, digging up and replanting the area. At Hyde Park Corner, around 500 people gathered for a protest cycle ride.

The Reclaim the Streets group, which organised the guerilla gardening event, had denied that a repeat of last year's June 18 London riots was inevitable. However, some masked marchers at other events over the weekend accused police of increasing tension with their heavy-handed presence.

Last year's anti-capitalist demonstration by about 10,000 people started peacefully but descended into chaos, catching police by surprise. Some marchers burned cars, smashed office windows and fought with riot police, leaving a £2m trail of destruction in London's most violent protests since local tax riots in 1990.

 In Hamburg, Germany, protesters clashed with police, injuring 12 police. Protesters threw stones at banks, broke shop windows and set fire to several cars in the city centre after midnight.

Authorities across Germany readied themselves for trouble and more than 6,000 police were deployed across the capital, Berlin. Reinforcements guarded government buildings in the city centre.
