webTitle: Use mobile windfall billions to bring down the high pound

fields.headline: Use mobile windfall billions to bring down the high pound
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's promise to deliver a "stable and competitive exchange rate" is one which now he almost certainly regrets. The cries of pain from the car industry are being echoed in chemicals, pharmaceuticals, textiles, coal and in shipbuilding.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's promise to deliver a "stable and competitive exchange rate" is one which now he almost certainly regrets. The cries of pain from the car industry are being echoed in chemicals, pharmaceuticals, textiles, coal and in shipbuilding.

The pound has risen by more than a third since the last low point in 1996 and by 15% since May 1997. There is no such thing as a "right" exchange rate but the IMF estimates an appropriate rate is about 15% below present levels.

The strong pound has reduced inflation and the level of interest rates which would otherwise be necessary to curb inflation itself. Indeed, some argue that a strong pound is desirable. Under 25% of GDP is now manufacturing and some of that is unaffected by currency swings.

Some countries, like Switzerland, have flourished in the face of currency appreciation by specialising in price-insensitive goods and services.

Such optimism derives support from the fact that export volumes continued to rise by 5% in 1999. However sales have been achieved with unsustainably tight margins and the future is less sanguine.

The conventional wisdom is that there is nothing we can do because the real problem is a weak euro.

This is like an athlete arguing that he lost a race because the winner was too fast, not because he was too slow.

But the pound has also appreciated strongly against the Australian dollar and the South African rand (leading coal exporters), the Korean won (the top shipbuilder) and even the Swiss franc.

If the problem is indeed the euro, it raises the question of how Britain can co-exist with a currency zone which absorbs half our visible exports but has a currency which with its predecessors has devalued by 40% against sterling in the last four years. Such divergence is in the interests neither of the UK nor Euroland.

The greater the evidence of distress in manufacturing and agriculture, the more the demand for action will grow. There are contrasting approaches to the problem.

The easy option would be to change the terms of reference of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee so that interest rates achieve a devaluation rather than narrowly serving the current anti-inflation objective.

This would be a mistake, since the MPC is only just beginning to establish the credibility of the UK as a low inflation country. There is a risk that higher inflation would rapidly erode the real value of any devaluation as it has done in the past.

The more satisfactory route is to find ways to influence the exchange rate without undermining the MPC'S anti-inflation credentials. One idea is to buy euro securities and sell long-term sterling securities to stabilise the impact on the money supply.

A unique opportunity arises using the down payments from the third generation mobile phone auctions: £10bn out of an eventual £22bn. By investing the windfall in this way the government can ease aid exchange rates both directly through the purchase of foreign assets and indirectly through tight fiscal policy.

We also need to reduce our dependence on short-term interest rates to manage inflation. More active fiscal policy is part of the story. Another is curbing inflation in asset markets, notably housing.

It is absurd that manufacturing in the north should pay the price for a property boom in London. This may mean reviving the power to regulate mortgage lending depending on market conditions.

If the government carries through its commitment to join Emu after a referendum - when entry conditions are right - the Bank of England will have to manage the transition to a fixed, and appropriate, exchange rate. New techniques of inflation management will be required.

Displays of impotence over the exchange rate comfort only those who see no alternative but for British industry to be tossed around like driftwood on the waves of currency movements.

Vincent Cable is the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman and a former chief economist at Shell

The easy option would be to change the terms of reference of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee so that interest rates achieve a devaluation rather than narrowly serving the current anti-inflation objective. This would be a mistake, since the MPC is only just beginning to establish the credibility of the UK as a low inflation country. There is a risk that higher inflation would rapidly erode the real value of any devaluation as it has done in the past. The more satisfactory route is to find ways to influence the exchange rate without undermining the MPC'S anti-inflation credentials. One idea is to buy euro securities and sell long-term sterling securities to stabilise the impact on the money supply. A unique opportunity arises using the down payments from the third generation mobile phone auctions: £10bn out of an eventual £22bn. By investing the windfall in this way the government can ease aid exchange rates both directly through the purchase of foreign assets and indirectly through tight fiscal policy. We also need to reduce our dependence on short-term interest rates to manage inflation. More active fiscal policy is part of the story. Another is curbing inflation in asset markets, notably housing. It is absurd that manufacturing in the north should pay the price for a property boom in London. This may mean reviving the power to regulate mortgage lending depending on market conditions. If the government carries through its commitment to join Emu after a referendum - when entry conditions are right - the Bank of England will have to manage the transition to a fixed, and appropriate, exchange rate. New techniques of inflation management will be required. Displays of impotence over the exchange rate comfort only those who see no alternative but for British industry to be tossed around like driftwood on the waves of currency movements. Vincent Cable is the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman and a former chief economist at Shell

fields.headline: Hague stirs race row
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader accused of aiding extreme right
Exclusive comment from Michael White
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday stoked the simmering political race row to new intensity when he warned that Britain would see more National Front supporters taking to the streets if it did not tackle the problem of asylum seekers "flooding" into the country.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday stoked the simmering political race row to new intensity when he warned that Britain would see more National Front supporters taking to the streets if it did not tackle the problem of asylum seekers "flooding" into the country.

The Tory leader, making his most outspoken comments on the issue ahead of Thursday's local elections, immediately drew accusations from Jack Straw, the home secretary, of "pandering" to the extreme right.

Mr Straw, who is considering whether to ban a National Front march planned in Worcester on May 6, charged Mr Hague with feeding "anxieties which can lead to extremism" by "gross exaggeration" of the asylum situation.

The home secretary's attack echoed strong criticism from the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, who accused the Conservative leader of behaving like a "saloon bar politician" and lowering the tone of British politics.

Mr Hague's comments, made four days before voters around the country go to the polls in town hall elections, underline his belief that his strategy of seizing on high-profile causes such as asylum or householders' right to self-defence is gaining his party electoral ground.

Party insiders believe proposals to lock up asylum seekers in "reception centres" have played well with most voters. The Tory leader will push the race debate still further soon in a speech to the Police Federation, where he will warn that police officers should spend less time on "politically correct race awareness courses" and more time fighting crime.

The tone of yesterday's remarks, made on ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme, took him on to more extreme territory than previously. Denying playing the race card, he argued that the influx of asylum seekers into Britain was running "out of control".

After a complaint from a black audience member that there had been a National Front march in Birmingham (a reference to the Bromsgrove march) last week, he claimed: "We would end up seeing more National Front marches in Birmingham if we failed to deal with these problems.

"This country has managed to improve race relations, community relations, over many years by being firm but fair about immigration, asylum and so on. Now those rules are being abused."

Mr Straw ordered a ban on a planned National Front march on St George's Day in Worcester last month amid fears of serious public disorder and anxiety among ethnic minority communities. One person was arrested as around 30 supporters tried to defy the ban.

Earlier in April, five people were arrested during a 50-strong NF march in Margate, Kent, organised in protest at the number of asylum seekers accommodated in the seaside town.

Yesterday's exchanges indicate that Mr Hague is unrepentant over his party's decision to make asylum a political issue.

After an audience member on the Dimbleby programme, herself from an ethnic minority, appealed to him to soften his rhetoric, arguing that words such as "flooding and swamping" made her feel intimidated, the Tory leader refused, saying: "We should use words properly with their full meaning and their true meaning. The dictionary definition of a flood is a flow that is out of control."

He also restated pledges to amend the law on self-defence, possibly to restrict the mandatory life sentence for murder, and underlined his own support for capital punishment, though denying that any commitment to reintroduce the penalty would be included in the Tories' next election manifesto.

Mr Straw, whose strategy has been to leave the Tories little ground on asylum by taking a tough approach, yesterday clung firmly to the moral high ground as he directed his most impassioned criticism to date at the Tory leader.

Claiming Mr Hague's comments showed up the "dangers of weak leadership", he said: "Pushed to the right by forces in his own party, he now justifies his stand by claiming that otherwise support for even more extreme views would grow - but pandering to the National Front and other such groups is no way to oppose them.

"Mr Hague has fed the anxieties which can lead to extremism by grossly exaggerating the position on asylum and by irresponsibly opposing our sensible measures like the new civil penalty on hauliers."

The Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, also rejected Mr Hague's remarks. "The number of asylum seekers coming in is going down, not up," he said.

"It's not up to Britain as to how many asylum seekers there are; it reflects the situation in the rest of the world."

Last month Mr Hughes reported both the Conservatives and Labour to the commission for racial equality, prompting a commission warning to both parties.

But yesterday Mr Hague said: "I will not be told by attitudes of political correctness to stop using the English language ... We have asylum seekers who are bogus, and if they're bogus we should call them bogus."

webTitle: Can Greenspan escape a crisis he helped create?

fields.headline: Can Greenspan escape a crisis he helped create?
fields.trailText: In the pantheon of finance, few gods rank higher than Alan Greenspan. Worshipped from Wall Street to Main Street, the chairman of the US Federal Reserve is credited with saving the world from economic disaster not once but twice.
fields.body:
In the pantheon of finance, few gods rank higher than Alan Greenspan. Worshipped from Wall Street to Main Street, the chairman of the US Federal Reserve is credited with saving the world from economic disaster not once but twice.

On the first occasion, two months into the job, he slashed US interest rates in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash and kept the ball rolling. On the second, he won plaudits for averting a global depression by bailing out Long Term Capital Management, the US hedge fund, and injecting liquidity into financial markets.

It is little wonder that the American public has faith in him steering the overheated US economy to a soft landing this time round.

Yet, Greenspan is arguably as much villain as hero in the story of economic "success". Even allowing for the pick-up in productivity associated with the adoption of new technology, US growth is powering ahead at a rate which far exceeds the economy's potential. Notwithstanding recent falls, share prices remain detached from reality, encouraging a casino mentality among consumers and businesses.

A new paper by Phillips & Drew's Bill Martin highlights the scale of excess. America's New Era Revisited, an update of his earlier work with Wynne Godley, argues that blind faith in the economy's invincibility and inflated stock prices have fuelled an orgy of borrowing which has taken the private sector to an unprecedented level of debt.

Scales of excess

Private net saving in most of the post-war period has averaged about 2.5% of GDP - but in the second half of the 1990s it dived to nearly minus 5%.

The willingness of US consumers and businesses to borrow has, in turn, supported the stock market. This could trigger a self-feeding reversal: private net saving starts to rise, which depresses growth, causes a stock market fall and triggers a further jump in saving - the paradox of thrift, as John Maynard Keynes called it.

Martin has carried out a number of simulations of what could happen when US consumers and businesses decide to retrench. The results make grim reading.

Under the worst case scenario - in which the net saving rate reverses sharply and rises above normal - growth collapses and stagnates over five years, sending unemployment above 10%. Even a return of net saving to normal levels sees growth slow to 0.7% a year for five years and unemployment up to 9.4% by the end of the period. This would have unpleasant consequences: lower US import demand means lower exports from elsewhere.

Greenspan must assume his share of the blame for the precarious situation the global economy in now in.

The argument in his defence is that in the circumstances prevailing in the autumn of 1998 there was nothing else he could have done. Faced with a meltdown in financial markets, standing back and letting LTCM fail while leaving monetary policy on hold could have unleashed economic devastation.

That may be so. Confidence was certainly fragile. But Greenspan could have acted more promptly to tighten credit conditions once the danger of depression had passed. Now, he appears to be playing catch-up with the markets rather than staying, as all central bankers should, ahead of the game.

So what can he do to ensure a soft landing for the US economy? Some argue that a sharp rise in interest rates is needed to jolt people to their senses - but the danger is that this could precipitate the very crash Greenspan is trying to avoid. A continuation of the softly, softly approach, raising rates in quarter-point increments, therefore seems appropriate.

Faith and Magic: Investor Beliefs and Government Neutrality - a new paper by Henry TC Hu at the University of Texas -sets out some extra steps that Greenspan could take to shake the American public out of its myopia.

Hu argues that the Fed is guilty of helping to establish a "stock-based investor religion", and thereby distorting the market demand for stocks. The price of Greenspan's success in preventing disaster is that it has become natural for naive investors to think that share prices cannot collapse or that, if they do, investors will somehow be insulated.

In particular, the Fed's rescue of LTCM - "well-connected financial speculators" deemed too big to fail - has fostered socially destructive illusions among investors. Such illusions could lead to the federal government being forced to provide a safety net for millions of ordinary stock market investors who would be deemed too small to fail.

Hu argues that we are now in a world where Greenspan's presence means disasters simply do not happen. He says investor optimism needs to be tempered with genuine fear that crashes, while ex tremely rare, can still happen and that the Fed may not ride to the rescue.

Since Greenspan's famous "irrational exuberance" speech in December 1996 the Dow has climbed more than 60%. Having failed to "jawbone down" the market, the Fed should now declare that it will not provide liquidity for mutual funds which run into redemption problems. This would force investors to re-think the existence of a federal safety net.

Secondly, Hu suggests that the Fed should forswear intervening directly in equities or equity derivatives. By ruling out intervention, the Fed would force investors to re-do their sums to take account of the extra risk involved in piling into equities.

Such a reassessment is clearly needed. Although recent wobbles indicate that the market may have entered a new bear phase, valuations are still stretched. Martin reckons that trend growth of the US economy would have to be close to 10% and inflation zero to justify Wall Street's current level.

Greenspan's reputation is still high. His achievements have earned a place on the cover of Time; a Thai newspaper characterised him as a demi-god in the aftermath of the Asian crisis; he has an unofficial fan club on the web - GetExhuberant.com.

He is arguably the world's second most powerful person, and is watched closely for clues to his thinking. His status is truly superhuman. But even HIS powers may not be enough to get him out of the mess he is now in - one that he has in part created.

fields.headline: Hague walking a rightwing tightrope
fields.standfirst: The Conservative leader's statements on asylum may endear him to the right of his own party but could backfire, says political editor Michael White
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader's statements on asylum may endear him to the right of his own party but could backfire, says political editor Michael White
fields.body:
William Hague shows no sign of easing up on his criticisms of the government's handling of asylum policy, or indeed any of the other hot button issues which have caught his fancy of late, such as law and order in rural areas in the wake of the Tony Martin trial.

Far from it. He will return to such themes in the days and weeks ahead, starting today in Romsey where the Conservatives are fighting to hold off a strong Liberal Democrat challenge for the parliamentary seat left vacant by Michael Colvin's death.

The Tory leader does not apologise for doing so. Politicians must address the concerns of the voters, Mr Hague says correctly. If they do not, they risk creating a vacuum which may be filled by extremists, the National Front for example. He is right about that too. But the manner and tone of Mr Hague's intervention is also crucial. If his talk of "floods" of "bogus" asylum seekers "abusing" the system misjudges the public mood, voters will not warm to him as his advisers hope. Instead they will mark him down as a lightweight opportunist.

For a party leader who is already regarded as too young - while looking and sounding "too old" at 39 - that would be a blow. Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, is already charging him with using "saloon bar" tactics.

Today Mr Kennedy will accuse Mr Hague of "immature politics" and of turning his party into "little more than an extremist sect". Jack Straw, the home secretary, says he is "pandering" to the far right.

Labour is rattled. Some of its own supporters and the newspapers they read also resent foreigners who "live on benefit" - on their taxes - or occupy houses their children might want. If the economy falters, the red-top tabloids will start complaining about "stealing our jobs" as well.

The current furore is, of course, partly to do with Thursday's byelection, plus those for 3,300 council seats. Potentially most damaging to Tony Blair is the contest for mayor of London, not forgetting the 25-strong Greater London Authority (GLA) which will keep him or her in check.

But it is about more than mere May 4 tactics. Mr Hague is barely a year away from a general election he is all but universally expected to lose and lose quite badly. If Labour's majority is halved it will be seen as proof that the Tories are on the road to recovery. But Mr Blair's Commons majority will still be 90 seats.

So Mr Hague's first task is to secure his own position. He knows that most opposition leaders get a second chance - but rarely get three. What he seems to be doing is searching out themes which appeal to voter concerns on which he can outflank the government.

It is not easy. Voters are disappointed in NHS reforms so far, worried about transport issues, concerned about crime. After three cautious years Blair and his chancellor, Gordon Brown, have money to throw at these problems as election day looms. They have left it too late for many people, but Mr Hague can scarcely complain: his government bequeathed many of the problems and the tight spending plans.

Law and order, Europe and immigration - in this case asylum seekers - represent a better target, closer to traditional core issues for the Conservatives, those of authority and national identity. Throw in a dash of family values, Mr Hague's curious attack on the section 28 controversy, and the leadership has a script to cheer up Tory voters who may have drifted to the Referendum Party or UKIP last time.

Winning back defectors to the right is not enough to win a general election. Commons majorities are won on the centre ground. But it may be enough to consolidate Mr Hague's leadership after the 2001 election when a bid to oust him can realistically be expected.

The Tory leader is a clever man, smart enough to know that his party is best led from the right, whatever the tolerant social views on gay rights, single parenthood and multiculturalism he briefly exposed when he first succeeded John Major in 1997.

Such a positioning also wrong-foots his most likely challenger, Michael Portillo, who has softened his own hardline social views during his three year exile from Westminster to the point where even some leftwing Tory MPs could vote for him.

Their fear would be that, unless Ken Clarke runs again and does better than before, the run-off second round would be between Mr Portillo and Ann Widdecombe. Since the party rank-and-file decide the second round result, that could produce a Widdecombe victory - a nightmare to the Tory left and a boon to Tony Blair.

So Mr Hague treads a tightrope. A generation ago in 1968 Enoch Powell, convinced that Ted Heath would lose the 1970 election (he didn't), launched his "rivers of blood" speech against immigration, the shocking tone of which - even now - makes Mr Hague's talk of floods seem quite mild.

In the late 70s, when the National Front was still active in byelections, Margaret Thatcher used the word "swamped" in an interview. It caused a row and she did not do it again during her long premiership.

It did not matter. Hardline rightwingers were mesmerised by her. The National Front and successors like the BNP were pushed to the margins where they remained, even during the Major years.

Economic prosperity for much of the country must have contributed to their demise, but the prospect of Rover's collapse - Dagenham's too - must have sent a chill down the spines of mainstream politicians and cheered both right and left. After all, it is the left, not the right, which is resurgent in London's mayoral campaign.

All of which should give Mr Hague pause for thought. One serious slip and he might never recover. Blair will be waiting to pounce, just as Bill Clinton did when his Republican foes piled in behind the rightwing Miami Cubans and their reckless campaign to "save" Elian Gonzalez from Fidel Castro. They will pay for it on election day in November.

After all, it is the left, not the right, which is resurgent in London's mayoral campaign. All of which should give Mr Hague pause for thought. One serious slip and he might never recover. Blair will be waiting to pounce, just as Bill Clinton did when his Republican foes piled in behind the rightwing Miami Cubans and their reckless campaign to "save" Elian Gonzalez from Fidel Castro. They will pay for it on election day in November.

fields.headline: End of the exodus?
fields.standfirst:
Enticed by giant salaries and lucrative share options, journalists last year headed off into the new world of internet start-ups. But now, finds David Teather , old media companies are fighting back; and, as Jane Martinson reports from the US, some hacks are already having second thoughts

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Enticed by giant salaries and lucrative share options, journalists last year headed off into the new world of internet start-ups. But now, finds David Teather , old media companies are fighting back; and, as Jane Martinson reports from the US, some hacks are already having second thoughts
fields.body:
Eighteen months or so ago most journalists accepted they would never be rich. There were probably only three paths to making money. Going into management (selling out), going into public relations, preferably financial (selling out) or becoming editor of a national newspaper (highly unlikely).

The fourth way of course was to come from money in the first place and enjoy the job as a kind of hobby which, in fairness, accounts for a not insignificant number.

The internet, though, has changed all that and lifted the pecuniary veil to reveal previously unheard of possibility. Hacks, who not so long ago had no idea what a share option was, now lobby for changes in the law to remove national insurance contributions because the tax is allegedly holding back the new economy and their path to untold riches.

It has been a while since conventional media companies in print, broadcast or radio stopped talking about the threat of the internet and realised it should be an opportunity. But the problem of retaining personnel in the face of the stock options on offer at start-ups is still very real.

The flood of staff, particularly from the financial press, has been enormous. TheStreet.co.uk attracted Martin Baker (since departed) and Nils Pratley of Sunday Business, Ian Griffiths from the Independent and Hilary Clarke of the Independent on Sunday. Fahrenheit 451 has taken on Paul Taylor from the Financial Times and Dawn Hayes from Sunday Business.

BreakingViews.com is being led by Hugo Dixon and Jonathan Ford of the Lex column in the Financial Times and has taken on Antonia Feuchtwanger of the Evening Standard. Talkcast has Paul Durman of the Times, Neil Thapar of the Mail on Sunday and Matthew Lynn from the Sunday Times.

Most will adopt the terribly British stance that money is not the prime reason for their involvement in the web. Given the FT's failure to net national newspaper journalists for its online service FT.Com, which came without the promise of share options, the protests ring a little hollow. The raft of new ventures has set the value of content providers (also known as journalists) at a premium.

The problem is exacerbated in the old media empires which set up new media divisions and find they can't compete with the rewards on offer at start-ups. Signs have begun to emerge, however, that conventional media firms are beginning to wake up to the problem. United News & Media, which owns the Express newspapers, and holds the ITV franchises for Meridian, Anglia and HTV, is one.

United, run by Lord Hollick, recently announced plans to pool its online assets into a single company called Xilerate. It is offering "shadow options" against the performance of the business and has lined it up for flotation to develop a "currency" with which to retain staff. "Equity incentives being offered in [the new media market place] by our competitors significantly outstrip those United is able to offer under current incentive plans," the group admitted when the plan was presented to shareholders at the end of last month.

Carlton has also introduced an options package for staff in its online division. Reuters has helped to see off mass defections almost by happy accident with an award of 2,000 shares to every member of staff 18 months ago which they can sell next year. Today, 2,000 shares give them a profit of just over £11,000, laughable for City workers but a tidy sum for your average journalist not used to bonuses.

The sums on offer from dot.coms appear to vary widely. One City editor was offered a salary of £150,000 and shares worth around £250,000 over two years by an American website coming to Britain last year.

Others are perhaps less gargantuan, but in the context of newspapers still high. One journalist at the Express was offered and turned down a package of £67,000 a year salary plus £20,000 of share options at TheStreet.co.uk. Others at the company worked out that if it floated at £500m - a not unrealistic sum - their options would be worth £200,000.

Richard Rivlin, a 25-year-old rising star on the FT, is leaving the newspaper to join Talkcast. Rivlin won't discuss the package at Talkcast but has been approached by a number of web start-ups over the past 12 months. "The mega deals on offer are something of a myth. We are talking a salary which any national newspaper could match if they really wanted to and an options package of 100% or 150% of one year's pay. Maybe it gets better higher up the food chain but it's not mega millions, which was really quite disheartening."

Pearson, the media group run by Marjorie Scardino and which owns the Financial Times, was finally rattled enough when Robert Peston and William Lewis, two of its key figures on the paper, began talking to backers about setting up a website to rival the FT. The pair ultimately stayed and both have been beneficiaries of a scheme being introduced at Pearson to retain staff. But the awards have caused some disgruntlement among the rank and file. Only a handful of people in the FT Group have so far been singled out for options and all at relatively senior level.

Even if an old media company offers shares in the business, however, the problem is that they are in traditional companies with less volatile share prices which do not have the same promise of extraordinary wealth that comes with a start-up. Offering part of the staff within a group options and leaving out the people on old media - usually the ones who currently make the money for an organisation - can also be divisive.

The answer, and one so far rejected by Pearson, may be that adopted by United - to float minority stakes of internet interests on the stock market in order to create a purer internet currency with which they can reward staff. Channel 4 insiders admit privately that the company faces real issues in recruiting enough staff for its plans to build a significant web presence and the internet business could be floated off.

If the conventional media companies are lucky, however, the issue may become less thorny as the air is let out of the start-up boom. Durlacher, one of the most prolific investors in start-ups last year, has begun taking a far more rigorous approach to backing new businesses and wants a clearer idea of where revenues will come from, beyond a vague notion about advertising.

People who have defected to dot.coms are also starting to think again. At TheStreet.co.uk, Hugh Fraser (who joined from the BBC) is no longer full time, editor-in-chief Martin Baker left on Friday and former Birmingham Post city editor Guy Dresser is leaving to join Sunday Business less than three months after launch. "Morale is so low on a lot of dot.com start-ups that I doubt the large companies will have to do much to attract us back," said one disillusioned would-be millionaire.

fields.headline: When the web goes wobbly
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: April can be the shortest month. In the space of fewer than 30 days, the shoe that made dot.com media types appear so much taller than their peers in traditional media now seems to be on the other foot.
fields.body:
April can be the shortest month. In the space of fewer than 30 days, the shoe that made dot.com media types appear so much taller than their peers in traditional media now seems to be on the other foot.

The schadenfreude enjoyed by those who had not jumped wholeheartedly into the brave new world of the web has been palpable in recent weeks. Seizing on evidence that share options in a fledgling website do not guarantee unlimited wealth, many people have been patting themselves on the back for sticking with the old world order. Pension plans and a career path of sorts suddenly seemed less pathetic.

James Cramer, the hedge fund manager turned media pundit and dot.com founder, proved an unlikely source of encouragement for such behaviour. At the very start of the week in which the Nasdaq composite index, the benchmark for US technology companies, lost an astonishing 25% of its value, Cramer returned to writing a column for New York magazine after a four-year break.

During that break, Cramer had started TheStreet.com , one of the earliest and most successful of the financial news sites. Since being formed in 1996, TheStreet.com had attracted some top talent and about 100,000 subscribers. Earlier this year, it launched a UK website. Cramer predicted that the company would overtake both Dow Jones and Reuters as the most important source of financial news when the company listed on the US stock market last year. Its shares reached $70 on that first day, before falling in an almost straight line to about $6 now.

As if this was not bad enough, Cramer has used his return to the dead-wood world to berate investors for their initial enthusiasm. "Our best day was our first day, the day when the market gave us a valuation similar to the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times. My, what was the market thinking?" he wrote last week.

Although the contrarian investor has also said that the recent downturn in TheStreet.com's share price has been overdone, he has managed to add insult to injury by publicly relishing his return to a magazine known for its gossip and high-life concerns. He told the New York Post that he was glad to return to print because, "I like to be read by my peers on Wall Street".

Of course, one man saying that the party is over does not mean that others have stopped having a good time. It's just that the party poppers now look more like slow-burning fires as the attraction of instant wealth turns into, perhaps, a belief that the internet is not just about the booming US stock market.

Yet there is likely to be some fairly swift fallout from the crash in sentiment. One change could be a reassessment of plans by traditional media companies to spin off their internet assets. Both News Corporation and Viacom have reaffirmed their commitment to such plans in the past week. But, after complaining that they were not being taken seriously as new media moguls, both Rupert Murdoch and Sumner Redstone could hardly have failed to notice that their old media companies managed to avoid last week's sharp Nasdaq sell-off.

A more immediate consequence of the sudden change is likely to be in recruitment. Kurt Andersen, a member of New York's old media elite who is about to launch a new website, admits that he "lucked out" in enticing reporters from many of America's most respected newspapers to join Powerful Media, his new venture, just before the crash.

The company's 65 employees will own about 25% of it. Andersen, a novelist and founder of Spy magazine, recognised that without such a recruitment bonus it would have been far harder to attract staff to Inside.com, a media and entertainment news website to be launched next week. Andersen's experience at Powerful Media to date also suggests that the long-term outlook for media websites is slightly rosier than it appears now, if not as golden as before.

The company founders managed to complete the second round of funding just after the stock market reached its lowest point. In spite of one nervous investor phoning to ask whether anyone else was pulling out, they managed to raise more than the $20m they had hoped for.

"We had some upset stomachs for a few days but it hasn't delayed a thing," Andersen says. He even welcomes the fact that a new-found sense of reality has stopped people "indulging in fantasies - there was a sense of unreality with everybody floating up and up in the new world. That's obviously, at least for now, done and over."

Andersen is also unfazed by his old friend Cramer's change of heart. Cramer is still, after all, an investor in Powerful Media.

webTitle: 'For society, the internet is great. For capitalists, it's a net negative'

fields.headline: 'For society, the internet is great. For capitalists, it's a net negative'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Warren Buffett, the legendary US investor, attacked boardroom pay this weekend as he continued to warn about the dangers of an overinflated stock market.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett, the legendary US investor, attacked boardroom pay this weekend as he continued to warn about the dangers of an overinflated stock market.

Mr Buffett compared the big rise in internet shares to other manias such as a tripling of prices for farmland in Nebraska in the 1980s. "For society, the internet is a wonderful thing. For capitalists, it's a net negative."

The man who has built one of the world's biggest personal fortunes during 35 years of investing used the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, his investment vehicle, to criticise the increasing use of share options for senior executives. "What is happening at the top level is really unbelievable".

Mr Buffett, the world's second richest man who is paid far less than the average US chief executive, said he could see no end to the increase in payouts because they were driven by "ego as much as money".

He directed particular criticism at the pay consultants who stoke corporate greed and institutional investors who "get involved in the details of corporate governance, which frankly don't mean a damn in terms of performance".

During a six-hour question and answer session with shareholders after the five-minute annual meeting, Mr Buffett said he was no longer invited to sit on compensation committees after objecting to 1980s Wall Street excesses. "You can only belch so many times at the dinner table and be invited back."

However, Mr Buffett, a board member and major shareholder of Coca-Cola, was forced to defend last year's multibillion-dollar severance package for Doug Ivester, the former chief executive, as "the right decision".

He then mentioned employment contracts and darkly alluded to "other factors that maybe I will put in a book". But any hint of darkness was out of keeping with the rest of the day, as shareholders applauded him in spite of having just survived Berkshire's worst performance to date. A man from Santa Barbara offered to give him "10 lashes with a wet noodle". He quickly added that the slap was "because you have spoiled your shareholders into expecting 25%-plus a year".

Mr Buffett revealed his dissatisfaction with the equity market. Speaking about selling Walt Disney shares, he said: "We have more generally reduced equities as prices began to get more full. General ownership of equities over the next 10-15 years is not going to be very exciting."

fields.headline: The brothers look east
fields.standfirst: It's been losing money steadily for 40 years, but the Saudi-owned UPI press agency could soon be bought by the Barclay twins. What are they up to?
fields.trailText: The Barclay brothers are being tipped as likely winners of a contest to buy one of the world's most famous, if somewhat troubled, news agencies.
fields.body:
The Barclay brothers are being tipped as likely winners of a contest to buy one of the world's most famous, if somewhat troubled, news agencies.

Press Holdings, the publishing company run by David and Frederick Barclay, owns the Scotsman and Sunday Business and is among the final three left in the race for United Press International (UPI). Bidding is expected to reach its final stages early this week though UPI's president and chief executive, Arnaud de Borchgrave, refused to confirm the identity of the short-listed companies, let alone the Barclays' prospects. "I'm covered by a secrecy agreement," he said from his Washington headquarters, "so I can't tell you who's involved. All I can say is that I expect to make an announcement very soon."

But he made a similar statement in February, when he spoke of having had seven suitors which, he claimed, would soon be reduced to one: a so-called "cash rich" internet company. The Barclays' executive thought to be negotiating the deal, Andrew Neil, not only refused to comment but declined to say which country he was speaking from by satellite phone last week. His public relations spokesman would only say that he was in "eastern parts".

It is therefore feasible that Neil was in Saudi Arabia. Though UPI is owned by the London-based ARA group, its ultimate owner is a Saudi Arabian corporation that has grown disenchanted with the agency's deepening financial problems in recent years.

In 1998, six of the Saudi directors pledged to inject $18m to clear UPI's debts, but it is uncertain whether they ever fulfilled the promise. Since then, UPI has sold off lucrative radio interests to raise money.

The Saudis bought UPI after it went bankrupt in 1991, its second bout of insolvency under its fourth set of owners since being sold by the family of its founder, newspaper magnate EW Scripps. He launched United Press in 1907 because he needed a news agency to serve his string of afternoon daily papers and was frustrated that the dominant agency, Associated Press, targeted morning titles. He was also concerned to prevent the growth of a news monopoly.

In 1958, United Press merged with William Randolph Hearst's International News Service to form UPI. But the new service began losing money in 1962 and has made a loss in almost every year since. It has gradually dwindled in size and lost clients, though it has maintained some journalistic prestige. One of its greatest assets has been Helen Thomas, regarded as the dean of the White House press corps. In 1997, it was forced to close several of its foreign bureaux, including those in Moscow, Paris and Brussels.

De Borchgrave, now 73, is an award-winning veteran journalist, a star foreign correspondent for Newsweek and later editor-in-chief of the Washington Times, who took charge of the agency in December 1998. He has struggled to maintain the agency as a going concern despite its gradual loss of clients and relentless need for cost-cutting. After a restructuring operation, he continued the move towards creating an internet-based service begun by his predecessor, James Adams, a former Sunday Times Washington and defence correspondent.

Adams was also ground down by financial problems and found his relationship with the Saudi owners a difficult one. He even threatened to close down UPI's wire service at one point because of allegations that the Saudis had not delivered promised operating capital. When he resigned after just 15 months he set up his own company, taking a number of key UPI staffers with him. It is not known whether Adams - one of Neil's closest friends - has played any part in the Barclays' decision to bid for UPI.

What is also unclear is their reason for wanting to buy the agency. It is possible that it could form a key part of their burgeoning internet enterprises. If not, it is difficult to see the point of taking on such an ailing company while its newspaper division is finding profits hard to generate.

He was also concerned to prevent the growth of a news monopoly. In 1958, United Press merged with William Randolph Hearst's International News Service to form UPI. But the new service began losing money in 1962 and has made a loss in almost every year since. It has gradually dwindled in size and lost clients, though it has maintained some journalistic prestige. One of its greatest assets has been Helen Thomas, regarded as the dean of the White House press corps. In 1997, it was forced to close several of its foreign bureaux, including those in Moscow, Paris and Brussels. De Borchgrave, now 73, is an award-winning veteran journalist, a star foreign correspondent for Newsweek and later editor-in-chief of the Washington Times, who took charge of the agency in December 1998. He has struggled to maintain the agency as a going concern despite its gradual loss of clients and relentless need for cost-cutting. After a restructuring operation, he continued the move towards creating an internet-based service begun by his predecessor, James Adams, a former Sunday Times Washington and defence correspondent. Adams was also ground down by financial problems and found his relationship with the Saudi owners a difficult one. He even threatened to close down UPI's wire service at one point because of allegations that the Saudis had not delivered promised operating capital. When he resigned after just 15 months he set up his own company, taking a number of key UPI staffers with him. It is not known whether Adams - one of Neil's closest friends - has played any part in the Barclays' decision to bid for UPI. What is also unclear is their reason for wanting to buy the agency. It is possible that it could form a key part of their burgeoning internet enterprises. If not, it is difficult to see the point of taking on such an ailing company while its newspaper division is finding profits hard to generate.

webTitle: Neil's new look:  a cultural revolution, or a sinking ship?

fields.headline: Neil's new look:  a cultural revolution, or a sinking ship?
fields.standfirst: Andrew Neil explains his vision for the Scotsman's future to  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: In case the Scotsman's detractors haven't got the message, its publisher is overjoyed by the upheaval of the past couple of months. Recalling the Wapping siege of 1986, Andrew Neil says: "If 5,000 print workers can't beat me, then this bunch of amateurs have no chance."
fields.body:
In case the Scotsman's detractors haven't got the message, its publisher is overjoyed by the upheaval of the past couple of months. Recalling the Wapping siege of 1986, Andrew Neil says: "If 5,000 print workers can't beat me, then this bunch of amateurs have no chance."

By amateurs, he mainly means the paper's media rivals, along with recently departed staff and the chattering classes. Neil has always attracted enemies and it doesn't seem to disturb him. "I know they'd love me to fall flat on my face," he says. He has always thrived on adversity and it's no surprise that he should evoke the memory of his early years as editor of the Sunday Times.

Then, he felt himself surrounded by a stuffy establishment and was relieved when many of those who he most distrusted refused to make the move to Wapping. He says: "Famous names left, and people forecast doom. It didn't happen." Shrugging aside their complaints, he created a paper in his own image and, significantly, reversed the downward sales trend. One major difference between the situation at the Sunday Times then and the Scotsman now is that Neil was the architect of the move to Wapping. He controlled the circumstances. This time he doesn't but, apparently, it makes no difference.

Since the dismissal of Alan Ruddock at the beginning of February, a raft of senior staff have jumped ship, or been ordered to walk the plank. So where's the benefit? "The dead wood has gone," says Neil. "We're glad to see the back of most of them so that we can bring in a new team and unlock the young talent that we already have."

He returns time and again to this theme, a mixture of positive spin and his natural swagger. The departed staff, he says, are "carthorses replaced by frisky young stallions and mares, lots of mares". Top mare is Rebecca Hardy, the deputy editor pitched into the hot seat when Neil's recently appointed editor, Tim Luckhurst, was ordered to take a month's rest by his doctor. She will oversee the changes in the paper to be unveiled to readers on May 8, but exclusively previewed in the dummies shown here.

As with the recent changes to the Times, the Guardian has again been the template: a broadsheet main section is complemented by a tabloid-sized section, entitled S2, containing features, health, lifestyle, arts and women's pages. Neil says the advantage of this arrangement is that older, current readers need not be alarmed because the main section will continue to cover politics, home and foreign news as before.

But he hopes to attract younger readers - especially those who have strayed to the Scottish editions of London-based papers - with the better coverage of lighter fare. He also hopes it may persuade people who take the Scotsman once or twice a week to do so more often.

The changes, backed by an expensive TV campaign, are the culmination of an eight-month process aimed at repositioning the paper. Market research evidently validated Neil's own view that the Scotsman wasn't comprehensive enough. "It's so refreshing, and I've never been more confident or more excited," he bubbles. "We have embarked on a major cultural upheaval which will be a liberating experience for the Scotsman."

What, though, of the paper's political coverage, the source of much criticism in the past couple of years? "We have been schizophrenic in our political message. But what we really stand for will be coming through clearly from now on. We remain a small-L liberal paper. We're on side with Blairism, but we won't hesitate to say when it's wrong." Again, he compares it to his days at the Sunday Times, when "we were for Thatcherism but never scared to criticise when we thought it right to do so".

He is quick to deny the charge of dumbing down. European coverage, for example, is to be boosted by taking advantage of correspondents working through the group's forthcoming internet site, businesseurope.com.

None of this optimism can conceal the difficulties faced by the Scotsman. In the six months between October 1999 and this March, it recorded an average sale of 74,793, more than 6% down on the same period the year before. Neil is confident that it will bounce back up to 80,000, but the competition is fierce. The London-based nationals have made inroads, though their upward rise has been checked of late, and the Scotsman's main competitor, the Herald, is still way ahead. The Glasgow-based paper's last official ABC sale was over 100,000.

By chance, Herald editor Harry Reid resigned last week after three years, though his departure is to be delayed, probably until the end of the year. Reid, 52, a highly respected journalist, says: "I'm proud of the fact that the Herald has been more open-minded than other papers here." He has decided to go just before the paper also undergoes a redesign. Among the possible successors are his deputy Alf Young; Charles McGhee, the editor of the Glasgow Evening Times; Ramsey Smith, editor of the Daily Mail's Scottish edition; and Andrew Jaspan, editor of the Sunday Herald and one of Neil's foremost antagonists.

Reid has been much more reticent than Jaspan in voicing his views on the Scotsman, but he is one of a chorus of critics. He says: "I spent 10 happy years there and I'm genuinely distressed at what's happening." Neil is unmoved by such views. "We're embarking on a cultural revolution," he says. Nothing will deter Neil from his conviction that MacWapping is going to be a winner.

fields.headline: For sale: one marriage
fields.standfirst: How dare he sell the old Rover! It's not just a car, it's a very important part of their relationship.  Sophie Radice  wonders how her marriage will survive without the banger that brought them together
fields.trailText: On my first date with my husband Dan, he picked me up from my parent's house (no, I wasn't 16 and never been kissed, but a 29-year-old with a child and a failed marriage) in a plump, shiny, turquoise Rover Coupe 69 with a Webasto sunroof. The heavy doors swung open and I sunk into the generous blond leather seats. The engine throbbed as he had to lean over and help me put on the old- fashioned seatbelt whose design I had never seen before. By the time he dropped me home that night I was smitten by the big, generous man and his big fat car.
fields.body:
On my first date with my husband Dan, he picked me up from my parent's house (no, I wasn't 16 and never been kissed, but a 29-year-old with a child and a failed marriage) in a plump, shiny, turquoise Rover Coupe 69 with a Webasto sunroof. The heavy doors swung open and I sunk into the generous blond leather seats. The engine throbbed as he had to lean over and help me put on the old- fashioned seatbelt whose design I had never seen before. By the time he dropped me home that night I was smitten by the big, generous man and his big fat car.

A couple of weeks after that, my sister looked after my son and we went away together on a walking holiday in the Brecon Beacons - except that we didn't do any walking. Instead we sat in the comfortable interior of the Rover and looked at the hills and the rain and talked, ate sweets that we had bought from the service stations along the M4 (in a classic car you have to stop and fill up frequently) and er, consummated our relationship. It was the best weekend away I had ever had.

That was seven years ago. We got married, bought a house and had another child. We have a sensible family car that we use for everyday purposes. The Rover is still used for important motoring experiences - for trips away or to make an entrance at a wedding or a party. 0ur children love it and when we all went on holiday to Italy there was none of the usual claustrophobia, car-sickness or "How long until we get there?" nagging. They are proud of the admiring stares the Rover gets as it hums majestically along the road and it makes going on long trips an expensive but pleasurable experience.

A couple of weeks ago Dan suddenly announced that he was going to put it up for sale. My son burst into tears and my husband explained that the car needed some work on it that he didn't have the time or money to carry out and that it made him feel guilty that we don't use it enough. He wanted to sell it to someone who would give it all the attention it deserved. A single man, perhaps, like he had been 10 years before when he bought it off his next door neighbour.

I have never been able to bring myself to nag Dan about the Rover. While my sister insisted that her partner got rid of his old 70s gangster Jaguar because it seemed a luxury and could never be a practical family car, I knew that the Rover was part of the deal when we got together. He has always told me that it is worth a fortune and that we could sell it if we needed money. I nodded, thinking he was part of the Eddie Grundy school of finance, but basically ignored him because I knew that it was an asset that could never be realised. There is just too much personal history and emotion attached to his beautiful old banger.

If he has to sell it I worry about the effect on his psyche. I can't help wondering if part of his personality will go along with the sale of the car, if his largess and spontaneity will just shrivel up and disappear. The Rover is like his signature. His friends say things like "Saw you were in Kentish Town today" because they know it is him in that curvy blue car.

I may associate the Rover with our courtship but he has other important memories that were before my time. In Marseilles some gangsters started shooting from a speeding car at the garage owner who was selling Dan a new tyre and they both found refuge on the cosily carpeted floor of the Rover. A river bursts its banks in Dorset and the strength of the engine stopped him being swept away by the water and he simply drove through the deluge. These are the times the Rover saved his life but the most important memory of good times in the Rover is when Dan drove his late father through France.

He had never allowed Dan to drive him before - in fact he had never really allowed anyone to drive him before and Dan felt that it was not only a sign that he regarded Dan as a man at last but that he trusted and admired the reliability and comfort of the Rover. I suppose Dan must have driven other women in it too but I can't bear to think about anyone else testing just how far the passenger seat can tip backwards, thank you very much.

Car owners are perfectly capable of having strong emotions about cars that do not have the obvious appeal of a classic like Dan's Rover, which has the ability to inspire feelings of nostalgia even from those born long after it was made. Adam Richards, 25, owns a Peugeot 309 that most people would have great difficulty mustering up any sentimental attachment for.

"I know that she looks totally ordinary but this used to be my family car. My parents gave me it a couple of years ago. It has probably hindered rather then helped my love life and yet I have such good memories of going on family trips with my parents and my sister. It would seem immensely disloyal to my parents who saved up to buy it and kept it going in such good condition to ever sell it. It would mean nothing to someone else but for me it has come to symbolise the later part of my childhood."

Gemma and David Ackerman feel that they will never be able to sell the BMW 5 series that they bought in the late 80s even though they don't feel it reflects the kind of people they are now. "We both worked in the financial sector when we met but now I am a teacher and David retrained as a doctor. We don't really like anything about the car except the fact that my waters broke all over the back seats when I was in labour with my first son Joseph. Because of that the car must belong to us and we belong to the car. It has transcended its function as a motor vehicle and because of this one little incident has become a deeply personal object."

So is it ever worth selling a car whose price can hardly reflect its emotional value? "Yes," says Dan, who is selling the Rover for £1,200, "but only if you love the car enough to let it go. It is a car that makes things happen and owning it has been a real adventure. So much has happened in that car. Anyone who buys it will not only be buying a beautiful machine but a piece of motoring history. The closure of Longbridge makes it even more poignant. If I feel that the buyer understands all this then the pain of seeing it drive away for good will be made much easier." Is there anyone out there?

webTitle: Road test  Honda Logo and HR-V

fields.headline: Road test  Honda Logo and HR-V
fields.trailText: If Honda's cunning market dream comes true, any man who buys a Logo will find a Benny Hill-style queue of women chasing his exhaust. Not since the 80s has Honda offered something smaller than the Civic for UK drivers. As a result, the Japanese maker believes it's been neglecting the girls. (Ironic then that out of around 40 journalists assembled to test it, I counted zero women.)
fields.body:
If Honda's cunning market dream comes true, any man who buys a Logo will find a Benny Hill-style queue of women chasing his exhaust. Not since the 80s has Honda offered something smaller than the Civic for UK drivers. As a result, the Japanese maker believes it's been neglecting the girls. (Ironic then that out of around 40 journalists assembled to test it, I counted zero women.)

The Logo is more stalking horse than prime candidate. Groomed to test European taste, it's a close rework of the same Logo that's been running around Japan for a few years. Its job is to smooth the road ahead for the successor, a Swindon-built mini scheduled for 2002.

In its league, the Logo comes up against the Polo, Clio and Peugeot 206. It has some good points: visibility is fine - the seating position, perhaps with women in mind, is pronounced. The car has nice, deep windows and the cabin is well lit. The engine (aluminium, 1.3) could provide more power and has no fizz after 60mph, but it feels like a quality job and is reasonably smooth (I'd like to see a rev counter, but that's a bloke thing).

But it's painfully bland. There are options that add an extra ripple of plastic to the front spoiler and rear roofline, but any attempt to beef up the Logo is like adding a red stripe to your wheelbarrow. It's so dull, it's invisible. Then you start to notice other styling goosebumps: the window frame on my driver's door was welded to the body with what looked like pie crust; the gearstick is like a liquorice pipe-cleaner and, from the pavement, you can gawp through the rear wheel arch and see the skinny exhaust.

This is wonderful news for Honda: when the Logo replacement arrives, it can't fail to be less drab. For now though, the price (£9,495) tends to put the premium rivals into perspective. What would you rather spend: £13,500 on a space-age Audi A2, or just less than £10,000 on a not-so-super mini?

Next to the Logo, Honda also has something far more palatable in the launch cupboard: a five-door version of the small HR-V offroader. Until now, you could get only a three-doored HR-V, but the car's sold so well to young drivers in search of quirkiness that Honda wanted to keep pace - in case they all settle down and breed.

For kicking sand, the HR-V was a great set of wheels, but its short undercarriage made it Mr Fidget on the motorway. By adding 10 centimetes to the length, you're not only able to have two more doors, you also get a machine that sits as it should in high-speed traffic. Now with more mature road manners, the car still has the same volume of bag space, including clever cargo hooks and underfloor storage sections. For added zip, there's now a 124bhp 1.6 engine, instead of the 103bhp.

Honda admits the HR-V is "not designed as a serious offroader". As with the bigger CR-V, the drive engages all four tyres only when it is needed - most of the time, you're in front-wheel drive mode.

While no major news event, the stretched HR-V is a worthy improvement. The car also has a certain urbane charm that the owners of Suzuki's Vitara, Daihatsu's Terios and other hairdressery can only dream about. Unlike the Logo, it shows the middle ground doesn't have to be dead flat.

Logo HR-V 5 door

Top speed 94mph 106mph

0-62mph 14.5 secs 11.3 secs

Engine 1343cc 1590cc

On the stereo Steps Beach Boys

For Um . . . Cheeky looks

Against Well . . . Lacks true 4x4 cred

As with the bigger CR-V, the drive engages all four tyres only when it is needed - most of the time, you're in front-wheel drive mode. While no major news event, the stretched HR-V is a worthy improvement. The car also has a certain urbane charm that the owners of Suzuki's Vitara, Daihatsu's Terios and other hairdressery can only dream about. Unlike the Logo, it shows the middle ground doesn't have to be dead flat. webTitle: Me and my motor: Kevin Sheerin

fields.headline: Me and my motor: Kevin Sheerin
fields.trailText: Kevin Sheerin is the driver of Ken Livingstone's campaign bus
fields.body:
Kevin Sheerin is the driver of Ken Livingstone's campaign bus

What sort of bus is it?

It's an open-top Metro bus from the mid 60s, an ex LT bus. It didn't use to be open top, but one of the drivers took it under a low bridge in Battersea - sliced the top off. He was supposed to turn left, did an illegal right instead and ignored all the low bridge signs. No one was hurt. He was a new driver but the police had to prosecute and he lost his job.

That's never happened to you?

No. I have to watch out for things like that - bridges, lamp-posts. It almost happened in Redbridge when we came across Steven Norris in his car (we were out looking for his bus but only found him in his car, going into the leisure centre). There was a 14ft bridge and we just made it under. I had to have someone on the roof to give me the all-clear.

That would have been embarrassing - crashing right in front of Norris.

Yeah, that would have gone done down really well.

What do you know about the other candidates' vehicles?

The Greens have got a bus I think. I heard it got pulled up for smoke emission - I don't know if that's true. Norris's bus got pulled over - but just for a routine check.

How green is your bus?

Very. We use this green fuel. It doesn't spew out black fumes like some do. Nothing comes out at all.

Is there anything else special about your bus?

All the seats upstairs have been taken out and it has a generator and speakers.

Who's on the bus?

There's a crew of about 15-20 volunteers. They just stand upstairs waving, and singing along with the music.

Where does Ken go?

He stands upstairs at the front with a hand held mic. There's a camera crew up there too so we have to take it very easily - no sudden braking if I can help it.

Isn't it off-putting, driving with all that racket going on?

I do sometimes have to tell them to turn it down. There are two speakers right above my head and when it echoes back off the sides of buildings it can be too much. Normally it doesn't bother me. You get used to it after four weeks.

What sort of reaction do you get from the bus?

We get a lot of waving and cheering. And the odd finger as well. There's also been at least a couple of moonies. One time when Ken was upstairs, this bloke came out of a betting shop on the Walworth Road to see what all the noise was about. And he just pulled his trousers down. He was quite friendly really. I think Ken was quite surprised - it was the first time it's happened to him on a campaign.

Will you vote for Ken?

Oh yes definitely. But I would have done anyway. I was there when he brought in "Fare's Fair" in the 80s and that was a good scheme.

Why is Ken always late?

He's not. We're always spot on time. To the minute. Yesterday we were a little bit late because we got held up round Liverpool Street, but normally we're spot on time.

webTitle: I changed my run-up and made Surrey sorry

fields.headline: I changed my run-up and made Surrey sorry
fields.standfirst: Every Monday throughout the English season wisden.com gets the inside story on one of the week's best performances. This week, Somerset seam bowler Steffan Jones, 26, talks about his 5 for 41 at Taunton on April 27, which helped bowl out Surrey for just 185.
fields.trailText: Imagine the scene. You're a bowler who hasn't played much Championship cricket because you're considered more of a one-day specialist. You're playing the reigning champions, your No. 1 bowler has just been carted during his opening spell, you come on second-change and your first over goes for 12 runs. What do you do? The important thing, as explained by the surprisingly soft Welsh voice of Steffan Jones, is not to panic.
fields.body:
Imagine the scene. You're a bowler who hasn't played much Championship cricket because you're considered more of a one-day specialist. You're playing the reigning champions, your No. 1 bowler has just been carted during his opening spell, you come on second-change and your first over goes for 12 runs. What do you do? The important thing, as explained by the surprisingly soft Welsh voice of Steffan Jones, is not to panic.

I started to think, if they can do that to Andy Caddick, what will they do to me? But after that first over, which was horrible, Marcus Trescothick noticed that my run-up wasn't right. I was running in too fast - so I adjusted it and it paid off. The ball was seaming around all over the place and I tried to vary the deliveries.

I bowled a full-length ball to Ally Brown which swung away and he nicked it to Marcus at second slip. I got one to rise sharply at Adam Hollioake and he tried to take his bat away but it hit his glove and went through to the keeper. I bowled a short one at Martin Bicknell and managed to get plenty of pace and bounce - he tried to play it but it hit his bat and rolled back on to the stumps. The ball to Ian Salisbury was one of the best I've bowled in a long time, full-length and on leg stump. He nicked it and it went through for Rob [Turner, the wicketkeeper] to take a great catch. Then I bowled a straight full-length delivery to Ian Bishop - he just missed it and it took out his middle stump.

I was definitely having a good day - I was fielding at fine leg when Andy Caddick got Ben Hollioake to chip one off his legs. It came to me really quickly and I didn't have much time so I just stuck my hand out. The others told me I looked really cool about it but my heart was thumping - I don't mind if you say that I didn't know much about that one!

It was particularly satisfying to play so well against Surrey - I think people tend to look for their results first as they're the champions and they have a lot of big names. To be honest I wasn't really expecting to be in the team, but now I've started hopefully I'll be a regular in the Championship side this year. My aim is to take 50 wickets - I'd be very satisfied with that.

I've given up rugby to concentrate on cricket, which was a tough decision. I've been training hard all winter, working on my run-up, trying to get more explosive pace and more power at the crease. I try to hit the wicket as hard as I can. I've also been working on my batting, with Peter Bowler as my mentor, but I'm still going in at No. 11. [Cue shouts in the background from the Somerset captain, Jamie Cox, saying he'll never get promoted.] I scored my first hundred last year, and I'm hoping to become a genuine all-rounder. But although I'll always give 100%, I know that players who boast always end up failing so I'm not making any claims in that direction!

Steffan Jones was talking to Catherine Hanley

fields.headline: A little local difficulty
fields.standfirst: The Scottish press is in chaos - relaunches, walk-outs, sackings and the prospect of another newspaper. Matt Wells assesses the chances for Andrew Neil's Scotsman when it reveals its new look next week
fields.trailText: The Scottish press is in chaos - relaunches, walk-outs, sackings and the prospect of another newspaper. Matt Wells assesses the chances for Andrew Neil's Scotsman when it reveals its new look next week
fields.body:
Holyrood Road is the heart of Inspector Rebus's Edinburgh: think council estates and run-down tenements. But these days the source of rivulets of blood flowing towards the Palace of Holyroodhouse is more likely to be slashed wrists in the Scotsman's swanky new headquarters than gang fights on the Dumbiedykes housing scheme.

One week before the Scotsman relaunches, complete with the S2 tabloid and overhauled picture-heavy broadsheet news section, the paper is not exactly experiencing a period of industrious teamwork. Rather, an executive merry-go-round at Scotland's national newspaper is in full spin.

In the past few months, barely a week has gone by without another resignation or sacking, culminating most recently with the announcement that editor Tim Luckhurst has been forced to take an extended period of sick leave, just as the final touches were being put to the paper's relaunch. For those staff who remain, led by former Daily Mail showbiz writer Rebecca Hardy, it is a period of unprecedented instability.

Yet, if that wasn't excitement enough, the Scotsman's rival in Glasgow is also undergoing a period of change, albeit at a rather more sedate pace. The Herald's editor Harry Reid is to step down, as the paper begins a gradual repositioning of its brand. And throwing the whole arena into confusion is the imminent launch of Scotland's first new national newspaper in over a century, backed by Bonnier - a Swedish media group whose name is almost unknown in Britain, but whose foray into Scotland could just signal a transformation in the entire British newspaper market. Anyone who still labours under the impression that the Scottish newspaper scene is not worth a second look is seriously deluded.

It is easy to focus on the troubles at the Scotsman at a time of such turmoil. Andrew Neil, the paper's publisher, is a convenient hate figure and has been (rightly, in the view of many observers) blamed for the Scotsman's woes. Its editorial stance has shifted radically from being a staunch supporter of devolution to Scotland's sceptic-in-chief. Teachers, social workers and other assorted lefties have felt the sharp end of the editorial pen. The trouble is, these assorted lefties make up the core of the its readership.

But while Neil-baiting is good clean fun - and patient readers will be rewarded with more soon - the development in Scotland which has the potential for far more impact on the rest of the UK media industry is the investment by Bonnier in the Scottish newspaper market. For the past two years, it has been conducting extensive research into the viability of a niche-market business and political daily newspaper aimed at the Scottish elite. Now, plans are well advanced for a new title, provisionally called Scottish Business, possibly to launch later this year. It should come as no surprise that many of the key staff at the new venture have been recruited from the Scotsman. Its editor, John Penman, is a former Scotsman political editor; his deputy, Richard Neville, quit his post as joint deputy editor at Holyrood Road a few weeks ago; a number of other former Scotsman staffers are now on the Penman payroll.

All, he says, have joined not because they were desperate to escape the clutches of Neil, but because they were genuinely excited by the new venture. "Nothing like this has ever been tried in Britain before," he enthuses.

As the bigger newspaper groups go global, Bonnier has identified a potential niche readership in Scotland of 600,000. Of course, circulation will be nothing like that: most observers reckon the new venture would be doing well if it topped 30,000. So how could it possibly survive? Penman insists that to write it off now demonstrates a serious misunderstanding of niche market potential: "We have got a very defined target market, and we know our readers extremely well. We will give our readers exactly what they want."

Such a tight readership base is attractive to advertisers seeking out a particular market. At the moment, because Scotland's newspaper scene is predominantly city-based, high-quality advertisers have to split their budgets between the Herald and the Scotsman, and possibly even Aberdeen's Press and Journal and the Dundee Courier as well. "We will give them one place to go," says Penman.

He says Bonnier knows what it is doing - it has an impressive track record in similar ventures around Europe. "They are not philanthropists, they are in it to make money." And if it works north of the border, the group has indicated it has its eyes set on England. Other proprietors should be worried by the upstart snapping at their heels.

Back in Scotland, Penman is keen to distance his paper from the instability elsewhere in the market. The Scotsman's impending relaunch and expected three-month price cut from 45p to 20p will have no effect, he insists. While the Scotsman pursues the Mail and even Daily Record readers, the new journal is seeking out an entirely new market. "What happens with the Scotsman will have no impact on our plans."

That is not, however, how others see it. "All eyes are on the Scotsman," says one Scottish newspaper editor. "If a price cut gets the Scotsman back up the circulation ladder, it is hard to see how the new paper can get a toehold as well. The Scottish newspaper market is so fierce."

However much Penman protests, it is clear that what happens at the Scotsman over the next few months is critical - and the problems at Scotland's national newspaper can not be underestimated. The exodus of staff has been of biblical proportions. And while Neil insists on these pages that he is glad to see the back of most of them, it should be pointed out that the departing hacks are not exactly members of a Scotsman establishment - that band all went three or four years ago during the reign of Martin Clarke.

Many say that Neil's problem is that he constantly appears to need an enemy against which to rail. What he fails to realise, says one recently departed senior staff member, is that the Scotsman had the youngest, most dynamic staff in Scottish newspapers. The abrupt sacking of the respected successor to Clarke, Alan Ruddock, and the stringent budget cuts in the last months of his reign, shook the core. "There was an incredible amount of goodwill. But when you start turning the screws on the staff, and alienating readers at the same time, things start to go wrong."

Neil's immediate challenge is to beef up the top echelons of the Scotsman hierarchy. The departure of Neville, and that of production editor Nigel Donaldson - a Scotsman veteran of 22 years and the man responsible for getting the paper out on time every night - were severe blows. Hardy, now in the acting editor chair after being parachuted in by Neil's resident consultant Sue Douglas to oversee the launch of the tabloid features section, has been shored up with a couple of key appointments. Terry Watson, experienced in production at the Scotsman, has been made acting deputy editor and Tom Little, former Glasgow bureau chief, is now assistant editor, news. And Jeff Randall, the editor of the Scotsman's sister paper Sunday Business, has agreed a flying visit as a safe pair of hands to oversee the business coverage in the Scotsman relaunch. In the longer term, if Luckhurst does not return from sick leave (and he is, contrary to unkind rumours, seriously ill) it is rumoured that Neil is seeking north and south of the border for a Scottish intellectual heavyweight to run the paper.

In the short term, the Scotsman will undoubtedly gain a swell of readers over a summer of price-cutting - perhaps clearing the ever-elusive 100,000 barrier. But to retain them it will have to get itself a clear editorial strategy. However much Neil hates them personally, the Scotsman must learn to love its leftie readers.

Matt Wells is a former Scotsman journalist
