fields.headline: Hitchens and me
fields.standfirst: He's one of the most enigmatic journalists left in the trade, but he allowed novice film-maker  Palash Davé  to follow him round the US armed with only a digital camera
fields.trailText: He's one of the most enigmatic journalists left in the trade, but he allowed novice film-maker Palash Davé to follow him round the US armed with only a digital camera
fields.body:
In April 1999, the British radical journalist Christopher Hitchens prepared to tour the United States with his latest savage but elegant screed, No One Left To Lie To: The Triangulations of William Jefferson Clinton. Fresh out of college, struggling with freelance writing stints and bored of acting gratis in underground plays, I decided to pick up a camera, take off and join him.

I had first met "Hitch" in 1995 when I was an undergraduate, at a forum on Radical Journalism convened by the New Statesman. As someone who seemed scarcely to have aged in spirit since his 60s street-fighting days, Hitchens cut quite a heroic figure (as he still does) among many of the young aspirants to whom he spoke. Then, some months before his books tour, while he was a visiting lecturer at UC Berkeley's journalism school, I had visited him and struck up a distant friendship.

When the Observer published an extract from his Clinton book, I sent him an email, discovered he was touring the US, and decided I had found the ideal subject for a film. I'd just bought a digital video camera and was vainly trying to make a documentary. But a grand tour of the major American cities, studying the stateside reaction to this very English internationalist savaging the leader of the Free World, seemed like a much better gig.

It was with guarded admiration and affection - and the certain promise of gathering telegenic material - that I flew out on a whim to film Hitchens' sybaritic stateside book tour, as he attempted with some success to whip up an orgy of scepticism towards the president.

I secured vague interest (but no funding) from the production company that had turned out Hitchens' last film. The Mourning After was Hitchens' essay on the hysteria that followed the death of Princess Diana, and it was strangely squandered by Channel 4 on a late-night slot during that brief, culture-wide window of revisionism on the anniversary of her death in 1998. The company offered to pitch my film to the channel while I was in the US, with the aim of turning it around within a few weeks. With this tentative proposal, I flew out to New York four days after conceiving the idea.

Digital video and home desktop editing were much-vaunted at the time in guerrilla film-making circles, both as democratising tools and as a way to get out and make movies on the cheap, without waiting for years to garner professional experience, development funding and commissions. I wanted to find out whether this technology could empower a complete novice to shoot, edit, direct and produce a half-way decent documentary film.

Hitchens occupies a unique position in America's media culture. He crossed over in the early 80s, when he was poached from the New Statesman by the small, prestigious left-liberal magazine, The Nation, and sent to fill the great IF Stone's shoes as its Washington correspondent. In 1992 Graydon Carter, the urbane Canadian founder of Spy magazine (New York's Private Eye), took the editor's chair at Vanity Fair, and made his old friend and fellow bon-vivant satirist a contributing editor.

Hitch, the "lazy Balliol dandy with the killer instinct of a pit-bull terrier" (according to Jonathan Raban) had already aroused the suspicions of his Trotskyite student comrades at Oxford because of the ease with which he would change from donkey jacket to dinner jacket and back. Similarly, with his new role in his hated Washington, he would rub shoulders with the political elite (though he was never quite the insider that he has lazily been tagged), and then rub their noses in their own troughs.

His microcelebrity status in the US was ratcheted up several notches by his deposition last February to the House Judiciary Committe, the very last act in the impeachment trial of President Clinton. Hitchens testified, on the basis of a lunch he'd had with a friend and White House aide, that the White House had been systematically defaming Monica Lewinsky and other women who had come forward to challenge the president.

CNN's unflattering bright lights homed in on the unshaven, boozy, limey hack as he left Congress, and his notoriety reached household proportions overnight. Here, in a ballroom in the Washington Hilton, was the American political-media consensus made flesh, bathed in rich gravy and washed down with cheap wine.

The nauseating stench of a common purpose between chief executive and fourth estate led Hitchens to slip out before Clinton's speech and prepare for his role as de facto host of the Vanity Fair after-party. Meanwhile, my camera caught Clinton's eerily charming quips about the battles he'd had with his audience of reporters over the preceding 12 months. And it caught, in turn, the journalists' enthusiastic appreciation of their president's apparent magnanimity.

Gatecrashing the White House correspondents' dinner was always the kind of thing any investigative journalist worth his salt could have pulled off. But only with mini-DV does it become possible to smuggle in a broadcast-quality camera with which to capture the closed-door proceedings with crystal clarity.

Now, incredibly, and thanks to a commissioning system that has begun to catch up with the technology, my experiment in guerrilla film-making finally paid off with a sale to Channel 4's prolific low-budget DV strand, The Other Side.

That's not to say it paid off financially. Notoriously, films for The Other Side (made by the production company Ideal World) are produced for a micro-budget of £5,000. This includes a £1,000 fee for the director and 10 days in linear and non-linear edit suites. (A normal 50-minute documentary would take six weeks to edit.) Many film-makers come to the series, as I did, with half-finished projects that have had more than £1,000 worth of money and time invested in them, so that Channel 4 has been accused of effectively taking a subsidy from the film-maker.

Darren Bender, commissioning editor of 4Later, disagrees: "The channel could not afford to give so many brand new film-makers (110 so far) the chance to get their films made any other way. If I wanted to save money by filling late night with cheap programmes I'd show some of the free American shows that are sitting in the library."

There are potential downsides here. Some in the industry warn that the pressure to slash budgets and further exploit workers will only get worse when managers see that programmes can be made on the cheap. Others feel that the shift from film and Digi-Beta to DV heralds a decline in the technical quality of documentaries. But The Other Side is marginal to the schedules, a technical experiment as well as a showcase for new talents. The mainstream use of cheap and basic one-person DV crews in the schedules has concentrated on programmes such as The Real Holiday Show and Deals on Wheels, where access is required.

And the attraction of DV-stock costs low enough to allow you to shoot extensive rushes will not be lost on observational documentary-makers - even those working on well-funded TV factual strands. The concerns are real, and it's important that the debate over new technical and editorial formats isn't miscast in generational terms.

But from my own experience I would not hesitate to encourage untrained aspiring film-makers to blag access to a camera and try their hands. People have been doing it since the birth of film, but there are now unprecedented opportunities to produce near-professional material that will air on national, terrestrial television.

fields.headline: Hello boys!
fields.standfirst: After spearheading Maxim's assault on the US market,  Mike Soutar  last week announced his return to Britain - to shake up IPC's male mag scene (and drink warm beer). Here he draws a few parallels with our transatlantic cousins
fields.trailText: After spearheading Maxim's assault on the US market, Mike Soutar last week announced his return to Britain - to shake up IPC's male mag scene (and drink warm beer). Here he draws a few parallels with our transatlantic cousins
fields.body:
As usual Felix Dennis, chairman of Dennis Publishing, stole the show when he announced my departure from the editor's chair at his magazine Maxim US. His press release to US media last week was a classic piece of mischief and spin. "Soutar," he headlined it, "- missing soccer team, warm beer, weird spelling, bad plumbing - returns to head up British publishing division!"

And what a publishing division. By July, I'll be back in London as managing director of IPC's Music & Sport, overseeing some of the most high profile media brands in men's entertainment, including Loaded, Later and the NME. I can't wait. In the meantime, I am in the position of being able to pontificate on the peculiarities of men's publishing on both sides of the Atlantic. Which is why, I presume, the Guardian has asked me to write this.

So, America. The most striking thing about the US men's publishing business in 2000 is how much it resembles the UK men's publishing business back in 1995. Remember how British GQ and British Esquire - the established, snooty, advertiser-worshipping titles - were usurped so quickly by the funny, reader-driven men's upstarts led by Loaded and FHM? Well, it's happening all over again in the US. Only this time Maxim leads the brash upstarts. And this time, the established, snooty, advertiser-worshipping titles are . . . American GQ and American Esquire! Shouldn't they be sacking people over at Condé Nast and Hearst for screwing up so badly? Twice in a row?

The new titles are, frankly, running away with it. Maxim has achieved figures well in excess of 2m this year, double its 1999 circulation. Stuff is bumping up against 1m and it hasn't even published 10 issues yet. FHM launched here three months ago and if that's not outselling GQ's 700,000 and Esquire's 600,000 within a year, they'll be disappointed. Meanwhile, 10-year-old style mag Details has bitten the dust as a general interest magazine, and will be relaunched as a fashion book after summer.

Five years ago in the UK, the established titles reacted decisively to the threat of the new by, er, pretending nothing was happening - that the new wave of men's titles were just a flash in the pan, that they'd soon go away and things would be like they were before. Until recently, that's exactly what Art Cooper and David Granger - the editors-in-chief of GQ and Esquire respectively - were saying here. Cooper, who is approximately 1,000 years old, was quoted last year as saying that Maxim's readers were a) losers, and b) "masturbators". At the start of this year, he shamefacedly let slip that Condé Nast research showed that the majority of Maxim readers also read GQ. Statistically speaking, given that Maxim has now three times GQ's circulation, he has to go down as the first magazine editor in history to call all of his own readers wankers. He hasn't spoken publicly much since.

Esquire's Granger is taking a smarter and more realistic approach, finally recognising that Maxim and the others do what they do, and they're good at it; but he wants to do something different and capture some mythical "high ground". Whether he'll achieve this or not is as uncertain as whether his counterpart on UK Esquire, Peter Howarth, will get his magazine out of the doldrums by putting big blokes' faces on his cover.

But at least they're facing up to the fact that, like women's magazines, men's general interest magazines won't go away any time soon. In both the US and the UK, they are now an established part of men's lives. There is a whole generation of male readers which is now conditioned to expect magazines that entertain and enlighten them, and bring them useful, relevant stuff to look at and read.

Guys are simply not going to go back to reading specialist magazines about trout fishing and ferret breeding, unless the general interest men's magazines forget to grow with them. (Incidentally, I think that was at the root of the UK men's magazine "slump" scare six months ago: there was no overall drop in total figures, it was just that the leading titles had forgotten to evolve their offerings, become formulaic and started to shed bored readers.)

So to the future. The Holy Grail now, of course, is to be first to figure out where to guide that audience of men who are growing out of the twenty-something men's titles. IPC's Later, launched for that very purpose, has had a decent start but will still take some developing - and I look forward to being involved in that. The conventional wisdom is that older men want magazines stuffed with features about the child support agency, their careers, their weight and, um, fatherhood skills. But that sounds pretty dire to me. I don't think I've ever had a conversation with another man about male "issues". I don't think that I want to be reminded of the grown-up parts of my life. In fact, there's a good case for proposing that what men want as they get older is less realism, more escapism and more fun.

What I am betting on, given the lead that the UK has over the US in pioneering men's publishing formats, is that the revolution will happen in Britain. Thanks for the last year, Felix; it's been a blast. I'll buy you a warm beer back in London any time . . .

fields.headline: Alive and kicking
fields.standfirst: The BBC still hasn't found a new head of current affairs. But don't panic, urges  Mark Damazer  - rumours of the demise of the great Beeb investigation have been greatly exaggerated
fields.trailText:
The BBC still hasn't found a new head of current affairs. But don't panic, urges Mark Damazer - rumours of the demise of the great Beeb investigation have been greatly exaggerated

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.body:
Last week's Media Guardian read the last rites over BBC current affairs, which, it said, is apparently at an all-time low - again. But before the undertaker arrives it might be worth pausing to look at the quality of the journalism produced by the programme teams here. Of course, it is tougher than it used to be to command a place in the schedules. Everyone in the industry is acutely aware that a lot of the audience has a lot of choice. Journalists know that television current affairs needs to fight harder than ever before to seize the imagination and make an impact. But there is much to be proud about .

The gravediggers fretted about Panorama. The programme has a far wider remit than any ITV current affairs strand. It does not turn its nose up at good, popular stories - provided there is something new to say. The investigation into the health risks associated with mobile phones pulled a big audience - and contained significant new research. The exposure of the extent of price fixing by big car manufacturers targeted senior figures in the boardroom - who were not short of legal advice. The competition commission followed up. And long before bank closures became headline fodder, Panorama revealed just how keen the banks are to lose customers who don't add to profits.

But surely Panorama - even on BBC1 - must be allowed the right to chase stories that have less immediate box-office potential. It was Panorama that broke new ground on the killing of Rosemary Nelson. Nowhere else in television current affairs has so much been done to reveal the Labour party's frantic efforts to control the consequences of devolution (programmes widely praised by reviewers and disliked in Millbank Tower). And if it was the Guardian that unravelled the government's byzantine accounting claims for expenditure in education, it was Panorama that did the same for the health service. And so on.

Current affairs has mutated. Twenty years ago - perhaps even 10 years ago - all you had to do to gauge the health of current affairs was look at a handful of distinguished, long-running titles - headed by Panorama and World in Action - and stay alert for a very occasional series or blockbuster event (A Question of Ulster). Current affairs can now be just as well assessed by focusing on the many two- or three-parters, supplemented by individually titled single documentaries, that are deeply embedded in the BBC2 and Channel 4 schedules - and, from time to time, BBC1 too. And some of these are very strong - last month's unflinching and unsentimental look at the plight of Romanian children who came to the UK after Ceausescu's fall (The Forgotten Children, BBC1), the headline-generating Spying Game on BBC2, and many others.

There is a case for re-examining how the identity of the strands fits together with the journalism on offer elsewhere. It was a Panorama team that put together the two-hour Kosovo anniversary programme on BBC2 - which unearthed political, diplomatic and military stories that normally stay buried until the memoirs are written. It might have been better to keep a Panorama title around the programme but as things stand titles are associated with channels.

There are other, bigger issues. There were good daily current affairs programmes before the birth of Newsnight (1979) and Channel 4 News (1982), but these two have set very high standards for reactive, studio-based journalism. If Newsnight devotes most - or all - of a programme to, say, the Macpherson report or the release of General Pinochet or the Tony Martin verdict, what should BBC1 and ITV offer outside the scheduled news bulletins? Should we consciously set out to change the balance of resources we put into daily news and current affairs and work that takes longer to reach the audience? How many editions of a programme like Panorama do you need to have in one year to maximise impact while keeping a profile?

Can current affairs find a consistent and coherent proposition that attracts younger audiences? Can someone reinvent a serious television contribution to policy debates (something we have not managed to do in recent years)?

None of this is easy and it would be perverse for me to assert that everything is just fine as it is. There needs to be a debate about the future of current affairs, but things will change - because they often do and because they should. They changed when John Birt was here. When he arrived he hardly had such popular formats as Here and Now or Crime Squad in the front of his mind. And things will change under Greg Dyke - and why not? There is plenty to ponder. This generation of BBC current affairs programme makers is as good as any that has come before it. They deserve to be part of a debate - not a funeral.

Mark Damazer is assistant director of BBC News and formerly head of BBC current affairs

fields.headline: A very British mess
fields.standfirst: As ITV bosses hold crisis talks to cobble together a news rescue plan,  Maggie Brown  looks at the series of blunders that led to a showdown with the regulator
fields.trailText: As ITV bosses hold crisis talks to cobble together a news rescue plan, Maggie Brown looks at the series of blunders that led to a showdown with the regulator
fields.body:
ITV is in turmoil. Its senior executives, fury barely controlled, have been in constant meetings for the past few days, with more to come this week. They are trying to cobble together a plan to win big audiences back to news programmes, without bringing back News at Ten, or being forced into a News at 10.30pm compromise.

Are their hearts in it? "It's like being told to revive a Des O'Connor Show when you know in your heart you can't," says one key observer. They believe heavy political pressure has been applied. "What time ITV shows its news has absolutely nothing to do with the government," says one of the channel's leading executives.

Extraordinarily, no one within ITV seems to have anticipated that the regulator, the independent television commission (which pliantly allowed ITV to bring in a radical new schedule on March 8, 1999), would rule, after reviewing the first year, that the status quo was unacceptable - and demand detailed proposals to reverse the slide by May 18. "[ITV has] been in denial about it," says an executive. Crucially, the diplomatic architect of the original deal, Richard Eyre, has moved on; fatally, the role of ITV network chief executive is vacant. When the 10 members of the commission met on April 20, they were in a grim mood. They know they are handling the hottest of hot political potatoes. And that their role so far in protecting ITV from folly has hardly been heroic.

Research before them outlined the substantial collapse in ITV's news audiences, down 13.9% in a year for national bulletins, and an "unacceptable" 22% on average for regional news. (In the worst case, Northeast Tonight is down by 33%.) When they had greenlighted the changes - on November 19 1998, sealing the death of News at Ten - the meeting was swung by the full-time senior officials, who said it was time to free up ITV to allow more variety and combat audience decline.

Despite huge support for News at Ten in November, much was made of research which showed that the public, if offered the choice, wanted a wider range of programming. The members split, but the move towards a lighter touch won majority backing, and, predictably, unleashed huge controversy. Recklessly, ITV opted to change within four months, before its replacement line-up was ready.

This time ITV bosses expected that their argument - that such a massive change needed more time to settle in - would again win the day, although they were savaged by Gerald Kaufman's culture, media and sport committee in March. They expected to escape the regulatory rocks and face yet another review in a year's time. In the month before the key meeting, ITV started furiously promoting its nightly news programmes and presenters, with posters, press ads, and on-air plugs. It was too late.

Instead, led by chairman Sir Robin Biggam, and with a roster of new members uncommitted to the original decision around the table, the commission unanimously rallied behind the tough statement, tugging officials behind them. Biggam, a pragmatic businessman who in 1998 declared that it was not the job of a regulator in this age to dictate the time news was shown, has completely changed tack. He is now signalling that he wants resolute action, not a fudge. Insiders say: "He's raising the temperature. We think he wants the 11pm News moved forward, to 10.30pm."

When the changes came in, shortly before the Kosovo War last March, no one knew for sure what would happen, given that mass market audiences are on the slide. Behind the scenes, the commission indicated that it could live with a single-figure decline in news audience figures. But the outcome has been far worse than anyone predicted. For instance, the appeal of regional news in the early evening has been hard hit by a revamped Neighbours on BBC1.

Within ITV, there is no appetite for bringing back News at Ten, no matter what Tony Blair and other politicians facing an election perhaps a year away think. Nor does the 10.30pm slot find favour, though it's the most likely option to fix part of the problem. As ITV executives know only too well, millions have been committed to making programmes for the 10-11 pm slot, from two-hour dramas spanning 9-11pm to Real Lives documentaries.

But beating away at the centre of the debate is an argument that extends way beyond News at Ten. It's about the amount of regulation which is deemed appropriate for the media - in this case commercial television - an issue obviously raised by the proposed Carlton/United merger, which is far more critical for the network even than News at Ten.

Biggam was leading ITV towards the lighter touch regulation most see as inevitable in a multi-channel era in the run-up to a new communications white paper and then bill. Yet the very same politicians who wax lyrical about the huge potential of the digital era and e-commerce have reacted furiously to protect something which harks back to the 1960s, a primetime ITV news show. From Blair's outburst in 1998 to Kaufman's report, they clearly view television as much more than a purely profit-making industry. What, then, will they do with the competition commission's report on the merger, due out next month?

The confusion is inherent, too, in the stance of advertisers. They are opposed to further ITV consolidation because of the unacceptable concentration of media airtime brought under one roof. But the institute of practitioners in advertising, a key lobby behind last year's changes, attacked the commission's interven tion: "At a time when we have been pressing for a lighter touch regulation, we view regulator demands based on the ratings levels of individual programmes with some alarm." Can you have it both ways? Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB - another advocate of a light touch - asked last week: "How can you still regulate ITV in this manner in an age of true multi-channel choice? Is there really any point in worrying about falling audiences for one particular news programme in a world of five 24-hour news channels?"

Yet behind the commission's decision to get tough lies substantial research into the views of 6,000 people. It constitutes a frank anatomy of ITV. Read it and you understand why this is the hottest of political issues. ITV is seen as "light-hearted with entertainment at its core". But within this approachable channel, ITN news (and News at Ten in particular) was seen as "the people's news". It was "broad-minded, understandable, recognisable, light-hearted and straight. In sum, ITV news is credible yet not in-your-face." In contrast, BBC News was described as "businessman's news" and characterised as "pompous, difficult, serious and reluctant to change". The survey also contains a riposte to those who say the solution is 24-hour news. Even people who take news less seriously than others "expected television to motivate their involvement. This suggests that the rolling news coverage offered by cable and satellite is inappropriate."

The research highlights the impossibility of getting a solution to suit everyone; 53% of respondents felt they were watching less news, but 57% liked watching dramas and films uninterrupted by News at Ten. However, there was a real sense of grievance that the schedule changes had not delivered good films. The research talks of a sense of betrayal.

Whatever happens, it's clear the new 6.30pm Evening News is a bit too early for most people, and the 11pm Nightly News too late, while late-night regional news is judged irrelevant and the early evening regional programmes too long. It remains truly surprising that the commission took so much on trust in 1998. But in trying to retrieve ground now, it knows that the last thing the ITV barons want is to start legal challenges, or make relations with the government any worse. It's a very British mess.

Nick Pollard, head of Sky News, former executive producer of News at Ten
"My head tells me such things have gone with the end of regulation. My heart tells me that the weaker ITN is, the better for Sky - though if you believe in quality TV news you don't want that. I don't believe News at Ten will come back, though there would be an audience for it. People have a feeling that news at 10 o'clock is right - there is a definite switch-on factor for our programme."

Nicky Campbell, Radio 5 Live presenter
"The return of News at Ten would seem an unnecessary addition to the abundance of bulletins we have now. If I want a 10pm news hit I'll watch Sky or the vastly improved News 24; I'd listen to The World Tonight, or get a short blast of 5 Live. I suppose I miss Trevor intoning "and finally", or Sir Alastair drooling "today Princess Diana went shopping", but it's in the same way I miss World in Action, 24 Hours or Nationwide - as TV history."

Lindsay Nicholson, editor-in-chief, Good Housekeeping
"The change was a tragedy. News at Ten had tremendous cultural significance. Ordinary people talked about it. The timing was perfect: 11pm is too late if you have to get children up for school or go to work. ITV hasn't replaced it with anything memorable; since it's gone I barely watch ITV."

Ray Barrett, founder of ad agency BCD&P
"I don't think News at Ten will ever reclaim the enormous gap it once occupied. Serious news audiences have Channel 4 News, News 24, Sky News, even Bloomberg. Or people want soundbite news, like Channel 5's. For advertisers there is a loss: you could use the 10.15pm ad break to launch your most powerful images."

Mandy Merck, professor of media arts, University of London
"I want the news back at 10pm. Not for Reithian reasons, or to scupper Lord Hollick's chances to coin another billion - just to escape more evenings of prime time pulp. So I'm tuning to BBC2 and waiting for Newsnight."

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: * What's happening to that pillar of Radio 4's schedule, The News Quiz? It seems that the diary has not been alone in noticing that sometimes it's hard to follow. A reader who raised a particularly bewildering April edition with the BBC has received the following explanation: some of the questions about the week's news are being cut out, to fit in the panel's best jokes, resulting "in the show not making sense". The recording in question went on for one hour and 16 minutes, and was edited down to 28 minutes, meaning five out of the 16 questions put to the four panellists were lost. "It's a comedy show and not a news programme," says the BBC. But it seems to be veering more towards the crafted mannerisms of its TV lovechild, Have I Got News For You, and away from spontaneous wit. New controller Helen Boaden might want to inject a framework of sense.
fields.body:
* What's happening to that pillar of Radio 4's schedule, The News Quiz? It seems that the diary has not been alone in noticing that sometimes it's hard to follow. A reader who raised a particularly bewildering April edition with the BBC has received the following explanation: some of the questions about the week's news are being cut out, to fit in the panel's best jokes, resulting "in the show not making sense". The recording in question went on for one hour and 16 minutes, and was edited down to 28 minutes, meaning five out of the 16 questions put to the four panellists were lost. "It's a comedy show and not a news programme," says the BBC. But it seems to be veering more towards the crafted mannerisms of its TV lovechild, Have I Got News For You, and away from spontaneous wit. New controller Helen Boaden might want to inject a framework of sense.

*The Blair baby, due in two weeks, is starting to loom large in media minds. Cherie and Tony are expected to give just one photocall, but that's not stopping the cameramen plotting. "It's a nightmare, we're planning to mount 24-hour stakeouts, everyone wants the picture of Cherie departing from Downing Street or arriving at the hospital," says a prominent political editor. Meanwhile, Lindsay Nicholson - editor-in-chief of Good Housekeeping and its spin-off monthly, She's Having a Baby - reports that, as a close friend of the Blairs, she's inundated with daily calls from foreign news crews and magazines seeking interviews. "There's a huge level of interest. I could give up my day job and just become a baby correspondent," she says. "I'm refusing all invitations. It's a very private thing."

*Mal Young, the BBC's head of drama series, has made quite an impact in the past two years with the launch of Casualty spin-off Holby City, Harbour Lights, Sunburn and Doctors. And he'll be soaking up quite a bit of the extra £8m allocated to drama by Greg Dyke. So the Diary's delighted to pass on the tag his staff have coined for the typical Young production, courtesy of the Stage newspaper. "He's brilliant at long-running series, not so good at something a bit harder like Silent Witness," says a script editor. "It's all those soap stars he has. We have a name for what he does: Malodrama".

*BSkyB boss Tony Ball attracted a big audience keen to get his measure, including Greg Dyke, for an after-dinner speech to the Royal Television Society last week. But his thunder was stolen by reckless questioning from one Julie Hull, who branded Sky a "superbly parasitic organisation". Standing at Ball's side was Sarah Thane, host, chair of the RTS and programme director of the supposedly Independent Television Commission - where Hull toils in the policy department.

*The Bank of Scotland- sponsored Scottish press awards nominations list has just reached the diary desk. Among the nominations are Scotsman scribe Jenny Booth, for reporter of the year. Yes, you've guessed it, Booth was one of those to fall victim to the Scotsman axe recently. Oops.

*With the search on for a heavyweight intellectual to edit the Scotsman, the hot seat needs filling over at the Herald in Glasgow, too. A number of names are in the frame - but one not yet mentioned is the editor at Andrew Neil's Edinburgh Evening News, John McLellan. He's something of a closet intellectual and, due to the hours he puts in at the Balmoral hotel gym every lunchtime, is most certainly heavyweight.

*The row over News at Ten has made it certain that no one will be appointed as chief executive of the ITV Network until a deal is sorted out. However, things are looking up at the unloved ITC, where chief executive Peter Rogers plans to retire by September. The headhunters have done their work: it's now down to a shortlist, with an announcement due shortly.

*Television journalists: know your place. The overwhelming view of the public is that the job doesn't involve creative decisions, because "news is news", according to ITC audience research. "What do you mean, 'What they should cover'?"a young woman from London asked a researcher. "They have to cover the news. What's happened, what's going on, there's not a lot of deciding to do about it."

You can contact Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

webTitle: Free publicity might cost Motorola dear, as we reveal in the first of an occasional series

fields.headline: Free publicity might cost Motorola dear, as we reveal in the first of an occasional series
fields.trailText: Question: how long does it take to persuade 10 local journalists to step out on a summer's evening for an all expenses paid booze-up?
fields.body:
Question: how long does it take to persuade 10 local journalists to step out on a summer's evening for an all expenses paid booze-up?

Answer: If you're a leading public relations firm working for a white-hot technology company, around 32 hours - for a total bill of £2,240. And that's before you chuck in the vol-au-vents and sparkling wine. Or beer.

This fascinating insight into the workings - and expense - of the hyperactive technology spin sector was delivered to the Guardian this week by what one must assume was a misdirected fax, transmitted twice, both times with a cover sheet marked "Urgent News Release".

The fax was, in fact, a communication between PR company Firefly and its client Motorola, and contained a whole sheet of similar proposals as part of the company's "suggested 12-month retainer proposal" with the mobile phone giant.

The knees-up, planned for August, is one of a programme of events for local journalists, and the price quoted is for the PR effort required to contact the "10 key local press", and persuade them to come along. The annual bill for this kind of work - taking an average 4.5 days a month - comes in "at under £29,000," the document says.

The treats are not just for the local journalists. The inhabitants of Swindon, where Motorola has a large site, will be treated to "100 things you never knew about Motorola" in their local media, if all goes to plan. "Motorola," the proposal reminds us, "is a big part of the Swindon community and an interesting place to work." Reinforcing that point will be press releases that will cost £1,400 to produce.

The most expensive event in the first five months of the plan is a round table discussion for the benefit of four "niche" journalists, costing £5,600 to plan, execute and follow up - or £1,400 a hack. The journalists, joined by a panel of four experts, will discuss what the high-speed UMTS mobile phone market will look like by 2005.

The prices may appear high. But with multi-million pound funding rounds and share offerings commonplace, and with more venture-capital-rich dot.coms than there are reputable PR firms, successful agencies such as Firefly are being pitched to by potential clients, rather than the other way round.

And as those dot.coms splash their cash on attempting to get their names known in the increasingly crowded internet world, mentions of their brand in the press are worth much more than their weight in gold.

This, of course, counts as a "national mention" in that all-important metrics column. Which raises another question: could the accidentally leaked fax be a new weapon in the internet PR war? In which case, all other "accidental" leaks can be sent to the usual Guardian Online number. Just the once will do, though.

Neil McIntosh is deputy editor of Guardian Online

And as those dot.coms splash their cash on attempting to get their names known in the increasingly crowded internet world, mentions of their brand in the press are worth much more than their weight in gold. This, of course, counts as a "national mention" in that all-important metrics column. Which raises another question: could the accidentally leaked fax be a new weapon in the internet PR war? In which case, all other "accidental" leaks can be sent to the usual Guardian Online number. Just the once will do, though. Neil McIntosh is deputy editor of Guardian Online

fields.headline: Carla's court
fields.standfirst:
Seven years after an International War Crimes Tribunal was established, the men who raped, murdered and tortured their neighbours in the former Yugoslavia are at last facing their accusers in the Hague. Maggie O'Kane meets the mafia-busting Swiss judge set on bringing Slobodan Milosevic to justice

Kosovo: special report

fields.body:
Three judges sit up on the bench looking straight at the witness who is screened from the public by a large cream venetian blind. Everything is blue except the polished teak veneer benches. The stenographer is dressed in jeans and a white shirt. The three judges - male, female, black, white - talk soothingly to the witness. Would you like a break? Another glass of water, perhaps? How is the hotel? The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia is a haven of political correctness and human civility.

Then you sit for a while in one of those blue seats and listen. Or catch snippets of the short circuit television broadcast that wafts along the corridors where people chat about where to go for lunch.

A lawyer on the TV screens asks the witness: "When the bodies were laid out, dead, on the football pitch, did there seem many more of them than when you had seen them alive and crowded into the gym?"

A 23-year-old man, the only survivor of the massacre of 7,000 men and boys in a field near Srebrenica, is asked by the judge if he wants to say anything. "If I could speak in the name of the innocent victims, I would forgive the actual perpetrators of the executions because they were misled," he says. Inside the blue courtroom, the weight of justice is palpable.

"Do you recognise the man who raped you?"

"Yes, I can recognise him."

"Can you look around the courtroom and let us know where he is?"

"He is there, with the security guard on his right."

"For identification purposes, can you describe him? Please take your time."

"He had a light blue tie and a dark blue suit."

"What is the name of the man who raped you."

"His name is Zoran Vukovic."

The guard tries to hold his gaze straight ahead, but the temptation to sneak a look at Vukovic is too much. Vukovic sits still, only the fingers of his right hand fumbling with the papers in front of him.

Unnoticed by the world, dramas like these are being played out five days a week in the Hague. It has been a good spring for the tribunal. Last month, for the first time in the history of war, a United Nations court focused exclusively on rape as a war crime. The trial was running simultaneously with that of one of generals accused of the massacre of 7,000 Muslim men in Srebrenica. Two weeks later, the champagne bottles were cracked open following the arrest of a top political aide to Radovan Karadzic, the psychiatrist with the big hair who led the Bosnian Serbs in the bad, bad years.

Thirty-seven suspected war criminals are already here. The last one was delivered only a week ago to chief prosecutor Carla Del Ponte's remand centre by the sea. At a cost to the United Nations of £116.14 per day, each prisoner gets art classes twice a week, video, a coffee machine, satellite TV and conjugal visits. Such is the backlog, these men will wait for at least two and a half years before they step into one of the Hague's three courts.

But the prisoners do not include any of the three big names: Karadzic; his creator, Slobodan Milosevic, president of Serbia; and their loyal, brutal general, Ratko Mladic.

When Graham Blewitt, an Australian lawyer who specialised in the prosecution of Nazis, arrived as deputy prosecutor in February 1994, he found an empty office with a desk and chairs: "I started making calls around the world, to Scotland, England, the United States, trying to recruit the right people. We had stacks of applications, but they were from lawyers who had no skills in this area. In the end, it was the old Nazi network that took on the core of the work here."

Six years later, Blewitt has built an institution with a budget of almost $100m, with 832 staff working as judges, lawyers, intelligence analysts, field investigators, forensic experts and translators. Others have come and gone, but on a Saturday afternoon you can still find Blewitt in his office, trawling through papers and listening to classical music.

"You get bitten by the war crimes work. It gets into your blood. It has been so exciting, just getting this thing started and off the ground. When we got here, there was nothing."

Next door to Blewitt's third floor office is his new boss, Del Ponte, a Swiss-born judge who has already taken on the mafia and corrupt Russian politicians. Today she's in a good mood. George Robertson, Britain's former defence secretary and now secretary general of Nato, has just visited her office. Robertson has power and is one of the strongest supporters the Hague has ever had.

Normally, Del Ponte hates the press, but today she's happy to pose in front of her wanted poster with a "watch this space" look in her eye. She won't talk about when she expects Karadzic, Milosevic and Mladic to arrive at her jail, but gives the impression that Karadzic, at least, could be here quite soon. "Come back and talk to me in a couple of weeks," she says.

Unlike her predecessors, Del Ponte is now also getting cooperation from the French, who were once so indifferent to picking up war criminals that their soldiers rented houses from them. "President Chirac was here in February and she handed him an new arrest order," says a Hague employee. "Ten days later we had the guy here."

The man Del Ponte wants most is Milosevic. If he is arrested he will be the first democratically elected leader to face the justice of an international court, theoretically laying the legal framework of a system that could try Russia's president elect for Chechnya; could have tried Nixon for Chile or Cambodia. That would not make everyone happy; the US is the most fervent opponent of a permanent international court.

In these old insurance company offices in the centre of the dull, well-organised city of the Hague, generous salaries mean that some of the staff can earn double what they get in most of their 68 home countries. Jeffrey Nice, 52, a wealthy English barrister, abandoned his practice in London for a year to prosecute war criminals. Part of his work involved the prosecution of a man who called himself the Serbian Adolf and whose favourite method of execution was to ask his victims to kneel on the ground and place their heads on a grate so it would make less of a mess.

Nice, who lives in Canterbury, says the two things that shock him about his work are the "ease with which a common criminal turned into a killer once you put a mobile phone in one hand and a gun in another", and the bewildering submissiveness of the victim. "It seemed like they queued up and waited to be executed. One minute they are well nourished people living in comfortable homes and the next they've got their head on the grate, waiting to be executed.

"You'll never, in England, have cases of such sheer scale. Here your overall project is to deliver international justice."

Terry Cameron, a field investigator in Bosnia who also served during the war, used to wake up sweating from nightmares. "The worst thing was dealing with the sniper victims who came in. Some were as young as eight.To see the guys responsible being brought in is a tremendous feeling."

Glenn Morgan came from the West Midlands police and has worked as an intelligence officer for six years. His job is to work out the command structures of military operations. His training was in British Army intelligence in Northern Ireland. "It's like working on a jigsaw puzzle. You've got 40 pieces and you need to get a good idea where the other 60 pieces fit in."

Every fact they uncover is processed into the Hague's computer system, which is sealed to the outside world. On most desks there are two computers, one that accesses the internal computer files, a second for everyday use with email connection and internet facilities. The computer unit has almost 100 staff and 2m documents on file, new ones coming in at the rate of 16,000 a month.

But getting Karadzic will be the real signal to the outside world that the Hague is serious. Milosevic and Mladic are more likely to die in the bloody civil war that is brewing in Serbia than surrender to international justice.

"I will have room for a hundred more of them," says Del Ponte. She points to a poster offering $5m (£3.2m) for the capture of Bosnia's big three: "There, they are my three."

After the Blair government came to power in 1997, the SAS carried out the first arrest. Until then, western governments had been worried more about body bags than justice for the battered Balkans and the crack squads of the SAS, the US Delta Force and commandos from France, Holland and Germany sat around on their well-trained hands and watched the war criminals drink beer in Bosnian bars.

Another reason Del Ponte's cells are filling up fast is that nobody in Bosnia seems to care very much that their former leaders are being kidnapped and brought to trial. Initially Britain, France, Germany and the US were all worried about a backlash against their soldiers on the ground. "So far we've had car tyres slashed, but that's been about it," says Terry Cameron.

Del Ponte doesn't want to talk about why it is taking so long to get the big names. "What I care about is when they are going to bring them in. Come to me the day after Karadzic arrives and I will explain everything. I am doing things a prosecutor should not be doing."

Such things include visiting George Robertson in Nato headquarters to discuss plans for a special international snatch squad to speed up the pick-ups.

When, if, Karadzic arrives in the Hague, the hood and earplugs he has been forced to wear during the two-hour flight so he will not recognise the nationality of his captors will be removed. He will be met by a Dutch immigration offical who will sign him into Holland. Tim McFadden, a tall Irishman and his chief jailer in the prison, will be on hand to take charge of him.

"The biggest success with Karadzic will be getting him here alive," says Morgan. "The worry is that there are a couple of Milosevic stooges waiting to put a bullet in his head before he gets here."

Karadzic will then be dispatched to a cell on one of three floors, where he will be watched on a security camera in case he attempts suicide. At 7.30 the next morning, over breakfast of muesli and fruit juice, he will be reunited with some old friends and enemies, for there is no segregation.

"The funny thing about these guys is that they are pussycats to handle," says McFadden. "They are not idealists. They don't seem to believe in what they were fighting for."

From the press gallery, we couldn't see the 19-year-old giving evidence. But Zoran Vukovic could, and for two days he listened to her tell the tribunal how he had been part of a group of soldiers who had gang-raped her over a period of five weeks. How, at the end, he had taken her alone to a deserted apartment, to a room on the left hand side of the hallway and raped her again.

"Then, when he had finished, he sat down on the armchair and lit a cigarette," she said. "He said to me, I could do much more to you, but since you're the same age as my daughter, I'll leave it at that."

Vukovic again scratches desperately at the paper in front of him with his blue Biro.

The older women are tougher, merciless in telling it as it was. Vukovic was the kind of a guy who forced them to give him oral sex because he couldn't get an erection. Then he got a gun and became a big guy. The women and girls leave the bench devastated and high, so high.

Tejshree Thapa, a young Nepalese woman lawyer, spent more than two years preparing the rape cases. "After they've given their testimony and left the stand I have broken down and cried," she says. "The older women are better able to cope - they have some sort of social structure. It's the young girls that get to me. They are just completely bewildered by what has happened to them.

"Their best friends are the girls who were raped with them. They are all traumatised, but they end up in refuges in different countries where they don't speak the language.

"They have been terrified of coming into court," says Thapa. "But as soon as they get into the witness box, their anger replaces the fear. All of them have been glad they have done it."

fields.headline: Britain 'planning evacuation' from Zimbabwe
fields.trailText:
British diplomats and military officials are preparing a 'worst case' plan to
evacuate up to 20,000 UK citizens from Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
British diplomats and military officials are preparing a 'worst case' plan to evacuate up to 20,000 UK citizens from Zimbabwe.

As the country slides towards chaos, there are fears of a mass exodus by white farmers and supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Tension has risen markedly since President Robert Mugabe signalled at the weekend that he would use his special powers to authorise the seizure of white-owned farms, without compensation.

Meanwhile, mobs of supporters of Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party, who have taken over 600 farms by force, are now roaming through rural areas seeking out MDC supporters to brutalise and intimidate.

Although the MDC has solid backing in the main cities of Zimbabwe, the national trade union movement has been forced to call off today's Workers' Day parade in the capital, Harare, for fear that it might be attacked by Zanu-PF thugs.

In all, 14 people have died since the land dispute flared into confrontation and bloodshed. Opposition leaders accuse Zanu-PF of deliberately fanning the violence to bolster its sagging political fortunes in the run-up to national elections.

The deteriorating security situation has led to foreign secretary Robin Cook cancelling a planned visit to Iran next week. He will attend a meeting of Commonwealth ministers in London tomorrow, at which discussion is expected to focus on the Zimbabwe crisis.

The Foreign Office said that the two-day visit to Tehran had been called off because it would coincide with the announcement of Iranian election results. But a spokesman conceded that Mr Cook was "very occupied" by events in Zimbabwe.

The foreign secretary has strongly condemned Mr Mugabe's latest moves to confiscate white-owned farms. "There can be no justification for this. This cannot be the way to solve the genuine problems of land reform," he said.

Britain has offered to help compensate white commercial farmers whose land is taken for redistribution to black peasants. But it insists that the government must first rein in the army of squatters who have seized land by force.

Now, instead of mediating in the dispute and possibly helping to solve it, Britain could be forced to play a leading role in what could become the ethnic cleansing of Zimbabwe.

The white farmers and their families account for around 4000 of Zimbabwe's 70,000-strong white community, of whom up to 20,000 are British passport holders.

If there is a rush to leave the country, the outline plan is for an armed convoy to carry the evacuees eastwards into neighbouring Mozambique, whose president Joaquim Chissano says he will welcome them.

But the exodus may not just involve the white minority. South Africa is preparing refugee camps along its northern frontier, in fearful expectation that black farm workers and MDC supporters may join a stampede to escape an increasingly turbulent and dangerous land.

fields.headline: May Day protests
fields.standfirst: Anti-capitalism demonstrations are planned in London and other cities on 1 May. Sean Dodson explains what's likely to happen and why
fields.trailText: Anti-capitalism demonstrations are planned in London and other cities on 1 May. We explain what's likely to happen and why
fields.body:
What is MayDay2K and what is likely to happen?
MayDay2K is the latest round of anti-capitalism demonstrations planned in cities around the world on 1 May. It is the fourth such demonstration, after last summer's shut-down of the City of London (J18), the harassing of the World Trade Organisation in Seattle in November (N30) and the ugly confrontations at the IMF and World Bank meeting in Washington DC in mid-April (A16).

In London the day will start with a cycle protest by the pressure group Critical Mass. Then, at 11am a number of groups will meet at Parliament Square to take part in a "guerrilla gardening" demonstration organised by the road protesters' organisation Reclaim the Streets (RTS).

Elsewhere in the UK, demonstrations are planned for Glasgow, Manchester and Sheffield. Events will also take place in 60 cities around the world, including New York, Washington DC, Seattle, Sydney, Auckland, Manila, as well as across Europe and Africa.

Who else will be taking part?
A number of environmentalists, trade unions and left wing activists. But one key point about the anti-capitalism movement is that many of the demonstrators are unaffiliated to political parties and find out about the demonstrations on the internet. Also, unlike mass demonstrations in the past, such as CND or the poll tax riots, the anti-capitalism movement has a much vaguer political agenda and thus can draw people from a much broader base.

What is guerrilla gardening?
The first guerrilla gardening took place in New York, when a number of community activists began to reclaim waste ground by planting seedlings and creating community gardens. The gardens were removed by the city authorities in January 2000. RTS hopes to replicate the guerrilla gardens on 1 May on a far grander scale.

Demonstrators are being encouraged to bring seedlings, herbs, flowers and planting equipment. One RTS pamphlet urges demonstrators to "return urban land to its real usefulness... come prepared and ready to get your hands dirty".

What international trade meeting are the demonstrators trying to block this time?
They're not. Most of the groups involved in the demonstration stress that MayDay2K is about "celebration not confrontation". However, in November 1999, many thought that white-collar Seattle would be immune from rioting during the WTO summit. The ugly clashes that ensued proved them wrong, and this time the police will be taking few chances.

Who is organising the demonstrations?
One feature of the anti-capitalism movement is that it has no discernible leadership. Most groups operate on a non-hierachical basis and many even refuse to have official spokespeople. An umbrella group, People's Global Action, representing at least 200 small pressure groups, first suggested 1 May as a day of action on specialist bulletin boards. The idea was then advertised on websites associated with the anti-capitalism movement.

Why May Day?
Ever since pagan times, May Day - or Beltane - has been celebrated as a rite of passage between winter and summer, using the maypole as a symbol of fertility. Since the late 19th century it has also been celebrated as International Workers' day.

In 1886 80,000 workers in Chicago participated in a general strike demanding a legal right to an eight-hour working day. This caused a number of clashes with police, culminating in a bomb being thrown and a number of protesters shot. One person was killed and several wounded. Six anarchists were later tried and hanged.

A year later, demonstrations moved further afield and strikes were held across the US and in Europe. In 1889, May Day was adopted as International Workers' Day by the International Labour Congress. It has been celebrated across the world ever since.

In London, the Metropolitan and City of London police - criticised for their separate operations during the J18 protests - will mount a joint operation throughout the Bank Holiday weekend. They have warned City firms to look out for potential saboteurs among temporary staff. Chief Inspector Norman Russell said that temps might have "the intention of infiltrating systems and preparing them for a hacking attack".

webTitle: Football's coming Dome with Wembley replica

fields.headline: Football's coming Dome with Wembley replica
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: A huge replica of Wembley stadium is to be built outside the Millennium Dome to cash in on the wave of football mania expected to grip the nation during the European Championships this summer.
fields.body:
A huge replica of Wembley stadium is to be built outside the Millennium Dome to cash in on the wave of football mania expected to grip the nation during the European Championships this summer.

The wood and fibreglass structure, complete with twin towers, royal box and three-quarters scale all-weather pitch, will hold 5,000 people. "I don't know if we will be able to persuade the Queen and Prince Philip to come and sit in the royal box," a dome spokeswoman said yesterday, "but we're hoping Posh and Becks might oblige."

A spokesman for Coca-Cola, the dome sponsor which is paying for the £1m mock-up, said: "We're very hopeful of getting David Beckham and the other England players to help out. Since we are also sponsors of Team England and the European Championships and have direct access to the team we are hoping as many of them as possible come along during June and July.

"We hope to stage matches for everything from school teams right up to the professionals and we hope to bring the stars along too for coaching sessions," he said. "Football is part of the nation's very fabric and we are sure it will be a huge attraction, particularly since Wembley itself will be demolished in the autumn."

The dome has never needed the boost so badly. Latest estimates indicate it will get nowhere near the 10m visitors it needs to break even. Despite drafting in extra entertainers over the Easter break, including the 80s group Black Lace, who had a novelty hit with Agadoo, and Rob Fowler, "line dancing personality of the year", only an average of 17,000 a day turned up over the week, half what was hoped for.

Even so - and despite a threat of an invasion from eco-warriors - things are likely to look up today as thousands of trade unionists join the TUC-organised May Day celebrations there. More than 23,000 members and their families have already bought special half-price tickets, holding out the prospect that it could break the dome record daily attendance of 27,000 set during the February schools half-term break.

Visitors will be handed postcards addressed to the prime minister urging an increase in the minimum wage.

The Manufacturing Science and Finance union will also launch a campaign to recruit nuns, vicars, priests and other church workers.

webTitle: Police braced for May Day clash

fields.headline: Police braced for May Day clash
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands are expected to join a "guerrilla gardening" action in London today for the last, and potentially most explosive, stage of a four-day protest against global capitalism.
fields.body:
Thousands are expected to join a "guerrilla gardening" action in London today for the last, and potentially most explosive, stage of a four-day protest against global capitalism.

Activists from Reclaim the Streets, the "dis-organisation" behind the demonstrations on June 18 and November 30 last year which ended in rioting, were preparing to use compost, seeds and garden tools to "transform" central London on May Day.

An action in Parliament Square, opposite the Houses of Parliament, has been advertised for 11am but other protests are expected, including what activists say will be "a very big surprise for the Millennium Dome".

RTS fliers said: "The seeds of an unprecedented global revolution have been sown."

Police are mounting their biggest response to any political protest for 30 years. More than 5,000 officers were on duty over the weekend but made no arrests. They operated a "softly softly" policy during disruption to traffic in the West End on Friday night by about 600 cyclists protesting against congestion and pollution.

But both protesters and police are braced for clashes today. Police fear the protesters' gardening tools will be used as weapons. A Met spokesman said they believed that between 200 and 300 of the expected 10,000 people could be intent on causing trouble.

At Highbury Fields in north London yesterday, campaigners, including Billy Bragg, Mark Thomas, Rob Newman and Bruce Kent, gathered for a photocall to protest against the terrorism bill, which they say will limit people's rights to legitimate protest.

They lined up in a parody the Beatles' Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band album cover to illustrate the diversity of groups which they say will be hit by the bill.

They accused police of hyping the potential for violence and said that a heavy police presence could spark clashes.

fields.headline: Ta-ra to sex, says Binchy
fields.trailText: The insatiable appetite of publishers for steamy sex in bestsellers has persuaded Britain's most popular female novelist to hang up her pen.
fields.body:
The insatiable appetite of publishers for steamy sex in bestsellers has persuaded Britain's most popular female novelist to hang up her pen.

Irish writer Maeve Binchy has confirmed that her next book, Scarlet Feather, will be her last. Her career, spanning almost 20 years, hit a high last year with Tara Road which sold over 1m copies worldwide.

But the 59-year-old writer has decided to retire at the top. Binchy said she was unwilling to allow her books to become peppered with the "steamy sex" scenes so often desired by today's publishers.

"It's not something I can do, nor will do," she told the Sunday Times. "I've never been to an orgy so I can't do orgy scenes."

She published her first novel, Light a Penny Candle, in 1982, and it became the first of 10 bestsellers.

But despite the fact there will be no more novels from Binchy, she has promised to publish some short stories.

webTitle: A-level maths to be made harder

fields.headline: A-level maths to be made harder
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to make mathematics A-level harder because evidence suggests that the standard of exam papers has slipped over the past 20 years, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is to make mathematics A-level harder because evidence suggests that the standard of exam papers has slipped over the past 20 years, it emerged yesterday.

Students will be required to study more algebra, trigonometry and geometry, and use of calculators will be restricted in the first exams covered by the syllabuses being introduced in September. Easier topics such as statistics are to be dropped as part of the drive to reassert tougher standards.

Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority which oversees all examination syllabuses, said: "The overall standard of A-level maths in future is going to be somewhat more demanding than the current one."

Mr Tate said: "What we are doing is putting right what we felt was a slight backsliding of a few years ago. In other A-level subjects the overall standard is being maintained. In maths we are reasserting earlier standards."

An analysis by the authority found that important elements of maths A-level from previous years such as algebra had disappeared, while widespread use of calculators had affected the content of exam papers. In particular it was found that the introduction in 1992 of new-style modular maths A-levels, involving regular assessment, had led to students being asked shorter, less demanding questions.

Ministers believe that it is important to make the examination more relevant to students' needs, and not necessarily just more difficult.

Yesterday John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "The country desperately needs more people with A-level maths, and it desperately needs more maths teachers. Making A-level maths harder is unlikely to help. There is no firm evidence that maths A-level is easier than it used to be, and it is not unreasonable to expect exam papers to change over the years."

Because of the low numbers of students who take A-level maths, a new intermediate modular maths course pitched between GCSE and A-level is to be introduced in September.

The government has also launched a wide-ranging programme, Maths Year 2000, in a drive to make youngsters more interested in the subject at an early age, with help and support from their parents.

Research last year claimed graduates with A-level maths could earn around 10% more in the jobs market than their colleagues without it.

Under the changes, the existing six hours of written papers for A-level maths is also being extended to eight hours.

Ministers and exam officials have faced increasingly strong criticism that A-levels are getting easier, with the pass rate and proportion of top-performing students getting A grades edging up every year.

Last year the head of Winchester - which is consistently at the top of exam performance league tables covering state and independent schools - attacked on the government for apparently dumbing down A-levels. James Saben-Clare claimed his most recent students were no brighter than those of 30 years ago even though they achieved better results.

Yesterday a spokeswoman for the Department for Education and Employment said: "The QCA is conducting a rolling programme called the 'standards over time' study to ensure that A-level standards are maintained. Inevitably, some elements of A-level subjects will be identified that need to be adjusted periodically. However, ministers are determined that the introduction of new A-level syllabuses will not be accompanied by falling standards."

fields.headline: Old is the new new
fields.standfirst:
The Telegraph and Emap were both linked to dot.coms last week. Imogen O'Rorke on why the web has gone mad for dead wood

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Last week, rumours were flying around the stock market and the web about a proposed £4bn takeover of Emap by the web navigation giant Yahoo!, which pushed Emap's share prices up by more than a third.
fields.body:
Last week, rumours were flying around the stock market and the web about a proposed £4bn takeover of Emap by the web navigation giant Yahoo!, which pushed Emap's share prices up by more than a third.

Both parties refused to comment on the uber-bid but privately dismissed the rumours as "unfounded". End of story - potentially the biggest convergence story since the announcement of the AOL/Time Warner merger in January.

It would not have been the first time Yahoo! had flirted with conventional media (it has been linked with Dorling Kindersley, the educational publishers, and Murdoch's News Corp among others), but it is no coincidence that the rumour followed in the wake of the Nasdaq catastrophe, which saw the market for hi-tech stocks lose a quarter of its value in five days. It made perfect sense that Yahoo! would want to consolidate its position by buying into a publishing powerhouse, especially when shares were cheap.

The great wobble in the new economy has been a wake-up call for big internet brands such as Yahoo!, Excite and Freeserve. In the US, internet companies across the spectrum, from AOL to Salon.com and ebay.com, have started getting into bed with old media or diverging into traditional media forms. One by one, the webbies are coming back onto dry land.

Rebecca Ulph, new media analyst at Fletcher Research, sees two possible reasons for the flow back into old media. "It's certainly a way new media companies can convert share prices into real value, and with exclusive content they can improve their offering and differentiate themselves from the others. There is a certain amount of honesty attached to old media brands compared to new media, which can appear to be fly-by-night and unsubstantiated."

The announcement last week by Hollinger, the group behind the Telegraph, that it was open to the idea of a merger with a major internet company was well timed. It was surely influenced by the crash. "The last five weeks have been a resounding wake-up call to a lot of people," says Daniel Colson, vice-chairman of Hollinger. "The AOL/Time Warner deal was the benchmark really. People realised that while the internet is here to stay, there is still a need to identify businesses that have fundamental revenue streams."

Yahoo! refuses to comment on any rumours relating to the Telegraph or Emap - or indeed on any of its future plans. The world's number one portal with 35m visitors a month has always maintained that it is keen to develop its own content rather than merge with a media company. Its European rival Excite, on the other hand, is cautious of trying to become a mass media brand in its own right.

"To develop content in-house is a huge effort," says Ronnie Planalp, senior director of business development at Excite. "Do people associate Yahoo! with a sports magazine or lifestyle magazine? No. But the pre-eminent brands of Time Warner, for example, are worth something. The message to glean from the Yahoo!/Emap rumour is that new media companies need content to go down their pipes." Excite currently has around 70m users. The dilemma it faces now is the same one that publishers have had for years: how to keep them?

ISPs face a deeper identity crisis still. With unmetered or unlimited free access to the internet just around the corner, the wires or pipes which provide the service will become increasingly invisible. Many are already feeling the pressure to come offline.

"ISPs and portals are facing a huge dilemma," says Matt Peacock, head of corporate communications for AOL Europe, which incorporates Compuserve, AOL UK and Netscape Online. "They are having to start asking 'what are we here for?' The smart players realise that the days of providing raw internet access are going - access is becoming irrelevant. Consumers are increasingly concerned with look and feel, the content and the features on their sites. The next growth phase is when all the providers start thinking, 'how are we going to keep all our subscribers?'"

This, he confirms, was the "key driver" for the merger with Time Warner. It was a logical progression for AOL. The investment in 450 individual content providers has also paid off. According to Mediamatrix, AOL users stay an average of 30 minutes per visit on the site, while for other ISPs the average is 3.2 minutes - enough time to pick up email and leave.

In the past week, Freeserve, the UK's biggest internet portal and service provider, has also been linked with Emap (the Times reported that Emap rebuffed Freeserve's offer) and the publishers of Loot in content/acquisition deals. A spokesperson for Freeserve said they would not comment on the speculation in the press.

But Freeserve has been aware of the shift towards content for a while and created an in-house editorial team with a staff of 150 and new offices in Clerkenwell, central London.

Identity crises aside, the flow back into traditional meat 'n' two veg media is in many ways a natural process of evolution for many internet brands which are now mature enough to compete in the non-virtual world.

In America, cult websites such as Salon.com (3.4m unique users) and The Onion.com (500,000 visitors a week) have been syndicating their content to TV and print for some time. The Onion has a newspaper with a readership of 400,000; Salon has several book deals pending and its columnists are reproduced in newspapers. Its latest deal with Endeavour, a Hollywood talent agency, and a deal with Bravo, a subsidiary of Cablevision, will leverage Salon's content onto mainstream TV. Andrew Ross, the executive VP, claims, "We never really left old media. [Moving into TV] is a natural for us. The content is primary, the platform is secondary."

The recent US launch of sexy literary website Nerve.com's own glossy magazine created waves in the business press because of the way it was self-consciously "reverse-engineered" by the chief executive, Rufus Griscom.

Griscom told Sunday Business that it had used the internet "for finding readers and getting subscriptions" for the 50,000 print-run glossy.

"What people are realising is there is no such thing as a company that cannot benefit from the efficiencies offered by the internet," he said.

What the Time Warner/AOL taught us is that the old/new media convergence works just as well both ways. Only a year ago, it seemed new media needed old media like a fish needs a bicycle - now both are becoming increasingly amphibious.
