The world's number one portal with 35m visitors a month has always maintained that it is keen to develop its own content rather than merge with a media company. Its European rival Excite, on the other hand, is cautious of trying to become a mass media brand in its own right. "To develop content in-house is a huge effort," says Ronnie Planalp, senior director of business development at Excite. "Do people associate Yahoo! with a sports magazine or lifestyle magazine? No. But the pre-eminent brands of Time Warner, for example, are worth something. The message to glean from the Yahoo!/Emap rumour is that new media companies need content to go down their pipes." Excite currently has around 70m users. The dilemma it faces now is the same one that publishers have had for years: how to keep them? ISPs face a deeper identity crisis still. With unmetered or unlimited free access to the internet just around the corner, the wires or pipes which provide the service will become increasingly invisible. Many are already feeling the pressure to come offline. "ISPs and portals are facing a huge dilemma," says Matt Peacock, head of corporate communications for AOL Europe, which incorporates Compuserve, AOL UK and Netscape Online. "They are having to start asking 'what are we here for?' The smart players realise that the days of providing raw internet access are going - access is becoming irrelevant. Consumers are increasingly concerned with look and feel, the content and the features on their sites. The next growth phase is when all the providers start thinking, 'how are we going to keep all our subscribers?'" This, he confirms, was the "key driver" for the merger with Time Warner. It was a logical progression for AOL. The investment in 450 individual content providers has also paid off. According to Mediamatrix, AOL users stay an average of 30 minutes per visit on the site, while for other ISPs the average is 3.2 minutes - enough time to pick up email and leave. In the past week, Freeserve, the UK's biggest internet portal and service provider, has also been linked with Emap (the Times reported that Emap rebuffed Freeserve's offer) and the publishers of Loot in content/acquisition deals. A spokesperson for Freeserve said they would not comment on the speculation in the press. But Freeserve has been aware of the shift towards content for a while and created an in-house editorial team with a staff of 150 and new offices in Clerkenwell, central London. Identity crises aside, the flow back into traditional meat 'n' two veg media is in many ways a natural process of evolution for many internet brands which are now mature enough to compete in the non-virtual world. In America, cult websites such as Salon.com (3.4m unique users) and The Onion.com (500,000 visitors a week) have been syndicating their content to TV and print for some time. The Onion has a newspaper with a readership of 400,000; Salon has several book deals pending and its columnists are reproduced in newspapers. Its latest deal with Endeavour, a Hollywood talent agency, and a deal with Bravo, a subsidiary of Cablevision, will leverage Salon's content onto mainstream TV. Andrew Ross, the executive VP, claims, "We never really left old media. [Moving into TV] is a natural for us. The content is primary, the platform is secondary." The recent US launch of sexy literary website Nerve.com's own glossy magazine created waves in the business press because of the way it was self-consciously "reverse-engineered" by the chief executive, Rufus Griscom. Griscom told Sunday Business that it had used the internet "for finding readers and getting subscriptions" for the 50,000 print-run glossy. "What people are realising is there is no such thing as a company that cannot benefit from the efficiencies offered by the internet," he said. What the Time Warner/AOL taught us is that the old/new media convergence works just as well both ways. Only a year ago, it seemed new media needed old media like a fish needs a bicycle - now both are becoming increasingly amphibious.

webTitle: Struck off doctor wins seat on GMC ruling body

fields.headline: Struck off doctor wins seat on GMC ruling body
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council is to review the way doctors are elected on to its governing body after it was revealed that one who was struck off for racial abuse and neglect of patients has won a seat.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council is to review the way doctors are elected on to its governing body after it was revealed that one who was struck off for racial abuse and neglect of patients has won a seat.

Jennifer Colman was struck off 13 years ago after allegations that she had referred to a senior colleague as a "coon".

She was found guilty of gross professional misconduct for racial abuse and convicted of failing to give some patients urgent medical attention.

But after serving a two-year ban Dr Colman was allowed to return to practice and has now been elected to the GMC's 104-strong governing body.

She was restored to the register after the GMC accepted that her behaviour had been linked with an illness she suffered as a result of a head injury.

In GMC elections, Britain is split up into four constituencies - England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

All registered doctors then get to vote in what amounts to a general election. Dr Coleman was elected following the recent death of a serving member.

A spokesman for the GMC confirmed that Dr Coleman had been struck off their register in the past but added: "We use in our elections the same principle as elections to parliament.

"If someone is found guilty of something and has served their time then they are considered rehabilitated and are therefore eligible to stand."

The news is bound reignite the debate about self regulation following the Harold Shipman case. The GMC was criticised for not suspending the Hyde GP while the investigation into the murder of 15 of his patients was being conducted.

Under tough government rules announced after the Shipman case doctors struck off the register will be barred from practising for life, except in exceptional circumstances.

The GMC spokesman confirmed they were reviewing the way in which doctors are elected on to the governing body.

"We are aware of concerns about the fact that doctors are allowed to stand if they have been struck off. But that is not out of touch with the way other regulatory bodies operate."

The spokesman added that another reason for the review was the low turnout in the elections. In the GMC's general election last year turnout was 22%.

Although the Department for Health would not comment on the specific case a spokesman said it was "vital the GMC maintained public confidence in its ability to regulate its own doctors".

Dr Colman, 56, who works as a medically qualified barrister in Norfolk, could oversee areas of fitness to practice, standards, registration or education.

She said in a statement: "I am pleased to have been elected by my fellow doctors."

webTitle: Moving on  Israeli police break up a protest occupation in Hebron

fields.headline: Moving on  Israeli police break up a protest occupation in Hebron
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli soldiers and paramilitary police forcibly removed dozens of Jewish settlers from a shipping container they had illegally set up to try to expand their presence in the West Bank town of Hebron yesterday.
fields.body:
Israeli soldiers and paramilitary police forcibly removed dozens of Jewish settlers from a shipping container they had illegally set up to try to expand their presence in the West Bank town of Hebron yesterday.

Some settlers barricaded themselves inside the structure and others handcuffed themselves to its roof.

About 500 Jewish settlers live in Israeli-controlled enclaves in Hebron in tense proximity to the town's 130,000 Palestinians.

The settlers said setting up the container on land near the Jewish enclave of Tel Romeida was also a protest against Israeli concessions to the Palestinians. Peace talks were due to resume in the southern town of Eilat yesterday.

Meanwhile, the chief Palestinian negotiator protested against Israeli plans to expand what is already the West Bank's largest Jewish settlement, Maale adumim with 25,000 inhabitants. Yasser Abed Rabbo said the decision was "proof of the lack of the seriousness of the Israeli government in dealing with the negotiations".

fields.headline: Buffett backs Bill Gates
fields.standfirst:
Justice department attacked for plan to break up 'perfect US company'

E-finance: special report

The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: The US justice department has come under heavy fire for its attempts to break up Microsoft, the world's largest software company.
fields.body:
The US justice department has come under heavy fire for its attempts to break up Microsoft, the world's largest software company.

Wall Street delivers its verdict on the latest developmentswhen trading resumes today but at the weekend Microsoft won strong support from middle America.

Charlie Munger, vice-chairman of Berkshire Hathaway and the right hand man of Warren Buffett - the world's most successful investor - prompted rounds of applause from 15,000 shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Omaha when he attacked the government's landmark anti-trust lawsuit.

The US justice department and 17 states called for Microsoft to be broken in two in order to end its abuse of a monopoly position.

Mr Munger, said: "[America] finally gets a huge leadership in a new field, software, that's needed all over the earth, and somebody drawing a salary from the US government gets the bright idea to dramatically weaken the one place where we are winning big."

Shares in Microsoft have fallen more than 40 per cent since it was found to have acted illegally last month.

Mr Munger said Microsoft, in which Berkshire has a tiny stake, was a perfect example of capitalist success.

"It is hard for me to see how Microsoft is sinful because it tried to improve its products every time and make next year's business position stronger. If that's a sin, every subsidiary of Berkshire is a sinner, I hope."

Mr Buffett, a long-term friend and mentor to Microsoft's Bill Gates, said: "I think we have something that is working very well and it probably doesn't make a lot of sense to tinker with too much."

Such comments at "America's capitalist Woodstock" may underline the lack of political support for the case outside Washington. George Bush, the Republican presidential hopeful, has warned the judge against damaging the US economy but has stopped short of directly criticising the justice department.

The government's call for a break-upand restrictions on how Microsoft does business, were more onerous than some other options available.

Vivek Varma, a Microsoft lawyer, said that the company could ask for a new "mini-trial" to present further evidence to Judge Thomas Penfield as he decides on a remedy.

The justice department has argued that a break-up is the only way of preventing Microsoft from abusing its stranglehold on the world's computer market. It believes that Microsoft is too contemptuous of the courts to comply with legal restrictions on its conduct, presenting evidence that Microsoft continued its unlawful anti-competitive conduct after the launch of the case.

The court case did not stop Mr Gates from appearing in a video at Berkshire's annual meeting. In the video Mr Buffett appeared on a game show called "Who wants to be a gillionaire" in which he phoned Mr Gates asking for an investment tip.

Mr Gates resisted the temptation to push Microsoft.

fields.headline: Labour to double jobs aid
fields.standfirst:
Labour to double New Deal jobs aid
Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown and David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will this week unveil plans to more than double the scale of the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme during the next two years, bringing 800,000 more jobless people into the programme.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown and David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will this week unveil plans to more than double the scale of the New Deal welfare-to-work scheme during the next two years, bringing 800,000 more jobless people into the programme.

In an acknowledgement that the government must do more for workers such as those facing redundancy in the car industry, the expansion plans will include the launch of a new "rapid response" New Deal programme to help in areas hit by severe job losses.

The extension of the employment programme, launched two years ago for 18 to 24-year-olds, represents a firm commitment that the now-broadened scheme will be made permanent. This is the first time specific expansion targets have been given.

Ministers want to use the scheme, which they already regard as a success story, to keep clear water between Labour and the Tories, who have dismissed the programme as an expensive failure.

The expansion plan will be unveiled this week as a final campaigning shot before Thursday's local elections, which are expected to see substantial Tory successes and a poor showing for Labour, but the New Deal will also feature heavily in Labour's general election strategy.

The government still has work to do to convince business that the New Deal pro gramme is effective, amid employers' complaints that they are being left to deal with the lowest quality trainees.

Spending on the scheme, which was initially financed using the £5.2bn windfall levy on the privatised utilities, will be disclosed in July's comprehensive spending review, though the expansion details will renew speculation that the government could spend some of the £22bn mobile phone auction revenues on boosting the programme.

A government source said: "Training and jobs will be key features of the spending review. We want to extend and strengthen the New Deal as part of Labour's aim of abolishing long-term unemployment."

Ministers also hope that the rapid response New Deal will avoid the current problem that, under present rules, job seekers have to be unemployed for at least six months before entering the scheme. The emergency programme would mean that, as soon as the government received warnings of job losses, it could offer threatened workers one-to-one help and reskilling without the need for a six-month wait.

Bringing an additional 800,000 people into the programme would take the total to 1.5m by 2002, ministers estimate. They aim for an eventual total of 2m by the end of the next parliament across the range of New Deal programmes, subject to the economy remaining strong.

Although intended to make a signficant dent in dole queues, currently standing at 1.1m, the expansion would primarily tackle the problem of new waves of young people leaving school or college with no job available.

Around half of those to be targeted are expected to join the New Deal for young people, which offers under-25s the choice of taking one of four options - including a work placement or further education - or forfeiting benefits.

Seventy thousand will sign up to the New Deal for lone parents, while the remaining 330,000 will be on the programme for the 25-plus age group, and, in smaller numbers, the scheme for over-50s.

At the moment, the scheme for young people is by far the largest with 437,000 involved. The latest figures, released on Friday, show that 199,340 under-25s had moved into jobs through the New Deal by the end of February - a sizeable step toward the government's manifesto target of getting 250,000 jobless young people into work.

The rapid response New Deal would mean a more proactive approach in areas hit by high job losses. There would also be moves to examine and improve transport links to areas with jobs.

As with all New Deal programmes, those on the scheme would receive one-to-one help in identifying and promoting their own skills, including those which could be transferred to other occuptional sectors.

fields.headline: £150m state funds for Rover bid
fields.standfirst:
Byers to shore up Phoenix bid to win City backing
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government is prepared to pump more than £150m of state aid into the private Rover rescue plan to save the Longbridge car plant and 24,000 jobs.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Jill Treanor  and  Lucy Ward
fields.body:
The government is prepared to pump more than £150m of state aid into the private Rover rescue plan to save the Longbridge car plant and 24,000 jobs.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is ready to back the Phoenix bid with public cash if the consortium can convince ministers and city investors - as well as BMW - that it can keep the West Midlands plant open.

His stance could be crucial to Phoenix's chances of raising money from institutional investors. Potential backers are understood to have made it clear to the Phoenix team, led by the former Rover boss John Towers, that any hope of City cash depends on funding from the government.

Last Friday, after the 11th hour collapse of its deal to sell Longbridge to the venture capital group Alchemy, BMW said it would close the plant unless it could find another buyer within the month. Phoenix is currently the only bidder and despite previous scepticism about its financial backing the German car maker has now handed over vital financial information and will start detailed discussions with the consortium tomorrow.

Mr Byers spoke to Mr Towers yesterday and is to meet him this week.

The Department of Trade and Industry was seeking European approval for a £152m aid package, £129m of it from central funds, to redevelop Longbridge when BMW decided six weeks ago to sell.

Sources close to the department said Mr Byers was prepared to switch the £129million to underwrite the consortium's bid.

Insiders said no decision could be taken on the government's final offer, or whether it would be a grant, loan or a mixture of the two, until Phoenix produced its final proposal.

The help is dependent on BMW making it clear that it believes a viable plan is on the table. One industry source claimed that Phoenix had scaled down its initial plan to build 250,000 cars a year to as low as 150,000, to reduce the funding needed.

That would trigger thousands of redundancies among Longbridge's 9,000 workers and its suppliers, but would still retain many more jobs than under the ill-fated Alchemy scheme.

Rover union officials have disclosed that as recently as last Thursday Werner Samaan, BMW's UK head, dismissed the consortium's chances during a meeting with union members at the car firm's headquarters in Gaydon, Warwickshire.

"He said it was a boy scout operation that stood no chance of succeeding," said a union official.

"BMW is under pressure to sell and pull out, not shut and quit. They have signalled more cash will be on the table. We and Phoenix want to see the colour of their money by the end of the week."

As the Longbridge crisis deepened yesterday, the Munich-based BMW denied reports that it was planning to close Rover's Cowley plant and switch production of the new Mini to Germany. "It was never our intention to move the Mini from Cowley," said a spokesman.

Mr Byers' readiness to invest public cash in Phoenix underlines how seriously the government takes the threat of an economic and political melt down in the West Midlands if Longbridge is closed.

"The government has told us it will offer financial support," said a source close to the talks. "But it is not an unconditional offer. Phoenix has to show that it can make Longbridge work because there is no point in wasting huge sums of public money."

Ministers and union leaders still have huge reservations about the Phoenix consortium and the possible public support would fall well short of the £700m aid one insider claims would be needed to support the consortium.

Ministers are confident of approval from Brussels for a Rover cash lifeline if they can demonstrate that it is a short- term measure to stop the company going under.

Mr Byers recently unveiled £100m in state aid to stave off pit closures and a £520m loan to enable British Aerospace to develop a superjumbo.

The Conservatives last night accused Mr Byers of adopting a "crisis management" approach to manufacturing. The shadow trade secretary, Angela Browning, said: "Stephen Byers must identify what the government's policy is on providing financial support for business."

She called on the trade and industry secretary to identify the legal basis on which the money was being offered and ensure that the grant was eligible under EU rules.

fields.headline: Grateful to bury and grieve
fields.standfirst:
Digging resumes tomorrow in a final search for the bodies of IRA murder victims lost to their families for long years
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Digging resumes tomorrow in a final search for the bodies of IRA murder victims lost to their families for long years
fields.body:
Margaret McKinney is in fine fettle these days. She is finally off the tranquillisers she chewed throughout the past two decades, at last enjoys a few hours unbroken sleep, and, according to her family and doctor, is a new person.

To the anguished relatives of the so-called disappeared, Mrs McKinney's transformation holds out the prospect of the serenity they have craved for much of their lives. A year ago she was in poor health, having suffered several heart attacks, but then a year ago she too did not know where the IRA had dumped her son, Brian, 22.

Police in the Irish Republic will tomorrow again try to close a chapter on one of the most notorious episodes of the Troubles. They will begin digging at five sites, hoping to find six IRA victims murdered and secretly dumped more than 20 years ago. Last year gardai abandoned excavations after five weeks. Acting on fresh information from the IRA, they will try again for three weeks. But they say this will be the final search.

The IRA last year raised families' hopes that they would at last be able to accord the victims, all Catholics, a fitting burial when it announced it would be passing to the authorities details of the graves of nine people it had murdered.

The development came as the doomed talks to save the Good Friday agreement in March last year were getting under way.

In May last year the remains of one on the list, Eamon Molloy, 25, accused of being an informer, were left at a graveyard in Faughart, Co Louth. IRA members had disinterred his body and transferred it to a new coffin.

But the information the IRA passed to the authorities about the eight others, buried in six places, was inadequate. The sites, including bogs and a beach, were remote with few landmarks, and geologists believe there would have been substantial underground changes.

The IRA's hopes of a quick resolution, and that its move would be seen as an indication that its terrorist war was at an end, backfired. Irish opinion was revolted for a time, as the mounds of earth grew. The independent commission for the location of victims' remains, specially set up, called off the searches last June.

That day, Mrs McKinney was on her way to discuss the decision with the commissioners, Sir Kenneth Bloomfield and John Wilson, when word came through that two bodies had been found at Colgagh in Co Monaghan. The IRA said it had buried Brian and John McClory, 18, there.

Gardai stopped work at the area identified by the IRA, and instead began digging at a spot near where two old houses had stood. They found Brian's size six white training shoes within 25 minutes, and the bodies soon afterwards.

The IRA said it had killed the two men for stealing one of its weapons. But Mrs Mc-Kinney believes it was for a £70 rob bery on a social club, run by the IRA. She had repaid Brian's share days before he was abducted as he made his way to work on May 25, 1978.

Mrs McKinney, 69, a mother of four, with seven grandchildren, said: "He was daft, rather than bad. He was slow. He was diagnosed as having the mental abilities of a six-year-old when he was 14. He had asthma, and we all felt protective towards him.

"He had a lovely nature, was a great singer and mimic. He was my favourite, I suppose, and I just went to pieces."

Both men were killed at their grave. Postmortem examinations showed each took a single bullet in the skull.

Mrs McKinney had already bought a plot for her son at Milltown cemetery, close to her home in republican west Belfast. He was buried there in September. His marble headstone went up last week.

She visits every day. The family also goes regularly to Colgagh, where there is now a simple wooden cross and flowers.

"It is only looking back I realise what a dark place I was in. I lay awake every night wondering where he was. I pray the other families find the peace I now have.

"It might sound crazy that I am grateful just for the right to bury my younger son after 21 years, but the anger at the IRA is gone now ...

"I often think about his killer coming to the door. I would really like that to happen. I would forgive him completely, because I have my peace now and maybe it is time he had his too."

The strains of not knowing have had hefty consequences for several of the families. Marriages have collapsed, causing serious problems for the children. Several have turned to drink or substance abuse.

The 10 children of Jean McConville, 37, a widow abducted from her home in west Belfast after she comforted a dying British soldier, were sent to different homes after her murder. They are currently fighting over a forthcoming book.

While the IRA last year owned up to killing nine people, others believed to be among the disappeared were left off its list.

They were likely to have been victims of the IRA in south Armagh, and it is thought the hardliners refused to help.

fields.headline: A little local difficulty
fields.standfirst:
Predicted Labour losses this week will not be a result of the protest vote. They are, instead, a sign of the different priorities of local government

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: There is something very strange about the local elections this Thursday. On average, Labour is no less than 19 points ahead in the polls. Yet not only are we being told that Frank Dobson is heading for ignominious defeat in the London but also that we should expect Labour to lose loads of seats in contests in 152 local authorities up and down provincial England. Are the polls wrong again, the spin doctors telling us lies or is there a new, uncomfortable reality for Labour in devolved Britain?
fields.body:
There is something very strange about the local elections this Thursday. On average, Labour is no less than 19 points ahead in the polls. Yet not only are we being told that Frank Dobson is heading for ignominious defeat in the London but also that we should expect Labour to lose loads of seats in contests in 152 local authorities up and down provincial England. Are the polls wrong again, the spin doctors telling us lies or is there a new, uncomfortable reality for Labour in devolved Britain?

The spin doctors are certainly not telling us the unvarnished truth. As ever they have been attempting to lower our expectations. They have reminded us just how well Labour did when the majority of the council seats up for grabs were last contested, in May 1996. It is hardly reasonable - they suggest - for Labour to repeat such a performance. After all, the party is in power now and voters will always use local elections to give the government of the day a bloody nose.

Trouble is, Labour did not do that well in 1996. If the whole country had voted in the way that those who had local elections actually did, Labour would have won around 43% of the popular vote. That is 6% less than its standing in the polls as of now. Surely we should be expecting Labour to make gains on Thursday, not losses?

The truth is Labour did not match its poll rating in 1996 either. Indeed, it was even higher in the polls then, at 52%. So perhaps the polls were wrong and they are wrong again now. And perhaps as a result we are all mistaken in assuming that Tony Blair should coast home to a second term in a general election that may be no more than 12 months away.

The polls may not be perfect, but they are not bad. Rather there is persistent evidence that while Labour is admired at Westminster, this is not necessarily a good enough reason for voters to want to back the party in other than a general election.

Take a look at last year's local elections. Among members of the British election panel study living in England who voted in last year's local elections, 41% said they backed Labour, 32% the Tories and 22% the Liberal Democrats. But when those who had local elections last year were asked how they would have voted in a general election held at that time, no less than 51% backed Labour, 30% the Tories and 16% the Lib Dems.

A similar pattern has been apparent since the late 80s. The Lib Dems do far better in local elections than they would do in a general election if held at the same time. Indeed since 1993 they have rarely polled less than the equivalent of a quarter of the national vote. Labour never does as well. Despite having been either a little below or a little above the 50% mark in the polls for the last seven years, it has only once done better than 45% in council elections. And last year it scored no more than 36%.

The latest ICM London poll tells a similar story. It suggests that in a general election Labour would win 48% of the vote in the capital. In the Greater London assembly election, however, the very same poll puts Labour at just 43% on the constituency vote. Meanwhile the Lib Dems are languishing at 15% for Westminster but perk up to 19% in assembly preferences.

Labour thus has a long-standing local difficulty. It is not simply a case of Labour "core" voters staying at home, disillusioned. Labour's underperformance locally predates Labour's accession to power and even Tony Blair's elevation to the Labour leadership. The election panel study does not suggest that Labour voters were particularly likely to stay at home in last year's local elections, as certainly was the case in the European elections the following month.

So why this difference between local and national? One reason why voters in England opt for the Lib Dems in local elections is because their pavement politics has helped convince voters that they will do a good job of standing up for local interests. And what do voters want their local council to do? Well, most likely, to stand up for their local interests. If this argument is correct, the implications for the new devolved institutions and for Labour are clear. In last year's elections to the new Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, there was again a Labour shortfall. Fewer voters backed Labour and more voted nationalist than would have done in a Westminster election. Just as some English local voters look to the Lib Dems to defend their interests, so the Scots and the Welsh looked to their nationalist parties to do the same job for them in Edinburgh and Cardiff.

It now looks as though we are seeing the same thing in London. Who do Londoners want as their mayor? Tony Blair's poodle or the man who is associated with the idea of London government? Ken Livingstone's current 34-point lead suggests that, faced with that choice, there is no contest.

Labour came to power in 1997 believing in the power of staying "on message". One implication was that the party should sing from the same hymn sheet, whether it be in Wick or St Ives. But perhaps voters do not want all their politicians to do the same job. Voters may want their councillors or their representatives in Cardiff or Edinburgh to do a different job from Westminster MPs. And while Labour may have delivered devolution, it is not clear voters are convinced they know what to do with it.

John Curtice is deputy director of the ESRC Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends.

webTitle: Celibacy rule could go, says Catholic leader

fields.headline: Celibacy rule could go, says Catholic leader
fields.standfirst:
Archbishop of Westminster believes in reform and may take a more low-key approach to personal morality than Scottish counterpart

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the Archbishop of Westminster and new leader of the 4.1m Catholics in England and Wales, has said he believes the church's centuries-old tradition of a celibate priesthood could be changed.
fields.body:
Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the Archbishop of Westminster and new leader of the 4.1m Catholics in England and Wales, has said he believes the church's centuries-old tradition of a celibate priesthood could be changed.

The archbishop, who was installed at Westminster cathedral in March in succession to Cardinal Basil Hume who died last year, is a theologically orthodox figure but made it clear in an interview with the Guardian that he believes in church reform and, unlike his Scottish counterpart, Cardinal Winning, may take a more understanding line on personal morality.

His appointment at the age of 67 - which means he will only have seven years in the job - has been welcomed by mainstream church leaders, especially Anglican bishops who have worked closely with him in promoting closer links between the churches.

There is unlikely, however, to be any compromise in the archbishop's support for the Catholic church's line either on abortion or its opposition to the ordination of women, despite a growing campaign by women within the church.

On celibacy - which has already been breached in Britain by the acceptance of some married Anglican clergy who have left the Church of England over the issue of women priests - Archbishop Murphy-O'Connor said: "Disciplines can change. When a priest accepts celibacy when he is ordained that rule should be kept. But is it (marriage) incompatible with priesthood? The answer is obviously no. I would not rule it out. The matter will come up again."

The new archbishop, a tall, dominating, genial figure with a shock of grey hair, has transferred from the diocese of Arundel and Brighton where he was a popular bishop for 23 years. In his youth he was a rugby player and might have become a professional musician had he not chosen to become a priest instead. He plays the piano and old colleagues remember him singing Gilbert and Sullivan at the seminary in Rome.

He has moved from a large country house at Storrington in the Sussex Downs to the archbishop's flat behind the cathedral in the middle of Victoria.

He unites the two main strands of English Catholicism, the Irish and the English middle class. He was born in Reading, the fifth son of an Irish-born doctor (a relative of the Murphy brewery family of Cork) and largely educated in England.

Two of his brothers (as well as three uncles) were also priests, one other brother is a doctor and the fourth was an officer in the Royal Artillery. Apart from his years in Rome, all the archbishop's priesthood has been spent in the south of England.

"I come from an Irish family which was very proud to be here. My father was never a nationalist and he had no interest in Irish politics. When we were evacuated to Cork at the beginning of the war and I spent two terms in a school there, I was always known as the English boy, so when people ask whether I am Irish or British I don't answer. I feel a wider context than narrow nationalism."

Despite attendances at Catholic churches having fallen by more than 20% in a decade, he said: "I don't think these are particularly bad times for the church in this country. People are going to be Christians these days because they really believe, not because their parents were.

"I want to encourage the clergy to be open and brave about new initiatives in this culture where people are questioning religion and religion is privatised, where people believe that truth and reality are what you choose them to be and happiness is the most you can achieve.

"The church must always reform and there is always room for development but there is a heritage handed down which the church must always be sensitive to. It has to relate its faith to changing conditions, times and cultures. It cannot be static or fundamentalist, nor liberal, but must be faithful as it marches on its pilgrim way. It has to teach truths in different circumstances."

Cardinal Winning has made opposition to repeal of legislation preventing schools from "promoting" homosexuality a personal crusade.

It is clear the new archbishop will take a more low-key approach. "People should try to understand what the church is saying. Society can't divorce sex from marriage and children. I am not going to make a judgment about a couple, that is not my job and ... I would encourage tolerance, but if people are in a relationship outside marriage, heterosexual or homosexual, that is not right.

"If you want happiness and a stable society you must provide real encouragement to marriage. Stability for children is crucial.

"It is unfair to put all the responsibility of the law on teachers and tell them they have to do all the work. They should be backed up by parents and the culture."

Catholics no longer "feel insular, separate in this country any more. We are part of it and we want to make a distinctive and particular contribution.

"I would just like to be seen as a good shepherd. Anything else I leave confidently to the judgment of God."

In an eminent line of succession

George Basil Hume March 1976-June 1999. A Benedictine monk and abbot of Ampleforth monastery in North Yorkshire for 13 years. As archbishop he set about reorganising the diocese and virtually eliminated a £12m debt in 14 years.

John Carmel Heenan February 1965-November 1975. Known as the Radio Priest due to his numerous contributions to broadcasting.

William Godfrey December 1956-January 1963. A former teacher of philosophy and dogmatic theology in Rome,the ceremony of his enthronement in 1957 was televised in its entirety.

Bernard William Griffin December 1943-August 1956. He became the youngest cardinal in the world in 1946 and travelled widely across war-devastated Europe working towards building a better world. In England his interest in social welfare helped him to encourage the reforming efforts of the post-war Labour government.

Arthur Hinsley March 1935-March 1943. He was an outspoken opponent of the fascist powers during the second world war and was also highly critical of the negative stand taken by Pope Pius XI over Italy's invasion of Ethiopia in 1935.

Francis Bourne September 1903-January 1935. The longest serving archbishop of the 20th century is memorable for his development of rescue and social works and for the opening of a large number of missions.

webTitle: West End awash with the next big things

fields.headline: West End awash with the next big things
fields.standfirst: A flood of big musicals is coming. But are producers just playing safe?
fields.trailText: Since 1782, when John Rich and John Gay opened The Beggar's Opera in London, theatre producers have been certain that all you need for guaranteed fame and fortune on the stage is the right big musical.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Since 1782, when John Rich and John Gay opened The Beggar's Opera in London, theatre producers have been certain that all you need for guaranteed fame and fortune on the stage is the right big musical.

The Beggar's Opera famously made "Gay rich and Rich gay" but the theory is about to be tested to destruction, as an unprecented wave of new musicals hits the West End. Collectively they will have cost more to stage than the vast new Tate Modern gallery cost to build on Bankside.

The flood starts on Wednesday when the King and I opens at the London Palladium. It comes with Elaine Paige returning to the West End stage as Anna, and trailing awards from previous outings in Australia and on Broadway. It is hyped as having the all-time record for advance box office takings - £7m and rising as of this weekend - and several thousand seats have already been sold for the first week of 2001.

The show cost about £6m, slightly less than the reputed £6.5m which Disney spent on the last big thing, The Lion King, but more than the mere £4.5m which the next big thing, The Witches of Eastwick, opening at Drury Lane in July, cost Sir Cameron Mackintosh. He describes the show, which has Ian McShane nervously taking singing lessons, as "a modest little show - spectacularly modest".

Also on the way are Notre Dame de Paris at the Dominion, a show which opened in Paris two years ago and charmed even the most cynical; Charles Dickens's Hard Times, an improbable musical starring Roy Hudd and Brian Blessed, at the Haymarket; and La Cava, at the Victoria Palace, even more improbably set in 8th century Spain and Moorish Africa. Next autumn will see Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber teaming up with Ben Elton for a football musical, The Beautiful Game, and a new musical biography of Napoleon at the Shaftesbury.

They join a family of musicals which look set to occupy every other large stage in the West End indefinitely: Spend Spend Spend, Chicago, Fosse, Blood Brothers, Buddy, Cats, Les Miserables, Starlight Express, the Phantom of the Opera, and the outside chance which romped home, the Abba musical Mamma Mia!

Many observers believe the phenomenon reflects the consolidation of London theatres in fewer hands, particularly since last year's takeover of the Stoll Moss group by Sir Andrew's Really Useful Group.

David Ian, of Magnum Productions, producer of The King and I, thinks the reason for the influx of musicals is much simpler. "The truth is that in these huge theatres you have to put on the shows a lot of people want to see. There are always going to be small theatres which will put on straight plays, but you could argue that small plays don't even look their best in these giant Victorian and Edwardian theatres.

"I don't personally think you can match the experience of a live orchestra of 23 and a cast of over 50. It's not something you can get on video, it's something that everyone, from eight to 80, will want to come and see - and that's what we're all looking for."

Ian Albery, now chief executive of Sadler's Wells, whose family has been trying to second guess audiences' tastes for three generations, thinks the wave of huge musicals is not necessarily healthy.

"You could certainly argue that, although probably inevitable, it is a sign of producers playing safe, being unwilling to experiment or take chances. Even in my grandfather's day there probably never was more than a total audience of about 100,000 people for stage plays, and they have now largely abandoned the West End for the subsidised national theatres, and theatres like the Almeida which have set out to court them. To get them back you have to try something special."

His response has been to dig a West End bear trap: any theatregoer who goes to an innocuous musical - like the very successful Tango Por Dos - in the small Peacock Theatre will find themselves enmeshed in the coils of the Sadler's Wells mailing list, bombarded with special offers for classical ballet and contemporary dance.

Rewards

The rewards, once a production like Cats has earned back its vast set-up costs and seems set to run for ever, are dramatic. But the costs are enormous, and growing. Sir Cameron said recently: "Any big new show is going to cost a record amount of money. Of course my new shows cost more than Miss Saigon: Miss Saigon was 11 years ago."

There are enough spectacular failures littered along the musical byways to make any producer pause: Tess, a musical of Hardy's novel, which had no big name backers and cost a hard-raised £1.4m, died under a barrage of atrocious reviews at the Savoy last year. Lautrec, Charles Aznavour's first and, it is confidently predicted, last musical, which the Financial Times found "lavishly mounted and yet bizarrely empty", is struggling at the Shaftesbury.

And even the original formula for success is not assured. Sir Trevor Nunn's new regime at the Royal National Theatre was much criticised for relying on revivals of classics, and big musicals - like the runaway box office success Oklahoma! - which the commercial producers bitterly feel are not the province of a heavily subsidised national theatre.

Two months ago he announced the jewels in the crown of this year's season: Singin' in the Rain, opening next month, and The Villain's Opera, a new version of the Beggar's Opera set in east end gangland. It opened last month, and has attracted some of the worst reviews of his entire career: the Beggar's Opera will not be making Nunn richer.

Long runners

Cats at the New London theatre opened in May 1981.

Based on the 14 poems of TS Eliot's Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats with music by Andrew Lloyd Webber, the show has taken more than £100m in London, where it has been seen by 8m people.

Starlight Express at the Apollo Victoria theatre opened in March 1984.

Second only to Cats in longevity, there have been eight productions since 1984 including London, New York, a US/Canada tour, Las Vegas, Japan, an Australia/ Japan tour, Germany and Mexico.

The show claims to combine family entertainment with high technology.

Around 16m people have seen the show and it has an estimated gross box office worldwide of £352m.

Les Misérables at the Palace theatre since December 1985 after opening two months earlier at the Barbican.

"Les Mis" is Cameron Mackintosh's production of the Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg musical based on the novel by Victor Hugo.

The Phantom of the Opera at Her Majesty's theatre opened in October 1986.

The original London cast recording was the first in British musical history to enter the charts at No 1. Since then it has gone gold and platinum in the UK and US, selling more than 2m copies.

In the past 16 years it has played in 90 cities in 15 countries around the world to more than 58m people, grossing over £1.5bn worldwide (£86m in London alone).

Blood Brothers at the Phoenix theatre since November 1991 after opening at the Albery theatre in July 1988.

Buddy at the Strand theatre where it has been playing since October 1989. It opened four years earlier at the Victoria Palace theatre.

Miss Saigon opened at the Drury Lane theatre in September 1989 and closed 10 years later in October 1999.

fields.headline: Mugabe takes land-grab powers
fields.standfirst:
White farmers sidelined as opposition feels the heat

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe will invoke special powers next week to seize white-owned farmland without compensation and redistribute it to poor blacks, effectively legalising the recent wholesale occupation of farms led by veterans of the independence war.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe will invoke special powers next week to seize white-owned farmland without compensation and redistribute it to poor blacks, effectively legalising the recent wholesale occupation of farms led by veterans of the independence war.

Mr Mugabe's spokesman, George Charamba, said the president would give himself the authority to continue the confiscations for six months.

The opposition accused Mr Mugabe of misusing his powers. The leader of the white farmers union, David Hasluck, said: "The [union] feels that this is a lack of good faith on behalf of the government while we are trying to negotiate in good faith with the war veterans in an attempt to stop violence and prepare the situation for a free and fair election."

The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, said: "The confiscation of farms without compensation would be a big step backwards. There can be no justification for this. This cannot be the way to solve the genuine problems of land reform."

The announcement from Mr Mugabe's office appears to reflect a new confidence before the parliamentary elections, which are expected to be called soon.

Increasing violence against and intimidation of the government's opponents, and an agreement by white farmers which effectively ends their political activity in many rural areas, has delivered a severe blow to the campaign to topple Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party.

It is a sign that the opposition is shying away from further confrontation that the trades unions congress called off the strikes and protest rallies planned to mark May Day today and asked its members to stay at home and pray.

The main opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), insisted that his supporters would not be intimidated.

"We will maintain our activities. Intimidation can never win a vote. We are the majority," he said.

But the impact of the coercion could be seen at an MDC rally in the opposition's heartland yesterday. Fewer than 200 people turned out for the meeting in the Harare township of Chitungwiza, and most of them declined to wear MDC badges or T-shirts.

One young man said his family had urged him not to go.

"People are very afraid to show they support Tsvangirai," he said.

"Even if nothing happens today they are worried that Zanu-PF is watching and will remember. People here will still vote for the MDC, but they will not want to say so publicly if they think it will get them killed."

Zanu-PF has effectively conceded a general election victory to the opposition in the cities, leaving rural areas to decide whether the ruling party will be humiliated at the ballot box.

But that issue appears to have been settled by an agreement between the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents most of the country's 4,500 white farmers, and the war veterans' leader, Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi.

Mr Hunzvi has promised to end the violence in which at least 14 farmers and farm workers have been killed, and hundreds beaten. In return, the union has agreed that its members will stop supporting the MDC and curtail opposition rallies and activities on their farms.

It is a blow to the opposition, which has relied on white farmers and businessmen for funds, communications and transport in the campaign, and was hoping to gather considerable backing from farm workers.

The white farmers' evident support for the opposition increased the government's fear that many black labourers and their families were swinging behind the MDC. But the widespread intimidation and scattered violence of the land invasions has effectively corralled the farm workers under Zanu-PF control.

Labourers are being subjected to political indoctrination and forced to denounce the opposition. It is unlikely that many will dare to vote against the government.

Mr Tsvangirai clearly feels betrayed.

"The farmers and farming leaders are wrong to be negotiating with outlaws," he said.

"They are pursuing an unsustainable strategy. The farmers must be advised that we must first have the resurrection of law and order."

Privately, other opposition activists go further, one of them accusing the white farmers of putting their own interests before those of the many Zimbabweans who want a change of government.

"I think this will create a lot of unhappiness with whites," he said.

"People will now say they only want to look after themselves. It is a mistake, because it is very easy for Mugabe to turn on the whites any time he wants, and next time there will not be so much sympathy for them."

Some farmers are not happy with their union, either. They believe it has compromised them and will ultimately make it much harder for them to hold on to their land.

But union officials say they are trying to look after the interests of the owners of all the 4,500 large farms, not just the several hundred that have been occupied.

fields.headline: More jury woes for Martin
fields.standfirst:
Writ large
Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: I doubt if the Tony Martin debate will lead to any changes in the law on self-defence - the concept of reasonable force cannot easily be defined further - nor result in the abolition of the pernicious mandatory life sentence, which Jack Straw is protecting just as adamantly as his Tory predecessors. But perhaps the case will provoke a discussion on another piece of flawed legislation - the Contempt of Court Act 1981 on juries.
fields.body:
I doubt if the Tony Martin debate will lead to any changes in the law on self-defence - the concept of reasonable force cannot easily be defined further - nor result in the abolition of the pernicious mandatory life sentence, which Jack Straw is protecting just as adamantly as his Tory predecessors. But perhaps the case will provoke a discussion on another piece of flawed legislation - the Contempt of Court Act 1981 on juries.

As it stands, it seems to me that it will totally preclude any investigation into a jury's verdict, to see if it was tainted, as has been suggested (though by no means substantiated) in the Martin case. Under section 8, it's a contempt "to obtain, disclose or solicit any particulars of statements made, opinions expressed, arguments advanced or votes cast by members of a jury in the course of their deliberations". That is a very firm ban.

In a Martin-type case, it wouldn't be enough for a juror just to say "I felt intimidated" for the verdict to be overturned. The point would be whether or not that affected the jury's decision, and I do not see how that can be ascertained without looking into what happened in the jury room, and that can't be done because of section 8.

A few years ago, the appeal court did manage to quash a jury's verdict when it emerged that some of the jurors had used a ouija board to help them determine the accused's guilt. But because the jury was staying overnight in a hotel at the time, and not all the jurors had participated in the ouija session, the appeal court was able to say that there hadn't been 'jury deliberations' as covered by the Act. That was exceptional.

The appeal court would normally not even think of entering the jury-room, so to speak. (In one case in the 1960s, they even refused to consider evidence that the foreman had read out to his fellow jurors the accused's previous convictions, which neither he nor they were supposed to know about).

I believe the law is too harsh. In principle it is right that a jury's deliberations should be confidential. But there need to be exceptions where breaching that confidentiality is the only - I stress only - way of preventing a greater injustice.

I happened to be reading the article I'd written on gun litigation that appears just to the right - I rarely read my own work; it's painful enough to write it without imposing that extra burden - when the idea suddenly struck me. I have the answer to the Pokemon menace taking over the world's children - litigation. Here is the law.

The Pokemon people are releasing a dangerous thing into the community. They know that the competition for some of the Pokemon cards is so intense that children are being pressured, threatened with violence (sometimes with knives) and robbed by other children determined to get the cards.

The makers of the cards have a duty of care towards their consumers, the children. They are negligent in releasing the cards in such a way as to provoke widespread unrest, tension and fighting. Ergo, there is a claim in law. I am now trying to work out a way for parents to sue for their mental distress in having to sit through the Pokémon film.

fields.headline: Worm's Eye
fields.trailText: One unfortunate byproduct of the coincidence of the City's "anti-capitalist" demonstrations and the bank holiday is that the rest of us are deprived of the opportunity to laugh at bond dealers and merchant bankers "dressing down" in a vain attempt to escape attention.
fields.body:
One unfortunate byproduct of the coincidence of the City's "anti-capitalist" demonstrations and the bank holiday is that the rest of us are deprived of the opportunity to laugh at bond dealers and merchant bankers "dressing down" in a vain attempt to escape attention.

It was very different at the recent IMF meeting in Washington, during which just about the only people wearing suits were the representatives of the world's media; the bureaucrats of global finance scuttled into their meeting in combat trousers more costly than those issued by the Brigade of Guards.

That said, opportunities to witness City types going all casual are less rare than they were. Once you had to wait for blue moon events such as the flotation of Richard Branson's Virgin group to see corporate financiers attempting to relax in their long discarded Supertramp T-shirts. Now, both in London and Wall Street, institution after institution is falling over itself to declare the age of the suit to be at an end.

Until recently this trend was ascribed to the need to attract "talent" from the laid-back world of the internet. Now, with the hi-tech bubble leaking like a punctured spacehopper, this explanation will no longer do.

A more likely reason is a crumbling of confidence inside the citadels of global capital. Just as the trendy vicar throws off his dog collar and embraces denim in a desperate attempt to be "relevant", so the contemporary financier hopes by dressing down to blend into a society in which he has become aware he has precious few supporters.

When did this panic attack begin? A possible date would be autumn 1998, when the Long Term Capi tal Management debacle exposed the horrible truth that "free enterprise" capital is the biggest welfare claimant of all.

Ironically, there are still corners of the economic and industrial scene where leadership figures have the confidence to dress like leadership figures, and not like students filling in on a holiday job. It is hard to imagine, for example, Bill Morris, head of the Transport & General Workers' Union, appearing in anything other than a dark suit, collar and tie.

Clothes maketh not man, but they help identify those who believe the future belongs to them. Bad news for the City, with or with-out demonstrators.

webTitle: Tate Modern in talks for key US art collection

fields.headline: Tate Modern in talks for key US art collection
fields.trailText: The Tate Modern is in talks with an American financier who may be about to give part of his £100m art collection - one of the world's largest in private hands - to the new museum.
fields.body:
The Tate Modern is in talks with an American financier who may be about to give part of his £100m art collection - one of the world's largest in private hands - to the new museum.

Kent Logan, a colourful San Francisco-based entrepreneur who "retired" last year at the age of 55, has bought several pieces by young British artists, including Tracey Emin's Psycho Slut and Damien Hirst's Philip (The Twelve Disciples), a bull's head suspended in formaldehyde, although he is not a collector of Brit Art on anything like the scale of Charles Saatchi.

He is an admirer of Rachel Whiteread, too, and has described young British artists, or the YBAs as they are called, as "the most important art movement certainly in the last decade".

What makes his collection particularly attractive to the Tate is its range of contemporary Asian and European art, as well as its 17 Warhols and early works by David Hockney. Mr Logan also has the prototype of Antony Gormley's Angel of the North on display at his second home in Vail, Colorado, which he jokingly refers to as the Angel of the Rockies.

According to the Sunday Times, Mr Logan feels the Tate Modern is set to become the most important modern art museum in Europe, and he in tends dividing his collection between it, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, a gallery he is building himself in Vail, and possibly Moma in New York.

Mr Logan is one of several major American collectors who have been wooed by the Tate in recent years. The gallery has a fundraising office in New York and its director, Nicholas Serota, has gone to great lengths to cultivate important art buyers.

Many of them, including Mr Logan, have been invited to the official opening of the £134m museum on the South Bank of the Thames in 10 days time in the hope they will part with some of the works they hold. Several have already made large donations to pay for the building itself.

Mr Serota confirmed that negotiations had been going on with Mr Logan, but remained tight-lipped about the likelihood of a deal.

"The Tate and Kent Logan have been in discussion over the past year," he said. "We are delighted to hear that he is enthusiastic about London and Tate Modern, and that he is seriously considering giving part of his collection to the Tate, as well as to other museums."

Meanwhile, Hirst, the most prominent young British artist to be featured in the new museum, has said he will not be able to attend the launch for "personal reasons". He intends to visit the converted power station at a later date.

webTitle: Dementia may trigger latent artistic talents

fields.headline: Dementia may trigger latent artistic talents
fields.trailText: Dementia does not always mean a distressing descent into oblivion. Psychiatrists in the United States have found 12 patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) who have developed or maintained remarkable musical and artistic abilities, apparently as functions in one part of the brain are released to compensate for the damage elsewhere.
fields.body:
Dementia does not always mean a distressing descent into oblivion. Psychiatrists in the United States have found 12 patients with frontotemporal dementia (FTD) who have developed or maintained remarkable musical and artistic abilities, apparently as functions in one part of the brain are released to compensate for the damage elsewhere.

A formerly gifted linguist with limited musical training began to compose classical music at the age of 68. His mind, he told psychiatrists who saw him at 78 when he was confusing the names of his children, dogs and horses, was "taken over" during composition and he "sensed" different tonal intervals which he put to music. He gradually lost his fluency in Chinese, Italian and several of the languages of the former Soviet Union, but musical abilities developed. Some of his pieces have been publicly performed.

His story is related in the latest issue of the British Journal of Psychiatry by Bruce Miller and colleagues from the UCSF school of medicine, in San Francisco. They assessed seven dementia patients who developed new skills and five whose artistic or musical talents remained intact. The 12 were compared with 46 patients also suffering from FTD who showed no such abilities.

Nine out of the 12 had a loss of function in the left anterior temporal lobe of the brain. Other studies have shown that the right hemisphere is responsible for the spontaneous production of music and that damage to it devastates the ability to copy or paint.

The psychiatrists note that the 12 produced music and art in an almost instinctive but non-verbal manner. "A bridge champion and a chess master continued playing by manipulating visual images of cards or chess pieces learned earlier," they write. Although the patients were losing their ability to talk and socialise, they all became increasingly interested in, and eventually obsessed by, the fine detail of their artistic work.

One of the 12, a woman who had been a scientist and a brilliant inventor, but never en joyed reading, began to have language difficulties at 68. By 71 she was losing the meaning of words. She stopped reading, but continued to perfect her inventions, receiving new patents until her 74th year.

Not everybody with dementia can expect to develop new talents, the researchers caution, but the study shows "dementia is not invariably associated with relentless loss of all intellectual abilities".

webTitle: Star uses curtain call to turn on Miller producers

fields.headline: Star uses curtain call to turn on Miller producers
fields.trailText: A British actor launched a mutiny at the weekend against the producers of an Arthur Miller play on Broadway.
fields.body:
A British actor launched a mutiny at the weekend against the producers of an Arthur Miller play on Broadway.

After a performance in the starring role in The Ride Down Mt Morgan, Patrick Stewart returned to the stage and told the audience: "Arthur Miller and I no longer have confidence in our producers' commitment to the production or their willingness to promote and publicise it.

"I know we have an extraordinary, provocative and vastly entertaining play. What is also needed is promotion and publicity. People need to know a play is out there.

"This I find deeply puzzling if for no other reason than this is an important play by America's most distinguished living playwright.

"Arthur and I feel frustrated and helpless. All we can do now is ask you, our audience, for help."

Stewart, 59, who played Captain Jean-Luc Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation, stars in the Miller play at the Ambassador Theatre as a wealthy bigamist whose two wives meet at his hospital bedside after he is involved in a car crash.

He claims the producers reneged on promises to take out newspaper advertisements and to place favourable quotes from reviews outside the theatre.

"The front of the theatre looks the same as it did seven weeks ago when we started previews," said Stewart. "People tell me it looks like the show has not opened yet. Or that it has closed."

He added: "This is not an easy thing to do. It's like breaking ranks but I felt I had no other choice."

Miller said: "There has been no attempt to promote the play and we've had enough. I don't know the reason why they're not promoting the show. It's as though the play doesn't exist."

But Philip Smith, president of the Schubert organisation, which is producing the show, said: "The producers' commitment could not be stronger.

"To have Patrick Stewart on Broadway in an Arthur Miller play is a producer's dream come true."

Figures show that a healthy 87.8% of seats were taken for the show in the week finishing April 23, marginally down on sales for the previous week.

webTitle: A shot in the arm for gun victims

fields.headline: A shot in the arm for gun victims
fields.standfirst: There are 90 shooting deaths in the US every day.  Marcel Berlins reports on how American cities are suing gun-makers in their crackdown on lethal weapons
fields.trailText: The 16-year-old assured me that he could get a gun within a few minutes of leaving school. His fellow pupils nodded in agreement; so could they. How many of them, I asked, had personal experience of a friend or relative killed or injured by a gun? All of them. Did they think anything could be done to reverse the appalling litany of deaths by gun violence in the United States? They looked dubious.
fields.body:
The 16-year-old assured me that he could get a gun within a few minutes of leaving school. His fellow pupils nodded in agreement; so could they. How many of them, I asked, had personal experience of a friend or relative killed or injured by a gun? All of them. Did they think anything could be done to reverse the appalling litany of deaths by gun violence in the United States? They looked dubious.

I was at a school in Brooklyn, New York, making a Radio 4 programme trying to assess the chances of litigation in the American courts succeeding where politics had failed - in controlling the seemingly unstoppable spread of fatal weapons. If Brooklyn is any touchstone, the law hasn't a chance.

The shocking cases in the headlines - the Columbine High School massacre; the six-year-old boy who shot dead a seven-year-old girl at school; within the past two weeks, the fatal Washington Zoo teenage gun battle - are a tiny proportion of the annual death toll caused by guns. The latest figures for the US reveal 32,000 fatalities - close on 90 every day. More than 13,000 were murders. Many of the rest were suicides or unintentional shootings - but many of those only happened because of a ready-to-shoot gun lying around.

So-called gun-control laws have made little impact. The firm restrictions on gun ownership imposed by some states penalise the law-abiding but don't stop criminals from being armed. Other states make buying a gun not much more difficult than buying a beer. For its part, the US Congress can't pass tough laws because of the powerful political influence of the National Rifle Association (current president, Charlton Heston).

So what can litigation do? There is one development which gives the gun control lobby hope - aiming to hit gun manufacturers where it hurts them most, in their pockets, by suing them for compensation. The new twist is that instead of being left to the victims, lawsuits are now being brought by more powerful interests - cities, including some of the most important: Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Philadelphia, Washington DC.

The similarities with tobacco litigation are obvious, and not coincidental. At first, lawsuits against the cigarette makers were brought by ill and dying smokers, with limited success. It was only when cities and states started suing that the tobacco companies began taking the litigation seriously, eventually capitulating. The result was a deal expected to cost them more than $300bn (£190bn).

The anti-gun campaign hopes that concerted action by the cities - who are suing for the price of dealing with gun violence, from providing ambulances and hospital treatment for victims to the costs of prosecuting and imprisoning offenders - will achieve a similar success; at the very least, that it will shake the gun-makers into a new sense of responsibility.

The parallels between guns and cigarettes are not altogether convincing. The gun industry doesn't have anything like the deep pockets of tobacco. This affects the amount of compensation that might be obtained, and therefore the enthusiasm of lawyers working on a no-win, no-fee basis in the hope of a cut of huge winnings (some of the tobacco lawyers became mega-millionaires at a stroke).

There's a more fundamental legal difficulty distinguishing tobacco from guns. With cigarettes, quite apart from the fact that the manufacturers consistently lied about the dangers of their product, the chain of causation was simple. They made harmful cigarettes, people smoked them and got ill as a direct result.

But how do you make the makers of a gun responsible if, say, a year after it legally sells it to an authorised dealer, it finds its way into the hands of a criminal who kills in the course of a robbery? Or where a gun is left on the kitchen table by irresponsible parents, and their 10-year-old son picks it up and shoots his sister? Isn't the chain between the manufacturers and the ultimate tragedy too lengthy and too interrupted for the makers to bear the blame?

That's the line taken by the arms industry and the gun lobby, and by the sincere people at the shooting range in Chantilly, Virginia, where I learned to fire a .38. How can the manufacturer of a legal product become liable because some hot-head or psychopath uses it to take a life? After all, you can't sue General Motors if one of its cars is driven by a drunk and kills a pedestrian.

The claims against the manufacturers are based on two main grounds. First, they could easily be making guns safer, by the use of trigger-locks, safety devices and smart-gun technology; but many of them aren't doing so. Second, their distribution and marketing allow guns to get into the wrong hands.

"People who make and sell dangerous things have to take responsibility for them," says John Coale, a tobacco litigation pioneer now pursuing the gun interests. "The manufacturers seem to think that once the gun leaves their factory, they have no responsibility. We say they do, and that they're not protecting the public from their product.

"They know that guns go to dealers who are selling them to criminals. If you have a toxic chemical and it leaves the plant, you're responsible for it all the way down the line because you know it's dangerous."

So far there's been one successful lawsuit against manufacturers; not by one of the cities - their litigation is still in its early stages - but by an individual. In 1998 Stephen Fox won a judgment in a New York court which broke new ground in gun-makers' liability. The teenager was accidentally shot by a friend boastfully showing off the gun he'd recently bought, illegally.

The bullet went into his head. It's still there. The gun was never recovered and he didn't know what make it was. So he (and six other plaintiffs, some of them representing victims who had died) sued 25 main manufacturers for compensation.

A jury heard all the manufacturers explain exactly what, if any, precautions they took to ensure that their guns couldn't fall into criminal hands. Were they, for instance, sold at gun shows, where there are very few restrictions, or did they sell only to registered dealers? The jury divided the manufacturers into the careful (who were ruled not liable) and the careless, who had "failed to use reasonable care in the distribution of their guns".

Eventually they decided that three companies were liable to pay for Stephen Fox's injuries. His compensation was set at nearly $4m (£2.5m). But the guilty manufacturers will pay only the proportion equal to their market share of the gun business.

That decision may not be the final word; the result of an appeal is expected soon. But what's already clear is that manufacturers are rattled by the legal onslaught against them.

How far the litigation will succeed in bringing down fatalities is another question. Gun culture is deeply embedded in the national psyche; and there are around 250m guns in American hands. It will take more than a few successful lawsuits to make any real difference. But it will be a start.
