webTitle: Labour struggle for the heart of Hartlepool

fields.headline: Labour struggle for the heart of Hartlepool
fields.standfirst:
Election countdown: In-fighting and opposition pact could lose the party overall control of the council in Mandelson's constituency
Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Overlooking the birthplace of Andy Capp, now all reborn dockland, big retail sheds, ring roads and flattened steelworks, the men of the Headland district reflect on a town in transition.
fields.body:
Overlooking the birthplace of Andy Capp, now all reborn dockland, big retail sheds, ring roads and flattened steelworks, the men of the Headland district reflect on a town in transition.

Like the famous beer-swilling, pigeon fancying, chain-smoking, sexist cadger of the cartoon, the grimy north of old Hartlepool depicted by his creator, the late Reg Smyth, has long since disappeared, along with the flat caps, the whippets and the pit heaps.

That should be good news for New Labour, and the local MP - the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson - who played a key role in rebranding the party. Andy Capp might turn in his grave but Hartlepudlians are beginning to question their long-standing political loyalties.

There is a whiff of rebellion in the air. This week the unthinkable might just happen: Labour could lose overall control of the local council, thanks partly to an "unholy alliance" of Liberal Democrats and Tories.

"That Labour council," scoffs Thomas Longwill, walking his dogs along the Headland prom beside the tall Georgian villas of the old industrial elite. "Takes us for granted. Never see Labour people. Folks feel cheated. OK, Labour say they are addressing the country's problems, but they don't seem to have improved a great deal yet."

Like scores of others on the Headland, Mr Longwill, a chemical worker, will vote Liberal Democrat this week. He sees Hartlepool changing, partly for the better, but he does not give the Labour council much credit.

Disaffection with Labour's town hall rulers runs across northern England and the Lib Dems are steadily gaining ground. But Hartlepool's political elite has been edging towards self-destruction, although Mr Mandelson has generally managed to rise above the turmoil. "He sees it as old Labour feuding and nothing to do with the new politics," says a local ally.

Nationally, Tony Blair, who represents neighbouring Sedgefield, has distanced New Labour from the old party machines running local councils in the north. But with the party facing big losses in seats won four years ago at the height of Tory unpopularity, strategists recognise Labour has much ground to recover before a likely general election next year, particularly in heartlands like Hartlepool.

Having had three council leaders over the past three years, Labour's opponents in Hartlepool can capitalise on a bitterly divided Labour group. Its officials are resigned to the Lib Dem-Tory opposition making headway this week, partly as a result of the in-fighting.

"I don't think we will lose control, but I'd be foolhardy if I suggested we will not lose any seats," says Russell Hart, an accountant who has been council leader for a year and - unlike his predecessor - is a strong Mandelson supporter.

He points to an "unholy alliance" under which Tories are not fielding candidates in six key seats, to give the Lib Dems a clear run, and the Lib Dems are not contesting two wards which the Tories could win.

"Wholly unprincipled, gutter politics," he says. "To deny Tory and Lib Dem supporters an opportunity to vote for their parties is plain evil."

Arthur Preece, the Lib Dem leader, says he is confident the combined opposition will make the seven gains necessary to remove Labour from overall control. Whatever the reservations of his party or the Conservative leadership, Mr Preece says he will offer places to Tories in an anti-Labour administration.

"They know that if Labour loses we will talk to them, and, in turn, they will talk to us," he says. But arrangements are strictly informal, he insists. "This is not an electoral pact."

But Frank Rogers, the veteran Tory leader, says idle talk about a pact should not cloud a wider issue - dissatisfaction with Labour. "It's like what went wrong with the Tories, all this in-fighting and people are saying it's time for a change," he says. "There's too much backbiting in the Labour camp, clashes between personalities."

By that he means the rivalry between Russell Hart and the former council leader, Ray Waller, who challenged Mr Mandelson for the Labour constituency nomination. A year ago Mr Hart eventually triumphed over Mr Waller by one vote in the Labour group. Relations are strained. A council insider explains: "Russell is close to Peter [Mandelson] and Ray isn't."

Mr Waller, a councillor for 38 years, cannot disguise his frustration with New Labour. He hints broadly that long-serving members feel excluded from the Blairite project and that traditional supporters are turning away.

"The area which I represent has very high unemployment, and at this point people are not seeing the real benefits which seem to be happening elsewhere in the country," says Mr Waller, adding diplomatically that in a second-term, Labour will "hopefully be able to deliver those core values".

It is a message which could further distance the Hartlepool old guard from New Labour and the local MP - although last year, Mr Mandelson acknowledged that the government needed to try harder to improve the economies of towns like Hartlepool, where unemployment is at least twice the national average.

Labour's opponents say this week's battle for Hartlepool could have more symbolism than elsewhere. "It would be embarrassing for the MP if Labour loses the council," says Mr Preece. "No doubt some people would take great delight in pointing out that he can't hold his own backyard."

Nationally, Tony Blair, who represents neighbouring Sedgefield, has distanced New Labour from the old party machines running local councils in the north. But with the party facing big losses in seats won four years ago at the height of Tory unpopularity, strategists recognise Labour has much ground to recover before a likely general election next year, particularly in heartlands like Hartlepool. Having had three council leaders over the past three years, Labour's opponents in Hartlepool can capitalise on a bitterly divided Labour group. Its officials are resigned to the Lib Dem-Tory opposition making headway this week, partly as a result of the in-fighting. "I don't think we will lose control, but I'd be foolhardy if I suggested we will not lose any seats," says Russell Hart, an accountant who has been council leader for a year and - unlike his predecessor - is a strong Mandelson supporter. He points to an "unholy alliance" under which Tories are not fielding candidates in six key seats, to give the Lib Dems a clear run, and the Lib Dems are not contesting two wards which the Tories could win. "Wholly unprincipled, gutter politics," he says. "To deny Tory and Lib Dem supporters an opportunity to vote for their parties is plain evil." Arthur Preece, the Lib Dem leader, says he is confident the combined opposition will make the seven gains necessary to remove Labour from overall control. Whatever the reservations of his party or the Conservative leadership, Mr Preece says he will offer places to Tories in an anti-Labour administration. "They know that if Labour loses we will talk to them, and, in turn, they will talk to us," he says. But arrangements are strictly informal, he insists. "This is not an electoral pact." But Frank Rogers, the veteran Tory leader, says idle talk about a pact should not cloud a wider issue - dissatisfaction with Labour. "It's like what went wrong with the Tories, all this in-fighting and people are saying it's time for a change," he says. "There's too much backbiting in the Labour camp, clashes between personalities." By that he means the rivalry between Russell Hart and the former council leader, Ray Waller, who challenged Mr Mandelson for the Labour constituency nomination. A year ago Mr Hart eventually triumphed over Mr Waller by one vote in the Labour group. Relations are strained. A council insider explains: "Russell is close to Peter [Mandelson] and Ray isn't." Mr Waller, a councillor for 38 years, cannot disguise his frustration with New Labour. He hints broadly that long-serving members feel excluded from the Blairite project and that traditional supporters are turning away. "The area which I represent has very high unemployment, and at this point people are not seeing the real benefits which seem to be happening elsewhere in the country," says Mr Waller, adding diplomatically that in a second-term, Labour will "hopefully be able to deliver those core values". It is a message which could further distance the Hartlepool old guard from New Labour and the local MP - although last year, Mr Mandelson acknowledged that the government needed to try harder to improve the economies of towns like Hartlepool, where unemployment is at least twice the national average. Labour's opponents say this week's battle for Hartlepool could have more symbolism than elsewhere. "It would be embarrassing for the MP if Labour loses the council," says Mr Preece. "No doubt some people would take great delight in pointing out that he can't hold his own backyard."

fields.headline: Attacking Goliath
fields.standfirst:
As anti-capitalist protesters claim they'll take to London's streets, Isabel Hilton sees their point

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: The prediction is that today's anti-capitalist demonstration in the City of London will be the biggest to date in the series of protests provoked by globalisation. At the time of writing, it's too early to tell if this is an inflated prediction by police and organisers, each with an interest in boosting the anticipated numbers.
fields.body:
The prediction is that today's anti-capitalist demonstration in the City of London will be the biggest to date in the series of protests provoked by globalisation. At the time of writing, it's too early to tell if this is an inflated prediction by police and organisers, each with an interest in boosting the anticipated numbers.

But more interesting than crude numbers will be the composition of the demonstrations. Will it be the familiar anarchists, bolstered by a few kids out for a bit of amusement, or will it, as the organisers also predict, be a more rounded crowd, professionals as well as unemployed, the anxious middle-aged alongside the rebellious teens? My bet is there will be a fair sprinkling of civilians among the class warriors. To expect otherwise would be to pretend that only the perennially disaffected have a grievance against global capital to determine what kind of lives we will live in the 21st century.

Multinational corporations have been a bogy for the left since Karl Marx first chewed the end of his pencil. Never have they offered more cause for concern than 10 years after the collapse of the socialist bloc and five after the establishment of the Word Trade Organisation. According to Corporate Watch, 51 of the world's 100 largest economies are corporations and the combined revenues of just two of them - General Motors and Ford, exceed the combined GDP for all of south Saharan Africa. Here in the UK we seem to be deeply attached to the idea of national sovereignty. Without such an attachment in the wider population, the Europhobes would find it harder going than they do.

But why are the British so easily aroused by the suggestion that sovereignty has been lost to the European Union when they are so much less moved by globalisation? After all, the steps towards integration in the European Union were clear. They were subject to exhaustive parliamentary debate and, on occasion, referendum. The extent of the powers vested in the institutions of the EU is described in exhaustive detail in volume after volume of acquis communitaire . And though there is general agreement that there is a democratic deficit in the structures of the EU, there is at least an elected parliament that is steadily acquiring powers. It may be full of defects, but at least it is there.

The anti-European lobby's favourite epithet - faceless - is unfair. If you want to complain or protest about the conduct of matters in the EU, it is possible to find out where you should do so. A far more convincing symbol of a powerful, faceless process that not only attacks national sovereignty and weakens democratic institutions but invades every aspect of daily life is the WTO.

Since it was set up in 1995, the WTO and the globalisation that it is there to promote, has impacted on our lives on every level. The advocates of untrammelled global free trade argue that this is all to our benefit. The demonstrators in Seattle last year and today on the streets of London - and those who quietly cheer them on - say that's not the whole story. We are wealthier, better fed, better housed and longer lived than at any time in history. And the last two decades have delivered an extraordinary rate of growth that has lifted millions out of poverty. Free market purists argue that all the ills the process has produced can be cured by further liberalisation.

The counter argument was thoroughly made at Seattle: that the cost of this economic growth in environmental terms is unpayable, that the political price is too high, that the power of the global corporations that are the prime beneficiaries of the system is too great, that the huge disparities in wealth the process has produced are immoral. For most people the argument is not whether there should be capitalism or not. It is: what kind of capitalism? What degree of rapacity can I accept in return for the benefits I enjoy?

If I want to say yes to capitalism but not on the terms proposed under the WTO millennial round, to whom do I say it, short of joining the protest on the street? If I want to say yes to trade, but only if the workers in south China's free trade zone factories can get some modicum of labour protection, whom do I lobby? If I want to say yes to internationalism but no to a world in which international institutions are a thin disguise for dominating US corporations, to whom do I address my postcard?

And today's protesters have their answer, as the protesters in Washington and Seattle had theirs. Their presence in Seattle and since has focussed the unease felt by many who would not join them. But protest has its limitations and one of them is that protest is not a negotiating position. Even if negotiations were offered, it is hard to see a coherent alternative vision in the many positions on the street.

Lucy Parsons, of Reclaim the Streets, told the Financial Times that the protests were aimed at "taking power away from the politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats" and forcing "radical social and ecological changes". But taking power from the politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats does not of itself make power disappear. My limited experience of moments when nobody was in charge (in countries that were in the throes of disintegration) suggests that they are more dangerous and unpleasant than even the most rapacious forms of capitalism are able to be in a society that has not broken down.

Last century's alternative to capitalism was voted out by history. Since overthrowing capitalism is not really an option, what we are faced with is the much more complicated challenge of fashioning capitalism into a garment that we can live with. We are unlikely to find contentment where we are valued mainly for our ability to produce and consume; when the planet we inhabit in common is being depleted in pursuit of profits that enrich an ever smaller group; when global capitalism overrides democratic mechanisms and reaches ever deeper into our lives; trying to shape our societies down to the smallest detail, using our selfishness and greed as its main weapon. The global market delivered growth, but what is the purpose of this growth? The only acceptable answer is that it is to enhance human welfare, a standard by which we are entitled to measure the damage to the environment, health, dignity and family life.

The WTO has given globalisation a huge boost, but where are the international bodies parallel to the WTO that can regulate and control the corporations - or even force them to pay tax? Where is the democratic body that corresponds to the WTO, where then objections of the citizens can be heard? These are all concerns raised by the protesters and echoed by a much wider group, but nowhere does the political conversation reflect them. We are in the grip of an orthodoxy that tells us not only that there is no alternative to further globalisation, but that it is all for the best.

Yet in the last few months, the IMF and the World Bank, pillars of that orthodoxy, admitted that the liberalising prescriptions that they have dispensed for 20 years may not have done any good - staggering admissions, which have produced almost no political debate. Globalisation of trade has generated the globalisation of protest - the internet allows movements to build critical mass - as they fight against the Multilateral Agreement on Investment or Monsanto's terminator gene. But so far it has failed to create a global political ground on which the terms and conditions of capitalism can be negotiated. Until it does, the discussion will stay in the streets.

webTitle: Cabinet return ruled out for Dobson 'after defeat'

fields.headline: Cabinet return ruled out for Dobson 'after defeat'
fields.standfirst:
Mayor for London
Frank Dobson
Ken Livingstone
Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson's chances of a return to the cabinet after near-certain defeat in the London mayoral elections are slim, Labour sources acknowledged last night, as the party joined the Tories to level last-ditch accusations at front runner Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson's chances of a return to the cabinet after near-certain defeat in the London mayoral elections are slim, Labour sources acknowledged last night, as the party joined the Tories to level last-ditch accusations at front runner Ken Livingstone.

Speculation that the former health secretary could return to a frontline job is widely regarded as unfounded by party insiders, though sources insisted Mr Dobson did not want sympathy and the offer of "sweeties".

With four days to go before Londoners go to the polls, the bitterness tainting the race for the top job showed no sign of receding. Independent candidate Mr Livingstone once more claimed he was a victim of a smear campaign as Labour officials and the Tory candidate, Steve Norris, questioned whether his election costs breached spending limits.

Meanwhile, Mr Dobson was left denying claims that - unless he was given a job to return to after his defeat - he would write a book exposing a campaign by Downing Street to bounce him into the mayoral race.

Claiming to be mystified by the reports, he said: "I'm not preparing a book."

However, it appears that Mr Dobson is unlikely to return to the cabinet after the election, which according to latest polls could see him slipping into fourth place behind Mr Livingstone, Mr Norris and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer.

One Labour source stressed Mr Dobson's popularity within his own party, but admitted scepticism over reports that the former health secretary could take over from Margaret Beckett as the leader of the house.

With the exception of the "special case" of Peter Mandelson, made Northern Ireland secretary after resigning as trade secretary over a home loan, Tony Blair has no track record in bringing former cabinet members back to the front bench after they are reshuffled, insiders point out.

With days to go to the election, Labour spin doctors are attempting to focus last-ditch campaigning on to the alleged untrustworthiness of Mr Livingstone.

Labour yesterday made clear its intention carefully to scrutinise the expenses lodged by the former GLC leader to see if he has passed the £420,000 spending limit.

Advertising industry insiders estimated the cost of Mr Livingstone's election broadcast at £200,000, while there had also been a costly poster blitz, Labour claimed.

A spokesman said: "When Ken puts his (expenses) in we will be looking to see whether he has followed the rules and accounted for his spending properly, and if any of his figures are suspicious we will go ahead with a complaint."

Mr Norris told LWT's Seven Days debate: "I think he [Mr Livingstone] had better check with his treasurer because we all know what the prices are and a lot of us think Ken is getting pretty close to the wire."

However Mr Livingstone said that he had given his campaign staff "clear instructions" not to spend more than £400,000.

fields.headline: Postcards from the edge
fields.standfirst: A New York exhibition of old photographs of lynchings has brought home the brutal reality of life for many African-Americans in the US
fields.trailText: The sign outside the main gallery in the museum is not what you might expect, certainly not for an exhibition made up largely of postcards.
fields.body:
The sign outside the main gallery in the museum is not what you might expect, certainly not for an exhibition made up largely of postcards.

But this is not just any old show at the New York Historical Society and they are not just any old postcards.

The warning reads: "The exhibition Without Sanctuary contains graphic photographs of lynchings which may be particularly disturbing to young viewers."

And not just to young viewers. Mary Kern, 63, says: "It hurts: even though you knew about it, the pictures bring home the brutality. We did this to people without concern for their dignity or their human rights. What were we thinking?"

It is estimated that almost 5,000 people, the vast majority of them black, were lynched in the US between 1880 and 1968.

Their alleged crimes, for which they were put to death by white mobs, ranged from murder to lack of respect for white people. Each black-and-white image in the exhibition tells a horrifying story, though not one taught in school.

Many of the photographers and some of the victims are not known, but the fate of the latter could not be more plain - often whipped, mutilated, disfigured and burned either before or while dying with a rope around the neck.

The case of Jesse Washington is even harder to stomach than most. The 17-year-old boy, who had learning difficulties, was found guilty of murder and grabbed by a crowd who cut off his ears and castrated him before dangling him over a fire.

When he tried to climb the chain from which he was suspended each time they dipped him into the flames below, his tormentors cut off his fingers.

The scene became a post card and was put to immediate use: "This is the barbecue we had last night. My picture is to the left. Your son, Joe." That was near Waco, Texas, in May 1916.

The most recent photograph shows the corpse of an unidentified man hanging by the neck after he was found by two boys on a fishing trip.

According to the acompanying material, the head of the state bureau of investigations took a look at the scene and said: "Suicide." That, in Georgia in 1968, was the end of the inquiry.

"It took a number of years to decide to collect pictures like these," said James Allen, the Atlanta antiques dealer who started putting together the photographs in Without Sanctuary 15 years ago.

"They're too painful to look at. But once you've seen these you can't talk about race without factoring in the reality of what African-Americans really went through."

They went through it mainly in the South, but in other places too: in Missouri, Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, Florida, Indiana, Minnesota and California.

And after they had gone through it members of the attendant crowds sometimes posed casually for the camera as though they were participants in a hunting party or even a routine civic function.

"It's terrorising me," said Kenny Osei, a 20-year-old black student from Brooklyn, who was sent to the exhibition by a teacher.

"It's savagery and, yes, it makes me angry. It would make any sane person angry. The exhibition allows people to know what was going on. People of my age, even African-Americans, don't read.

"Look at what goes on in the land of the free. And it's still going on in a different way."

A signature of any performance by Billie Holiday was her rendition of Strange Fruit, with the words: "Southern trees bear a strange fruit, Blood on the leaves and blood at the root."

The photograph that inspired Abel Meeropol, a New York Jew, to write the song is featured at the exhibition. It shows Thomas Shipp and Abram Smith dead in a double lynching in Indiana in 1930.

webTitle: Clinton pokes fun at the president

fields.headline: Clinton pokes fun at the president
fields.trailText: It might have been a vision of a future about 12 months hence: President Bill Clinton hosting a press conference to an audience of one slumbering reporter; running after his wife's limousine with her lunch; and, all alone, playing Battleship.
fields.body:
It might have been a vision of a future about 12 months hence: President Bill Clinton hosting a press conference to an audience of one slumbering reporter; running after his wife's limousine with her lunch; and, all alone, playing Battleship.

Any of this might yet come true, but for now it was merely an exercise in poking fun at himself for an audience full of people experienced in doing just that, the White House correspondents' group.

Mr Clinton produced the video for the journalists' annual dinner, revealing a talent that might even be put to use one day, should any of the occasional rumours about him seeking a job with his old friend Steven Spielberg in the post-presidential years ever come to anything.

"You like me! You really like me!" the president said in mock surprise to the 2,600 reporters, editors, politicians and celebrities.

But he could not resist giving himself credit for at least one thing: "In good times and the bad, I have actually shown up here for eight straight years."

For the rest, it was all barbed humour about political friends and enemies. Speaking about the possibility of Vietnam war hero John McCain joining George W Bush's presidential ticket, the president cracked: "Hasn't the man suffered enough?"

Jay Leno, the comedian and talk show star who hosted the event, turned to Hillary Clinton and said "Don't worry about the tip. I've taken care of that," a reference to her failure recently to leave a small consideration for a waitress while campaigning for the Senate - a near-capital crime at any time in New York.

The three-hour dinner was also attended by a host of politicians and celebrities, including former Democratic presidential candidate Bill Bradley, film director Spike Lee, actors John Cusack, Kevin Spacey, Sharon Stone and Alec Baldwin, and the cast of the NBC program The West Wing, who make a living by satirising politics.

Jay Leno, the comedian and talk show star who hosted the event, turned to Hillary Clinton and said "Don't worry about the tip. I've taken care of that," a reference to her failure recently to leave a small consideration for a waitress while campaigning for the Senate - a near-capital crime at any time in New York. The three-hour dinner was also attended by a host of politicians and celebrities, including former Democratic presidential candidate Bill Bradley, film director Spike Lee, actors John Cusack, Kevin Spacey, Sharon Stone and Alec Baldwin, and the cast of the NBC program The West Wing, who make a living by satirising politics.

fields.headline: Labour plan to privatise Channel 4
fields.standfirst: Sell-off would raise £2bn to fund pledges in manifesto
fields.trailText: The government hopes to privatise Channel 4 soon after the next election to raise up to £2bn to help fund its manifesto pledges.
fields.body:
The government hopes to privatise Channel 4 soon after the next election to raise up to £2bn to help fund its manifesto pledges.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is understood to be in favour of the sell-off, but it is likely to be opposed by the culture secretary, Chris Smith.

The move would be fiercely opposed by many senior figures at Channel 4, notably the chairman, Vanni Treves, a Labour supporter. However, many in the broadcasting industry believe that a sell-off makes sense, as long as the privatised channel is regulated by strict public service obligations.

Labour has already announced plans to introduce a broadcasting bill early in the new parliament, signalling a shake-up of the bodies which regulate the broadcasting industry. There could be external regulation of some BBC activities for the first time, and watchdogs that have overlapping responsibilities, such as the Independent Television Commission and the Broadcasting Standards Commission, could be merged.

Many in the industry believe the bill will also pave the way for consolidation of the ITV network. Already, most of ITV is owned by four big compa nies: Carlton, Granada, United and the Scottish Media Group. Carlton and United plan to merge, unless the plans fall foul of regulations. Granada has said it will bid for Carlton or United if the merger fails.

But any encouragement of consolidation by government would be resisted by campaign groups worried that ITV would lose its regional identities.

Privatisation of Channel 4 would be equally controversial. When it was set up in 1984, it was given a strict public service remit to encourage diversity and innovation, a definition it has stretched in recent years. The channel is profitable: it made £17.7m in 1998, and is expected to report another successful year last year.

The chief executive, Michael Jackson, says he opposes privatisation, but is driving through a highly commercial strategy. The channel now broadcasts programmes, such as the Uncovered series and a documentary on Victoria Beckham, which stretch its remit.

Its subscription movie channel, FilmFour, had attracted 250,000 subscribers by the end of last year, more than double the initial aspirations. It is already thinking about launching other subscription services, such as a racing channel and an education channel.

Other broadcasters, however, are envious of the channel's privileged position. It does not pay for the frequencies on which it broadcasts. When it was set up, it had to pay part of its advertising revenue to ITV, but this funding formula has been abolished.

The previous chief executive, Sir Michael Bishop, fought off attempts by the Conservative government to sell the channel. Mr Treves, in the last annual report, said: "Channel 4's responsibility is to satisfy the full range of viewers' interests. That is what increasingly dis tinguishes us from other commercial broadcasters, old and new, and it is that distinction which leaves us in no doubt that privatisation would be a disaster both for the channel and for the viewer."

fields.headline: Robotic future rushes toward us
fields.trailText: The first robot-controlled taxi service will be installed somewhere in the world between 2004 and 2007.
fields.body:
The first robot-controlled taxi service will be installed somewhere in the world between 2004 and 2007.

Not only that, but before the present decade is out, tomorrow's Kate Adie and her television journalist colleagues will transmit what they see - live - to television screens from microsensors embedded in their optic nerves.

And what they say will be picked up by mobile phone transmitters implanted in their shoulders.

Two years after that, the first factories will be at work in space, making high-quality microchips and pharmaceuticals from very pure crystals grown in space, and shipping the finished products back to earth in autopilot space shuttles.

This is the future, according to Roke Manor Research, part of the technology giant Siemens. And, the scientists say today , they are not proposing a robot fairyland.

"We are working on many of these future technologies now, and all of these scenarios are technically possible already," said Ian Stewart of Roke Manor Research.

Some of these future shocks are not just technically possible, they have already been proposed by British government foresight committees. Others are gradually being introduced by commercial groups.

By 2006, "biometric" signatures will be commonplace. Workers will gain entry, and customers will get their credit balances, at a mere glance, after computer-based optical recognition of the unique pattern of the iris.

Stolen personal technology equipment will refuse to work because it cannot recognise the pattern of the owner's fingerprints. PIN numbers will, like pen and ink signatures, just be "old technology."

People will vote online by 2007 in local and national elections, from mobile terminals anywhere in the world, and the numbers voting will be greater, the researchers say. But the two main parties will suffer at the expense of liberals and minority candidates.

By 2005 viewers "going out" will be a matter of staying in: people will download films, live concerts and football matches to watch at any time, and work on the move with their slimline digital communications devices.

If people do go to the cinema or the supermarket, they will do so without credit cards or cash: the vendor's till will negotiate with customer's "mobile phone wallet", deducting money which will be topped up by automatic wireless contact with the banks. Children won't carry bulging satchels, because all their school textbooks will be available at the touch of a screen.

There will be problems in this electronic, bionic nirvana. Implants will help foreign correspondents get the story swiftly and discreetly - but there won't be many who will go for an optic nerve camera fitment. It could go expensively wrong, and it will raise huge surveillance and civil liberties problems.

Robot taxis, responding to electronic signals from navigation beacons, should be safer, cheaper and more fuel efficient - but their use will become part of a status symbol package, which should drive the price up.

In a cashless, automatically-deducted world, spending money will become alarmingly easy. But internet trading across national boundaries will make tax collection accordingly difficult.

The space factory is, paradoxically, one of the oldest prophecies. Sixties seers confidently expected huge settlements of 10,000 people living and working in vast, wheeling space stations by 2001.

In fact, the International Space Station now being assembled in orbit is behind schedule - but there is increasing pressure from entrepreneurs who want space factories and businesses to grow up around the space station like traders around a western frontier fort.

Some of the Siemens projections are quite conservative. There are probably more than a million industrial robots in the world already. Ian Pearson, employed as a futurologist by BT, several years ago predicted robots will rescue people from burning buildings by 2009 at the latest, followed swiftly by household domestic robots to fetch and tidy, with robot mail delivery and robot personal trainers arriving by 2015.

By 2030 at the latest, he says, there will be more robots than people in developed countries.

Kevin Warwick, professor of cybernetics at Reading University, long ago predicted takeover by machines. Three years ago, he implanted an identification chip and transponder in his arm to make doors open and machines switch on, and introduced himself to the world as "Kevin Warwick, part man, part cyborg."

Meaningful glances

 Bank customers will get their credit balances at a glance as machines recognise unique iris patterns by 2006.

 People will vote online in elections from mobile terminals by 2007.

 Robot controlled taxis will be in use by 2007.

 TV journalists will be able to transmit what they see using sensors in their optic nerves by 2010.

 By 2030, there will be more robots than people in developed countries.

fields.headline: Learning difficulties hospital suspends six
fields.trailText: Six nurses at a hospital for people with severe learning difficulties have been suspended over claims they mistreated patients.
fields.body:
Six nurses at a hospital for people with severe learning difficulties have been suspended over claims they mistreated patients.

An investigation has been launched at Lennox Castle hospital in Lennoxtown, Stirlingshire, after complaints by student nurses.

Ian Crawford, the hospital's manager, confirmed that three senior nurses and three nursing assistants had been suspended while the inquiry into allegations of misconduct was undertaken.

"We are at a very early stage of the investigation and the staff are innocent until proved guilty," he said.

"The complaints originated from student nurses and we are looking into them.

"Three of the staff are fully qualified nurses and the other three are assistants who are in volved with patient care but don't have the same responsibility."

The long-stay hospital, which is due to close in two years, has 250 patients and 400 staff.

Kay Ullrich, the Scottish National party's shadow minister for health and community care, said the hospital should carry out the investigation quickly to allay the concerns of patients and their relatives.

She said: "Six is a large number of staff to be suspended from one hospital at one time. Patients at Lennox Castle are among the most vulnerable in our community and they must be protected.

"We don't want the disciplinary process to drag out. It should be got through as quickly as possible and if need be, once it is complete, there may be a need for a public inquiry into general conditions at the hospital."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sheik's sons in kidnap scare
fields.body:
Sheik's sons in kidnap scare

Two young sons of Sheik Maktoum Bin Rashid Al Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai, were mistakenly reported to have been kidnapped from their home in Knightsbridge, west London, yesterday.

Armed police stopped a private jet from leaving Farnborough airport in Hampshire after a 999 call from the children's nanny. It is thought the sheik had asked his bodyguards to escort the children to Dubai.

Poisonous plant thieves warned

Two pots containing Europe's most poisonous plant were stolen from Wanborough Herb Nursery, near Swindon, at the weekend. Acontium, or Monkshood, can cause burning, sweating, pain, dizziness and numbness. Police warned anyone who came into contact with the plant to get hospital treatment.

Mountain trams in collision

Two trams collided head-on in Llandudno yesterday, injuring 17 people. They hit each other on the century-old tramway at Great Orme headland, about two-thirds of the way up the 679ft mountain, after the tram heading to the summit took the wrong line while on a short passing loop. All the injuries were minor.

Man charged with abduction

A man was yesterday charged with the armed kidnap of a mother and her two children. Peter Robert Hughes, 58, was charged in connection with the alleged abduction of Marilyn Rowell, her children and a family friend, after a man made an appointment to view her home in Horsforth, Leeds. He will appear before magistrates today.

Two winners in lottery jackpot

Two tickets shared Saturday's £6,702,652 National Lottery jackpot. The winning numbers were 15, 16, 19, 27, 29 and 42. The bonus ball was 24. No one won the £250,000 top prize in the Thunderball game. The winning numbers were 2, 8, 13, 14, 27 and Thunderball 10.

fields.headline: Running on empty
fields.standfirst:
Having put political ideology to death, Blair can scarcely complain that the voters reject it

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Having put political ideology to death, Blair can scarcely complain that the voters reject it
fields.body:
Our prime minister's toothpaste smile is about to be wiped off his face. A victory for Ken Livingstone in the London mayoral election seems a foregone conclusion. It will be another blow to Tony Blair's undeserved reputation as a dazzling tactician and manipulator of the electorate. But it is also a consequence of Mr Blair's own career, though not in quite the sense that is generally supposed. It might even be seen as a victory for Blairism.

Londoners are going to the polls like schoolchildren who know they are doing something naughty to tease the grown-ups. There are good reasons for voting for none of the other candidates, and if there had been any chance of Jeffrey Archer winning it would have been a good reason for never setting foot in London again.

But there are also good reasons for not voting for Livingstone, on the personal rather than political level. It is a fact that he is liked least by those who know him best, notably his parliamentary colleagues on the Labour left. Anything said about him by Tory politicians should be discounted (and William Hague has good reasons for hoping that Livingstone will win).

There is no reason to discount the contempt in which Livingstone is held by an MP like Brian Sedgemore, one of the better and more honest men on the left. Sedgemore can see that a Livingstone victory won't in any sense be "a victory for the left". It will not be a credit to any political ideology, but rather a reflection on our non-political culture.

Obviously Londoners are backing Livingstone to snub Blair. Just as obviously, no one believes that Londoners will be voting for Ken in terms of concrete political disagreement, in protest against Robin Cook's less-ethical-than-he-claims foreign policy, or Peter Mandelson's suspension of the Northern Ireland executive, or the prime minister's own failure to show leadership on Europe. This is why the London election is truly odd. Not only is the economy booming, every opinion poll still gives the government a crushing lead over the Tories, and the Lib Dems too. If Ken's triumph made strict sense, it would harbinger trouble for Blair in next year's general election, which everyone still assumes the government will win.

Nor can the Livingstone campaign honestly claim that his victory will mean a new mood of revolutionism in the capital. Does anyone think that prosperous London bourgeois are turning out for Ken because of burning socialist conviction? On the simplest level, the election is a classic protest vote. For all the government's economic success, it inspires little affection. In this respect as others, Blair resembles Margaret Thatcher. During our 1987 general election, the veteran American political commentator James Reston shrewdly said that the British people still thought that Thatcher was doing them good (which is why she won that year), but they had never actually liked her. Something of the same is true of Blair.

And yet there is more to it. Not merely will a Livingstone victory be no triumph for a particular ideology. It will actually be a landmark in "the end of ideology" which the American writer Daniel Bell descried years ago. That has come to pass, and with remarkable consequences in British politics. Only when all the isms are wasms can the idea of voting for a man like Livingstone seem amusing to well-heeled Londoners, something Livingstone's serious supporters might ponder.

The final irony concerns Tony Blair. He is going to have his nose tweaked on Thursday, and in consequence of this death of ideology - something for which he more than anyone bears responsibility and from which he more than any other has benefited.

Bell wasn't the first to see the demise of ideological politics. On December 2, 1851, the mountebank Louis Napoleon carried out a coup d'etat in Paris, to become emperor the following year in the footsteps of his more formidable uncle. This coup inspired "The Eighteenth Brumiare of Louis Bonaparte", Karl Marx's pasquinade (in which history repeats itself, "the first time as tragedy, the second as farce").

The coup also prompted a less well-known reaction from another great writer. "Le 2me decembre m'a physiquement depolitique," Charles Baudelaire wrote. "Il n'y a plus d'idees generales... Si j'avais voté, je n'aurais pu voter que pour moi." That "exactly" describes May 1997. In the age of Tony Blair, we have all been physically depoliticised. There are no more general ideas. Might many Londoners of the Me Generation, be voting for Ken as a way of voting for themselves? The most significant statistic at the last general election was that turnout was 71.5%, down from 77.7% in 1992. There can't be a single safer bet about the next election than that turnout will be down again.

Incompetent a tactician as he is, Blair does have a larger strategy. This mysterious man who, in a form of "internal entryism", took over a party in which he had no emotional roots at all and which he actively disliked, then went on to win an electoral triumph. But he did that by following the end of ideology to its logical conclusion, and emptying politics of its content. He understood instinctively that there were no more general ideas, and that as a nation we are, in Baudelaire's words, physically depoliticised. If depoliticised people now take it out on Tony by voting for Ken, then that's poetic justice.

 comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Three years on Labour must learn how to talk - and listen

fields.headline: Three years on Labour must learn how to talk - and listen
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: There will not be a birthday cake with three candles delivered to Number 10 this morning. Today might be the third anniversary of that warm spring day when the country turned out one government and turned to another, but there will be little celebration in Downing Street. Rather, the Labour high command will probably shake its head and sigh: "Who'd have thought it, eh? Three years! Where does it all go. . ."
fields.body:
There will not be a birthday cake with three candles delivered to Number 10 this morning. Today might be the third anniversary of that warm spring day when the country turned out one government and turned to another, but there will be little celebration in Downing Street. Rather, the Labour high command will probably shake its head and sigh: "Who'd have thought it, eh? Three years! Where does it all go. . ."

The source of the maudlin mood will not just be human bewilderment at the passage of time. No, there will be a harsher cause at work: mid-term blues. Every government gets them, and this one is suffering from a milder - and later - case than most. Tony Blair's administration is not watching over an economy in tailspin, like some of its predecessors. Nor is it mired in sleaze, like others. The cabinet is not split down the middle in an ideological civil war. The papers are not baying for blood, nor are the poll numbers in freefall. The country is not at war and the government is not fighting for its life.

Quite the reverse. The economy is in ruddy-cheeked good health, surging ahead to become the fourth largest in the world, while every opinion poll predicts comfortable re-election. As mid-term blues go, this government is getting off pretty lightly.

Still, for a prime minister who enjoyed the longest honeymoon in living memory, these are unhappy days - the cloudiest patch of political weather he has yet experienced. To name his woes on this anniversary may be harsh, but he knows them already. On Thursday he will receive the traditional mid-term bloody nose as Labour sustains perhaps hundreds of losses in local elections across England. If the vote collapses in traditional Labour areas, the "heartlands" cry will be raised again - with former minister Peter Kilfoyle among others claiming that the party is being punished for abandoning its traditional supporters.

This year the mid-term nosebleed will come with an extra agony: the London mayoral election. If Ken Livingstone wins by a landslide, as every poll says he will, that will represent the biggest defeat of Mr Blair's leadership to date. Add to that the ongoing anguish of Rover, the frustration at the government's failure to help manufacturing industry and the continuing stalemate in Northern Ireland, and one can soon see why the bubbly is staying on ice at Number 10.

How can the government make life better for itself, at least in the year or so that stands between now and the next election? The answer may be dialogue. Labour needs to improve the quality of its conversation with the British electorate, in both directions: it needs to smarten up the way it both talks and listens. That means an effort to explain itself and its programme in clearer, less defensive language. That should be easier now that the Tories are on a roll, eagerly defining themselves as the party of xenophobes, homophobes and gun-toting vigilantes. Labour must start to make sense of its claim to be a progressive force - something more positive than a mere enemy of the forces of conservatism.

But it also means a readiness to listen. Tony Blair began the process by acknowledging his mistake in imposing Alun Michael on Wales, but he needs to listen to London on Thursday, too. While he's at it, he should listen to those other, well-meaning critics - the ones who wish this government well but wish it would do better on asylum or freedom of information or the state of our schools. On this May Day Mr Blair should remember these candid friends: for as he surely knows, they are the best friends he's got.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText:
John Owen in Revolution
www.revolution.haynet.com
fields.body:
John Owen in Revolution
www.revolution.haynet.com

Declining click rates are a fact of life that we all have to deal with. So what causes this disappointment? Poorly constructed websites, for sure, and the failure to direct users to the most relevant part of the site rather than just the home page. But also we have all been done a disservice by advertisers who have knowingly over-promised in a banner.

In a world where trust in your brand has never been more important, it is extraordinary to find banner design that revels in deceit of the user: banners that invite you to scroll through a menu of categories or promise to take you direct to the page on your chosen destination.

The first time I saw such a banner I pointed my cursor straight at the scroll bar and clicked. The fact that the ad was for Amazon - a brand I trusted - made that decision to click easier. It was very frustrating, therefore, to be transported to the Amazon home page.

The initial value of my click to Amazon was therefore zero. But it also resulted in a loss of that trust which the brand had previously worked so hard to generate. Net result: minus plenty.

David Lieberman in USA Today
www.usatoday.com

Analysts and investors flocked to hear John Malone discuss Liberty Media - and the digital future.

Malone is seen as a sage on interactivity. The message this year? Interactive TV is real and coming fast. And cable operators had better move more quickly to put the new generation of digital video set-top decoders into people's homes - providing more channels, clearer pictures and two-way communication. If they don't, then satellite broadcasters and phone companies will have time to siphon customers away from cable. Malone anticipates "a very serious three-way battle in every market".

The payoff will come from what Liberty calls "a world of walled gardens" - the e-commerce opportunities available on interactive TV, also known as t-commerce. Just a handful of companies will be able to sell goods and services across all major communications platforms including interactive TV, PCs, phones and personal digital assistants. Liberty wants to have pole position. It's a gamble. The question isn't so much whether Malone's grand vision is on target, but whether he's jumping on the bandwagon too soon.

Liberty Digital CEO Lee Masters is more optimistic. "In the next 18 months, interactive TV will be in the US," he says. He expects it to be "more powerful and robust" than it is abroad. That's saying something, because recent data from Britain suggest that consumers took to interactive TV shopping like eight-year-olds to Pokémon cards.

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Simon Hochhauser
fields.trailText: Age: 47.
fields.body:
Age: 47.

Who is he? A former venture capitalist and physicist, now chief executive of Video Networks and its newly implemented HomeChoice scheme.

So what's the clever idea? "You will be able to select your television viewing so that you can watch a programme when it's convenient, and not just according to a pre-set schedule - a combination of normal television together with controlled television. And you will be able to use your normal telephone line to run television-on-demand, phone calls, internet and faxes - all at the same time, with instant connection. There will be no call charges, and it will be four times faster than the standard internet."

What's the thinking behind it? "To let people see whatever they want, whenever they want - to give them control. And to provide a revolutionary combination of fast internet and digital on-demand television services."

How does it work? "Essentially, when you select a programme on your television screen, you send a signal all the way down a path - ADSL modem, copper wire, optical fibre - to the centre. We then start pumping the film out in the other direction. All this happens very quickly. The television comes out on one frequency. If you want an internet service on the same modem, then you just link the ADSL modem into the internet. The third service is a telephone, running at another frequency. And because ADSL allows different services to run at different frequencies, they don't disturb each other. You only need to have one telephone line. We supply the ADSL modem, so you don't have to pay for that. All you do is pay £19.99 a month."

Possible shortcomings? "You will need to have a wire installed in your home - you won't be able to use your existing wiring - and obviously you need to have a PC. Today, ADSL is available only in north-west London, but in the next couple of months it will become available throughout the whole of London and BT and other companies plan to roll it out into the whole of Britain."

What's next? "The speed of the internet service is going to be increased by a further four times this summer. We're going to add broadcast television - pay TV and free-to-air television - on to the HomeChoice system, so that you can then choose between television that you control and television that is standard. We're always adding content to the television side: multi-user games will be available later this year and a lot of sports content - live sport as well as the ability to pause. We're adding fixed-price telephony services next year, again using the ADSL modem, so there will be no call charges. By this time next year, you should be able to see all forms of television-on-demand and telephone and internet services, games and audio."

fields.headline: It was 40 years ago today
fields.trailText: It must have been a particularly good lunch that spawned the idea of Stars Sing The Beatles (Saturday, BBC1). Nothing short of a bottle a head could explain the concept; God only knows what more it took to get someone back at Television Centre to say yes to it.
fields.body:
It must have been a particularly good lunch that spawned the idea of Stars Sing The Beatles (Saturday, BBC1). Nothing short of a bottle a head could explain the concept; God only knows what more it took to get someone back at Television Centre to say yes to it.

The pitch was simple: it's 40 years since the band first got together, so to celebrate the fact we'll round up some celebrities and get them to sing their favourite Beatles song. But what seemed like a dead cert over the liqueurs and coffee must have looked a lot less appetising when it came to the sticky business of actually booking the turns.

Any show that promises "stars" singing the Beatles - ie, people who might actually be as famous as the Beatles, if not more so - is making itself a hostage to fortune, but who could have guessed that the take-up would be so spectacularly disappointing?

Topping the bill was Engelbert Humperdinck's cheerful interpretation of Penny Lane, which had a certain surreal charm ("fish and finger pie", anyone?). Anna Ford slunk on to the stage in a Dietrichy white trouser suit, hand in pocket, promising decadent delights.

Sadly, she neither smoked, nor kissed any of the women in the audience. On Let It Be, ex-EastEnder Sid Owen came over all R Kelly, revealed his own personal philosophy ("That's my motto - let it be") and plugged his new single before scarpering into the wings.

Hostess Jane "The Cruise" McDonald told everyone they were fantastic, and that "The Beatles started a worldwide music revolution." Among the other musical revolutionaries were Rebecca Wheatley from Casualty, Stephen Houghton from London's Burning and Heartbeat's Tricia Penrose. No Cradle Of Filth, then.

Far away at the other end of the BBC1 spectrum was Hearts And Bones, a big new drama series that represents the channel's best bet for Sunday night dominance. It certainly made a refreshing change from the usual Sunday night nonsense - not a doctor or policeman in sight (or, God forbid, a harbourmaster), nor was the scenery (Balham) in any sense attractive.

The cast, however, was a different matter, and among the eight principal characters there was someone for everyone to fancy. At the core of Hearts And Bones lies a simple erotic triangle - Emma (Dervla Kirwan) is about to marry Mark (Damian Lewis), the father of her child, but she fancies his brother Richard (Hugo Speer). And around these three orbits a galaxy of old friends and lovers, all of them reaching the end of their 20s and wondering what went wrong.

After the first 15 minutes, in which some rather grating soliloquies established who wanted to do exactly what to whom, the characters were up and running from one compromising situation to another. Emma stifled her brotherly lust, and then accidentally had sex with her boss over the photocopier. Richard, the butcher brother in both senses of the word, focused his energy on his work: never has a meat cleaver been wielded with such sexual fervour on primetime TV. Nervous best mate Michael (Andrew Scarborough) responded to taunts by threatening to get his penis out over dinner.

Comparisons with This Life and Cold Feet are inevitable at first, but Hearts And Bones is original enough to fight its way out of these shadows. What it most resembles is a heterosexual Queer As Folk, and although there were no scenes of underage rimming in last night's episode, the series promises its own shocks and surprises. The acting was spectacular - and special mention should go to the cast's two redheads, Damian Lewis and Rose Keegan, who may haunt Frank Dobson's ginger nightmares in the coming weeks.

Channel 4 continued the trend of hit-and-run film-making with a dramatisation of the recent David Irving case in The Holocaust On Trial (Saturday). John Castle was the unrepentant historian, squirming under the lethal examination of Michael Byrne as Richard Rampton QC. The holes in Irving's argument were unpicked stage by stage, his absurd claims looking particularly vicious against archive footage from the camps.

A cool and deadly lesson in the Holocaust's planning and execution. Watched, one hopes, by millions.

webTitle: Philippine troops close in on rebels holding hostages

fields.headline: Philippine troops close in on rebels holding hostages
fields.trailText: Philippine troops fought intense battles yesterday with Islamic rebels holding 27 mainly child hostages on a southern island, but the rescue attempt came to nothing.
fields.body:
Philippine troops fought intense battles yesterday with Islamic rebels holding 27 mainly child hostages on a southern island, but the rescue attempt came to nothing.

General Jose Calimlim, the deputy head of the armed forces and head of intelligence, said troops control 95% of the rebel camp on Basilan island.

The hostages and rebels are believed to be in a concrete-reinforced tunnel under the camp and troops are advancing cautiously to avoid harming the captives, said Gen Calimlim.

He said the guerrillas, who are fighting for an Islamic state in the south of this mostly Roman Catholic country, abandoned guns and other equipment when they retreated into the tunnel.

The hostages, all Filipinos and held for more than a month, include 22 children and five adults, one of whom is a Catholic priest.

"We suspect the remaining rebels have gone inside a tunnel that is 200 metres long and taken the hostages with them," the general said. "We still have to search the tunnel. We haven't recovered the hostages - there is no contact with them or with the rebels."

Elsewhere, the government's chief hostage negotiator said soldiers had surrounded rebels holding another 21 captives, including 10 foreign tourists, but warned against military intervention.

And, in a further move reflecting the widening religious conflict in the Philippines, the largest Muslim group fighting for an Islamic state in the south suspended peace talks yesterday, blaming the government for violating a ceasefire.

"The Moro Islamic Liberation Front hereby unilaterally declares that the peace talks [are] indefinitely suspended," an MILF statement said.

But the presidential press secretary, Ricardo Puno, appeared to disagree. "The lines are still open," he said.

The military has said that about 300 MILF guerrillas and more than 30 soldiers have died in clashes which started in mid-March after the rebels seized and briefly occupied a town hall in Lanao del Norte province on Mindanao island, 500 miles south of Manila.

The MILF is the largest of two groups fighting for Muslim self-rule in the Philippines' southern region. The more radical Abu Sayyaf is the one holding the two groups of hostages.

In the hostage crisis involving foreign tourists, Muslim regional governor Nur Misuari, a former rebel, threatened to end negotiations unless the guerrillas started releasing the captives.

"These people are already literally encircled from all sides," Mr Misuari said. "Either we expedite the release of these people or we terminate the negotiations.

The hostages were taken from Malaysia last Sunday and are being kept on the mountainous Jolo island, which is a stronghold of Abu Sayyaf.

Mr Misuari said his emissaries had reported that most of the hostages had diarrhoea and that one was "sick with a bleeding ulcer".

The hostages include 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French, nationals, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipino woman.
Reuters

webTitle: South Asia is new hub for terrorists, US claims

fields.headline: South Asia is new hub for terrorists, US claims
fields.standfirst: Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: Pakistan and Afghanistan have been singled out in a US government survey released today which for the first time pinpoints south Asia as a major centre of international terrorism.
fields.body:
Pakistan and Afghanistan have been singled out in a US government survey released today which for the first time pinpoints south Asia as a major centre of international terrorism.

The annual state department report says that Pakistan, traditionally a US ally, helps and provides safe haven for known terrorists, many of whom are fighting to take control of Kashmir from India. "They need to do better," said an official for the department.

Afghanistan is accused of being a major threat, not least because it harbours Osama bin Laden, who is wanted for the bombings two years ago of two American embassies in Africa.

But neither Pakistan nor Afghanistan features on the list of countries the US claims are sponsors of terrorism: Libya, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Cuba, Sudan and North Korea.

The list has remained unchanged for seven years, even though names can be added or removed at any time. Being named means coping with sanctions that cut off aid, loans and credit.

Pakistan does not appear on the list because "it is a friendly nation that is trying to tackle the problem", said Michael Sheehan, the state department coordinator for counter-terrorism. Afghanistan is not named because the US does not recognise its government, the fundamentalist Taliban movement.

The US president, Bill Clinton, presaged the criticism of Pakistan during a visit to the country in March, when he pressed its leader, General Per vez Musharraf, to ease tensions with India and restrain Islamic militants.

Pakistan must "create conditions that will allow dialogue to succeed" in resolving the Kashmir dispute, which nearly sparked a war with India last summer, he said.

But Zamir Akram, deputy chief of mission at the Pakistani embassy in Washington, said: "If they have evidence they should share it with us. We are more of a target and victim of terrorism than the United States has ever been.

"We need to jointly fight against terrorism. Charges like this simply get our backs up."

In New York, a spokesman for the Taliban said that the state department had unearthed no significant evidence against Afghanistan.

The report says that Americans are more at risk from groups pursuing religious and ideological ends, often funded by drug trafficking and crime, than by state-sponsored violence.

It adds that security in the Middle East has improved, even though the region remains a source of concern, and that although terrorist attacks worldwide had increased, casualties had fallen. Only five Americans were killed in such incidents last year.

Terrorists are moving away from the use of car and truck bombs, as well as other explosives, and towards biological, nuclear, chemical and other weapons of mass destruction, as well as cyber-terrorism, the report says.

The state department has asked for $40m (£26m) in the budget to combat terrorism this year.

Mr Sheehan said: "The positive experiences of Spain, Turkey and Algeria this year all suggest that tough counter-terrorism measures plus political dialogue with non-terrorist opposition forces seems to be the model."
fields.bodyText: Pakistan and Afghanistan have been singled out in a US government survey released today which for the first time pinpoints south Asia as a major centre of international terrorism. The annual state department report says that Pakistan, traditionally a US ally, helps and provides safe haven for known terrorists, many of whom are fighting to take control of Kashmir from India. "They need to do better," said an official for the department. Afghanistan is accused of being a major threat, not least because it harbours Osama bin Laden, who is wanted for the bombings two years ago of two American embassies in Africa. But neither Pakistan nor Afghanistan features on the list of countries the US claims are sponsors of terrorism: Libya, Syria, Iran, Iraq, Cuba, Sudan and North Korea. The list has remained unchanged for seven years, even though names can be added or removed at any time. Being named means coping with sanctions that cut off aid, loans and credit. Pakistan does not appear on the list because "it is a friendly nation that is trying to tackle the problem", said Michael Sheehan, the state department coordinator for counter-terrorism. Afghanistan is not named because the US does not recognise its government, the fundamentalist Taliban movement. The US president, Bill Clinton, presaged the criticism of Pakistan during a visit to the country in March, when he pressed its leader, General Per vez Musharraf, to ease tensions with India and restrain Islamic militants. Pakistan must "create conditions that will allow dialogue to succeed" in resolving the Kashmir dispute, which nearly sparked a war with India last summer, he said. But Zamir Akram, deputy chief of mission at the Pakistani embassy in Washington, said: "If they have evidence they should share it with us. We are more of a target and victim of terrorism than the United States has ever been. "We need to jointly fight against terrorism. Charges like this simply get our backs up." In New York, a spokesman for the Taliban said that the state department had unearthed no significant evidence against Afghanistan. The report says that Americans are more at risk from groups pursuing religious and ideological ends, often funded by drug trafficking and crime, than by state-sponsored violence. It adds that security in the Middle East has improved, even though the region remains a source of concern, and that although terrorist attacks worldwide had increased, casualties had fallen. Only five Americans were killed in such incidents last year. Terrorists are moving away from the use of car and truck bombs, as well as other explosives, and towards biological, nuclear, chemical and other weapons of mass destruction, as well as cyber-terrorism, the report says. The state department has asked for $40m (£26m) in the budget to combat terrorism this year. Mr Sheehan said: "The positive experiences of Spain, Turkey and Algeria this year all suggest that tough counter-terrorism measures plus political dialogue with non-terrorist opposition forces seems to be the model."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 20 arrested for immigrant scam
fields.body:
20 arrested for immigrant scam

Twenty people have been arrested after police dismantled an illegal work ring that brought deaf foreigners to France and forced them to sell trinkets for very little pay, judicial sources said.

The ring's alleged leaders, who were also deaf, were said to have lured hundreds from eastern Europe with the promise of papers.

The workers were forced to sell key rings and lighters in restaurants, going from table to table with notes explaining their disability. Their work earned around £180,000 a month for the gang.
AP, Paris

Actors to strike in pay dispute

Actors in the United States are due to go on strike today and refuse to participate in any commercials until a pay dispute is settled.

Unions representing 135,000 actors have called the nationwide strike and marches and rallies are planned in big cities. Advertisers plan to break the strike by using non-union actors wanting to get into the business, or filming abroad.
Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

Poles gather for canonisation

The Pope welcomed fellow Poles to St Peter's Square yesterday for the canonisation of the church's first saint of the millennium - a Krakow nun who died of tuberculosis in 1938, aged 33.

The Vatican credits Sister Mary Faustina, born Helena Kowalska, with two miracles - healing a priest with heart trouble and a woman with a condition which causes fluid to accumulate in the body.
AP, Vatican City

Scuffles at antique sale

Christie's auctioned Chinese antiques behind a metal curtain at a hotel yesterday after eight protesters demanding the return of looted 18th century treasures scuffled with guards.

Sotheby's also drew protests for plans to auction pieces reportedly looted by British and French troops in 1860.
AP, Hong Kong

fields.headline: Uncle Ho's army
fields.standfirst: Celebrations mark the 25th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam war
fields.trailText: Vietnam celebrated its stunning victory over one of the world's superpowers 25 years ago with a remarkably unwarlike parade yesterday and hopes it can battle its way out of poverty in the new millennium.
fields.byline: Denis Gray in Ho Chi Minh City
fields.body:
Vietnam celebrated its stunning victory over one of the world's superpowers 25 years ago with a remarkably unwarlike parade yesterday and hopes it can battle its way out of poverty in the new millennium.

Ageing veterans of that victory against the US and its South Vietnamese allies saluted as thousands of soldiers, students, women in flowing traditional ao dais and barefooted mountain tribespeople filed past the grounds of the Reunification Palace.

The day belonged to the independence hero, Ho Chi Minh, who died 30 years ago and whose three-storey portrait hung from the palace facade. But the mood was more akin to a spring-time festival than a remembrance of war. The heaviest weapons wielded were assault rifles and most units marched unarmed. Patriotic songs alternated with lilting, dance-like numbers during the 90-minute parade.

More than 12,000 prisoners, including convicted murderers, were also released in the country's biggest amnesty.

 AP

fields.headline: Todd Webb
fields.standfirst: Photographer with a mission to record the family of man
fields.trailText: T odd Webb, who has died aged 94, took up photography as a second career 60 years ago, and remained committed to it for more than half a century. His first fame came with his images of cities, principally New York and Paris. His work gradually expanded to encapsulate all forms of people and architecture, perhaps most of all people in their own environments.
fields.body:
T odd Webb, who has died aged 94, took up photography as a second career 60 years ago, and remained committed to it for more than half a century. His first fame came with his images of cities, principally New York and Paris. His work gradually expanded to encapsulate all forms of people and architecture, perhaps most of all people in their own environments.

While he was a master of the absent presence - writer Mike Rowell commented that "even in the emptiest of scenes, we have the feeling that someone has just left and will step back into view any second" - Webb also incorporated subjects in their surroundings, as though they could belong nowhere else. His portrait of his great friend, the painter Georgia O'Keefe, photographed from behind and looking out of the studio across the New Mexico desert, is as firmly planted in the frame as a snail in its shell.

Webb was born in Detroit, Michigan, and educated at the University of Toronto. "Until I discovered photography in 1939, I had quite a normal life," he later wrote. "The banking business and the export business, with a few years prospecting for gold in southwestern United States and Central America constituted my conception of the ideal life. Came 1939, and photography - and I really started to live."

What Webb learned, while studying in Detroit under Ansel Adams and Art Siegel, was the mastery of a large format view camera (with a frame of either 5x7in or 8x10in) and the pursuit of a passion around the streets where he lived. Later on, he acknowledged a formative generation as his "teachers" - Stieglitz, Walker Evans, Helen Levitt, Paul Strand and Harry Callaghan, among others.

When America entered the second world war, Webb joined the navy, and was fortunate in being given photographic missions. Two years were spent with the US 7th Fleet in the south Pacific, photographing particularly in New Guinea and the Philippines.

This experience marked out a fascination with the way people live that was to later include studies of the Pennsylvanian Amish, indigenous Mexicans, the inhabitants of Spanish and black Harlem, sub-Saharan Africa, and 19th-century Texas homes and public buildings - the subjects of two later books and exhibitions which signalled his involvement with south-west America, an area to which he repeatedly returned, eventually to live.

In 1946 he joined Roy Stryker, whose famous Farm Security Administration (FSA) had included such luminaries of documentary photography as Dorothea Lange, Jack Delano, Marion Post - and, of course, Walker Evans. Their task was to at tempt to improve social conditions in the dustbowl states by showing the unacknowledged poverty at the heart of what was already the wealthiest nation on earth. Webb was promptly sent to New York to document the building of the Rockefeller Centre, and he later worked on projects following pipelines to Montreal and ice jams on the Ohio river, interspersed with his Louisiana story, and others on the streets of New York.

It was a natural progression from Stryker to work for the United Nations, the UN Children's Fund (Unicef), the World Health Organisation and the World Bank. Webb's Esso building was included in Steichen's Family Of Man book, with images from around the world intended to demonstrate how people are "everywhere different and everywhere the same." At the same time, he was completing assignments for a raft of US magazines, ranging from Fortune to Life, and Ladies Home Journal to Cosmopolitan.

In 1949, Webb met his New York-born wife Lucille in Paris. Living in the French capital for four years formed the basis of two of his most successful touring exhibitions, Paris Architecture (1950) and Photographs Of Paris (1951). Back in America by the mid-1950s, and winner of a Guggenheim fellowship, he used the diaries of 19th-century prospectors as a guide to a series of projects on the great American gold rush - in five months, travelling from New York to San Francisco, he took more than 7,500 pictures.

The alternation between commercial and social photography, combined with his talent for capturing an atmosphere, persisted throughout. Webb's work appeared regularly in solo and group shows, and he was a formative element in the New Subjectivity movement that emerged in the 1950s.

Of his own method, he wrote: "Creative photography does not have anything to do with location, projects or causes as such, yet it can involve any one of them. It is a need to express something within the photographer. A creative photograph is one seen through the photographer. The reason for making the photograph is often unexplainable."

Webb's early friend and lifelong mentor, Beaumont Newhall, put it differently. "He has chosen to record that which is not spectacular; his approach is the opposite of the news photo- grapher, who seeks the novel and the unusual."

Webb was compared to many eminent predecessors and contemporaries, among them Eugene Atget, Berenice Abbott and Edward Weston. His photographs are on permanent display in 25 museums, including the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, the Musem of Modern Art, New York, and Washington's National Gallery of Art. His latter books include Georgia O'Keeffe: The Artist And Her Landscape (1984), and a reprise of Photographs Of New York and Paris 1946-60 (1985).

Todd Webb is survived by his wife.

Charles Clayton 'Todd' Webb, photographer, born September 15 1905; died April 15 2000
