fields.headline: Hardline crackdown grips Iran
fields.trailText: Conservative attempts to undo the gains of Iran's reformers intensified at the weekend as two prominent feminists were imprisoned and two newspaper editors and a national student leader were summoned before a Revolutionary Court.
fields.body:
Conservative attempts to undo the gains of Iran's reformers intensified at the weekend as two prominent feminists were imprisoned and two newspaper editors and a national student leader were summoned before a Revolutionary Court.

Members of the predominately conservative parliament are also considering impeaching the minister of culture and Islamic guidance, Ataollah Mohajerani.

He is blamed for allowing progressive newspapers to exceed what is defined as free expression in Iran. Last week conservatives in the judiciary closed 16 journals and newspapers.

Reformist leaders have told the public to remain calm to deprive hardliners in the security forces of any pretext for violent action. University students have so far heeded the call, staging peaceful protests nationwide.

According to a transcript of a meeting of the elite Revolutionary Guard which was obtained by the Guardian, the Guards drew up a strategy for reversing the political gains of the reformers, including provoking citizens to stage a violent crackdown. The last stage of the plan was to carry out a coup d'etat against President Khatami.

A member of the Guardian Council, a powerful body controlled by conservatives, cast doubts on plans for a coup. "There are problems but it is not a crisis. But if there is mischief, we will have to use force," said Mohammad Reza Zavarei.

He said the newspapers that were closed down had been exceeding the bounds permitted under Iranian law. "The judicial system has acted based on the laws. The writings in these dailies, rather than enlightening the people, caused tension in society," he said.

Reformers have accused the conservatives of carrying out the crackdown to invalidate the new parliament, due to convene on May 27. Reformers became the biggest bloc in parliamentary polls on February 18. They say the Guardian Council, charged with verifying the results, has annulled nine candidates in seven constituencies. The second round of voting is scheduled for Friday.

Yesterday the Revolutionary Court interrogated Hamid Reza Jalaiepour, editor of the newspaper Asr-e Azadagan, which was closed last week. Ali Afshari, a leader in the Daftar Tahkim Vahdat, the leading student movement, also appeared before the court, along with Ezzatollah Sahabi, an editor of the banned journal Iran-e Farda.

On Saturday, the Revolutionary Court imprisoned feminists Mehrangiz Kar, a lawyer, and Shala Lahiji, a publisher, after they attended a conference in Berlin at which an Iranian expatriate man stripped nude and a woman danced in a revealing blouse and no headscarf. State-owned television used a film of the episode to accuse conference participants of engaging in decadent activity.

The Foreign Office said yesterday that Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has postponed a trip to Iran until July, but denied that this was linked to the press crackdown or to concern about an ongoing trial of Iranian Jews accused of spying.

The trip, scheduled for May 8-9, will take place on July 4-5. A Foreign Office spokesman said the second round of Iran's parliamentary elections was set for May 5 and the final result would not be ratified until May 8, "and it's obviously not usual for a foreign secretary to visit a foreign country during or within a few days of parliamentary elections".

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Professor Brian Whalley writes: I was talking with Norwegian friends recently about the close links between their country, their language and the Lake District, and mentioned the part that the historical geographer and writer Bill Rollinson (Obituary, March 29) had played in showing these relationships to a wide audience with his books and lectures.
fields.body:
Professor Brian Whalley writes: I was talking with Norwegian friends recently about the close links between their country, their language and the Lake District, and mentioned the part that the historical geographer and writer Bill Rollinson (Obituary, March 29) had played in showing these relationships to a wide audience with his books and lectures.

Bill passed his enthusiasms for these links to me long ago; and to my students during many years of their visits from Queen's University, Belfast, to Cumberland. His passion for the people and places of the Lake District, and their history, was conveyed in his extra-mural activities.

I am sure many of my students will remember being shown Furness Abbey and his lively evening talks. He will be very much missed by all who have an interest in the Lake District.

fields.headline: Herbert Wechsler
fields.standfirst: Formidable US lawyer whose historic appeal to the supreme court strengthened press freedom in America
fields.trailText: The American lawyer who helped formulate one of his country's most important journalistic safeguards has died at the age of 90. Herbert Wechsler was already a formidable legal academic when the New York Times retained him to argue its appeal in the US supreme court against libel damages of $500,000 imposed by the Alabama courts.
fields.body:
The American lawyer who helped formulate one of his country's most important journalistic safeguards has died at the age of 90. Herbert Wechsler was already a formidable legal academic when the New York Times retained him to argue its appeal in the US supreme court against libel damages of $500,000 imposed by the Alabama courts.

On March 29 1960 the paper had carried a full-page advertisement seeking support for civil rights demonstrators in the state capital, Montgomery. The text listed actions taken by the local police to suppress peaceful protest, but got some of the details wrong. Though not named in the advertisement, the Montgomery police commissioner, Colonel LB Sullivan, claimed he had been libelled by inference. An all-white jury upheld his case and the verdict was confirmed by the higher courts in Alabama.

Finally, on January 6 1964, the issue came before the ultimate constitutional arbiters, the federal supreme court in Washington. The presumption was that Wechsler would base his appeal on the free speech guarantees of the US constitution's first amendment, relying on precedents going back 200 years. He certainly harked back to the earliest days of the republic, but startled everyone by citing not the Bill of Rights but the long-dead Sedition Act of 1798.

This had originally been passed to counter the violent criticisms levelled by Thomas Jefferson's supporters at President John Adams. Its purpose was to criminalise "any false, scandalous and malicious writings against the government of the United States" and resulted in 10 newspaper editors and a congressman being fined and imprisoned.

The measure came under ferocious assault from James Madison and other US constitutional experts. Their objections stirred up a general revulsion, which brought the disintegration of Adams's Federalist party. Jefferson won the White House and let the act expire under its own provisions in 1801. But the scars lingered. As Justice William Brennan noted in the court's unanimous 1964 finding in favour of the New York Times, "though the Sedition Act was never tested in this court, the attack upon its validity carried the day in the court of history".

The logic of this new ruling, as Wechsler had shrewdly anticipated, automatically legitimised any attacks on public officials which were not "false, scandalous, or malicious". In Justice Brennan's words, "the possibility that a good faith critic of government will be penalised for his criticism . . . strikes at the very centre of the constitutionally protected area of free expression".

For the past 36 years, therefore, in a significant extension of America's lively democratic debate, officials claiming libel are obliged to establish malicious intent.

Wechsler's court strategy stemmed from his encyclopaedic knowledge of US jurisprudence, accumulated during a long professorial stint at Columbia law school in New York. In tandem with his academic post, he had served for 21 years as director of the American Law Institute and was co-author of one of the nation's principal legal reference books. His interest at university had been in French, which he had hoped to teach at New York City College. However, his father persuaded the college that Herbert should follow him into the law, and after postgraduate service as a clerk at the supreme court, Wechsler joined Columbia law school in 1933. He stayed for 45 years.

Ironically, in view of his later concerns, his war service was spent administering the highly controversial (and, as it was later ruled, unconstitutional) internment of 110,000 Japanese-American citizens. In 1945, he became a technical adviser to the US team at the Nuremberg trials, and was such a trusted confidant of Francis Biddle, the senior American judge on the tribunal, that he eventually wrote a section of the court's final judgment.

The work of which Wechsler himself was proudest was his law institute's 1962 model penal code, which he spent 10 years compiling. This sprang from the extraordinary legal tangle which history has left across the 50 states of the union. Some have statutes dating from colonial days, others reflect conditions prevailing when they were barely-inhabited territories. Wechsler's code was designed to help state legislatures achieve greater uniformity. It has helped, though there is a long way to go.

Wechsler's most controversial legal excursion came in the Harvard Law Review in 1979, where he put the case for what he called "neutralprinciples". Examining the supreme court's reasoning in Brown v Board of Education (the famous 1954 desegregation ruling), he argued that the court had merely set out to achieve a specific result rather than to concern itself with broad principles.

There was an immediate storm of protest in which opponents pointed out that Wechsler's criteria would make segregation and affirmative action equally unconstitutional, since both involved racial discrimination. The argument was even joined by Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens. "There is no moral or constitutional equivalence", he declared, "between a policy that is designed to perpetuate a caste system and one that seeks to eradicate racial subordination".

Wechsler is survived by his wife, Doris.

As Justice William Brennan noted in the court's unanimous 1964 finding in favour of the New York Times, "though the Sedition Act was never tested in this court, the attack upon its validity carried the day in the court of history". The logic of this new ruling, as Wechsler had shrewdly anticipated, automatically legitimised any attacks on public officials which were not "false, scandalous, or malicious". In Justice Brennan's words, "the possibility that a good faith critic of government will be penalised for his criticism . . . strikes at the very centre of the constitutionally protected area of free expression". For the past 36 years, therefore, in a significant extension of America's lively democratic debate, officials claiming libel are obliged to establish malicious intent. Wechsler's court strategy stemmed from his encyclopaedic knowledge of US jurisprudence, accumulated during a long professorial stint at Columbia law school in New York. In tandem with his academic post, he had served for 21 years as director of the American Law Institute and was co-author of one of the nation's principal legal reference books. His interest at university had been in French, which he had hoped to teach at New York City College. However, his father persuaded the college that Herbert should follow him into the law, and after postgraduate service as a clerk at the supreme court, Wechsler joined Columbia law school in 1933. He stayed for 45 years. Ironically, in view of his later concerns, his war service was spent administering the highly controversial (and, as it was later ruled, unconstitutional) internment of 110,000 Japanese-American citizens. In 1945, he became a technical adviser to the US team at the Nuremberg trials, and was such a trusted confidant of Francis Biddle, the senior American judge on the tribunal, that he eventually wrote a section of the court's final judgment. The work of which Wechsler himself was proudest was his law institute's 1962 model penal code, which he spent 10 years compiling. This sprang from the extraordinary legal tangle which history has left across the 50 states of the union. Some have statutes dating from colonial days, others reflect conditions prevailing when they were barely-inhabited territories. Wechsler's code was designed to help state legislatures achieve greater uniformity. It has helped, though there is a long way to go. Wechsler's most controversial legal excursion came in the Harvard Law Review in 1979, where he put the case for what he called "neutralprinciples". Examining the supreme court's reasoning in Brown v Board of Education (the famous 1954 desegregation ruling), he argued that the court had merely set out to achieve a specific result rather than to concern itself with broad principles. There was an immediate storm of protest in which opponents pointed out that Wechsler's criteria would make segregation and affirmative action equally unconstitutional, since both involved racial discrimination. The argument was even joined by Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens. "There is no moral or constitutional equivalence", he declared, "between a policy that is designed to perpetuate a caste system and one that seeks to eradicate racial subordination". Wechsler is survived by his wife, Doris. Herbert Wechsler, lawyer and teacher, born December 4 1909; died April 26 2000

webTitle: How one village beat the drought

fields.headline: How one village beat the drought
fields.standfirst: Local planning makes the best of what water there is
fields.trailText: While more than 50m villagers dig and beg for water to survive India's worst drought in a century, in Rajsamadhiala they are playing cricket.
fields.body:
While more than 50m villagers dig and beg for water to survive India's worst drought in a century, in Rajsamadhiala they are playing cricket.

In one of India's most drought-ridden states, this dusty village, 10 miles outside Rajkot where the revered Mahatma Gandhi went to school, has ample drinking water for its 1,700 villagers and enough left over to water green fields of vegetables and animal fodder.

Politicians in New Delhi are facing mounting criticism for their failure to prepare for the long-predicted water crisis which has now struck 11 states across India. Food and water has been sent out to Gujarat and Rajasthan, the two worst-hit states, and an emergency relief fund has been set up.

Haradevsinh Jadeja, 49, Rajsamadhiala's opening batsman and village leader, is one of a growing number of critics who believe the solution to the country's water problems lies not in the big dams championed by the government but in cheap, small-scale irrigation schemes.

For the past 22 years and at a cost of 200,000 rupees (almost £3,000), he has built a series of small dams, water tanks and irrigation channels across the village. Now the groundwater in the wells is just six metres below the surface; in most Gujarati villages wells as deep as 60 metres have run dry and families wait by the roadside for government tankers, which stop for just 20 minutes at a time.

"Although we are suffering a very severe drought we never have to apply to the government to bring a tanker for our drinking water," said Mr Jadeja. "Under our arrangement we make our own water. We are all very proud." Mr Jadeja, whose efforts are held up as a model of social change, has taken his work a step further. "If people want this to work they need discipline. I am a combination of Hitler and Gandhi-ji. Too much liberalisation has become injurious to our society. Our democracy has become our hypocrisy," he said.

Mr Jadeja is one of the region's wealthier farmers, earning £14,000 in a good year.

India's penal code does not apply in the village, he said. Instead he runs his own legal system and the local police appear to turn a blind eye. Anyone caught dropping litter is fined 51 rupees (73 pence). Since Gujarat is a "dry" state in more ways than one, drinking alcohol brings a £2.20 fine and those found gambling are charged £3.70.

Since November, farmers have been warning that repeatedly poor monsoon rains would bring a crisis this spring. But only a handful of villages like Rajsamadhiala are prepared. Few have gathered and kept rainwater or built up their groundwater levels.

Politicians argue that the solution lies with major dam projects, such as the scheme planned for the Narmada River which straddles the states of Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra. "Narmada is the panacea for 8,000-odd water-starved villages of Gujarat," the state's chief minister, Keshubhai Patel, told a local newspaper. "Pipeline Narmada waters alone can help solve the problem forever."

However, court action has been taken to stop work on the £4.4bn project, which would displace more than 500,000 local people.

Some of those living in water-starved villages in Gujarat support the politicians and the Narmada project. They argue that New Delhi should be responsible for providing them with water and feeding their animals.

"So many people will benefit that if some have to move for the Narmada dam to be built, well they should just move," said Ashok Kanani, a doctor living in Amran village, near Jamnagar.

But others accuse the government of pandering to big business with massive dam construction projects. Oxfam has blamed much of the water shortage on commercial over-exploitation of supplies, which threatens to turn swathes of western India into desert as crops fail. "People have got used to the idea that the government will supply them with water. It is not the amount of rainfall, it is really how you manage it," said Sunita Narain, of the Centre for Science and the Environment, in New Delhi.

Although it rains in India on average for just 100 hours a year, Ms Narain insists that is enough to go around. "If you do all the small water harvesting, maybe you won't need such a large Narmada dam. It is a change in the way you do things, a change in the governance of the country."

fields.headline: Donald Frith
fields.standfirst: He gently reformed education in turbulent times
fields.trailText: The reputation of Donald Frith, who has died aged 81, was already established when, in 1975, he became president of the then Headmasters' Association. It was a turbulent time, and it took all of Donald's gentle strength to hold together the HMA's traditional and progressive, private and public sector strands.
fields.body:
The reputation of Donald Frith, who has died aged 81, was already established when, in 1975, he became president of the then Headmasters' Association. It was a turbulent time, and it took all of Donald's gentle strength to hold together the HMA's traditional and progressive, private and public sector strands.

Legislation was pushing the association towards trade union status, if it was to continue to represent its members in public negotiation; new laws on equal opportunities were pointing away from the male preserve; the optimism of comprehensive initiatives was dwindling, and the education black papers were dominating the national press. Donald had an unfailing ability to listen, to show real concern, and enable the HMA to keep its balance and make tensions productive. He was trusted.

Thus negotiations between the HMA and the Association of Headmistresses, both century-old organisations, led them to amalgamate in 1978 as the Secondary Heads Association, and in 1979 Donald became its general secretary - which meant he was also secretary of the Headmasters' Conference.

It was Donald who kept the SHA on course whilst it probed the new Conservative government, and the 1980 legislation which threatened to tear public and private sectors apart. His ability to wed traditional values with new insights made him the ideal negotiator. That year, too, initiatives for links with the Headteachers Association of Scotland, and to explore the prospects of membership for deputy heads, laid the foundations for the SHA as the significant body it is today.

Between 1979 and 1986 Frith chaired one of the most productive initiatives of the Schools Council, and the one which survived when Mrs Thatcher ignored the advice of her appointed investigator, Nancy Trenaman, and abolished that body (along with any such remaining representative educational bodies). This was what became the Schools Curriculum Industry Project. Its work in exploring the skills curriculum and reconciling individual learning needs and workplace needs typified its chairman: exploring and reconciling.

D onald Frith was educated at Whitgift school and won a scholarship to read classics at Christ's College, Cambridge. He and his wife Mary, whom he married in 1941, had plans for missionary work in Africa; instead, he served as a captain in the Royal Army Service Corps from 1940 to 1946, in the Mediteranean and at the War Office, devising educational programmes for the troops.

After the war, he taught at University College School, London, from 1946 to 1952, running the school orchestra, rowing, and sharing his classical scholarship. He was appointed headmaster of Richmond school at the age of 35, and six years later became head of Archbishop Holgate's school, York. This was an ancient, indeed antiquated, boys' grammar school, which, in 1963, Frith led on to a greenfield site next to the new York University. He ensured that the school's 400 years of history were not lost; chapel, rowing and swimming are all part of the comprehensive school today.

After leaving the SHA in 1983, Donald became assis tant director of the Centre for the Study of Comprehensive Schools, then based in York, and did much over the next five years to secure industrial sponsorship and support for the serious inquiry it continues today. In that decade, he edited the key text of the time for secondary school headship, School Management In Practice. He chaired the North Yorkshire Forum for Voluntary Organisations from 1983 to 1991, and in 1990 became director of the North Yorkshire Training and Enterprise Council.

In York, Donald served on the diocesan education committee; for six years, he chaired the York community council; he was founder-chair of York Youth Action; a magistrate and prison visitor, he later chaired the East Yorkshire probation committee. He was a member of North Yorkshire education committee from 1973 to 1977, and, for his youth and community service, he was made an OBE in 1980.

Donald Frith represented the best of a generation of British educators brought up between two world wars, determined that all young people should have a worthwhile future. For him, school education was a part of life. There was no discernible division, as later advocated, between the job and his own time, between faith and works. All this was made possible by the strength of his marriage to Mary, and their close family.

Mary died in 1989. Frith is survived by a daughter and four sons.

Donald Alfred Frith, educator, born May 13 1918; March 22 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Emirates plans A3XX purchase
fields.body:
Emirates plans A3XX purchase

Dubai's state-owned Emirates airline yesterday became the first launch customer for Airbus Industrie's new super jumbo, the A3XX, when it announced plans to buy five of the aircraft with an option on five more.

Airbus is understood to want half a dozen launch customers signed up before it gives the go-ahead for the new aircraft.

KPN delay

Telecommunications group KPN has suspended the initial public offering of its mobile arm KPN Mobiel, which was to have taken place tomorrow, because of talks with a possible strategic partner. KPN is one of the companies which has been linked with Britain's Orange.

Yes to euro

Denmark's ruling Social Democrats have decided that their country should join the EU's single currency, paving the way for a national referendum on membership in September.

fields.headline: WPP ditches Rubicam deal
fields.standfirst: Talks collapse after last-minute demand
fields.trailText: WPP, the marketing services group, will issue a statement to the New York stock exchange today that $5bn (£3bn) negotiations to acquire the American advertising business, Young & Rubicam, have been abandoned.
fields.body:
WPP, the marketing services group, will issue a statement to the New York stock exchange today that $5bn (£3bn) negotiations to acquire the American advertising business, Young & Rubicam, have been abandoned.

Sir Martin Sorrell, WPP chief executive walked away from the negotiations late on Friday over last minute demands being made by the Y&R board. The deal would have made WPP, which already owns the Ogilvy & Mather and J Walter Thompson networks, the world's largest marketing services company.

A separate statement will be made in London when the stock market opens for business tomorrow.

Y&R is expected to push ahead with an attempt to broker a deal with the French group, Publicis.

WPP presented the final terms for its hoped for takeover to New York-based Y&R on Thursday. Talks began in November and broke down in March before resuming again in recent weeks.

The earlier stumbling block had been the emergence of a series of golden parachutes that had been put in place for around 30 senior Y&R staff which would potentially cost WPP $60m.

In the current round of talks, Y&R dropped the demands and the all-share deal would have seen the American company's investors owning a third of the enlarged group.

On Friday however Y&R presented a new clause in the agreement. The clause demanded that Y&R be given autonomy for another year.

If WPP attempted to impose on the group during the 12 months, a series of punitive clauses would be triggered including Y&R executives being able once again pick up multi-million dollar pay-offs.

The clauses would also have been triggered had WPP forced Y&R staff either to travel more often or work longer hours than normal.

webTitle: IPC flotation abandoned in favour of sale

fields.headline: IPC flotation abandoned in favour of sale
fields.trailText: Plans for a stock market flotation of IPC, the magazine house behind titles such as Woman's Own, Marie Claire and Loaded, appear to have been abandoned in favour of a trade sale of the business.
fields.body:
Plans for a stock market flotation of IPC, the magazine house behind titles such as Woman's Own, Marie Claire and Loaded, appear to have been abandoned in favour of a trade sale of the business.

Cinven, the venture capital fund which bought the business two and a half years ago has approached a number of potential buyers including Telewest, the cable firm which has just completed its merger with pay-television group Flextech. IPC's putative sale figure is said to be about £1.5bn.

The sale is viewed as an opportunistic attempt by Cinven to recoup its investment in IPC at a time when traditional media businesses with strong brands and content are in demand from the emergent new media sector.

IPC has struggled since Cinven bought the business for £860m from Reed Elsevier, and last year operating profits dipped 3.1% to £65.6m - the company's second successive decline year on year.

In October, the group promoted Sly Bailey to replace Mike Mattews as chief executive in the hope of getting the business back on track.

Cinven is understood to have consulted investment banks Goldman Sachs and Warburg Dillon Read on the disposal.

IPC chairman David Arculus yesterday refused to comment but is known to have links with Telewest's chief executive, Adam Singer.

Telewest's interest indicates the direction Mr Singer intends to take the cable company. The former Flextech chief executive took the top job in the merger with Telewest and clearly wants to develop the business's content side.

Telewest sees the potential of leveraging the IPC content through its internet and interactive TV services. Magazines could also be used as the basis for spin-off programmes or even pay-TV channels.

Through the merger with Flextech, Telewest already has interests in a series of channels including the BBC stations UK Gold, UK Drama and UK Play.

Other potential bidders for IPC include privately owned German media group Bertelsmann and Hachette, the French publisher.

At IPC's most recent results presentation in December Mr Arculus had made the bullish forecast that it would float next year - 12 months earlier than planned. It is spending £25m on the development of an online business under the umbrella of IPC Electric.

webTitle: The end of Tara road? Let's hope Maeve will make it back

fields.headline: The end of Tara road? Let's hope Maeve will make it back
fields.trailText: To the surprise of the literary world and the mortification of her admirers, the best selling Irish novelist Maeve Binchy has announced that her new novel, due to be published in August, will be her last.
fields.body:
To the surprise of the literary world and the mortification of her admirers, the best selling Irish novelist Maeve Binchy has announced that her new novel, due to be published in August, will be her last. "I've enough money to live off," she is said to have explained. "So why carry on?" She is 60. That anyone with the talent to write books which give as much pleasure as Ms Binchy's - her last novel, Tara Road, has recorded sales which make even Bridget Jones look like a niche taste - should offer that explanation seems somehow shocking; much as it must have done to the contemporaries of the great Italian composer Rossini when he gave up the opera house in his mid-forties for much the same reason.

But her bulging bank balance may not be the whole story. Novelists hit their peaks at different ages. Some, like JD Salinger with The Catcher in the Rye, write debut novels of such perfection that the rest of their writing lives are an anti-climax. Others, like Mary Wesley, take up their pens at pensionable age and still write a string of bestsellers. Still others go into slow decline. Kingsley Amis, for reasons which the serialisation of his letters is making abundantly clear, could not maintain the riotous promise of the novels he wrote in his thirties. Sometimes it is a service, both to yourself and your public, to quit when you are still at the top.

But in any case the decisions in these matters are not always final. A writer's retirement is no more conclusive than Sherlock Holmes's plunge to his death over the Reichenbach Falls. Public demand brought Holmes back into action: public demand may yet do the same for Maeve Binchy. Even Rossini's decision was not as final as he intended. After years of near-inaction he suddenly, in his seventies, produced that wonderfully endearing late flowering the Petite Messe Solenelle. We look foward to an equivalent burst of blossom from Binchy some time in the next decade.

Sometimes it is a service, both to yourself and your public, to quit when you are still at the top. But in any case the decisions in these matters are not always final. A writer's retirement is no more conclusive than Sherlock Holmes's plunge to his death over the Reichenbach Falls. Public demand brought Holmes back into action: public demand may yet do the same for Maeve Binchy. Even Rossini's decision was not as final as he intended. After years of near-inaction he suddenly, in his seventies, produced that wonderfully endearing late flowering the Petite Messe Solenelle. We look foward to an equivalent burst of blossom from Binchy some time in the next decade.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

Standard Life has warned Barclays that it stands to lose hundreds of millions of pounds of business if the bank backs carpetbaggers who are trying to force the insurer to demutualise.

The threat has also been made to City investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. Both banks carry out huge amounts of share, bond and treasury dealings for Standard Life's £80bn investment funds.

New British Airways chief executive Rod Eddington is considering spinning off low cost airline Go so that it can raise its own funds for expansion.

US internet firm LastMinuteTravel.com is gearing up for a UK launch which will put it in direct competition with its near namesake, Lastminute.com.

Sunday Telegraph

Nomura, the Japanese investment bank, is preparing a £1.25bn bid for Associated British Ports, Britain's largest port operator. The group has hired Warburg Dillon Read to prepare a bid for ABP, whose share price has plummeted by almost a third in the past two years.

A further fall in the euro against the dollar of just two cents could push it into free fall and force the European Central Bank to raise interest rates sharply, a leading City economist predicts this weekend.

Douglas McWilliams, chief executive of the Centre for Economics and Business Research and the former chief economist at the CBI says the ECB "has been led with amazing arrogance, seeming to assume that it does not have to make any effort to demonstrate the credibility of the new currency".

Gavin Casey will announce he is stepping down as chief executive of the Stock Exchange this week when it confirms it is merging with the Deutsche Boürse, its German counterpart, to create Europe's largest stock market.

Sunday Times

Bill Clinton has launched a new offensive to overcome Tony Blair's pro-European stand in the heated battle for a missile order to equip the RAF's Eurofighter.

Within the past fortnight Mr Clinton has written to Mr Blair urging him to buy the Raytheon BVRAAMplus long-range missile instead of Europe's Meteor weapon, which the prime minister favours.

The crisis for the euro, which last week hit new lows against the dollar, has put the prospect of British entry into the single currency on indefinite hold, according to government officials.

But the euro's fall and its failure to respond to Thursday's quarter-point interest rate rise by the European Central Bank have heightened expectations of concerted central bank intervention to support it.

Sunday Business

Tina Green, wife of retail entrepreneur Philip Green, has sold her entire investment of 9.5m shares in Marks & Spencer for about £25m.

News of her disposal is expected to put further downward pressure on M&S shares which have slumped to 234p - more than 100p below their year's high.

Figures to be released this week are expected to confirm a slowdown in the housing market. Both the Nationwide and the Halifax mortgage lenders will release their latest house price reports - and the Halifax data are expected to show prices up only marginally, if at all, in April, after falls in February and March.

Littlewood's Leisure, the football pools business put up for sale this month for £250m has received around eight expressions of interest from trade and financial buyers.

IoS

The government is this week expected to cave in to pressure from the world's most powerful IT companies and rewrite a tax plan introduced less than a month ago.

Stephen Timms, the financial secretary to the Treasury, is to announce that companies will be freed from the 12.2% national insurance tax on employee share options.

T-Online, the internet company owned by Deutsche Telekom, is considering bidding for Britain's Freeserve, a deal which would create one of the world's largest internet service providers.

Interims Fibernet. Finals None scheduled. AGMs T Clarke, Davis Service Group, EBC Group, Flomerics, Govett Asian Smaller, Gowrings, Jardine Lloyd Thomson, Lasmo, Mallett, Prudential, Psion, Scottish Media Group. EGMs None scheduled.

Indicators this week Tuesday

Thursday

UK BoE MPC interest rate decision. UK Halifax house price survey (Apr). UK Net new consumer credit (Mar). UK SMMT new car registrations (Apr).

fields.headline: US power firm targets Hyder
fields.trailText: Shares in Hyder are expected to surge tomorrow as the Welsh water and electricity company examines a second bid which threatens to scupper its agreed £400m takeover by Japanese bank Nomura.
fields.body:
Shares in Hyder are expected to surge tomorrow as the Welsh water and electricity company examines a second bid which threatens to scupper its agreed £400m takeover by Japanese bank Nomura.

The fresh approach for Hyder, by the American owned Western Power Distribution which controls the neighbouring electricity company in Devon and Cornwall, is expected to be pitched at up to 300p, 40p more than the existing bid by Nomura.

News of the higher offer is expected to provide welcome to relief to Hyder's shares which have sat around 250p since the Nomura deal was announced. However, that relief may not be matched in Wales, as the Cardiff head office of Hyder is unlikely to remain in the principality if WPD wins.

Last night Hyder, which has been crippled by high debts and regulatory demands, would only say that it was "seeking further clarification".

Nomura insisted it was "relaxed" about the rival bid, raising questions about whether regulators would allow it to proceed and how it was being financed.

The bank, which hired Mike Kinski, the former head of Stagecoach to run the company if it is successful, has promised to keep the Hyder head office in Wales and played down the need for further job cuts.

WPD, however has not ruled out making a hostile offer directly to shareholders.

fields.headline: Sterling's strength is all set for a pounding
fields.trailText: You described Business for Sterling (Directors split over euro, April 20) as an "anti-European group", yet we have consistently made it clear that we are pro-EU and single market but opposed to adopting the euro on business and economic grounds for the foreseeable future. Half of our supporters run companies trading with the eurozone. This unequivocal position is made explicit in all our literature. The idea that being against Emu means being anti-European is as silly as it is offensive.
fields.body:
You described Business for Sterling (Directors split over euro, April 20) as an "anti-European group", yet we have consistently made it clear that we are pro-EU and single market but opposed to adopting the euro on business and economic grounds for the foreseeable future. Half of our supporters run companies trading with the eurozone. This unequivocal position is made explicit in all our literature. The idea that being against Emu means being anti-European is as silly as it is offensive.

Are German and French critics of the euro anti-European too?
Nick Herbert
Chief executive, Business for Sterling

 The crisis at Rover, the uncertainty of Ford of Dagenham, and warnings by the bosses of Nissan, Toyota, Mitsubishi, Honda, that the pound's strength is damaging exports will have knock-on effects throughout the rest of industry like the shock waves of an earthquake. Already the CBI business survey is showing a downturn in the economy, while euroland is forecasting growth of 3%.

All seems to hang on the interpretation of the phrase "foreseeable future" in polls. Most astute business people try to look ahead five years. By then the euro will be the major European currency, replacing all 14 other currencies. That is when the pound will be squeezed between the euro and the dollar. Have we learnt nothing from the fall out and billions lost on Black Thursday? Ruth Lea says "most Institute of Directors members support the anti-euro stance". Most people is usually more than a 5% majority. This quote typifies the fanaticism against the euro by a few employed to run the IoD by its members. What the poll also showed was that most - over 70% of respondents this time, welcomed the end of transaction costs and exchange rate volatility within euroland. A major IoD debate is planned in October by our branch to get a better picture of the feelings of more of the membership.
Stephen Pollock-Hill
Chairman, IoD Hertfordshire branch

 I do not find it at all surprising that Peter Middleton has not yet had sufficient experience to direct Barclays Bank in traditional banking practice. His unwise closing of many rural branches has been widely condemned and his late apology does not excuse this.

However, he and the other excessively rich "clearers" have a first class chance to make amends. Due to our over-strong pound, despite our inflation falling below 2%, our very important manufacturing sector will receive a death blow from BMW if the John Towers Phoenix bid fails due to a penal time requirement.

The clearing banks should together give their immediate unconditional support to the bid. In doing so they might recover their good names from the present ashes of public contempt.

Let us all see how patriotic they will be.
Arthur Elliott Bromley
Wadebridge, Cornwall

fields.headline: Term of trial for teachers
fields.trailText: As a teacher - and a dreaded "lefty" sociology teacher, at that - I do not believe that the exhaustion undoubtedly suffered by those in the profession is so distinctive that it needs more than a four-week summer break to remove it, which is the impression given by Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NAS/UWT (Teachers in holiday strike threat, April 29).
fields.body:
As a teacher - and a dreaded "lefty" sociology teacher, at that - I do not believe that the exhaustion undoubtedly suffered by those in the profession is so distinctive that it needs more than a four-week summer break to remove it, which is the impression given by Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NAS/UWT (Teachers in holiday strike threat, April 29).

The crucial claim that less learning is lost with a shorter summer vacation, if true, is surely because less learning has actually taken place. Most people concede that it is not easy facing a classroom of 30 children, five days a week. For real torture, however, consider teaching them (without air conditioning) in the 80-degree heat that usually sets in around June and July. Another two weeks of that and the pupils would be climbing up the classroom walls with the teachers.
Patrick Dodd
London

 I totally support teachers planning to strike over plans to reduce the six-week summer holiday. Strike on and strike hard! I am a working mother without the support of a nearby extended family and yes, the "long" summer break presents problems of childcare. But these are problems that local authorities should resolve by other means, not by depriving teachers and pupils of a vital rest from the high pressure, grinding machine that our education service has become.

Six weeks is a very short time for children to "forget what they have learned": it implies that teaching is so poor that nothing really goes in properly in the first place. And why must we always look to the American models of education? Why not look to Europe, where summer breaks of eight weeks or more are the norm in several countries?
Ellen Birley
Leicester

 A promising pupil, Blunkett - but his maths leave something to be desired. Putting cash into schools so that that they take more of the youngsters who don't want to be in there does not add up to a better school system - it adds up to chaos in classrooms, teachers on sick-pay, willing pupils disenchanted and educationally short-changed. If Blunkett would only pay attention to parents, instead of the rather unsavoury set of statistic-crunchers and policy-spitters he prefers to hang round with, the error of his ways would soon be made apparent to him.

Three out of ten, Mr Blunkett - see me after class.
Anne Sweeney
Lancaster
anne.sweeney@tinyworld.co.uk

 I am planning to enter teacher training next year. The events of the past week have severely undermined my decision. Does Mr Blunkett realise that introducing five-term years and the addition of performance-related pay on top of a laughable salary isn't quite the right way to attract graduates, or has the man just got a mean sense of humour?

Blunkett complains of the few inadequate teachers that let the profession down. If Blunkett wants to root out the inadequate staff surely performance related pay and the unwanted competition between teachers that it will surely foster is not the way forward? In a recent teaching vacancy it stated "Good sense of humour essential". At the time I didn't realise its seriousness and its allusions to sadomasochism.
Tom Mitchell
Wellington, Somerset
tomozzer@yahoo.com

 You quote Nigel de Gruchy as saying: "We are very strongly opposed to the five-year term." Who wouldn't be?
Mike Turner
Twickenham
mike.turner@brunel.ac.uk

fields.headline: Damned candidates
fields.trailText:
Jeremy Hardy (Hand-picked to halt Ken, April 29) says "none of the mayoral candidates has departed in a serious way from the government's asylum agenda". Perhaps he shares the view that what Susan Kramer's campaign needs is a good scandal. If so, he must charge her with something less horrible, and therefore more credible, than this. If he wants to try again, I suggest he should follow the case described by Gibbon, in which "the graver charges against the Supreme Pontiff were dropped and they persisted only with the charges of murder, heresy, rape, piracy, arson and incest". As one of those who have briefed Susan on asylum issues, I can confirm that she could bear all these charges with greater equanimity than the charge of agreeing with Jack Straw on asylum seekers. Thanks for his attempt to do her a good turn, but be must try harder next time.
Earl Russell
House of Lords

 Jeremy Hardy alludes, in passing, to the possibility of the GLA falling foul of the Criminal Justice Act. Little does he know that should his dream come true, and the London Socialist Alliance win four seats or more, then his nightmare will come true, too: the Blairites will change the rules (as usual), an assembly of four persons, elected or not, will indeed be illegal. Does Jeremy Hardy think Jack Straw would allow socialists to have power? In London? Not a likely scenario, let's face it!
Andrew Heenan
London
andrew@heenan.net

 Jeremy Hardy recommends voting for the LSA to ensure that Ken Livingstone, if elected, will have some assembly members supportive of his radical agenda. This won't work unless the LSA gains a threshold percentage of the vote. A safer way of achieving the same objective would be to vote for the Green list, which is already projected to win two assembly seats and has been endorsed by Livingstone himself.
Brian Fewster
Leicester
bfewster@gn.apc.org

 Jeremy Hardy may have ended his column on a "cheery" note, but regrettably not a factual one, as choosing London "Socialist" Assembly candidates will not be to "vote socialist against New Labour", since all of them (Paul Foot included) actually hold with waged work, profit-making and money - all fundamental features of capitalism.
Max Hess
Folkestone
max@truesocialism.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Khatami's critics
fields.trailText:
Reading your leader on Iran (April 27), I was utterly surprised by its shortsighted view. The crisis in my homeland is nothing new, since this regime in its totality survives only by creating crisis. But crediting Khatami with what essentially and wholeheartedly is the people's struggle for freedom and democracy is beyond any comprehension and is simply outrageous. This is a power struggle, pure and simple. Khatami, who was the first official to order the crackdown on the pro-democracy demonstrations of last July by the students and ordinary people all over Iran, is only interested in getting more share of the power.
Mahmoud Tabrizi
London

Mahmoud Tabrizi
London

The widespread repression of the newspapers is the proof that the regime cannot withstand any criticism even from within itself, and the slightest criticism, which is not aimed to keep the regime in its entirety will shake its foundations.

When the regime's own media talks about the destruction of Khatami's newspaper network, reveals the election fraud and vote rigging in the mullahs' parliamentary elections and questions the validity of Tehran's election, it proves once again that all illusions about political development and the moderation in the clerical regime are false and baseless.

fields.headline: Stopes and her smears
fields.trailText: Yet again that complex (though undoubtedly difficult) personality Marie Stopes and her campaign for birth control are dismissed with a one-dimensional allusion to "eugenics" (Why Marie Stopes' verse made Rudyard Kipling curse, April 29). She aimed to alleviate the suffering and misery of overburdened working-class mothers (she was far from unilaterally imposing a contraceptive agenda, as publications demonstrate).
fields.body:
Yet again that complex (though undoubtedly difficult) personality Marie Stopes and her campaign for birth control are dismissed with a one-dimensional allusion to "eugenics" (Why Marie Stopes' verse made Rudyard Kipling curse, April 29). She aimed to alleviate the suffering and misery of overburdened working-class mothers (she was far from unilaterally imposing a contraceptive agenda, as publications demonstrate).

Additionally, unlike many eugenist contemporaries who believed that healthy, white, middle-class women should breed for Britain and the Empire rather than "selfishly" restricting their families, she argued that all women should have the right to decide when to become pregnant. Furthermore, her correspondence reveals that she often reassured couples frightened by some of the more extreme eugenic fears in common circulation at the time and encouraged them to marry and have children.

While it is no longer possible to regard her with hagiographic awe as "St Marie", in no way should her very real achievements for women's benefit be dismissed.
Lesley Hall
London

 My grandfather assures me that he wore knitted trousers as a young child, and not a skirt.
Harry Stopes
Manchester

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No 1626: Rod Eddington
fields.body:
Age: 50

Appearance: Twinkly ageing cricketer.

He looks mighty pleased with himself. Well, he's just got a new job - starting this morning, in fact - replacing the beleaguered Bob Ayling as British Airways chairman.

Beleaguered? Languishing share price, rock bottom staff morale, a projected loss this year for the first time since 1987, that kind of thing.

What went so wrong? Perhaps you should ask what Eddington has got so right. He is blessed, BA said in a pointed announcement, with a "down to earth" manner and conciliatory "people skills".

And Ayling wasn't? Some cynical observers saw the incident three years ago, when thousands of BA staff developed 24-hour flu and coincidentally skipped work on the same day, as an expression of discontent. Perhaps because Ayling had just laid off 1,000 staff.

They must be grateful for Eddington's new broom. Except one of his first tasks will be to sack 6,500 workers.

And he's still smiling? Ah yes, but that's the key. An important part of conciliatory people skills is being able to fire people nicely. At his previous job, Eddington spoke personally to pilots he let go. You can achieve wonders with a cordial squeeze on the shoulder.

Where has he come from anyway? Australia's second favourite airline Ansett, where he turned a loss into a 6% profit.

Must have impressed the finance bods. Hmm. "You could have put a tin of baked beans in charge of the company and the results were still bound to improve," said one.

So what else do we know about him? He has a doctorate in nuclear physics from Oxford University, so must be brighter than the moustache implies. Oh, and he's best mates with Rupert Murdoch.

Isn't everybody these days? Even Tony loves him. Yes, but Tony isn't on the board of Murdoch's media empire, NewsCorp.

So we should expect to see glowing coverage of the new man at BA in the Times, the Sun ... I couldn't possibly comment.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: On... working with languages
fields.trailText: On... working with languages
fields.body:
Step into Liz Beck's office and you could be forgiven for being very confused for a moment about which country you are in. Of the seven people in her team, working on advertising at the internet search engine Yahoo!, two work with French clients, one with Scandinavian accounts and one with Spanish and Italians. And all can be chatting away at the same time in their respective languages. "Everyone speaks at least one European language fluently," says Beck, 24, now the senior advertising co-ordinator for Europe. She also deals with clients in Israel, the Middle East and South Africa.

Beck took a degree in French and German at Kingston University, which included a year abroad, but admits that, initially, she had no idea how she might use her skills. "After I graduated I did some travelling. When I came back I knew I wanted to work with my languages, but I didn't really know what I wanted to do. So I went to the London recruitment agencies, and through Appointments Bi Language [an agency specialising in admin positions requiring language skills] I found a job in the UK team at Yahoo!

"I had worked so hard at my languages, and get such a buzz from speaking them, that when I started the job I felt I could use the skills I already had. I liked the fact that the job was very varied, and there was a lot of potential."

After 11 months, she was promoted to her current position, overseeing the advertising deals managed by sales reps and country co-ordinators based in the different countries and the London office. "We get an order for ad space on the site, sold by a sales rep. We need to receive the creative instructions for the ad, make sure the customer has signed for the revenue and that the ad starts on time. I also need to ensure the customer has feedback and access to the statistical information on response to their ad." Beck's vocabulary is necessarily quite specialised. "A lot of people we speak to would have some English, but because we are talking about the technical side of things some people can struggle."

As internet use has boomed, particularly at Yahoo! (the site's European traffic grew to more than 940m page views in March 2000), Beck's team has expanded and she now delegates much of the first contact with overseas clients. "But I still deal on a day-to-day basis with customers and reps using my French and German. If you speak to people in their language, you build up a much better relationship."

While university courses with a language element increasingly concentrate on business, Beck is convinced of the value of pure language study. "People think, well, everyone speaks English so I don't have to, but it does make a difference." She has even picked up a little Swedish and Norwegian, and hopes to learn Spanish when she finds the time.

Working for such a fast-growing international company has its advantages, not least that it has offices around the world. "There is always scope to move abroad, and it's something I would consider. But at the moment I like being based in London, at the centre of things."

fields.headline: Empire lines
fields.standfirst:
Yvonne Roberts returns to Pakistan in search of childhood memories
Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: "Happy Felicitates," Ijaz says at Peshawar airport in Pakistan. He tells me he is 23, a law student, driving taxis to pay for his studies. I hire him for £20 a day, the equivalent of a month's salary. "I will not be forgettable," he truthfully promises. I had been advised to wear salwar kameez and keep my head covered since Islamic fundamentalism prevails. After a couple of days, I find these outfits far less intrusive and more enjoyable than western dress. Paradoxically, with fewer bits on show, I'm freer.
fields.body:
"Happy Felicitates," Ijaz says at Peshawar airport in Pakistan. He tells me he is 23, a law student, driving taxis to pay for his studies. I hire him for £20 a day, the equivalent of a month's salary. "I will not be forgettable," he truthfully promises. I had been advised to wear salwar kameez and keep my head covered since Islamic fundamentalism prevails. After a couple of days, I find these outfits far less intrusive and more enjoyable than western dress. Paradoxically, with fewer bits on show, I'm freer.

En route to the hotel (a sign politely asks guests to leave arms at reception), Ijaz asks if I'd like to see the sights. He is unfazed when I explain it is not Mogul artefacts I'm interested in but a trip down memory lane. My parents and I arrived in Peshawar in 1956 when I was nine. My father was a radio operator, a Morse code man, attached to the Foreign Office. For two days in July that year we were under siege in the British compound as students rioted in support of Nasser and the nationalisation of the Suez Canal. In 1998, when I began writing a novel, I wanted to use as a backdrop that place and that time, a period when class, race, gender and empire underwent a major overhaul.

Forty years on, however, British road names have been removed and clues are scarce. Ijaz takes me to the Peshawar Swimming Club and a memory stirs. In the 50s, this was the centre of social life. Now the horseshoe bar, the largest in the world, has been removed. Peshawar is teetotal. "The patient is alive but the pulse has gone," says one elderly member mournfully.

Ijaz and I eventually discover my old home has become the dilapidated office of a gas company. Clerks follow me from room to room, enthusiastically shifting furniture. "As you like?" Ijaz asks anxiously, as if he can tailor the past to suit my needs. I nod. Everyone breaks into relieved smiles.

The next morning we drive to Murree, a hill station near Kashmir, where I went to boarding school. Here, a magnificent figure in a fan-tailed turban introduces himself as Raja Umar Dad Khan. Umar is chief (raja) of a nearby village where each of his children has a house. In the evening dusk, he walks me to Pindi Point. The views are staggeringly beautiful; deep purple shadows creep across olive green valleys. "Damn beautiful," he says.

I spend a day at Umar's village. Head of the clan is his wife, Barbara, a magnificent matriarch not unlike that queen of Coronation Street, Elsie Tanner. She is ferocious, funny and has little time for Umar's sentimental affection for all things English.

Barbara believes in Islam and arranged marriages (though her own, 40 years ago, was a love match), and watches closely as her subdued daughters-in-law - her domestic help - prepare lunch.

Families like Umar's have to be monumentally industrious because corruption and poverty is rife. The average life expectancy for women is 50, for men 51. Electricity was supplied to the village a decade ago but "the flush" has yet to arrive. So several times a day the women carry on their heads tins of water from the well, each weighing many pounds. A 12-year-old can manage it; I can't.

Despite the hardships, Barbara is adamant her life is better than mine. While in this part of Pakistan, the chances of a woman escaping an abusive family are practically nil, and honour killings of raped and adulterous women still occur, legally they are now banned. Barbara points out it is the very strictness of the code that offers women security and grants them seniority as they age - a respect denied women in the west.

"You can't have something for nothing," she argues equably. "Your kind of freedom means everyday violence and women who are struggling alone, unprotected and unhappy." She doesn't change my mind, but she does make our lives appear less black and white, more different shades of grey.

Barbara is half-English. Her father was a soldier who left after the war, promising to return. She has no inclination to visit the UK, she says. "Why should I, when I have so many riches here?"

The day before my plane home, in a strange echo of my first visit to Pakistan, I find myself under siege. The tax imposed on travellers using the only road into Murree has been increased. Barricades appear, baton charges begin, shots are fired; only residents can move to and fro.

Umar has a plan. He and his son will smuggle me out to Islamabad. I will take the veil and sit in the back of the car. "And say bloody nothing," he insists in a tone that implies he believes this impossible.

Several times we are stopped. When we finally arrive safely, Umar enjoys the irony. I arrived in his country as a feminist and leave as his number two wife. "Bloody funny," he chuckles. "My family is now your family," he adds graciously. "You will come back."

We both treat it not as a question but as a statement of fact. As happened to my father before me, Pakistan has stolen my heart.

webTitle: The good old bad old days

fields.headline: The good old bad old days
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Last week I needed to borrow an onion because the shops were shut. It is at such times that I miss Rosemary. Then I noticed the new neighbours were throwing out Rosemary's radiators. Early on Sunday morning, the mother and a dutiful daughter carried them along the street to the council skip. What an odd feeling to see bits of Rosemary's old home dumped on the rubbish tip.
fields.body:
Last week I needed to borrow an onion because the shops were shut. It is at such times that I miss Rosemary. Then I noticed the new neighbours were throwing out Rosemary's radiators. Early on Sunday morning, the mother and a dutiful daughter carried them along the street to the council skip. What an odd feeling to see bits of Rosemary's old home dumped on the rubbish tip.

Naturally I report these goings-on to Rosemary. She consoles herself with the memory of her own rather rebellious children. They would never have done such a thing. On Sundays they generally woke mid-afternoon, then crawled to the drum kit or hi-fi and made a frightful noise. On sunny afternoons the daughters might dangle their legs over the window ledges and attract passing louts. Neighbours, tormented by sleep deprivation, would post desperate notes through Rosemary's letterbox. They perhaps do not miss her as much as I do.

Rosemary feels rather nostalgic about those years. Now she lives alone on the top floor of her auntie's house, she remembers the past fondly: her young son squirting water pistols, the daughters' parties, the gatecrashing mobs, frightful music, tantrums. But it's over now. Her children have grown up.

At least Rosemary thought they had, until the son and one daughter came home late one night for Easter. Where could she put them? Rather foolishly, she put Daughter in Auntie's spare room and Son on a sofa in the rather grand living room, without telling Auntie, who was fast asleep in the basement. But unknown to Rosemary, Son asked his friend to stay. Together they pulled the curtains down, left the hall lights on, had midnight snacks, clomped up and down, and slept wrapped in Auntie's priceless hand-embroidered bedspreads.

And Rosemary had thought the turmoil of her middle years was over. She had expected to miss it dreadfully. No such luck.

fields.headline: Waddaya mean, the war's over?
fields.standfirst: In the public arena, the battle between the sexes appears to rage on ... but in the privacy of our own homes, are we edging towards a ceasefire? Dave Hill reports on new research that suggests just that
fields.trailText: What is brought to mind by the words "gender debate"? Reflections on the striving of the sexes to make sweet music together, seated side by side on the same piano stool? Probably not. More likely the term signals discord and dismay. It evokes terrifying "findings" that having a job and a family - "having it all" - is making mothers and their children miserable. Or maybe it makes you think of frightening statistics showing that as women rise in the professions, the boardroom or the classroom, men and boys are sinking in despair.
fields.body:
What is brought to mind by the words "gender debate"? Reflections on the striving of the sexes to make sweet music together, seated side by side on the same piano stool? Probably not. More likely the term signals discord and dismay. It evokes terrifying "findings" that having a job and a family - "having it all" - is making mothers and their children miserable. Or maybe it makes you think of frightening statistics showing that as women rise in the professions, the boardroom or the classroom, men and boys are sinking in despair.

If so, who could blame you? Social commentators add to the impression that there can be no brave new settlement between the sexes, only a "sex war", portrayed as being fought out between all men on one side and all women on the other. Even when the sexes are identified as having some interest in common, the currency of mutual antagonism rules. A TV ad designed to sell the same car to male and female drivers does so by means of clashing archetypes - a caricature bloke talking down to womankind, a cartoon coquette returning the favour.

Do such depictions reflect reality? And are they helpful to the majority of people as they try to adjust to changing times? Emphatically not, according to a report out today. Though optimistically entitled The Sexual Renaissance, it exposes aserious dislocation between public debate about gender and citizens' real concerns over the significance of their sex and its influence on their lives.

Drawing on in-depth interviews with focus groups of "opinion leaders" from marketing and advertising, the media and politics, and 50 members of the public - 25 women, 25 men - the report's author, Sue Tibballs, concludes that the debate's "ambivalence and inertia" leaves unaddressed the challenges faced by men and women as old sex-based identities erode.

Furthermore, she finds it promotes "regressive trends that put pressure on individuals to remain within traditional roles, while introducing a tone of moral censure and personal blame that exacerbates the real problems women and men already endure". Result? Confusion, worry and guilt.

Tibballs, who also conceived and managed the project, is intriguingly qualified for her task. A freelance communications strategist who specialises in "gender issues and corporate responsibility", she is acquainted with both the academy of gender and the world of commerce.

She began her career as an activist with the Women's Environmental Network and later worked as a government consultant in the run-up to the Fourth United Nations World Conference on Women, held in Beijing in 1995. Until a year ago, she was women's affairs campaigner at the Body Shop, where she ran the company's body-image promotion of Ruby, the Rubenesque Doll; prior to that she was executive director of the Women's Communication Centre, a "virtual think-tank" and publisher of The Sexual Renaissance.

Tibballs began the project considering the question of whether a gender debate was still necessary. She has concluded that it most definitely is, but that the terms on which it is conducted need to move on sharply. The evidence of her survey, she argues, demands a new and more productive "gender paradigm" to replace those that have become outdated or rendered destructive by unruly propaganda.

It must be one that "recognises today's more complex relationship between gender and equality" and "understands that both women and men can experience inequality, and also that women's and men's interests are often entwined".

Such a paradigm would entail a shift away from a concern with "formal democratic equality" towards one with "substantive social equality". In other words, less of a preoccupation with comparing the respective rights and statuses of the sexes, and more close-up inquiry into the actual lives of men and women in a society in which broad generalisations about both do less justice than ever to social realities.

The "substantive" model of debate, Tibballs believes, has the flexibility to accommodate diversity among the sexes as well as growing areas of common ground, such as the desire in many couples for both partners to have careers and contribute equally to bringing up children.

At the same time, it would acknowledge people's clear recognition that their sex still makes a difference, both in the way they feel about themselves and the way others feel about them - often to their disadvantage.

Simply put, a gender debate reconfigured on such terms would help us to get to grips with our contradictions and confusions - and as Tibballs' research shows, there is no shortage of those. For every theme to emerge showing awareness of disparities between the sexes, there was another insisting not too much should be made of them - certainly nothing political.

It came out strongly that gender issues are overwhelmingly and disparagingly associated with feminism ... and feminism with sectarian man-haters. Less discouragingly, there was resistance to the identification of particular issues exclusively with one sex or the other. As one female "opinion leader" remarked: "Families, poverty, equality, opportunity are things that touch men as well as women."

Tibballs sees such perceptions as characterising "an age of ambivalence" wherein the belief that men and women are different - in some ways, valuably so - co-exists with the conviction that they should be treated as the same. At the same time, the feeling prevails that the social constraints imposed by our sex are not a proper object of political action (there were notably mixed views about the existence of a minister for women).

This ambivalence was common to both "opinion leaders" and the public, but perhaps the most worrying finding is how pronounced it was among the former. These often showed themselves chronically inhibited by their own prejudices - notably about feminism - and by an inability to think past categories and labels they disliked.

Predictably, the male opinion leaders were most likely to dismiss gender issues as unimportant or passé yet all seemed paralysed by the very stereotypes in which their own industries habitually trade and have, of course, done a great deal to create.

Asked about this variance, Tibballs says she noted with great interest that "the general public groups were more progressive than the 'opinion formers' in the sense that they were much more aware of the need for support to combine roles for the simple reason that circumstances have forced them to renegotiate those roles".

When asked to talk about the nuts and bolts of their daily existence, these men and women showed themselves thoroughly receptive to the idea of a "gender debate", even though they were put off by the actual expression. It seemed, in fact, that they were debating gender among themselves the whole time.

Tibballs believes if these private conversations were reflected on more public platforms - in the communications industries and in politics - it would greatly benefit the majority of women and men who have already been won over to the principle of equality and are now trying to figure out how to enjoy its benefits. The burning question seems to be: when will the leaders of opinion in this country catch up with the rest of us?
