fields.headline: Call yourself a supergroup?
fields.standfirst: New R&B trio Lucy Pearl are by no stretch the next Cream. And, warns  Adam Sweeting, a glance at pop history shows that the 'super' tag can be disastrous
fields.trailText: If you want to torpedo a new band before it has a chance to find its feet, all you have to do is describe it as a "supergroup". The term has become music business shorthand for "accident waiting to happen". The act is immediately saddled with an intolerable burden of anticipation. Rational discussion of its music and its prospects becomes impossible.
fields.body:
If you want to torpedo a new band before it has a chance to find its feet, all you have to do is describe it as a "supergroup". The term has become music business shorthand for "accident waiting to happen". The act is immediately saddled with an intolerable burden of anticipation. Rational discussion of its music and its prospects becomes impossible.

The newest victim of supergroupism is R&B trio Lucy Pearl. Comprising Raphael Saadiq, once of Tony Toni Tone, En Vogue refugee Dawn Robinson and A Tribe Called Quest's Ali Shaheed Muhammed, Lucy Pearl are gearing up to release their debut album, known merely as Lucy Pearl, on May 22. The so-called "super-trio" are being hailed by industry insiders for creating music which is forward-looking, while building on the members' past work. As for the name, Saadiq says, "Our music has a loose sound and feeling, while what we're doing is something precious to us, like a pearl."

With their previous success, the members are likely to be able to tap into a pre-existing R&B, soul and hip hop fan base, but it may be their good fortune that none of the three is actually famous enough to merit the "supergroup" tag. The accolade of "super" should be earned by groups which contain at least one member recognisable to a broad constituency of listeners. In other words, a real supergroup needs a Will Smith or a Lauryn Hill - except they're doing such spectacular business as solo artists that the last thing they want to do is join a band and have to share out the accolades, and the dosh. Lucy Pearl's previous bands presented collective identities; with the exception perhaps of A Tribe Called Quest's Q-Tip, the various individual members were not household names. Trying to elevate Lucy Pearl above their natural station smacks of an industry feverishly trying to clone some old-fashioned showbiz glamour.

The current lack of available superstars has made the supergroup a rare phenomenon. The 80s saw the last great wave of pop megastardom, with the likes of Madonna, Wham!, Bon Jovi and Michael Jackson displaying awesome stadium-filling power; the 90s witnessed a steady decline in the numbers of this once-flourishing species. In the past few years, the industry has leaned increasingly towards the design and manufacture of interchangeable, indistinguishable boy- and girl-groups; the notion of the Great Solo Artist has become correspondingly irrelevant, successes such as Macy Gray unusual.

Simultaneously, bands no longer become as famous as they used to (witness Oasis's failure to emulate the Beatles in the US), and they do not last as long. It is as if the splintered factions that now make up the pop audience don't respond so much to particular artists, but to generic trends where an act's identity is less important than the brand of music they perform, or the TV shows they feature in.

The idea of rock star as Messiah burned brightest during the 60s, and that was when the concept of supergroup appeared. Blues-rock trio Cream could lay claim to being the first supergroup, featuring as it did Eric Clapton (already known as "God" thanks to his work with John Mayall's Bluesbreakers) alongside jazz drummer Ginger Baker and Manfred Mann's bassist Jack Bruce. Their fate was instructive. After a streak of stunningly original singles, Cream imploded under the weight of their audience's expectations. They realised they were going through the motions, and split.

But rashly, Baker and Clapton promptly teamed up with Traffic's Steve Winwood in that archetypal supergroup, Blind Faith. Rarely has a band's name been more apt. Blind Faith was assembled amid media hysteria in February 1969. They made their live debut in front of 36,000 people in Hyde Park in June, broke box-office records across the US in July, released their solitary album in August and broke up in September.

"We didn't rehearse enough, we didn't get to know each other enough, we didn't go through enough trials and tribulations before the big time came," Clapton confided to Rolling Stone magazine, summing up the atmosphere of superstar lunacy that had surrounded the project. Clapton, later famed for his addictive personality, couldn't say no to another supergroup experience, and hooked up with John Lennon's Plastic Ono Band alongside Mr and Mrs Lennon and Ringo Starr. Despite a futile quest for anonymity in Derek & the Dominos, Eric was supergrouping it up again in 1971 at George Harrison's concert for Bangladesh. Pausing only to dally with heroin addiction, he returned tentatively to the limelight at London's Rainbow theatre in 1973, buttressed by Pete Townshend, Steve Winwood and Ron Wood.

Insecurity and instability are part and parcel of most supergroup experiences, since each member considers him or herself too important to hand control to anybody else. The Spice Girls offer a rare but perfect contemporary example. It is impossible to imagine all five sharing a stage again, since each one has become a fiercely competitive superpower in her own right. Thirty years ago, much the same was true of Crosby Stills Nash & Young, assembled from veterans of the Byrds, Buffalo Springfield and the Hollies. Adding Neil Young to the original trio was the equivalent of balancing a skip-load of cement on one wingtip of a light aircraft, sending it spinning out of control. CSNY were staggeringly successful for a short time, but fist-fights and acrimony were never more than a moment away.

Another reason why Lucy Pearl should move smartly to airbrush any reference to "supergroups" from their publicity is that it often suggests complacency and self-indulgence. Projects like the Power Station, featuring a couple of Duran Durans and Robert Palmer alongside Chic's Bernard Edwards and Tony Thompson, was never more than a rich man's plaything. Electronic, in which New Order's Bernard Sumner and Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr tinkered around with the Pet Shop Boys, enjoyed some chart success, but always felt like something the participants were doing as a temporary diversion before returning to their day jobs.

If the members of supergroups aren't throwing tantrums or drumkits, they are tiptoeing gingerly around each other, terrified of disturbing somebody else's fragile artistic equilibrium. Something of the sort was visible in the Travelling Wilburys, that tepid agglomeration of rock'n'roll legends - Harrison, Dylan, Orbison, Petty - churning out flimsy cartoons of rock, pop and country music. Supergroups sometimes come garnished with a country twang, too. The Trio, featuring Emmylou Harris, Linda Ronstadt and Dolly Parton, proved that female artists could be every bit as cantankerous as their male counterparts, though their debut album, when it eventually emerged in 1987, was at least worth the wait. The follow-up, a decade later, wasn't. In the case of the Highwaymen, combining hundreds of years' worth of country experience in the persons of Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Kris Kristofferson and Johnny Cash, the prevailing mood was one of benign mutual celebration among four whisky-soaked legends in the autumn of their years. Pleasant, but hardly "rebel country".

Some artists, having grown bloated on the massed adulation of a previous era, can never come to terms with living in reduced circumstances. The various spats between the countless line-ups of Yes as members struggled to seize control of this lucrative pomp-rock franchise have been far more entertaining than the music. As for Jimmy Page, erstwhile Led Zeppelin mastermind, he has dabbled fruitlessly with singer Paul Rodgers in the Firm, and indulged in unconscious self-parody by hooking up with Whitesnake's David Coverdale in Coverdale/Page. Currently, following another rancorous split from his Zeppelin partner Robert Plant, Page is warming over the Zep's back-catalogue yet again in harness with retro-boogyists the Black Crowes.

So, Lucy Pearl, be warned. When somebody tells you you're in a supergroup, it is time to check out the job vacancies at McDonald's.

 The Lucy Pearl album is released by Virgin on May 22.

fields.headline: Palace revolution
fields.standfirst: She looked and behaved like an exotic oriental princess, but became a champion of modernist architecture.  Sarah Howell  on Minnette de Silva
fields.trailText: She looked and behaved like an exotic oriental princess, but became a champion of modernist architecture. Sarah Howell on Minnette de Silva
fields.body:
In the drab postwar London of demob suits and bomb craters, Minnette de Silva seemed as dazzling as a tropical bird. She arrived from Ceylon in 1945. Beautiful, sure of herself and wrapped in a pashmina-wool cloak against the cold, she was thrilled that, in spite of her parents' opposition, she had achieved her ambition to study at the Architectural Association. She was to become the first Sri Lankan woman architect and the first Asian woman Associate of the Royal Institute of British Architects.

Contemporaries at the AA tend to remember her being followed about by a train of young men carrying her portfolio, drawing-board, bags and shawls. James Palmes, then the librarian at the RIBA, writes: "Her visits to the library always caused a little flutter. She seemed to us, with her beflowered hair, bangles and glittering saris, like some fabled oriental princess." Minnette found herself a "London nook" in Savile Row, a cheap attic flat with black-out paper still stuck to the windows. She made friends with the architect Denys Lasdun, Henry Moore, Lawrence Durrell, Gielguds and Huxleys, Fitzrovian poets and actors. She also worked on the first exhibition of Indian art at the Royal Academy, and went to all the parties and ballets at Covent Garden. "London seemed very small in those days," she said. But, most of all, she threw herself passionately into the world of progressive architecture, the propagation of modernism after the war.

Minnette died two years ago, but she left behind a book called The Life and Work of an Asian Woman Architect, which brings her vividly back to life. It is a chaotic, exhilarating collage of memories, photographs - from Cartier Bresson to "some of my old snapshots, better than nothing" - letters, crumpled yellow newspaper cuttings, postcards, theatre programmes and architectural drawings.

Both Minnette's argumentative radicalism and her social aplomb were, to some extent, family traits. Her father was a lawyer who made his children debate political issues at mealtimes. He was anti-imperialist, but by no means anti-western. He became one of the leaders of the National Movement in Ceylon and a minister in the first independent Sri Lankan government. Minnette's mother, who was of French and Dutch, as well as Sinhalese, ancestry, was a campaigner for women's rights. They were immensely hospitable and knew most of the radical politicians in Asia and Britain. As girls, Minnette and Indira Gandhi spent afternoons ironing each other's hair to straighten it, Lloyd George came to tea - "he was surprised at my savoir-faire" - and her sister, Marcia, was presented at court by, of all people, the Fabian socialist Beatrice Webb.

In her generation, the boys in the family became lawyers or ambassadors, or ended up drinking 15 pink gins before lunch. The girls were the stars. Marcia, even better looking than Minnette, fled to Europe and worked in films, married three times, and wrote biographies and art history.

Minnette's ambition to become an architect took hold in her teens, and she finally persuaded a rich uncle to finance her studies in Bombay. The only girl among 40 men, she says she was never teased, but she was expelled for taking part in a student strike over the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi. It turned out not to be a disaster. Her father finally agreed that she could go to Europe to study, and she was recommended to the RIBA by Lord Soulbury, who was in Ceylon on government business - "I know a winner when I see one," he remarked.

Throughout her life, Minnette attracted powerful men - though they often retreated briskly. "She was hugely strong-willed and a tremendous flirt. She had immense charm," says her nephew, the QC Desmond de Silva, "but she could be bossy and extremely difficult." She made a point of commissioning local potters, tile-makers and artists, and taught herself weaving in order to instruct craftsmen in the making of woven panels to divide rooms and cover ceilings. She later worked on housing for village communities, inexpensive blocks of flats, as well as houses for the new Sri Lankan professional classes, and, occasionally, public buildings like her (now dilapidated) elegant art centre in Kandy, which reinterpreted local building styles.

"She thought architecture morning, noon and night," says Ulrik Plesner, a Danish architect who worked for Minnette in the 50s, and later joined rival firms on the island. "She was always hard up, always struggling, but she was a genuine reformer, very bold, very clear in her ideas. Technically, though, she didn't have a clue," he says, "that was why she employed me. In Denmark, the training is very practical. But it never really mattered. In her drawings she tended to cover up the tricky technical bits with trees, and the local carpenters, builders and craftsmen were wonderful. They could make anything stay up. Sri Lankans were proud of her. In those days, not long after independence, they admired her British connections, too - going about with Larry Olivier cut ice then."

When Kathy Stevenson, who now works for the Serpentine Gallery, went out to Sri Lanka in the early 90s to help Minnette sort out her daunting archives for the book - every postcard, every theatre ticket, every grocer's bill had been kept - she found a formidable old lady with a grand contralto voice, immaculately dressed as ever. She still lived in her parents' crumbling old house high above Kandy. Pasted up on the hall walls were hundreds of photographs of friends who had stayed there during the past 70 years. Minnette sat up all night reading them for the last time, scoring through the passionate words with black ink as she read.

In the end, you had to love her." Kathy found the best way of coping with her was to answer back. She boldly told her hostess that her bed was bumpy and uncomfortable. "Well," said Minnette, "Gandhi never complained."

fields.headline: Call of the wild
fields.trailText: There's a French saying that cemeteries are full of indispensable men. And while television presenters are foolish to think themselves unique, there is still one sector of TV that's dominated by an individual who's come to seem irreplaceable. Wildlife shows are so associated with Sir David Attenborough that even those he doesn't host are discussed in terms of his absence or what his presence might have added.
fields.body:
There's a French saying that cemeteries are full of indispensable men. And while television presenters are foolish to think themselves unique, there is still one sector of TV that's dominated by an individual who's come to seem irreplaceable. Wildlife shows are so associated with Sir David Attenborough that even those he doesn't host are discussed in terms of his absence or what his presence might have added.

This is a key moment in the ecology of wildlife shows. Sir David has reduced his appearances, prompting the question of which presenter to use or whether to have one at all. Now there's even a doubt about the necessity for animals. The success of the computer-generated Walking With Dinosaurs raised the possibility of filming scenes of natural savagery or splendour in Shepherd's Bush rather than the African bush.

So, Predators (Thursday, 8.30pm, BBC1) - the first major non-Attenborough, post-Dinosaurs natural history series - won't be treated as just another TV show. Whatever credentials it tries to present, it'll be seen as the ambassador for a genre.

The cheetah, golden eagle and crocodile whose methods of what the script calls "precision killing" are featured in programme one are obviously descendants of Dinosaurs. Promising to use "the latest graphics and camera techniques", the series frequently feels more like drama than documentary, using fast-cutting and computerised sequences exposing the skeletons inside the creatures to create visceral scenes which feel not only post-Dinosaurs but post-Tarantino.

If only Tarantino, though, had written the script. Disneyfied lines like "crocodiles have a long memory" give way to tabloid zoology: "Dinner for one - death for the other." A knowledgeable presenter having been judged unnecessary, these are voiced by the actor John Hannah, extending the BBC's belief that Scottish accents are classless. Entertainment rather than education, Predators shows a great BBC tradition threatened with extinction.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Christian Slater in The Name Of The Rose (Jean-Jacques Annaud, 1986)
fields.body:
Christian Slater in The Name Of The Rose (Jean-Jacques Annaud, 1986)

Who? Former teen bad-boy who made his name doing little more than a passable Jack Nicholson impression in Heathers. His attempts to branch out into romance (Untamed Heart), and action (Hard Rain) were singularly unconvincing, and were all but overshadowed by his ongoing drug, alcohol and violence problems. Slater served jail time in 1998, and since then has got himself religion and a new girlfriend and baby. In his last film, Very Bad Things, he managed to give a great, and very convincing, performance as a coke-snorting megalomaniac.

The role: Adson von Melk, a young novice Franciscan monk, who assists William of Baskerville in his attempt to solve a series of murders at a monastery.

Best line: When William asks him a seemingly rhetorical question, Adson says, "Are you testing me, master?" William asks, "What do you mean?" and Adson explains, "Well, with all due respect, it seems that whenever you ask me a question, you already have the answer."

Cringe factor: Mild. You get used to the bowl-cut (complete with shaved patch) pretty soon and realise that this is actually one of his best, most understated, performances.

Other wannabes: Ron Perlman (The City Of Lost Children) as a hunchbacked heretic.

Critical judgement: The Washington Post thought that "While Connery rattles through his Holmes bit, Slater's features contract with admiration - he looks like someone's ratcheting a bolt into the back of his head, a bolt that gets tighter as the movie goes on."

Also not starring in: Living Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story, in 1983, and a 1985 episode of The Equaliser.

 The Name Of The Rose, tonight, 9 pm, Carlton Cinema.

fields.headline: Prime-time Ewing
fields.standfirst: OK, so the premise was unbelievable, the plotlines bizarre and the characters preposterous - but when JR was shot, the whole world watched. Dallas's place in TV's hall of fame is assured, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: In the late 70s, CBS asked the American television writer-producer David Jacobs to create a series for the actress Linda Evans. He, like many authors before him, adapted the action of Romeo And Juliet: two feuding families joined in marriage. For his Verona, Jacobs selected Texas.
fields.body:
In the late 70s, CBS asked the American television writer-producer David Jacobs to create a series for the actress Linda Evans. He, like many authors before him, adapted the action of Romeo And Juliet: two feuding families joined in marriage. For his Verona, Jacobs selected Texas.

The studio decided the script was unsuitable for Linda Evans but the project still developed into a series. But there was still the matter of the title. CBS suggested one snappy word: Dallas. Jacobs had two objections. He hadn't visualised the series being set there and - only 15 years after an American president had had his head blown open there - he felt that Dallas would lead viewers to expect a show about JFK. Jacobs suggested the title Oil, the commodity his feuding families dealt in.

The studio won the naming game and now Dallas is one of the most famous titles in television history. Channel 4 is screening three hours of classic episodes and analysis to mark the 20th anniversary of the plot-line in which JR Ewing was shot. That single episode, more than any other programme, established the cultural power of television: its potential to hold a global audience in suspense. No history of the medium could be complete without serious consideration of Dallas.

The one immutable rule of television is that great shows arise from their time. Dad's Army couldn't happen now because of the lack of actors, writers and viewers who remember the war. Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? would have been impossible before the National Lottery.

Dallas too emerged from a narrow historical corridor. The David Jacobs show premiered on CBS in April 1978. In the second year of the Carter presidency, America was in economic crisis. The country's drivers - their gas limited by the actions of the OPEC group of oil-producing nations - engaged in angry confrontations at petrol stations. Dallas was a reassuring fantasy in which America controlled the world's oil.

Dallas was also a reverie about extreme and conspicuous wealth, and it wasn't a coincidence that the show's greatest moments - the 1980 season in which JR was hot - coincided with the election campaign which led to the Reagan presidency. Money was becoming the profitable cultural subject of the time.

There is also in the story of the Ewings an intriguing connection with an earlier presidency. Despite the professed fears of David Jacobs that viewers might take the title Dallas as a reference to the Kennedys, the series already seems to contain several others. Both the actual Boston clan and the fictional Dallas one have a senior son christened John but known by his initials and a junior one called Bobby. Both initialled heroes are shot in Dallas and taken to the same hospital. CBS encouraged this association by screening the episode in which JR's assailant was revealed (his sister-in-law, Kristin) on November 21, the eve of the Kennedy anniversary.

These are all external explanations for the impact Dallas made. But there was a lot of internal cleverness. The Romeo And Juliet story is a reliably gripping plot, but Jacobs' twist was to make the star-crossed lovers - Bobby Ewing and Pam Barnes - relatively minor characters. This was the first mainstream serial in which the villain had been the central figure. At least one leading American TV actor refused to play JR Ewing on the basis that he was too unsympathetic. But Larry Hagman, who accepted, is credited with saying at rehearsal: "He's the villain, but I'll play him as if he's the hero." Such moral ambiguity is now standard in TV drama but it was Jacobs and Hagman who kicked that door open.

American audiences took Dallas seriously: as a kind of Tennessee Williams Lite. In Britain, the show was one of the first programmes to be watched ironically - a squint which most viewers now adopt routinely - by an audience which acknowledged it as being simultaneously gripping and ridiculous. The reputations of Terry Wogan as a broadcaster and Clive James as a television critic were made in part by their forensic demolition of this show. James noted how poor continuity made JR's hair change colour during scenes. Wogan pointed out that these super-rich tycoons all lived together in one small house and breakfasted by the pool in a wind so brisk that the actresses could be seen holding down their hair.

What's perhaps hardest to realise now is how exotic these characters seemed to British audiences. Our soaps - in the Coronation Street tradition - showcased broke proles. This was a glamour soap, doubly exotic for being American. With Freddie Laker having tried but failed to make the USA available to the masses, the Atlantic was culturally still an ocean rather than the river it subsequently became.

The series has now become shorthand for dramatic miscalculation - the later glossing of Bobby Ewing's death as a dream wrecked its reputation - but tonight's Channel 4 theme night should remind us that, early on, a much kinder assessment was merited. In the early 80s, during a Westminster debate about the future of broadcasting, a speaker warned about the prospect of "wall-to-wall Dallas". We could have done worse. We have done worse.

 Dallas Night, tonight, 8pm, C4

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Just 40 years ago today, a 30-year-old American pilot took off from Peshawar in Pakistan. Within hours,the U-2 reconnaissance plane of Francis Gary Powers flying at a supposedly invulnerable 65,000 feet, had been shot down over Sverdlovsk. The incident cast an alarming new light on Soviet missile technology, and the ensuing diplomatic row wrecked the 1960 Paris peace talks. William Hope reads Powers' own account of his trial and imprisonment as the Book Of The Week (9.45am, Radio 4).

In the second segment of his investigation into The Black Vote (8.0pm, Radio 4), Gary Younge discovers an unexpected voting shift. About the only bright spot in the Tories' disastrous 1997 election campaign was to have persuaded 20 per cent of Britain's largest ethnic minority, the Indians, to switch from Labour. But did that bring the Indians closer to effective power? Of 201 candidates in this week's London Assembly election, only 30 are black or Asian.
fields.bodyText: Just 40 years ago today, a 30-year-old American pilot took off from Peshawar in Pakistan. Within hours,the U-2 reconnaissance plane of Francis Gary Powers flying at a supposedly invulnerable 65,000 feet, had been shot down over Sverdlovsk. The incident cast an alarming new light on Soviet missile technology, and the ensuing diplomatic row wrecked the 1960 Paris peace talks. William Hope reads Powers' own account of his trial and imprisonment as the Book Of The Week (9.45am, Radio 4). fields.body:
Earl Spencer's Great Speech
7.45pm, BBC Choice

The first in a series looking at memorable speeches. Here it's Earl Spencer's address at Diana's funeral. Immensely irritatingly, we don't get his words in full - more focus is given to the ha'pennyworths of Eve Pollard, Andrew Morton and the paparazzi. But what we do see is as powerful as it was in 1997. David Dimbleby offers mild criticism, suggesting that the speech was emotional not rational; and rumours flew that Boris Johnson might have had a hand in its wording. Whatever. It was a knockout.

My Best Friend's Wedding
(PJ Hogan, 1997)
10am & 4.10pm, Sky Premier

Fun-filled modern take on the screwball comedy that saw Julia Roberts, aka Erin Brockovich at a cinema near you, doing big box-office. She's a cookery writer who realises, four days before her ex (Dermot Mulroney) is to marry Cameron Diaz (pictured), that she is still in love with him. Luckily her gay colleague (Rupert Everett) is on hand to pose as her beau, in order to make said ex jealous (look, it's not meant to make much sense. That's why it's screwball).

The Name Of The Rose
(Jean-Jacques Annaud, 1986)
9pm, 2.45am, Carlton Cinema

Medieval detective story adapted from Umberto Eco's novel about serial murder in a remote Italian monastery. Annaud seems in his element in the middle ages, directing with a real feel for a time that was both brutish and high-minded. And Sean Connery is superb as William of Baskerville who, aided by his little assistant Christian Slater, sets out to decipher the secret of the library, and outwit the saturnine F Murray Abraham's grand inquisitor.

Husbands
(John Cassavetes, 1970)
1.05am, FilmFour

One of the great Cassavetes' free-form improvisations, a darkly comic affirmation of life in the face of death. Ben Gazzara, Peter "Columbo" Falk and the director play a trio of middle-aged married men who, on the death of a friend, revert to teenage skirt-chasing mode on a binge in London.
